ACL injury.extraName: Also called: anterior cruciate ligament injury
ACL injury.symptomDescription: Symptoms include knee swelling, instability and pain.

symptoms.Also common: bruising, limping, or pain when standing

ACL injury.overview:
Description
A torn anterior cruciate ligament in the knee.
The ACL is tissue that connects the thighbone to the shinbone, at the knee. Most ACL injuries occur during certain sports such as basketball, football, skiing and tennis.
Symptoms include knee swelling, instability and pain.
Treatment may include surgery and physiotherapy.
ACL injury.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Surgery.Arthroscopy: Procedure to diagnose and treat joint problems using a tiny camera inserted through a small surgical opening.
Surgery.ACL reconstruction: Replacement of a torn ACL, one of the ligaments in the knee. The new graft can come from a tendon in the knee or a deceased donor.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Rehabilitation: Retraining the brain's pathways to improve mental and physical functioning after an illness or injury. For example, after a blow to the head (concussion).
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Devices.Elastic bandage: Stretchy bandages used to wrap sprains and strains. Provides support and compression during recovery.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Abdominal aortic aneurysm.symptomDescription: An AAA often grows slowly, without symptoms. As it grows, some people may notice a pulsating feeling near the navel. Pain in the back, stomach or side may be signs of impending rupture.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the abdomen, back, or flank
symptoms.Also common: nausea or pulsating abdominal mass

Abdominal aortic aneurysm.overview:
Description
An enlargement of the aorta, the main blood vessel that delivers blood to the body, at the level of the abdomen.
An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) can be life-threatening if it bursts. Abdominal aortic aneurysms are most common in older men and smokers.
An AAA often grows slowly, without symptoms. As it grows, some people may notice a pulsating feeling near the navel. Pain in the back, stomach or side may be signs of impending rupture.
Stopping smoking may slow their growth. Small ones may only need monitoring. Aneurysms that are too large or growing too quickly should be repaired with surgery.
Abdominal aortic aneurysm.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Surgery.Open surgical repair with vascular stent: Surgery to fix an abdominal aortic aneurysm by placing a tube (stent) to support the artery wall.
Surgery.Endovascular aneurysm repair: Surgical repair of a bulge (aneurysm) in the main blood vessel of the body (aorta) to prevent bleeding or rupture.

specialists.Vascular Surgeon: Specialises in surgery for vascular system diseases.
specialists.Interventional Radiologist: Uses image-guided procedures to diagnose and treat diseases.
specialists.Vascular Medicine Doctor: Specialises in circulatory and lymphatic diseases.

Achalasia.symptomDescription: Symptoms include a backflow of food in the throat (regurgitation), chest pain and weight loss.

symptoms.Also common: difficulty swallowing, difficulty belching, or weight loss

Achalasia.overview:
Description
A rare disorder making it difficult for food and liquid to pass into the stomach.
Achalasia results from damage to nerves in the food tube (oesophagus), preventing the oesophagus from squeezing food into the stomach. It may be caused by an abnormal immune system response.
Symptoms include a backflow of food in the throat (regurgitation), chest pain and weight loss.
Achalasia can usually be managed with minimally invasive (endoscopic) therapy or surgery.
Achalasia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medical procedure.Esophageal dilatation: Procedure to expand a narrowing along the food pipe (oesophagus).

Medication.Antianginal: Helps reduce chest pain or pressure caused by blockages in the arteries of the heart.

specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Acid reflux.extraName: Also called: GERD, gastroesophageal reflux disease
Acid reflux.symptomDescription: Symptoms include burning pain in the chest that usually occurs after eating and worsens when lying down.

symptoms.Also common: bitter taste, discomfort in upper abdomen, or dry cough

Acid reflux.overview:
Description
A digestive disease in which stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipe lining.
This is a chronic disease that occurs when stomach acid or bile flows into the food pipe and irritates the lining. Acid reflux and heartburn more than twice a week may indicate GERD.
Symptoms include burning pain in the chest that usually occurs after eating and worsens when lying down.
Relief from lifestyle changes and over-the-counter medication is usually temporary. Stronger medication may be required.
Acid reflux.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Elevate head of bed: Reduces the likelihood of acid reflux or developing a pneumonia from saliva entering the airways.
Self-care.Dietary modification: Adjusting diet to prevent or treat disease.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.

Medication.Antacid: Counteracts the effects of stomach acid.
Medication.Proton-pump inhibitor: Decreases acid release in the stomach.
Medication.Antidiarrhoeal: Reduces frequency and urgency of bowel movements.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Acne.symptomDescription: Symptoms range from uninflamed blackheads to pus-filled pimples or large, red and tender bumps.

symptoms.Skin: pimples, redness, or tenderness
symptoms.Also common: pimple or blackhead

Acne.overview:
Description
A skin condition that occurs when hair follicles plug with oil and dead skin cells.
Acne is most common in teenagers and young adults.
Symptoms range from uninflamed blackheads to pus-filled pimples or large, red and tender bumps.
Treatments include over-the-counter creams and cleanser, as well as prescription antibiotics.
Acne.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required

Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.
Medication.Vitamin A derivative: Unplugs blocked hair follicles and helps prevent new blockages from forming. Slows skin cell growth.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Topical antiseptic: Destroys or prevents the growth of microorganisms on the skin that may cause infection.

Self-care.Benzoyl peroxide / Salicylic acid: A topical medication that reduces acne-causing bacteria and sheds the skin.
Self-care.Antibacterial soap: Cleanses skin and reduces risk of infection.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Actinic keratosis.symptomDescription: It is most common on the face, lips, ears, back of hands, forearms, scalp and neck. The rough, scaly skin patch enlarges slowly and usually causes no other signs or symptoms. A lesion may take years to develop.

symptoms.Common symptoms: scaly patch on skin or itching

Actinic keratosis.overview:
Description
A rough, scaly patch on the skin caused by years of sun exposure.
Actinic keratoses usually affects older adults. Reducing sun exposure can help reduce risk.
It is most common on the face, lips, ears, back of hands, forearms, scalp and neck. The rough, scaly skin patch enlarges slowly and usually causes no other signs or symptoms. A lesion may take years to develop.
Because it can become cancerous, it's usually removed as a precaution.
Actinic keratosis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Topical anti-tumor medication: Treats skin cancer and other skin conditions.
Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Medical procedure.Photodynamic therapy: Treatment that uses special drugs (photosensitising agents) along with light to kill cancer cells. The drugs must be activated by the light.
Medical procedure.Freezing: Using extreme cold during surgery or medical treatment.
Medical procedure.Tissue scraping: Removal of tissue by scraping or scooping with a surgical instrument called a curette.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Acute Bronchitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms of bronchitis include coughing up thickened mucus and shortness of breath.

symptoms.Cough: can be chronic, dry, or with phlegm
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or malaise
symptoms.Also common: chest pressure, headache, shortness of breath, sleeping difficulty, or sore throat

Acute Bronchitis.overview:
Description
Inflammation of the lining of bronchial tubes, which carry air to and from the lungs.
Acute bronchitis is often caused by a viral respiratory infection and improves by itself.
Symptoms of bronchitis include coughing up thickened mucus and shortness of breath.
Treatments usually includes soothing remedies to help with coughing, which may last weeks. Antibiotics are not usually recommended.
Acute Bronchitis.notes:
Spreads easily
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Narcotic: Relieves pain, dulls the senses and causes drowsiness. May become addictive.
Medication.Cough medicine: Blocks the cough reflex. Some may thin and loosen mucus, making it easier to clear from the airways.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia.symptomDescription: Symptoms may include enlarged lymph nodes, bruising, fever, bone pain, bleeding from the gums and frequent infections.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, fever, loss of appetite, or night sweats
symptoms.Also common: bleeding gums, easy bruising, infection, nosebleed, pallor, red spots on skin, shortness of breath, swollen lymph nodes, or weight loss

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia.overview:
Description
A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that affects white blood cells.
Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia is the most common childhood cancer. It occurs when a bone marrow cell develops errors in its DNA.
Symptoms may include enlarged lymph nodes, bruising, fever, bone pain, bleeding from the gums and frequent infections.
Treatments may include chemotherapy or targeted drugs that specifically kill cancer cells.
Acute lymphoblastic leukemia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Medical procedure.Allotransplantation: Transfer of living organs or tissue from one part of the body to another or from one individual to another. Examples include organ transplants and bone grafts.

specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.
specialists.Paediatric haematologist-oncologist: Treats blood disorders and cancer in children.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Acute myeloid leukemia.symptomDescription: Symptoms include fatigue, fever, recurrent infections and bruising of the body easily.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, fever, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: bleeding, bruising, infection, pallor, red spots on skin, or shortness of breath

Acute myeloid leukemia.overview:
Description
A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow with excess immature white blood cells.
AML progresses rapidly, with myeloid cells interfering with the production of normal white blood cells, red blood cells and platelets.
Symptoms include fatigue, fever, recurrent infections and bruising of the body easily.
Treatments include chemotherapy, other drug therapy and stem-cell transplants.
Acute myeloid leukemia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Critical: needs emergency care

Medical procedure.Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell trans: Delivering stem cells from a healthy donor to a recipient.

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.

specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.

Addison's disease.symptomDescription: Symptoms tend to be non-specific and include fatigue, nausea, darkening of the skin and dizziness upon standing.

symptoms.Whole body: dehydration, dizziness, fainting, fatigue, light-headedness, loss of appetite, low blood pressure, low blood sugar, water-electrolyte imbalance, or sweating
symptoms.Also common: absence of menstruation, craving salty foods, darkening of the skin, excess urination, muscle weakness, reduced sex drive, or weight loss

Addison's disease.overview:
Description
A disorder in which the adrenal glands don't produce enough hormones.
Specifically, the adrenal glands produce insufficient amounts of the hormone cortisol and sometimes aldosterone, too. When the body is under stress (e.g. fighting an infection), this deficiency of cortisol can result in a life threatening Addisonian crisis characterised by low blood pressure.
Symptoms tend to be non-specific and include fatigue, nausea, darkening of the skin and dizziness upon standing.
Treatment involves taking hormones to replace those not produced by the adrenal glands.
Addison's disease.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Adult attention-deficit/hyperactivity di.symptomDescription: ADHD symptoms include trouble focusing, hyperactivity and impulsive behaviour.

symptoms.Behavioural: hyperactivity, fidgeting, impulsivity, irritability, risk-taking behaviours, or lack of restraint
symptoms.Cognitive: difficulty focusing, forgetfulness, lack of concentration, problem paying attention, racing thoughts, or short attention span
symptoms.Mood: anxiety, boredom, excitement, or mood swings
symptoms.Also common: depression, learning disability, or sleep deprivation

Adult attention-deficit/hyperactivity di.overview:
Description
A mental health condition exhibited by difficulty maintaining attention.
Adult attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a mental health condition that can lead to unstable relationships, poor work performance and low self-esteem.
ADHD symptoms include trouble focusing, hyperactivity and impulsive behaviour.
Drugs, talk therapy and treatment for associated mental health conditions can help.
Adult attention-deficit/hyperactivity di.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required

Medication.Antidepressant: Taking medications designed to help relieve symptoms of depression. Some antidepressants also have other uses, such as treating chronic pain and certain anxiety disorders.
Medication.Stimulant: Increases neurotransmitter levels, heart rate and blood pressure. Decreases appetite and sleep.
Medication.Cognition-enhancing medication: Improves mental function, lowers blood pressure and may balance mood.

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Cognitive therapy: Talk therapy that focuses on replacing negative, distorted thoughts with positive, accurate ones.
Therapies.Psychoeducation: Education about mental health that also serves to support, validate and empower patients.
Therapies.Behaviour therapy: A therapy focused on modifying harmful behaviours associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.
Therapies.Group psychotherapy: Talk therapy where the therapist works with clients in a group instead of one-on-one.

specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Agoraphobia.symptomDescription: Symptoms include fear and avoidance of places and situations that might cause feelings of panic, entrapment, helplessness or embarrassment.

symptoms.Mood: apprehension or panic attack

Agoraphobia.overview:
Description
Fear of places and situations that might cause panic, helplessness or embarrassment.
Agoraphobia is an anxiety disorder that often develops after one or more panic attacks.
Symptoms include fear and avoidance of places and situations that might cause feelings of panic, entrapment, helplessness or embarrassment.
Treatments include talk therapy and medication.
Agoraphobia.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required

Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Exposure and response prevention: A talk therapy based on exposing feared or traumatic experiences within a safe setting in order to help reduce any associated psychological distress.
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.
Therapies.Systematic desensitization: Psychological treatment that helps people overcome fears by gradually exposing them to the things they're afraid of.

Self-care.Relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, meditation, yoga, rhythmic exercise and other activities that reduce symptoms of stress

Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.
Medication.Anxiolytic: Relieves anxiety and tension. May promote sleep.
Medication.Sedative: Causes drowsiness, calmness and dulled senses. Some types may become addictive.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Psychoanalyst: Uses psychotherapy to treat mental disorders.

Alcohol use disorder.extraName: Also called: alcoholism, alcohol dependence, alcohol dependence, alcoholism, alcohol addiction
Alcohol use disorder.symptomDescription: Symptoms include repeated alcohol consumption despite related legal and health issues. Those with alcoholism may begin each day with a drink, feel guilty about their drinking and have the desire to cut down on the amount of drinking.

symptoms.Whole body: blackout, dizziness, shakiness, craving, or sweating
symptoms.Behavioural: aggression, agitation, compulsive behaviour, self-destructive behaviour, or lack of restraint
symptoms.Mood: anxiety, euphoria, general discontent, guilt, or loneliness
symptoms.Also common: physical substance dependence, problems with coordination, slurred speech, or tremor

Alcohol use disorder.overview:
Description
A chronic disease characterised by uncontrolled drinking and preoccupation with alcohol.
Alcoholism is the inability to control drinking due to both a physical and emotional dependence on alcohol.
Symptoms include repeated alcohol consumption despite related legal and health issues. Those with alcoholism may begin each day with a drink, feel guilty about their drinking and have the desire to cut down on the amount of drinking.
Treatment involves counselling by a healthcare professional. A detoxification programme in a hospital or medical facility is an option for those who need additional assistance. Medications are available that reduce the desire to drink.
Alcohol use disorder.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medical procedure.Detox: No longer consuming toxins or clearing toxins from the body through dieting, fasting or colon cleansing.

Medication.Sedative: Causes drowsiness, calmness and dulled senses. Some types may become addictive.
Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.
Medication.Alcoholism medication: Treats chronic alcoholism by decreasing cravings or by causing unpleasant side effects when alcohol is consumed.

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Aversion therapy: Suppressing unwanted behaviour, like smoking, by associating it with a negative experience, like an electric shock.
Therapies.Family therapy: Psychological counselling that helps families resolve conflicts and communicate more effectively.
Therapies.Behaviour therapy: A therapy focused on modifying harmful behaviours associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.
Therapies.Group psychotherapy: Talk therapy where the therapist works with clients in a group instead of one-on-one.
Therapies.Counseling: Professional advice and support that help people solve problems, make decisions and change their behaviour.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Allergic conjunctivitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms consist of eye redness, itching and increased tears.

symptoms.Eyes: itchiness, redness, watery eyes, or puffy eyes
symptoms.Visual: blurred vision or sensitivity to light

Allergic conjunctivitis.overview:
Description
Eye inflammation caused by allergies.
Allergic conjunctivitis is inflammation of the lining of the eye (conjunctiva) due to allergy. Although allergens differ, pollen is a common seasonal cause.
Symptoms consist of eye redness, itching and increased tears.
Treatment includes avoiding the allergen and taking antihistamine medication either by mouth or directly into the eye.
Allergic conjunctivitis.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.
Medication.Eye decongestant: Relieves redness and irritation in the eyes.

Self-care.Artificial tears: Moistens eyes to provide soothing relief.
Self-care.Cold compress: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Stop contact lens use: Reduces risk of irritation to the eye.

specialists.Allergy & Immunology Doctor: Treats allergy and immune system disorders.

Allergic rhinitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include sneezing, runny nose and red, watery and itchy eyes.

symptoms.Nasal: congestion, loss of smell, redness, runny nose, post-nasal drip, sneezing, or stuffy nose
symptoms.Eyes: itchiness, puffy eyes, redness, or watery eyes
symptoms.Respiratory: breathing through the mouth or wheezing
symptoms.Also common: coughing, fatigue, headache, itching, phlegm, or throat irritation

Allergic rhinitis.overview:
Description
An allergic response causing itchy, watery eyes, sneezing and other similar symptoms.
Allergic rhinitis occurs seasonally or year-round. Diagnosis involves history-taking, examination of the nasal passages and sometimes skin testing.
Symptoms include sneezing, runny nose and red, watery and itchy eyes.
Antihistamine medication can reduce symptoms.
Allergic rhinitis.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Avoid allergen: Staying away from triggers that can cause allergic reactions, such as pollen or certain foods.
Self-care.Nasal washing: Rinsing the inside of the nose with warm salt water to flush out irritants and excess mucus. Often done using a neti pot or squeeze bottle.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.
Medication.Decongestant: Relieves nasal congestion, swelling and runny nose.
Medication.Eye decongestant: Relieves redness and irritation in the eyes.
Medication.Bronchodilator: Helps open the airways of the lungs to make breathing easier.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.

Medical procedure.Desensitization: Reducing allergic reactions by injecting gradually increasing doses of the substance causing the reaction.

specialists.Allergy & Immunology Doctor: Treats allergy and immune system disorders.
specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.

Allergy to mold.symptomDescription: Symptoms include cough, itchy, watery eyes and hives. People who have asthma may experience wheezing and difficulty breathing.

symptoms.Nasal: runny nose, post-nasal drip, or sneezing
symptoms.Eyes: itchiness, puffy eyes, or watery eyes
symptoms.Also common: coughing, shortness of breath, or throat irritation

Allergy to mold.overview:
Description
An abnormal allergic reaction to mould spores.
In people who have mould allergy, being exposed to mould (at work, home or outdoors) causes the immune system to overreact.
Symptoms include cough, itchy, watery eyes and hives. People who have asthma may experience wheezing and difficulty breathing.
Treatment involves avoiding mould exposure. Medication such as antihistamines, nasal sprays and allergy shots can help relieve symptoms and manage asthma.
Allergy to mold.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Avoid allergen: Staying away from triggers that can cause allergic reactions, such as pollen or certain foods.

Medical procedure.Desensitization: Psychological treatment that reduces fear and anxiety by gradually exposing the person to what they're afraid of.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.
Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.
Medication.Decongestant: Relieves nasal congestion, swelling and runny nose.

specialists.Allergy & Immunology Doctor: Treats allergy and immune system disorders.

Alopecia areata.extraName: Also called: AA, patchy hair loss
Alopecia areata.symptomDescription: The main symptom is hair loss.

symptoms.Common symptoms: hair loss, anxiety, itching, or small dents in nails

Alopecia areata.overview:
Description
Sudden hair loss that starts with one or more circular bald patches that may overlap.
Alopecia areata occurs when the immune system attacks hair follicles and may be brought on by severe stress.
The main symptom is hair loss.
Treatment may address any underlying conditions and includes topical scalp medication.
Alopecia areata.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.

Self-care.PUVA: Applying UV light to the skin, often with a topical medication, to treat certain skin conditions.
Self-care.Stress management: Pursuing an enjoyable activity or verbalising frustration to reduce stress and improve mental health.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Alzheimer's disease.symptomDescription: Memory loss and confusion are the main symptoms.

symptoms.Cognitive: mental decline, difficulty thinking and understanding, confusion in the evening hours, delusion, disorientation, forgetfulness, making things up, mental confusion, difficulty concentrating, inability to create new memories, inability to do simple maths, or inability to recognise common things
symptoms.Behavioural: aggression, agitation, difficulty with self care, irritability, meaningless repetition of own words, personality changes, restlessness, lack of restraint, or wandering and getting lost
symptoms.Mood: anger, apathy, general discontent, loneliness, or mood swings
symptoms.Also common: inability to combine muscle movements, jumbled speech, or loss of appetite

Alzheimer's disease.overview:
Description
A progressive disease that destroys memory and other important mental functions.
Brain cell connections and the cells themselves degenerate and die, eventually destroying memory and other important mental functions.
Memory loss and confusion are the main symptoms.
No cure exists, but medication and management strategies may temporarily improve symptoms.
Alzheimer's disease.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Cognition-enhancing medication: Improves mental function, lowers blood pressure and may balance mood.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Amoebiasis.symptomDescription: If symptoms occur, they may be mild and include cramping and diarrhoea. Bloody stools, fever and, rarely, liver abscess may occur in severe cases.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: blood in stool, diarrhoea, or flatulence
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, fever, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: weight loss

Amoebiasis.overview:
Description
A parasitic infection of the colon with the amoeba Entamoeba histolytica.
Amoebiasis infection is most common in tropical areas with untreated water. It spreads through drinking or eating uncooked food, such as fruit, that may have been washed in contaminated local water.
If symptoms occur, they may be mild and include cramping and diarrhoea. Bloody stools, fever and, rarely, liver abscess may occur in severe cases.
Treatment includes antibiotics.
Amoebiasis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Spreads through contaminated food or water
HOW IT SPREADS
Through contaminated food or water.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

Supportive care.Oral rehydration therapy: Giving fluid by mouth to treat dehydration caused by diarrhoea.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.

Amyloidosis.symptomDescription: Symptoms depend on which organs are affected. They may include swelling, fatigue and weakness, shortness of breath, and numbness, tingling or pain in the hands or feet.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the abdomen, foot, or hands
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, feeling full sooner than normal, or nervous system dysfunction
symptoms.Sensory: pins and needles or reduced sensation of touch
symptoms.Heart: enlarged heart or irregular heart rate
symptoms.Respiratory: shortness of breath or shortness of breath on lying down
symptoms.Skin: rash of small purplish spots or red spots
symptoms.Also common: abnormally large tongue, bruising, carpal tunnel syndrome, diarrhoea, generalised body swelling, impaired voice, organ dysfunction, puffy eyes, swelling in extremities, tingling feet, or weight loss

Amyloidosis.overview:
Description
The build-up of amyloid proteins in the heart, kidneys, liver or other organs.
Amyloid is an abnormal protein that is usually produced in the bone marrow and can be deposited in any tissue or organ.
Symptoms depend on which organs are affected. They may include swelling, fatigue and weakness, shortness of breath, and numbness, tingling or pain in the hands or feet.
Depending on the type of amyloidosis, medication, chemotherapy or a stem-cell transplant may be options.
Amyloidosis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.

Medical procedure.Haematopoietic stem cell transplantation: Transplanting stem cells to restore a person's immune system. The transplanted cells can come from a donor or be the person's own cells.
Medical procedure.Hemodialysis: Using a machine and a special filter to clean the blood when the kidneys can no longer do it.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Anal fissure.symptomDescription: An anal fissure can cause pain and bleeding during bowel movements.

symptoms.Also common: cracked skin

Anal fissure.overview:
Description
A small tear in the lining of the anus.
Anal fissure may occur when passing hard or large stools.
An anal fissure can cause pain and bleeding during bowel movements.
This condition usually heals on its own in four to six weeks. Common treatments include dietary fibre and stool softeners, as well as creams to the affected area.
Anal fissure.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Self-care.Hip bath: A shallow bath where only the hips and buttocks soak in warm water. Often used to treat haemorrhoids.
Self-care.Dietary fiber: The parts of plant foods that the body can't digest. Helps to control blood sugar, soften stools and maintain bowel health.

Medication.Local anesthetic: Blocks pain at and near the site where it's given, or along the nerve that's blocked.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.
Medication.Laxative: Loosens stools, increases bowel movements and relieves constipation.

Medical procedure.Botox injection: Injecting a weak poison (toxin) to temporarily paralyse the muscles.

specialists.Colon & Rectal Surgeon: Performs surgery on the intestinal tract.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Anaphylaxis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include a skin rash, nausea, vomiting, difficulty breathing and shock.

symptoms.Whole body: fainting, light-headedness, low blood pressure, dizziness, or flushing
symptoms.Respiratory: difficulty breathing, rapid breathing, shortness of breath, or wheezing
symptoms.Skin: hives, swelling under the skin, blue skin from poor circulation, or rashes
symptoms.Also common: fast heart rate, feeling of impending doom, itching, tongue swelling, difficulty swallowing, facial swelling, impaired voice, mental confusion, or nasal congestion

Anaphylaxis.overview:
Description
A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction.
The reaction can occur within seconds or minutes of exposure to an allergen.
Symptoms include a skin rash, nausea, vomiting, difficulty breathing and shock.
If not treated right away, usually with adrenalin, it can result in unconsciousness or death.
Anaphylaxis.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Bronchodilator: Helps open the airways of the lungs to make breathing easier.
Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Supportive care.Tracheal intubation: Inserting a tube into the windpipe (trachea) through the mouth or nose to keep the airway open. Done when someone cannot breathe on their own.
Supportive care.Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR): Emergency procedure performed when someone's heart has stopped. Commonly known as CPR.
Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.
specialists.Allergy & Immunology Doctor: Treats allergy and immune system disorders.
specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Anemia.symptomDescription: Symptoms may include fatigue, skin pallor, shortness of breath, light-headedness, dizziness or a fast heartbeat.

symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, light-headedness, or malaise
symptoms.Heart: fast heart rate or palpitations
symptoms.Also common: brittle nails, headache, pallor, shortness of breath, or weakness

Anemia.overview:
Description
A condition in which the blood doesn't have enough healthy red blood cells.
Anaemia results from a lack of red blood cells or dysfunctional red blood cells in the body. This leads to reduced oxygen flow to the body's organs.
Symptoms may include fatigue, skin pallor, shortness of breath, light-headedness, dizziness or a fast heartbeat.
Treatment depends on the underlying diagnosis. Iron supplements can be used for iron deficiency. Vitamin B supplements may be used for low vitamin levels. Blood transfusions can be used for blood loss. Medication to induce blood formation may be used if the body’s blood production is reduced.
Anemia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.
Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.
Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.

Angelman syndrome.symptomDescription: Symptoms include lack of crawling or babbling, minimal speech and frequent smiling and laughter. Inability to walk, move or balance well (ataxia) is also a symptom.

symptoms.Developmental: speech delay in a child or short stature
symptoms.Muscular: abnormality walking or problems with coordination
symptoms.Cognitive: developmental disability or intellectual disability
symptoms.Also common: happy demeanour, speech impairment, drooling, lazy eye, seizures, or sleep disorder

Angelman syndrome.overview:
Description
A genetic disorder causing developmental disabilities and nerve-related symptoms.
Angelman syndrome usually isn't detected until developmental delays become noticeable, usually when a baby is about six to 12 months old.
Symptoms include lack of crawling or babbling, minimal speech and frequent smiling and laughter. Inability to walk, move or balance well (ataxia) is also a symptom.
Treatment includes anti-seizure medication and therapies to help manage medical and developmental concerns.
Angelman syndrome.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
Therapies.Behaviour therapy: A therapy focused on modifying harmful behaviours associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Occupational Therapy: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.

Medication.Sedative: Causes drowsiness, calmness and dulled senses. Some types may become addictive.

specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Angina.symptomDescription: Angina feels like squeezing, pressure, heaviness, tightness or pain in the chest. It can be sudden or recur over time.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the chest, jaw, or neck
symptoms.Pain types: can be like a clenched fist in the chest or sudden in the chest
symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, inability to exercise, light-headedness, or sweating
symptoms.Respiratory: rapid breathing or shortness of breath
symptoms.Also common: anxiety, chest pressure, or fast heart rate

Angina.overview:
Description
A type of chest pain caused by reduced blood flow to the heart.
Angina is a symptom of coronary artery disease.
Angina feels like squeezing, pressure, heaviness, tightness or pain in the chest. It can be sudden or recur over time.
Depending on severity, it can be treated by lifestyle changes, medication, angioplasty or surgery.
Angina.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Treatable by a medical professional
Critical: needs emergency care

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.

Medication.Antianginal: Helps reduce chest pain or pressure caused by blockages in the arteries of the heart.
Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.
Medication.Anticoagulant: Unwanted reactions from taking drugs that inhibit blood clotting. The most common problem is too much bleeding, which can be very serious.

Medical procedure.Coronary stent: A tube placed in the arteries of the heart to keep them open.
Medical procedure.Cardiac catheterization: Inserting a long tube into the groin, neck or arm and then threading it through the blood vessels to the heart.
Medical procedure.Revascularization: Restoring blood flow to an organ or a part of the body where it was previously blocked.
Medical procedure.Coronary angioplasty: Unblocking an artery by inflating a balloon inside it. A stent may also be inserted to hold the artery open.
Medical procedure.Angioplasty: Unblocking an artery by inflating a balloon inside it. A stent may also be inserted to hold the artery open.

Therapies.Cardiac rehabilitation: A supervised programme that includes exercise, lifestyle changes, education and emotional support for people with heart problems.

Surgery.Coronary artery bypass surgery: Surgery that restores blood flow to the heart by using a healthy artery or vein to bypass a blocked artery.
Surgery.Hybrid coronary revascularization: A minimally invasive procedure that combines heart bypass surgery with tubes to hold weakened arteries open (stenting).

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.
specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Cardiac Surgeon: Performs surgery on the heart or great vessels.

Ankylosing spondylitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms typically appear in early adulthood and include reduced flexibility in the spine. This reduced flexibility eventually results in a hunched-forward posture. Pain in the back and joints is also common.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the ankle, eyes, heel, hip, joints, lower back, middle back, neck, or shoulder
symptoms.Pain types: can be arthritic
symptoms.Eyes: inflammation of the eye's middle layer or redness
symptoms.Visual: blurred vision or sensitivity to light
symptoms.Also common: bone tissue formation, fatigue, hunched back, inflamed tendons, inflammatory bowel disease, physical deformity, or sleep disorder

Ankylosing spondylitis.overview:
Description
An inflammatory arthritis affecting the spine and large joints.
The condition is more common among men and usually begins in early adulthood.
Symptoms typically appear in early adulthood and include reduced flexibility in the spine. This reduced flexibility eventually results in a hunched-forward posture. Pain in the back and joints is also common.
Treatment includes medication, physiotherapy and in rare cases, surgery.
Ankylosing spondylitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Anorexia nervosa.symptomDescription: Symptoms include trying to maintain a below-normal weight through starvation or too much exercise.

symptoms.Whole body: dehydration, dizziness, fainting, fatigue, low blood pressure, low body temperature, osteoporosis, water-electrolyte imbalance, or feeling cold
symptoms.Behavioural: binge eating, compulsive behaviour, hyperactivity, impulsivity, or social isolation
symptoms.Weight: underweight, weight loss, or extreme weight loss and thinness
symptoms.Mood: anxiety, apprehension, or guilt
symptoms.Menstrual: irregular menstruation or absence of menstruation
symptoms.Also common: brittle nails, bruising, depression, dieting, dry hair, dry skin, headache, sensitivity to cold, or slow heart rate

Anorexia nervosa.overview:
Description
An eating disorder causing people to obsess about weight and what they eat.
Anorexia is characterised by a distorted body image, with an unwarranted fear of being overweight.
Symptoms include trying to maintain a below-normal weight through starvation or too much exercise.
Medical treatment may be required to restore normal weight. Talk therapy can help with self-esteem and behavioural changes.
Anorexia nervosa.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Dialectical behavior therapy: Talk therapy that encourages people to both accept themselves and change their negative behaviours.
Therapies.Counseling psychology: A branch of psychology that treats personal problems related to school, work, family and social life.
Therapies.Interpersonal psychotherapy: Short-term psychological treatment that focuses on the person's relationships with others.
Therapies.Family therapy: Psychological counselling that helps families resolve conflicts and communicate more effectively.
Therapies.Behaviour therapy: A therapy focused on modifying harmful behaviours associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.
Therapies.Brief psychotherapy: Short-term counselling that focuses on achieving specific goals.
Therapies.Group psychotherapy: Talk therapy where the therapist works with clients in a group instead of one-on-one.

Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.
Medication.Antipsychotic: Reduces or improves the symptoms of certain psychiatric conditions.

specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychoanalyst: Uses psychotherapy to treat mental disorders.

Antiphospholipid syndrome.extraName: Also called: APS, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
Antiphospholipid syndrome.symptomDescription: Symptoms may include blood clots, which may occur in the legs, arms or lungs. Recurrent miscarriages may also be common.

symptoms.Respiratory: blood clots in the lungs or shortness of breath
symptoms.Also common: deep vein thrombosis, pain in the affected area, purplish skin discolouration, recurrent miscarriage, or swelling of limb

Antiphospholipid syndrome.overview:
Description
A disorder in which the immune system mistakenly attacks normal proteins in the blood.
Antiphospholipid syndrome can cause blood clots to form within the arteries, veins and organs. It can also cause miscarriage and stillbirth in pregnant women.
Symptoms may include blood clots, which may occur in the legs, arms or lungs. Recurrent miscarriages may also be common.
Blood-thinning medication can reduce the risk of blood clots.
Antiphospholipid syndrome.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Anticoagulant: Unwanted reactions from taking drugs that inhibit blood clotting. The most common problem is too much bleeding, which can be very serious.

specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.
specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.

Antisocial personality disorder.symptomDescription: Those with antisocial personality disorder tend to lie, break laws, act impulsively and lack regard for their own safety or the safety of others. Symptoms may lessen with age.

symptoms.Behavioural: antisocial behaviour, deceitfulness, hostility, irresponsibility, manipulativeness, risk-taking behaviours, aggression, impulsivity, irritability, or lack of restraint
symptoms.Mood: anger, boredom, or general discontent
symptoms.Also common: physical substance dependence or substance abuse

Antisocial personality disorder.overview:
Description
A mental health disorder characterised by disregard for other people.
Those with antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) may begin to show symptoms in childhood, but the condition can't be diagnosed until adolescence or adulthood.
Those with antisocial personality disorder tend to lie, break laws, act impulsively and lack regard for their own safety or the safety of others. Symptoms may lessen with age.
Treatment may include talk therapy and support for affected family members.
Antisocial personality disorder.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Therapies.Family therapy: Psychological counselling that helps families resolve conflicts and communicate more effectively.
Therapies.Behaviour therapy: A therapy focused on modifying harmful behaviours associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Psychoanalyst: Uses psychotherapy to treat mental disorders.

Anxiety disorder.symptomDescription: Symptoms include stress that's out of proportion to the impact of the event, inability to set aside a worry and restlessness.

symptoms.Behavioural: hypervigilance, irritability, or restlessness
symptoms.Cognitive: lack of concentration, racing thoughts, or unwanted thoughts
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or sweating
symptoms.Also common: anxiety, excessive worry, fear, feeling of impending doom, insomnia, nausea, palpitations, or trembling

Anxiety disorder.overview:
Description
A mental health disorder characterised by feelings of worry, anxiety or fear that are strong enough to interfere with one's daily activities.
Examples of anxiety disorders include panic attacks, obsessive-compulsive disorder and post-traumatic stress disorder.
Symptoms include stress that's out of proportion to the impact of the event, inability to set aside a worry and restlessness.
Treatment includes counselling or medication, including antidepressants.
Anxiety disorder.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required

Self-care.Avoid alcohol: May be harmful and aggravate certain conditions.
Self-care.Reduce caffeine intake: Reduces risk of aggravating certain conditions.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, meditation, yoga, rhythmic exercise and other activities that reduce symptoms of stress
Self-care.Stress management: Pursuing an enjoyable activity or verbalising frustration to reduce stress and improve mental health.
Self-care.Healthy diet: A diet that provides essential nutrients and adequate calories, while avoiding excess sugar, carbohydrates and fatty foods.

Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Meditation: Improves mental health and helps with relaxation.
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.

Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.
Medication.Anxiolytic: Relieves anxiety and tension. May promote sleep.
Medication.Antidepressant: Taking medications designed to help relieve symptoms of depression. Some antidepressants also have other uses, such as treating chronic pain and certain anxiety disorders.
Medication.Sedative: Causes drowsiness, calmness and dulled senses. Some types may become addictive.
Medication.Nerve pain medication: Blocks pain caused by damaged nerves.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Aortic dissection.symptomDescription: Symptoms include sudden, severe chest or upper back pain that radiates to the neck or down the back, loss of consciousness and shortness of breath.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the abdomen or middle back
symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fainting, or low blood pressure
symptoms.Also common: acute severe chest pain, nausea, or shortness of breath

Aortic dissection.overview:
Description
A tear in the inner layer of the large blood vessel branching off the heart (aorta).
An aortic dissection is a medical emergency in which the inner layer of the large blood vessel branching off the heart (aorta) tears. It's most common in men in their 60s and 70s.
Symptoms include sudden, severe chest or upper back pain that radiates to the neck or down the back, loss of consciousness and shortness of breath.
Treatment may include surgery and medication, such as beta blockers.
Aortic dissection.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.

Surgery.Endovascular aneurysm repair: Surgical repair of a bulge (aneurysm) in the main blood vessel of the body (aorta) to prevent bleeding or rupture.
Surgery.Vascular grafting: Surgery to bypass a blocked or diseased blood vessel using a vein or a synthetic tube (graft).

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Vascular Surgeon: Specialises in surgery for vascular system diseases.
specialists.Cardiothoracic Surgeon: Surgically treats diseases affecting organs inside the chest.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Aortic stenosis.symptomDescription: The heart may weaken, causing chest pain, fatigue and shortness of breath.

symptoms.Whole body: fainting, fatigue, inability to exercise, or light-headedness
symptoms.Heart: murmur or enlarged heart
symptoms.Also common: chest pressure or shortness of breath

Aortic stenosis.overview:
Description
Narrowing of the valve in the large blood vessel branching off the heart (aorta).
This narrowing keeps the valve from opening fully, reducing blood flow to the body and making the heart work harder.
The heart may weaken, causing chest pain, fatigue and shortness of breath.
Mild cases may not need treatment. In severe cases, surgery can repair or replace the valve.
Aortic stenosis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.

Surgery.Aortic valve replacement: Replacement of a damaged heart valve with an artificial one. The new valve can be mechanical or animal tissue.
Surgery.Balloon valvuloplasty: Widening a narrow heart valve by inflating a balloon inside it. Sometimes used as a 'bridge' treatment for patients who can't undergo valve replacement surgery.

specialists.Cardiothoracic Surgeon: Surgically treats diseases affecting organs inside the chest.

Aphasia.symptomDescription: Aphasia affects a person's ability to express and understand written and spoken language.

symptoms.Behavioural: social isolation or persistent repetition of words or actions
symptoms.Also common: difficulty building and drawing things or loss of the ability to write

Aphasia.overview:
Description
A language disorder that affects a person's ability to communicate.
It can occur suddenly after a stroke or head injury or develop slowly from a growing brain tumour or disease.
Aphasia affects a person's ability to express and understand written and spoken language.
Once the underlying cause is treated, the main treatment for aphasia is speech therapy.
Aphasia.notes:
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Critical: needs emergency care

Therapies.Speech therapy: Treats people with speech and language problems.
Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Rehabilitation: Retraining the brain's pathways to improve mental and physical functioning after an illness or injury. For example, after a blow to the head (concussion).
Therapies.Stroke rehabilitation: Relearning skills that are lost when the brain is damaged by a stroke. For example, how to walk and talk.
Therapies.Group psychotherapy: Talk therapy where the therapist works with clients in a group instead of one-on-one.

specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Appendicitis.symptomDescription: Appendicitis begins with fever and pain near the belly button and then moves toward the lower-right side of the abdomen. This is often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, fever and chills.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the abdomen, mid-abdomen, or right lower abdomen
symptoms.Pain types: can be dull, sharp, mild, or severe
symptoms.Whole body: chills, fever, loss of appetite, or malaise
symptoms.Also common: abdominal pain migration

Appendicitis.overview:
Description
A condition in which the appendix becomes inflamed and filled with pus, causing pain.
The appendix is a pouch-like structure attached at the start of the large intestine that has no known purpose.
Appendicitis begins with fever and pain near the belly button and then moves toward the lower-right side of the abdomen. This is often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, fever and chills.
Appendicitis is usually treated with antibiotics and surgery is required within 24 hours of its diagnosis. If untreated, the appendix can rupture and cause an abscess or systemic infection (sepsis).
Appendicitis.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Surgery.Laparotomy: Surgical opening made in the abdomen to diagnose or treat various diseases.
Surgery.Laparoscopic surgery: Surgery that uses a video camera and thin tubes inserted into small cuts on the body to repair or remove tissue.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.

Self-care.Fasting from food and drink: Rests the bowel and reduces the risk of complications prior to procedures or surgeries.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Arrhythmia.symptomDescription: There may be no symptoms. Alternatively, symptoms may include a fluttering in the chest, chest pain, fainting or dizziness.

symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fainting, or light-headedness
symptoms.Heart: palpitations or slow heart rate
symptoms.Also common: shortness of breath

Arrhythmia.overview:
Description
Improper beating of the heart, whether irregular, too fast or too slow.
Cardiac arrhythmia occurs when electrical impulses in the heart don't work properly.
There may be no symptoms. Alternatively, symptoms may include a fluttering in the chest, chest pain, fainting or dizziness.
If required, treatment includes anti-arrhythmic drugs, medical procedures, implantable devices and surgery.
Arrhythmia.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Treatable by a medical professional
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Antiarrhythmic: Helps control abnormal or irregular heart rhythms.
Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

Medical procedure.Cardioversion: Using electrical shocks to restore normal heart rhythm in people with irregular heartbeats.
Medical procedure.Radiofrequency ablation: Removal of tissue using the heat from an electric current produced by a radio wave.

Devices.Pacemaker: A small device placed in the chest or abdomen that sends out electrical signals to keep the heart beating normally.
Devices.Implantable cardioverter defibrillator: A small device placed in the chest or abdomen that shocks the heart if it develops a dangerously irregular heartbeat.

Supportive care.Cardiac monitoring: Using an electronic device to monitor heart rate and rhythm. Can be done in the hospital or at home.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Arteriovenous malformation.symptomDescription: Symptoms can include headaches and seizures.

symptoms.Common symptoms: dizziness, headache, or seizures

Arteriovenous malformation.overview:
Description
An abnormal connection between arteries and veins, usually in the brain or spine.
Arteriovenous malformation (AVM) is usually present at birth. The arteries and veins in an AVM can rupture, causing bleeding into the brain or spinal cord.
Symptoms can include headaches and seizures.
Surgery is the most common treatment for brain AVMs. In some cases, a catheter or radiation may be used to close off vessels. Medication may be used to treat headaches and seizures.
Arteriovenous malformation.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Medical procedure.Embolization: Deliberately clogging abnormal blood vessels to block the flow of blood.
Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

specialists.Vascular and Interventional Radiologist: Uses images to diagnose and treat vascular diseases.
specialists.Vascular Surgeon: Specialises in surgery for vascular system diseases.

Asperger syndrome.symptomDescription: People with this condition may be socially awkward and have an all-absorbing interest in specific topics.

symptoms.Behavioural: aggression, compulsive behaviour, fidgeting, impulsivity, repetitive movements, social isolation, or persistent repetition of words or actions
symptoms.Muscular: inability to combine muscle movements, poor coordination, or tic
symptoms.Mood: anger, anxiety, or apprehension
symptoms.Also common: depression, intense interest in a limited number of things, learning disability, nightmares, or sensitivity to sound

Asperger syndrome.overview:
Description
A developmental disorder affecting ability to effectively socialise and communicate.
Asperger's syndrome is a condition on the autism spectrum, with generally higher functioning.
People with this condition may be socially awkward and have an all-absorbing interest in specific topics.
Communication training and behavioural therapy can help people with the syndrome learn to socialise more successfully.
Asperger syndrome.notes:
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Biofeedback: Controlling the body's heartbeat, brainwaves, breathing and blood pressure by monitoring them with sensors.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Anger management: Practicing mindfulness, coping mechanisms and trigger avoidance to minimise destructive emotional outbursts.
Therapies.Psychoeducation: Education about mental health that also serves to support, validate and empower patients.
Therapies.Family therapy: Psychological counselling that helps families resolve conflicts and communicate more effectively.
Therapies.Applied behavior analysis: A teaching method that helps autistic children learn socially significant skills by encouraging positive behaviour.
Therapies.Sensory processing: The way the nervous system receives messages from the senses and turns them into appropriate motor and behavioural responses.
Therapies.Group psychotherapy: Talk therapy where the therapist works with clients in a group instead of one-on-one.

Self-care.Stress management: Pursuing an enjoyable activity or verbalising frustration to reduce stress and improve mental health.

specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Asthma.symptomDescription: Asthma may cause difficulty breathing, chest pain, cough and wheezing. The symptoms may sometimes flare up.

symptoms.Cough: can occur at night, during exercise, can be chronic, dry, with phlegm, mild, or severe
symptoms.Respiratory: difficulty breathing, wheezing, breathing through the mouth, fast breathing, frequent respiratory infections, rapid breathing, or shortness of breath at night
symptoms.Also common: chest pressure, flare, anxiety, early awakening, fast heart rate, or throat irritation

Asthma.overview:
Description
A condition in which a person's airways become inflamed, narrow and swell and produce extra mucus, which makes it difficult to breathe.
Asthma can be minor or it can interfere with daily activities. In some cases, it may lead to a life-threatening attack.
Asthma may cause difficulty breathing, chest pain, cough and wheezing. The symptoms may sometimes flare up.
Asthma can usually be managed with rescue inhalers to treat symptoms (salbutamol) and controller inhalers that prevent symptoms (steroids). Severe cases may require longer-acting inhalers that keep the airways open (formoterol, salmeterol, tiotropium), as well as inhalant steroids.
Asthma.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Bronchodilator: Helps open the airways of the lungs to make breathing easier.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.

Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Respiratory Therapist: Treats and provides emergency care for patients who have trouble breathing.

Astigmatism.symptomDescription: A common symptom is blurry vision.

symptoms.Common symptoms: blurred vision, eye strain, or headache

Astigmatism.overview:
Description
A common imperfection in the eye's curvature.
With astigmatism, the front surface of the eye or the lens inside the eye is curved differently in one direction than the other.
A common symptom is blurry vision.
Treatments include prescription glasses or contact lenses. Laser-assisted surgery, such as LASIK, may also help.
Astigmatism.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Devices.Contact lenses: A lens placed directly on the eye to correct or assist with vision.
Devices.Glasses: A frame worn on the nose that holds a set of lenses to correct vision or protect the eyes.

Medical procedure.LASIK: Laser surgery that reshapes and removes tissue from the front of the eye (cornea) to correct vision.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Atherosclerosis.symptomDescription: Atherosclerosis often has no symptoms until a plaque ruptures or the build-up is severe enough to block blood flow.

symptoms.Pain circumstances: can occur in the leg while exercising
symptoms.Also common: erectile dysfunction (impotence), heart attack, mini-strokes (transient ischaemic attacks), poor wound healing, or stroke

Atherosclerosis.overview:
Description
The build-up of fats, cholesterol and other substances in and on the artery walls.
A build up of cholesterol plaque in the walls of arteries, causing obstruction of blood flow. Plaques may rupture, causing acute occlusion of the artery by clot.
Atherosclerosis often has no symptoms until a plaque ruptures or the build-up is severe enough to block blood flow.
A healthy diet and exercise can help. Treatments include medication, procedures to open blocked arteries and surgery.
Atherosclerosis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Heart-Healthy diet: A broad category of diets that reduce fat, sugar and red meat while increasing fruits, vegetables, white meat and fish.
Self-care.Supervised exercise program: An exercise programme under the guidance of a health professional.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.

Medication.Statin: Decreases the liver's production of harmful cholesterol.
Medication.Anticoagulant: Unwanted reactions from taking drugs that inhibit blood clotting. The most common problem is too much bleeding, which can be very serious.
Medication.Cholesterol medication: Lowers levels of harmful cholesterol in the blood or increases levels of beneficial cholesterol.

Medical procedure.Coronary stent: A tube placed in the arteries of the heart to keep them open.
Medical procedure.Angioplasty: Unblocking an artery by inflating a balloon inside it. A stent may also be inserted to hold the artery open.

Athlete's foot.symptomDescription: Symptoms include a scaly rash that usually causes itching, stinging and burning. People with athlete's foot can have moist, raw skin between their toes.

symptoms.Skin: rashes, dryness, fissures, peeling, or stinging
symptoms.Also common: infection, itching, stinging sensation, or swelling

Athlete's foot.overview:
Description
A fungal infection that usually begins between the toes.
Athlete's foot commonly occurs in people whose feet have become very sweaty while confined within tight-fitting shoes.
Symptoms include a scaly rash that usually causes itching, stinging and burning. People with athlete's foot can have moist, raw skin between their toes.
Treatment involves topical anti-fungal medication.
Athlete's foot.notes:
Spreads easily
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Medication.Antifungal: Kills or prevents growth of fungi.

Self-care.Warm soak: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Atopic eczema.symptomDescription: The main symptom is a rash that typically appears on the arms and behind the knees, but can also appear anywhere.

symptoms.Skin: rashes, dryness, flakiness, bumps, fissures, peeling, or redness
symptoms.Also common: itching

Atopic eczema.overview:
Description
An itchy inflammation of the skin.
Atopic dermatitis usually develops in early childhood and is more common in people who have a family history of the condition.
The main symptom is a rash that typically appears on the arms and behind the knees, but can also appear anywhere.
Treatment includes avoiding soap and other irritants. Certain creams or ointments may also provide relief from the itching.
Atopic eczema.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.
Medication.Topical antiseptic: Destroys or prevents the growth of microorganisms on the skin that may cause infection.
