Self-care.Ultraviolet light therapy: Ultraviolet light therapy for serious skin diseases. Used along with a special medication that increases light absorption.
Self-care.Barrier cream: A cream that soothes and protects irritated skin.
Self-care.PUVA: Applying UV light to the skin, often with a topical medication, to treat certain skin conditions.
Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Atrial fibrillation.symptomDescription: This condition may have no symptoms, but when symptoms do appear they include palpitations, shortness of breath and fatigue.

symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, inability to exercise, or weakness
symptoms.Heart: fast heart rate or palpitations
symptoms.Also common: shortness of breath

Atrial fibrillation.overview:
Description
An irregular, often rapid heart rate that commonly causes poor blood flow.
The heart's upper chambers (atria) beat out of coordination with the lower chambers (ventricles).
This condition may have no symptoms, but when symptoms do appear they include palpitations, shortness of breath and fatigue.
Treatments include drugs, electrical shock (cardioversion) and minimally invasive surgery (ablation).
Atrial fibrillation.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medical procedure.Cardioversion: Using electrical shocks to restore normal heart rhythm in people with irregular heartbeats.
Medical procedure.Catheter ablation: Using electrical energy to remove abnormal tissue. For example, in the heart to restore a regular heartbeat.

Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.
Medication.Antiarrhythmic: Helps control abnormal or irregular heart rhythms.
Medication.Anticoagulant: Unwanted reactions from taking drugs that inhibit blood clotting. The most common problem is too much bleeding, which can be very serious.

Supportive care.Cardiac monitoring: Using an electronic device to monitor heart rate and rhythm. Can be done in the hospital or at home.

Surgery.Cox maze procedure: Heart surgery where small cuts create a planned “maze” of scar tissue. The maze guides electrical signals, restoring a regular heartbeat.
Surgery.Mini maze procedure: Surgery that uses a tiny camera and small cuts to create a maze of scar tissue on a beating heart. The maze guides electrical signals and restores a regular heartbeat.

specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.

Atrial flutter.symptomDescription: Symptoms may include a racing heart (palpitations), shortness of breath and dizziness.

symptoms.Heart: fast heart rate, irregular heart rate, or palpitations
symptoms.Whole body: dizziness or light-headedness
symptoms.Also common: shortness of breath

Atrial flutter.overview:
Description
A condition in which the heart's upper chambers (atria) beat too quickly.
Rapid contractions of the upper chambers of the heart may spread to the lower chambers, resulting in a rapid heartbeat.
Symptoms may include a racing heart (palpitations), shortness of breath and dizziness.
Medication, electric shock or procedures that destroy abnormal tissue in the heart may be used to restore a normal heartbeat, control heart rate or prevent blood clots.
Atrial flutter.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.
Medication.Anticoagulant: Unwanted reactions from taking drugs that inhibit blood clotting. The most common problem is too much bleeding, which can be very serious.
Medication.Antiarrhythmic: Helps control abnormal or irregular heart rhythms.

Medical procedure.Cardioversion: Using electrical shocks to restore normal heart rhythm in people with irregular heartbeats.
Medical procedure.Catheter ablation: Using electrical energy to remove abnormal tissue. For example, in the heart to restore a regular heartbeat.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Atrial septal defect.symptomDescription: Many babies born with ASDs don't have symptoms. By the age of 30, adults may notice symptoms such as shortness of breath, heart palpitations, fatigue, swelling in the legs, feet or abdomen and heart murmurs.

symptoms.Heart: irregular heart rate, murmur, or palpitations
symptoms.Respiratory: pulmonary hypertension or shortness of breath
symptoms.Also common: failure to thrive, fatigue, or stroke

Atrial septal defect.overview:
Description
A birth defect that causes a hole in the wall between the heart's upper chambers (atria).
Atrial septal defects (ASDs) that aren't diagnosed until adulthood can damage the heart and lungs, shortening life.
Many babies born with ASDs don't have symptoms. By the age of 30, adults may notice symptoms such as shortness of breath, heart palpitations, fatigue, swelling in the legs, feet or abdomen and heart murmurs.
Small ASDs may close on their own. Medium-to-large-sized ASDs may need closure by device or surgical correction.
Atrial septal defect.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medical procedure.Transcatheter closure of atrial septal d: Closing an abnormal hole in the heart using a long tube (catheter) inserted through a blood vessel.
Medical procedure.Surgical ASD repair: Surgery performed to correct an abnormal hole in the heart.

Supportive care.Monitoring: Regular follow-up to evaluate for improvement.

specialists.Neonatologist: Provides medical care for newborn infants.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.extraName: Also called: ADHD, attention deficit disorder
Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.symptomDescription: Symptoms include limited attention and hyperactivity.

symptoms.Behavioural: aggression, excitability, fidgeting, hyperactivity, impulsivity, irritability, lack of restraint, or persistent repetition of words or actions
symptoms.Cognitive: absent-mindedness, difficulty focusing, forgetfulness, problem paying attention, or short attention span
symptoms.Mood: anger, anxiety, boredom, excitement, or mood swings
symptoms.Also common: depression or learning disability

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.overview:
Description
A chronic condition including attention difficulty, hyperactivity and impulsiveness.
ADHD often begins in childhood and can persist into adulthood. It may contribute to low self-esteem, troubled relationships and difficulty at school or work.
Symptoms include limited attention and hyperactivity.
Treatments include medication and talk therapy.
Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Anger management: Practicing mindfulness, coping mechanisms and trigger avoidance to minimise destructive emotional outbursts.
Therapies.Counseling psychology: A branch of psychology that treats personal problems related to school, work, family and social life.
Therapies.Psychoeducation: Education about mental health that also serves to support, validate and empower patients.
Therapies.Family therapy: Psychological counselling that helps families resolve conflicts and communicate more effectively.
Therapies.Applied behavior analysis: A teaching method that helps autistic children learn socially significant skills by encouraging positive behaviour.

Medication.Stimulant: Increases neurotransmitter levels, heart rate and blood pressure. Decreases appetite and sleep.
Medication.Cognition-enhancing medication: Improves mental function, lowers blood pressure and may balance mood.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Autism.symptomDescription: The range and severity of symptoms can vary widely. Common symptoms include difficulty with communication, difficulty with social interactions, obsessive interests and repetitive behaviours.

symptoms.Behavioural: inappropriate social interaction, poor eye contact, compulsive behaviour, impulsivity, repetitive movements, self-harm, or persistent repetition of words or actions
symptoms.Developmental: learning disability or speech delay in a child
symptoms.Cognitive: intense interest in a limited number of things or problem paying attention
symptoms.Psychological: unaware of others' emotions or depression
symptoms.Also common: anxiety, change in voice, sensitivity to sound, or tic

Autism.overview:
Description
A serious developmental disorder that impairs the ability to communicate and interact.
Autism spectrum disorder impacts the nervous system and affects the overall cognitive, emotional, social and physical health of the affected individual.
The range and severity of symptoms can vary widely. Common symptoms include difficulty with communication, difficulty with social interactions, obsessive interests and repetitive behaviours.
Early recognition, as well as behavioural, educational and family therapies may reduce symptoms and support development and learning.
Autism.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Therapies.Anger management: Practicing mindfulness, coping mechanisms and trigger avoidance to minimise destructive emotional outbursts.
Therapies.Family therapy: Psychological counselling that helps families resolve conflicts and communicate more effectively.
Therapies.Applied behavior analysis: A teaching method that helps autistic children learn socially significant skills by encouraging positive behaviour.
Therapies.Behaviour therapy: A therapy focused on modifying harmful behaviours associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Sensory processing: The way the nervous system receives messages from the senses and turns them into appropriate motor and behavioural responses.
Therapies.Animal-Assisted therapy: Using animals to enhance the physical, emotional and social well-being of humans.
Therapies.Telepractice: Using high-speed Internet, webcams, Skype and other communication technologies to provide speech therapy from a distant location.

Medication.Antipsychotic: Reduces or improves the symptoms of certain psychiatric conditions.

specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Avascular necrosis.symptomDescription: Early stages may be symptom-free. Eventually, the affected joint may hurt when weight is put on it or when lying down.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the hip, buttocks, groin, knee, or thigh
symptoms.Also common: collapse, joint stiffness, or limping

Avascular necrosis.overview:
Description
The death of bone tissue due to a lack of blood supply.
Avascular necrosis is associated with long-term steroid use and drinking too much alcohol. It's most common in people between the ages of 30 and 60 and often affects the hip.
Early stages may be symptom-free. Eventually, the affected joint may hurt when weight is put on it or when lying down.
Treatment includes physiotherapy, surgery and medication.
Avascular necrosis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Surgery.Bone surgery: Surgery to realign, lengthen or shorten a bone.
Surgery.Bone grafting: Surgical placement of new bone around fractures to help them heal.
Surgery.Joint replacement: Removing a damaged or defective joint and inserting a new, functioning one in its place.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Self-care.Limit alcohol intake: May be harmful and aggravate certain conditions.

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.

Bacterial vaginosis.symptomDescription: In some cases, there are no symptoms. In other cases, there may be abnormal vaginal discharge, itching or odour.

symptoms.Groin: abnormal vaginal discharge, vaginal itching, or vaginal odour
symptoms.Also common: vaginal burning

Bacterial vaginosis.overview:
Description
Bacterial overgrowth in the vagina.
Bacterial vaginosis tends to affect women of childbearing age. Activities such as unprotected sexual intercourse or frequent douching can increase a person's risk.
In some cases, there are no symptoms. In other cases, there may be abnormal vaginal discharge, itching or odour.
Treatment can include prescription cream, gel or medication. Recurrence within three to 12 months is common, requiring additional treatment.
Bacterial vaginosis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Balanitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include pain, redness and a foul-smelling discharge from under the foreskin.

symptoms.Also common: redness, tenderness, discharge from penis, itching, or swelling

Balanitis.overview:
Description
Inflammation of the foreskin and head of the penis.
Balanitis is most common in uncircumcised men. Causes include skin disorders, infection, poor hygiene, uncontrolled diabetes and harsh soaps.
Symptoms include pain, redness and a foul-smelling discharge from under the foreskin.
Treatment depends on the cause, but may require antibiotics, steroid creams or antifungal creams. In extreme cases, the foreskin may need to be removed (circumcision).
Balanitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Antifungal: Kills or prevents growth of fungi.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Barrett's esophagus.symptomDescription: Frequent heartburn and chest pain are symptoms, but many people with Barrett’s oesophagus have no symptoms.

symptoms.Also common: chronic cough, hoarseness, or throat irritation

Barrett's esophagus.overview:
Description
Damage to the lower portion of the tube that connects the mouth and stomach (oesophagus).
Barrett’s oesophagus is usually the result of repeated exposure to stomach acid. It’s most often diagnosed in people with long-term gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
Frequent heartburn and chest pain are symptoms, but many people with Barrett’s oesophagus have no symptoms.
Treatments include medical monitoring, medication and surgery. Rarely, it develops into oesophageal cancer.
Barrett's esophagus.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Proton-pump inhibitor: Decreases acid release in the stomach.

Medical procedure.Photodynamic therapy: Treatment that uses special drugs (photosensitising agents) along with light to kill cancer cells. The drugs must be activated by the light.
Medical procedure.Ablation: Removal of tissue using lasers, radiofrequency (RF) waves, focused ultrasound, heat or cold.
Medical procedure.Therapeutic endoscopy: Using a lighted medical instrument to see inside the body and provide treatment. For example, to stop bleeding or remove a foreign object.
Medical procedure.Catheter ablation: Using electrical energy to remove abnormal tissue. For example, in the heart to restore a regular heartbeat.
Medical procedure.Electrocoagulation: Using electric current to seal blood vessels and stop bleeding.
Medical procedure.Radiofrequency ablation: Removal of tissue using the heat from an electric current produced by a radio wave.
Medical procedure.Argon plasma coagulation: Using focused light to stop bleeding or treat abnormal tissue.
Medical procedure.Endoscopic mucosal resection: Using a small camera inserted into the body (endoscope) to remove abnormal tissue.
Medical procedure.Endoscopic surveillance: Regular monitoring using a small camera inserted into the body (endoscope) to evaluate the progression of disease.
Medical procedure.Procedural sedation and analgesia: Giving tranquilisers and painkillers before a painful or unpleasant medical procedure. Although not fully conscious, the person can still breathe on their own.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Bed sore.symptomDescription: Bed sores often develop on the heels, ankles, hips and tailbone. They can develop quickly.

symptoms.Skin: redness, dark scab, ulcer of ankle, ulcer of coccyx, ulcer of heel and mid-foot, or ulcer of hip
symptoms.Also common: chronic wound or swelling

Bed sore.overview:
Description
Injury to skin and underlying tissue resulting from prolonged pressure on the skin.
People most at risk are those with a condition that limits their ability to change positions.
Bed sores often develop on the heels, ankles, hips and tailbone. They can develop quickly.
Bed sores can be difficult to treat. Treatment includes cleaning and dressing the wound along with reducing pressure on the sore by frequent changes in position.
Bed sore.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.
Self-care.Barrier cream: A cream that soothes and protects irritated skin.
Self-care.Negative-Pressure wound therapy: Applying an airtight covering to a wound and then using a vacuum to remove fluid and other material. Done to promote healing.
Self-care.Relieve pressure on skin: Improves blood flow to skin, allowing for faster healing.
Self-care.High-protein diet: A diet high in meat, fish, chicken, dairy, soy and other protein sources.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

Medical procedure.Debridement: Removal of dead tissue and foreign matter from a wound to promote healing.

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Plastic Surgeon: Reconstructs defective, damaged or missing body parts.

Bedbugs.symptomDescription: Bites are often itchy, red and in a line.

symptoms.Skin: small bump or redness
symptoms.Also common: itching or swelling

Bedbugs.overview:
Description
An invasion of a type of bug that hides in beds, biting humans to feed on their blood.
Bedbugs are reddish brown and roughly the size of an apple seed. They infest homes, hotels and hospitals.
Bites are often itchy, red and in a line.
Bites usually disappear with time. Hydrocortisone creams and antihistamines may speed recovery. An exterminator can treat an infestation.
Bedbugs.notes:
Spreads by animals or insects
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By animal or insect bites or stings.

Self-care.Hygiene: Personal cleanliness that promotes health and well-being. For example, washing hands before eating.
Self-care.Disinfecting sheets and bedding: Washing and drying at the hottest possible temperature.
Self-care.Pest control: Using insecticide to kill insects such as bed bugs that can irritate the skin.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Bee and wasp stings.symptomDescription: In many cases, there's only pain and swelling at the sting site. In rare cases, a life-threatening allergic reaction can cause difficulty breathing, tongue swelling, nausea and unconsciousness. This may require emergency medical attention.

symptoms.Skin: rashes or redness
symptoms.Also common: swelling or itching

Bee and wasp stings.overview:
Description
An injury caused by a bee's venom.
Allergic reactions to bee stings are typically more severe in adults than in children.
In many cases, there's only pain and swelling at the sting site. In rare cases, a life-threatening allergic reaction can cause difficulty breathing, tongue swelling, nausea and unconsciousness. This may require emergency medical attention.
For mild to moderate reactions, treatment involves removing the stinger, washing the area with soap and water, and applying cold compresses or ice. Creams to the affected area can help reduce discomfort. Severe reactions may need adrenaline.
Bee and wasp stings.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Self-care.Cold compress: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Bell's palsy.symptomDescription: Bell's palsy is characterised by muscle weakness that causes one half of the face to droop.

symptoms.Sensory: abnormality of taste or sensitivity to sound
symptoms.Also common: facial muscle weakness, drooling, or dry eyes

Bell's palsy.overview:
Description
Sudden weakness in the muscles on one half of the face.
Bell's palsy may be a reaction to a viral infection. It rarely occurs more than once.
Bell's palsy is characterised by muscle weakness that causes one half of the face to droop.
Bell's palsy usually resolves on its own within six months. Physiotherapy can help prevent muscles from permanently contracting.
Bell's palsy.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Self-care.Artificial tears: Moistens eyes to provide soothing relief.

Devices.Eyepatch: A covering used to protect the eye from injury.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Benign prostate enlargement.symptomDescription: With this condition, the urinary stream may be weak or stop and start. In some cases, it can lead to infection, bladder stones and reduced kidney function.

symptoms.Urinary: dribbling after urination, excessive urination at night, frequent urination, sense of incomplete bladder emptying, urge to urinate and leaking, or weak urinary stream
symptoms.Also common: incontinence or sexual dysfunction

Benign prostate enlargement.overview:
Description
Age-associated prostate gland enlargement that can cause urination difficulty.
This type of prostate enlargement isn't thought to be a precursor to prostate cancer.
With this condition, the urinary stream may be weak or stop and start. In some cases, it can lead to infection, bladder stones and reduced kidney function.
Treatments include medication that relaxes or shrinks the prostate, surgery and minimally invasive surgery.
Benign prostate enlargement.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.

Bipolar disorder.symptomDescription: Manic episodes may include symptoms such as high energy, reduced need for sleep and loss of touch with reality. Depressive episodes may include symptoms such as low energy, low motivation and loss of interest in daily activities. Mood episodes last days to months at a time and may also be associated with suicidal thoughts.

symptoms.Mood: mood swings, sadness, elevated mood, anger, anxiety, apathy, apprehension, euphoria, general discontent, guilt, hopelessness, loss of interest, or loss of interest or pleasure in activities
symptoms.Behavioural: irritability, risk-taking behaviours, disorganised behaviour, aggression, agitation, crying, excess desire for sex, hyperactivity, impulsivity, restlessness, or self-harm
symptoms.Cognitive: unwanted thoughts, delusion, lack of concentration, racing thoughts, slowness in activity, or false belief of superiority
symptoms.Psychological: depression, manic episode, agitated depression, or paranoia
symptoms.Sleep: difficulty falling asleep or excess sleepiness
symptoms.Also common: fatigue or rapid and frenzied speaking

Bipolar disorder.overview:
Description
A disorder associated with episodes of mood swings ranging from depressive lows to manic highs.
The exact cause of bipolar disorder isn’t known, but a combination of genetics, environment and altered brain structure and chemistry may play a role.
Manic episodes may include symptoms such as high energy, reduced need for sleep and loss of touch with reality. Depressive episodes may include symptoms such as low energy, low motivation and loss of interest in daily activities. Mood episodes last days to months at a time and may also be associated with suicidal thoughts.
Treatment is usually lifelong and often involves a combination of medications and psychotherapy.
Bipolar disorder.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Psychoeducation: Education about mental health that also serves to support, validate and empower patients.
Therapies.Family therapy: Psychological counselling that helps families resolve conflicts and communicate more effectively.
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.

Medication.Anticonvulsant: Prevents or controls seizures, relieves pain and treats symptoms of certain psychiatric disorders.
Medication.Antipsychotic: Reduces or improves the symptoms of certain psychiatric conditions.
Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.

Supportive care.Hospitalization: A higher level of care whereby patients are closely monitored and may be given medications that would not be available at home.

specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.

Bladder cancer.symptomDescription: The most common symptom is blood in the urine.

symptoms.Urinary: dark urine, frequent urination, or blood in urine

Bladder cancer.overview:
Description
Cancer that begins in the bladder.
This cancer typically affects older adults. It's usually diagnosed early, when it's still treatable. It's likely to recur, so follow-up tests are typically recommended.
The most common symptom is blood in the urine.
Treatments include surgery, biological therapy and chemotherapy.
Bladder cancer.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.
Medical procedure.Urinary diversion: Surgery to reroute the flow of urine from its normal pathway. May require a new external opening.

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.

Surgery.Surgical removal of all or part of the b: Performed to remove an abnormal growth.
Surgery.Cystoprostatectomy: Surgical removal of the bladder and prostate.
Surgery.Cystourethrectomy: Surgical removal of the bladder and urethra.

specialists.Radiation Oncologist: Treats and manages cancer by prescribing radiation therapy.
specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.

Blepharitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include red, itchy eyelids that may look greasy and crusted. Dry eyes also are a symptom.

symptoms.Eyes: eyelid redness, irritation, puffy eyes, contact lens intolerance, eyelash rubbing against eyeball, loss of eyelashes, discharge, dryness, itchiness, or watery eyes
symptoms.Visual: blurred vision or sensitivity to light
symptoms.Also common: crusty eyelashes or peeling skin

Blepharitis.overview:
Description
An inflammation of the eyelid that affects the eyelashes or tear production.
Blepharitis commonly occurs when the tiny oil glands of the inner eyelid become inflamed. It often occurs along with other skin conditions or allergies.
Symptoms include red, itchy eyelids that may look greasy and crusted. Dry eyes also are a symptom.
Treatments include cleaning the eyelids, antibiotic or steroid eye drops and treating underlying conditions. However, blepharitis tends to come back.
Blepharitis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Hygiene: Personal cleanliness that promotes health and well-being. For example, washing hands before eating.
Self-care.Artificial tears: Moistens eyes to provide soothing relief.
Self-care.Warm compress: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

Blindness.symptomDescription: Blindness can occur suddenly or over a period of time. Often there's no pain.

symptoms.Visual: vision loss or blurred vision

Blindness.overview:
Description
Complete or partial loss of vision.
Many causes of blindness exist, including accidents, diabetes and certain eye diseases.
Blindness can occur suddenly or over a period of time. Often there's no pain.
Suddenly occurring blindness requires emergency medical treatment.
Blindness.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Sensory processing: The way the nervous system receives messages from the senses and turns them into appropriate motor and behavioural responses.

Devices.Intraocular lens: An artificial lens placed in the eye after the natural lens is removed during cataract surgery.
Devices.Artificial eye: An artificial eye. Formerly made of glass, now mostly made of hard, plastic acrylic.
Devices.Corrective lens: Corrective lenses placed over the eyes to improve vision.

Surgery.Refractive surgery: Surgery to reshape the front of the eye (cornea) to correct or improve vision. LASIK is the most popular type.
Surgery.Cataract surgery: Surgical removal of the clouded lens (cataract) of the eye. Typically replaced with an artificial lens to improve vision.

specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Body dysmorphic disorder (BDD).symptomDescription: People with this disorder may frequently examine their appearance in a mirror, constantly compare their appearance with that of others and avoid social situations or photos.

symptoms.Mood: anxiety or general discontent
symptoms.Also common: unwanted thoughts, compulsive behaviour, or depression

Body dysmorphic disorder (BDD).overview:
Description
A mental illness involving obsessive focus on a perceived flaw in appearance.
The flaw may be minor or imagined. But the person may spend hours a day trying to fix it. The person may try many cosmetic procedures or exercise to excess.
People with this disorder may frequently examine their appearance in a mirror, constantly compare their appearance with that of others and avoid social situations or photos.
Treatment may include counselling and antidepressant medication.
Body dysmorphic disorder (BDD).notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Therapies.Behaviour therapy: A therapy focused on modifying harmful behaviours associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.

Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Bone fracture.symptomDescription: The main symptom is pain. There may also be loss of functionality depending on the area affected.

symptoms.Also common: bleeding, bruising, limping, loss of height, physical deformity, swelling, or tenderness

Bone fracture.overview:
Description
A complete or partial break in a bone.
Causes of bone fractures include trauma, overuse and diseases that weaken bones.
The main symptom is pain. There may also be loss of functionality depending on the area affected.
Treatment often involves resetting the bone in place and immobilising it in a cast or splint to give it time to heal. Sometimes, surgery with rods, plates and screws may be required.
Bone fracture.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Medical procedure.Reduction: Surgery to fix a broken or dislocated bone by putting it back into place.

Devices.Elastic bandage: Stretchy bandages used to wrap sprains and strains. Provides support and compression during recovery.
Devices.Splint: A rigid accessory used to stabilise and protect an injured joint.
Devices.Orthopedic cast: A protective device applied to an injured joint or limb to limit motion and promote healing.
Devices.Traction splint: A splint used for leg fractures to relieve pressure on the injured limb.

Surgery.Surgery to connect broken bones (Interna: A surgery to repair a broken bone using implants.
Surgery.Surgery to stabilise broken bones (Exter: Using a splint or cast to hold a broken bone in place so it can heal properly.

Therapies.Joint manipulation: Stretching a joint past its current restricted range of motion to restore movement and reduce pain.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

specialists.Trauma Surgeon: Performs surgery to repair damage caused by injuries.
specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Hand Surgeon: Performs surgery to treat hand conditions.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Bone tumor.symptomDescription: A bone tumour may cause a painless mass. Some people have dull, aching pain. In some cases, minor injury causes a fracture near the tumour.

symptoms.Also common: bone fracture, feeling tired, limping, swelling, or weight loss

Bone tumor.overview:
Description
A mass of unusual cells growing in a bone. Most bone tumours aren't cancerous.
Causes of bone tumours include abnormal healing of an injury, inherited conditions and radiation therapy. They can also be caused by bone cancer or another cancer that has spread to the bone from other parts of the body.
A bone tumour may cause a painless mass. Some people have dull, aching pain. In some cases, minor injury causes a fracture near the tumour.
Treatments include surgery and radiation. Some non-cancerous tumours go away without treatment.
Bone tumor.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medical procedure.Tissue scraping: Removal of tissue by scraping or scooping with a surgical instrument called a curette.
Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

Surgery.Bone grafting: Surgical placement of new bone around fractures to help them heal.
Surgery.Arthrodesis: Surgical fusion of the bones that form a joint.
Surgery.Wide local excision: Surgical removal of a small area of tissue, along with a margin of normal tissue beyond the border of disease
Surgery.Limb sparing surgical resection: Surgical procedure that removes disease while preserving the affected limb.

Devices.Prosthesis: An artificial replacement for a missing body part, such as a leg, tooth or eye.

specialists.Radiation Oncologist: Treats and manages cancer by prescribing radiation therapy.
specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.

Borderline personality disorder.extraName: Also called: BPD, emotional dysregulation disorder
Borderline personality disorder.symptomDescription: Symptoms include emotional instability, feelings of worthlessness, insecurity, impulsivity and impaired social relationships.

symptoms.Behavioural: antisocial behaviour, compulsive behaviour, hostility, impulsivity, irritability, risk-taking behaviours, self-destructive behaviour, self-harm, social isolation, or lack of restraint
symptoms.Mood: anger, anxiety, general discontent, guilt, loneliness, mood swings, or sadness
symptoms.Psychological: depression, distorted self-image, grandiosity, or narcissism
symptoms.Also common: thoughts of suicide

Borderline personality disorder.overview:
Description
A mental disorder characterised by unstable moods, behaviour and relationships.
The cause of borderline personality disorder isn't well understood. Diagnosis is made based on symptoms.
Symptoms include emotional instability, feelings of worthlessness, insecurity, impulsivity and impaired social relationships.
Treatments include talk therapy or, in some cases, medication. Hospitalisation helps if symptoms are severe.
Borderline personality disorder.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required

Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Anger management: Practicing mindfulness, coping mechanisms and trigger avoidance to minimise destructive emotional outbursts.
Therapies.Dialectical behavior therapy: Talk therapy that encourages people to both accept themselves and change their negative behaviours.
Therapies.Transference focused psychotherapy: Psychological treatment developed for people with unstable moods, behaviours and relationships (personality disorders).
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.
Therapies.Schema therapy: Psychological treatment that helps people change negative, lifelong behaviour patterns (schemas). Often used when other therapies have not worked.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Brain aneurysm.symptomDescription: An unruptured aneurysm usually causes no symptoms. A key symptom of a ruptured aneurysm is a sudden, severe headache.

symptoms.Also common: bleeding, dizziness, light sensitivity, headache, stiff neck, or thunderclap headache

Brain aneurysm.overview:
Description
A weakness in a blood vessel in the brain that balloons and fills with blood.
Most intracranial aneurysms occur between the underside of the brain and the base of the skull. The aneurysm can leak or rupture, causing life-threatening bleeding.
An unruptured aneurysm usually causes no symptoms. A key symptom of a ruptured aneurysm is a sudden, severe headache.
Treatments for an unruptured aneurysm include medication to control blood pressure and procedures to prevent a future rupture. Emergency medical care is required for a ruptured aneurysm.
Brain aneurysm.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Treatable by a medical professional

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Medical procedure.Embolization: Deliberately clogging abnormal blood vessels to block the flow of blood.
Medical procedure.Endovascular coiling: Inserting tiny coils into a blood vessel to seal off a bulge (aneurysm) that could rupture and cause bleeding.
Medical procedure.Clipping: Surgically placing a clip to seal off a bulge in the artery wall (aneurysm) to keep it from bleeding.

Medication.Anticoagulant: Unwanted reactions from taking drugs that inhibit blood clotting. The most common problem is too much bleeding, which can be very serious.

Surgery.Endovascular aneurysm repair: Surgical repair of a bulge (aneurysm) in the main blood vessel of the body (aorta) to prevent bleeding or rupture.

specialists.Interventional Radiologist: Uses image-guided procedures to diagnose and treat diseases.
specialists.Vascular Surgeon: Specialises in surgery for vascular system diseases.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Brain tumours.symptomDescription: Symptoms include new or increasingly strong headaches, blurred vision, loss of balance, confusion and seizures. In some cases, there may be no symptoms.

symptoms.Muscular: difficulty walking, instability, muscle weakness, problems with coordination, weakness of one side of the body, or weakness of the arms and legs
symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, or vertigo
symptoms.Sensory: pins and needles or reduced sensation of touch
symptoms.Cognitive: inability to speak or understand language or mental confusion
symptoms.Also common: blurred vision, difficulty speaking, personality change, seizures, or sleepiness

Brain tumours.overview:
Description
A cancerous or non-cancerous mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain.
Tumours can start in the brain, or cancer elsewhere in the body can spread to the brain.
Symptoms include new or increasingly strong headaches, blurred vision, loss of balance, confusion and seizures. In some cases, there may be no symptoms.
Treatments include surgery, radiation and chemotherapy.
Brain tumours.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.

Surgery.Craniotomy: Brain surgery in which a piece of bone is removed from the skull.

Medical procedure.Tomotherapy: Cancer treatment that aims high-dose radiation at tumours from many directions. Reduces damage to nearby tissue.
Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Radiation Oncologist: Treats and manages cancer by prescribing radiation therapy.

Breast cancer.symptomDescription: Symptoms of breast cancer include a lump in the breast, bloody discharge from the nipple and changes in the shape or texture of the nipple or breast.

symptoms.Breast: discomfort, inverted nipple, lumps, or nipple discharge
symptoms.Also common: redness, swollen lymph nodes, or thickening or puckering of the skin

Breast cancer.overview:
Description
A cancer that forms in the cells of the breasts.
Breast cancer can occur in women and rarely in men.
Symptoms of breast cancer include a lump in the breast, bloody discharge from the nipple and changes in the shape or texture of the nipple or breast.
Its treatment depends on the stage of cancer. It may consist of chemotherapy, radiation, hormone therapy and surgery.
Breast cancer.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Surgery.Mammaplasty: Plastic surgery to increase or reduce the size of the breasts or to reconstruct a breast.
Surgery.Tissue expansion: Inserting a balloon under the skin and then gradually expanding it to stretch and grow the skin and surrounding tissue.
Surgery.Lymph node dissection: Surgical removal of a lymph node.
Surgery.Lumpectomy: Surgical removal of a lump (tumour) in the breast.
Surgery.Mastectomy: Surgical removal of some or all of the breast.

Medical procedure.Teletherapy: Radiation therapy that uses x-rays or other high-energy beams to destroy cancer cells and shrink tumours.
Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

Medication.Estrogen modulator: Mimics the effect of oestrogen on various tissues, including the breast, bones and reproductive organs.
Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.

specialists.Palliative Medicine: Focuses on improving quality of life for those with severe illnesses.
specialists.Radiation Oncologist: Treats and manages cancer by prescribing radiation therapy.
specialists.Plastic Surgeon: Reconstructs defective, damaged or missing body parts.

Bronchiectasis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include a daily cough that occurs over months or years and daily production of large amounts of phlegm.

symptoms.Cough: can be chronic, with blood, or with phlegm
symptoms.Respiratory: shortness of breath, sinusitis, or wheezing
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or inability to exercise
symptoms.Also common: phlegm, recurrent infection, deformity of nails, or weight loss

Bronchiectasis.overview:
Description
A condition in which the lungs' airways become damaged, making it hard to clear mucus.
Bronchiectasis may result from an infection or medical condition, such as pneumonia or cystic fibrosis. Mucus builds up and breeds bacteria, causing frequent infections.
Symptoms include a daily cough that occurs over months or years and daily production of large amounts of phlegm.
Treatment may include physiotherapy and medication, such as antibiotics and drugs to help loosen mucus.
Bronchiectasis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
Therapies.Pulmonary rehabilitation: Exercise, nutritional counselling, education and support to help people with chronic breathing problems improve their fitness.
Therapies.Airway clearance technique: Coughing, huffing or applying vibration devices to the chest to help mobilise phlegm that can build up in the lungs.

Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.

Medication.Bronchodilator: Helps open the airways of the lungs to make breathing easier.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Respiratory Therapist: Treats and provides emergency care for patients who have trouble breathing.

Bronchiolitis.extraName: Also called: inflammation of the bronchioles
Bronchiolitis.symptomDescription: The condition starts like a common cold. It progresses to coughing, wheezing and sometimes difficulty breathing. Symptoms may last for a week to a month.

symptoms.Respiratory: fast breathing, shortness of breath, wheezing, difficulty breathing, or shallow breathing
symptoms.Whole body: dehydration, fever, loss of appetite, or malaise
symptoms.Also common: coughing or nasal congestion

Bronchiolitis.overview:
Description
An inflammatory bronchial reaction in young children and infants.
Bronchiolitis is almost always caused by a virus. The condition most commonly occurs during the winter months.
The condition starts like a common cold. It progresses to coughing, wheezing and sometimes difficulty breathing. Symptoms may last for a week to a month.
Bronchiolitis can be treated with home care in most cases. Severe cases require hospitalisation.
Bronchiolitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Spreads easily
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Supportive care.Nasal suctioning: Removes mucus from the nose and upper airway.
Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.
Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.
Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.
Supportive care.Sodium chloride: A salt solution taken by mouth or injected into a vein to treat low levels of sodium in the body.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Bronchodilator: Helps open the airways of the lungs to make breathing easier.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Paediatric Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats children in intensive care.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Bulimia.symptomDescription: People with this condition binge eat. They then take steps to avoid weight gain. Most commonly, this means vomiting (purging). But it can also mean excessive exercising or fasting.

symptoms.Behavioural: binge eating, compulsive behaviour, impulsivity, self-harm, vomiting after overeating, or lack of restraint
symptoms.Whole body: dehydration, fatigue, food aversion, hunger, or water-electrolyte imbalance
symptoms.Mood: anxiety, general discontent, guilt, or mood swings
symptoms.Mouth: bad breath, dental cavities, or dryness
symptoms.Weight: body weight changes or weight loss
symptoms.Menstrual: absence of menstruation or irregular menstruation
symptoms.Also common: abnormality of taste, depression, poor self-esteem, or sore throat

Bulimia.overview:
Description
A serious eating disorder marked by bingeing, followed by methods to avoid weight gain.
Bulimia is a potentially life-threatening eating disorder.
People with this condition binge eat. They then take steps to avoid weight gain. Most commonly, this means vomiting (purging). But it can also mean excessive exercising or fasting.
Treatments include counselling, medication and nutrition education.
Bulimia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Cognitive therapy: Talk therapy that focuses on replacing negative, distorted thoughts with positive, accurate ones.
Therapies.Dialectical behavior therapy: Talk therapy that encourages people to both accept themselves and change their negative behaviours.
Therapies.Counseling psychology: A branch of psychology that treats personal problems related to school, work, family and social life.
Therapies.Psychoeducation: Education about mental health that also serves to support, validate and empower patients.
Therapies.Family therapy: Psychological counselling that helps families resolve conflicts and communicate more effectively.
Therapies.Behaviour therapy: A therapy focused on modifying harmful behaviours associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.

Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Psychoanalyst: Uses psychotherapy to treat mental disorders.

Burn.symptomDescription: Symptoms range from a feeling of minor discomfort to a life-threatening emergency, depending on the size and depth (degree) of the burn.

symptoms.Pain types: can be mild or severe
symptoms.Skin: blister, peeling, total loss of colour, or redness
symptoms.Whole body: flushing or sweating
symptoms.Also common: sensitivity to pain, swelling, or tenderness

Burn.overview:
Description
Damage to the skin or deeper tissues caused by sun, hot liquids, fire, electricity or chemicals.
The degree of severity of most burns is based on the size and depth of the burn. Electrical burns, however, are more difficult to diagnose because they're capable of causing significant injury beneath the skin without showing any signs of damage on the surface.
Symptoms range from a feeling of minor discomfort to a life-threatening emergency, depending on the size and depth (degree) of the burn.
Sunburn and small scalds can often be treated at home. Deep or widespread burns and chemical or electrical burns need immediate medical care, often at specialised burn units.
Burn.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Immersion in cool water: Soothes painful skin or joint irritations.
Self-care.Eye flushing: Removes toxins and soothes the eye.
Self-care.Aloe: A plant whose gel may help heal burns and other injuries when applied to the skin.
Self-care.Alginic acid: A natural carbohydrate that comes from algae in seaweed. Used in medications to create a foam barrier that coats and protects the stomach.

Medication.Topical antiseptic: Destroys or prevents the growth of microorganisms on the skin that may cause infection.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

Supportive care.Fluid replacement: Replacing fluids lost through sweating, bleeding, vomiting or diarrhoea to treat or prevent dehydration.
Supportive care.Hyperbaric medicine: Exposing all or part of the body to 100% oxygen at higher than normal atmospheric pressure. This increases the amount of oxygen in the blood and speeds healing.
Supportive care.Hydrotherapy: Using water to relieve pain, treat diseases and maintain health. For example, mineral baths and hot tubs.

Therapies.Hydrotherapy: Using water to relieve pain, treat diseases and maintain health. For example, mineral baths and hot tubs.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

C. Diff. Colitis.extraName: Also called: clostridium difficile colitis, pseudomembranous colitis
C. Diff. Colitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include diarrhoea, stomach pain and fever.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: diarrhoea, bloating, or blood in stool
symptoms.Also common: fever

C. Diff. Colitis.overview:
Description
Inflammation of the colon caused by the bacteria Clostridium difficile.
Clostridium difficile colitis results from disruption of normal, healthy bacteria in the colon, often as a result of antibiotics. C. difficile can also be transmitted from person to person by spores. It can cause severe damage to the colon and even be fatal.
Symptoms include diarrhoea, stomach pain and fever.
Treatment includes antibiotics. Even when treated with antibiotics, the infection may come back. In rare cases, faecal transplant or surgery may be needed.
C. Diff. Colitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Spreads by contact with a contaminated object or surface
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

specialists.Medical Microbiologist: Focuses on the diagnosis and spread of infectious diseases.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Canker sore.symptomDescription: The main symptom is a painful sore in the mouth that can make it hard to eat and talk.

symptoms.Also common: mouth ulcer

Canker sore.overview:
Description
A small, shallow sore inside the mouth or at the base of the gums.
Unlike a cold sore, a canker sore doesn't occur on the lips and isn't contagious.
The main symptom is a painful sore in the mouth that can make it hard to eat and talk.
Most canker sores clear on their own in one to two weeks. Treatments, if required, include mouth rinses, pastes and medication.
Canker sore.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Local anesthetic: Blocks pain at and near the site where it's given, or along the nerve that's blocked.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Dentist: Specialises in diseases of the oral cavity, especially the teeth.

Cardiac arrest.symptomDescription: The main symptom is loss of consciousness and unresponsiveness.

symptoms.Whole body: collapse, fainting, or light-headedness
symptoms.Also common: pulselessness, palpitations, or shortness of breath

Cardiac arrest.overview:
Description
Sudden, unexpected loss of heart function, breathing and consciousness.
In cardiac arrest, the heart abruptly stops beating. Without prompt intervention, it can result in the person's death.
The main symptom is loss of consciousness and unresponsiveness.
This medical emergency needs immediate CPR or use of a defibrillator. Hospital care includes drugs, an implantable device or other procedures.
Cardiac arrest.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.Defibrillation: Using an electrical shock to correct a rapid, irregular heartbeat and restore the heart's normal rhythm.
Supportive care.Tracheal intubation: Inserting a tube into the windpipe (trachea) through the mouth or nose to keep the airway open. Done when someone cannot breathe on their own.
Supportive care.Targeted temperature management: Cooling the body temperature after a period of poor circulation to protect the brain.
Supportive care.Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR): Emergency procedure performed when someone's heart has stopped. Commonly known as CPR.

Medication.Blood pressure support: Helps increase blood pressure when it's too low.
Medication.Involuntary nervous system blocker: Used to diagnose and treat certain neurologic and cardiovascular conditions.
Medication.Antiarrhythmic: Helps control abnormal or irregular heart rhythms.

Medical procedure.Coronary catheterization: Insertion of a tube to diagnose or treat an abnormal or blocked blood vessel in the heart.

Devices.Implantable cardioverter defibrillator: A small device placed in the chest or abdomen that shocks the heart if it develops a dangerously irregular heartbeat.

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Cardiomyopathy.symptomDescription: Symptoms include breathlessness, swollen legs and feet and a bloated stomach.

symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Heart: abnormal heart rhythm, fast heart rate, or murmur
symptoms.Gastrointestinal: bloating or fluid in the abdomen
symptoms.Also common: coughing, shortness of breath, swelling in extremities, or weight gain

Cardiomyopathy.overview:
Description
An acquired or hereditary disease of the heart muscle.
An acquired or hereditary disease of heart muscle, this condition makes it hard for the heart to deliver blood to the body, and can lead to heart failure.
Symptoms include breathlessness, swollen legs and feet and a bloated stomach.
Treatments include drugs, implanted devices, surgery and in severe cases, transplant.
Cardiomyopathy.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Anticoagulant: Unwanted reactions from taking drugs that inhibit blood clotting. The most common problem is too much bleeding, which can be very serious.
Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.
Medication.ACE inhibitor: Relaxes blood vessels, lowers blood pressure and prevents diabetes-related kidney damage.
Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.
Medication.Statin: Decreases the liver's production of harmful cholesterol.
Medication.Antiarrhythmic: Helps control abnormal or irregular heart rhythms.

Medical procedure.Cardiac catheterization: Inserting a long tube into the groin, neck or arm and then threading it through the blood vessels to the heart.
Medical procedure.Revascularization: Restoring blood flow to an organ or a part of the body where it was previously blocked.

Surgery.Coronary artery bypass surgery: Surgery that restores blood flow to the heart by using a healthy artery or vein to bypass a blocked artery.
Surgery.Heart transplant: Surgery to remove a diseased heart and replace it with one from a deceased donor.

Devices.Pacemaker: A small device placed in the chest or abdomen that sends out electrical signals to keep the heart beating normally.
Devices.Implantable cardioverter defibrillator: A small device placed in the chest or abdomen that shocks the heart if it develops a dangerously irregular heartbeat.

specialists.Cardiothoracic Surgeon: Surgically treats diseases affecting organs inside the chest.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Carpal tunnel syndrome.symptomDescription: Key symptoms are pain in the hand and arm with numbness or tingling.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the hands, wrist, or forearm
symptoms.Also common: hand numbness, sensation of pins and needles, hand clumsiness, hand pain at night, hand weakness, or wrist weakness

Carpal tunnel syndrome.overview:
Description
A numbness and tingling in the hand and arm caused by a pinched nerve in the wrist.
Wrist anatomy, underlying health conditions and patterns of hand use can contribute to carpal tunnel syndrome.
Key symptoms are pain in the hand and arm with numbness or tingling.
Treatment may include rest, ice, wrist splints, cortisone injections and surgery.
Carpal tunnel syndrome.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Devices.Splint: A rigid accessory used to stabilise and protect an injured joint.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Surgery.Carpal tunnel surgery: Performed to relieve pressure on the nerve passing through the wrist.

Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Rest: Reducing activity for a short period of time following an injury to promote healing.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.

specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Hand Surgeon: Performs surgery to treat hand conditions.

Cat scratch fever.symptomDescription: Symptoms include a red bump on the skin, fatigue and discomfort. Lymph nodes near the injury may swell.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or fever
symptoms.Also common: swollen lymph nodes or small bump on skin

Cat scratch fever.overview:
Description
An infection of the lymph nodes following a scratch or bite from a cat.
Cat scratch disease is caused by Bartonella henselae bacteria.
Symptoms include a red bump on the skin, fatigue and discomfort. Lymph nodes near the injury may swell.
This disease generally clears up on its own. In some cases, antibiotics may be required.
Cat scratch fever.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Spreads by animals or insects
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By animal or insect bites or stings.

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Cataracts.symptomDescription: The main symptom is blurry vision. Having cataracts can be like looking through a cloudy window.

symptoms.Visual: blurred vision, inability to see in dim light, seeing halos around lights, or vision loss

Cataracts.overview:
Description
Clouding of the normally clear lens of the eye.
Most cataracts develop slowly over the course of years.
The main symptom is blurry vision. Having cataracts can be like looking through a cloudy window.
When a cataract interferes with someone's usual activities, the cloudy lens can be replaced with a clear, artificial lens. This is generally a safe, outpatient procedure.
Cataracts.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Surgery.Cataract surgery: Surgical removal of the clouded lens (cataract) of the eye. Typically replaced with an artificial lens to improve vision.

Cauliflower ear.symptomDescription: If the initial injury is ignored, cartilage in the outer ear may then overgrow, resulting in a bulbous deformity on the ear.

symptoms.Common symptoms: physical deformity, swelling, or bruising

Cauliflower ear.overview:
Description
A deformity of the outer ear that may occur after injury to the ear.
Cauliflower ear may occur when blood that collects in the outer ear after an injury isn't drained properly or becomes infected. Common causes include injuries from sports, such as wrestling, boxing, rugby or mixed martial arts.
If the initial injury is ignored, cartilage in the outer ear may then overgrow, resulting in a bulbous deformity on the ear.
Plastic surgery is necessary to restore the ear's shape.
Cauliflower ear.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Surgery.Otoplasty: Plastic surgery to change the shape, size or position of the ears.
Surgery.Plastic Surgery: Reconstructs defective, damaged or missing body parts.

specialists.Plastic Surgeon: Reconstructs defective, damaged or missing body parts.

Cavity.symptomDescription: There may be no symptoms. Untreated cavities can cause toothache, infection and tooth loss.
Cavity.overview:
Description
Permanently damaged areas in teeth that develop into tiny holes.
Causes include bacteria, snacking, sipping sugary drinks and poor teeth cleaning.
There may be no symptoms. Untreated cavities can cause toothache, infection and tooth loss.
Treatments include fluoride, fillings and crowns. Severe cases may need a root canal or removal.
Cavity.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required

Medical procedure.Dental filling: Fillings, inlays, bonding and crowns used to restore decayed or damaged teeth.

Self-care.Oral hygiene: Keeping the mouth clean by regularly brushing teeth, flossing and using mouthwash.
Self-care.Fluoride: A mineral that helps prevent tooth decay by making tooth enamel stronger.

specialists.Dentist: Specialises in diseases of the oral cavity, especially the teeth.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Cellulite.symptomDescription: The main symptom is the appearance of lumpy, dimpled flesh on the thighs, hips, buttocks and stomach.

symptoms.Common symptoms: localized accumulation of fat, skin dimpling, or overweight

Cellulite.overview:
Description
Lumpy, dimpled flesh on thighs, hips, buttocks and stomach.
Cellulite is a fat deposit beneath the skin.
The main symptom is the appearance of lumpy, dimpled flesh on the thighs, hips, buttocks and stomach.
Weight loss and exercise can help improve the appearance of cellulite. Other treatments are laser and radio-frequency systems and retinol cream. These may need to be repeated regularly.
Cellulite.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Cellulitis.symptomDescription: Cellulitis may spread rapidly. Affected skin appears swollen and red and may be hot and tender.

symptoms.Skin: warmness, blister, red rashes, or swelling
symptoms.Whole body: chills, fever, or malaise
symptoms.Also common: pus

Cellulitis.overview:
Description
A common and potentially serious bacterial skin infection.
With cellulitis, the bacteria enter the skin.
Cellulitis may spread rapidly. Affected skin appears swollen and red and may be hot and tender.
Without treatment with an antibiotic, cellulitis can be life-threatening.
Cellulitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.

specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Cerebral palsy.symptomDescription: Symptoms include exaggerated reflexes, floppy or rigid limbs and involuntary motions. These appear by early childhood.

symptoms.Muscular: difficulty walking, difficulty with bodily movements, muscle rigidity, permanent shortening of muscle, problems with coordination, stiff muscles, overactive reflexes, involuntary movements, muscle weakness, muscle spasms, or paralysis of one side of the body
symptoms.Developmental: failure to thrive, learning disability, slow growth, or speech delay in a child
symptoms.Also common: constipation, difficulty raising the foot, difficulty swallowing, drooling, hearing loss, leaking of urine, paralysis, physical deformity, scissor gait, seizures, spastic gait, teeth grinding, or tremor

Cerebral palsy.overview:
Description
A congenital disorder of movement, muscle tone or posture.
Cerebral palsy is due to abnormal brain development, often before birth.
Symptoms include exaggerated reflexes, floppy or rigid limbs and involuntary motions. These appear by early childhood.
Long-term treatment includes physical and other therapies, drugs and sometimes surgery.
Cerebral palsy.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Special education: An approach to education that focuses on addressing the unique needs of individual students.

Therapies.Occupational Therapy: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medication.Muscle relaxant: Reduces muscle tension and helps relieve muscle pain and discomfort.
Medication.Sedative: Causes drowsiness, calmness and dulled senses. Some types may become addictive.

Surgery.Gastrostomy: Surgical insertion of a tube through the abdomen and into the stomach. Used for feeding or drainage.

specialists.Paediatric Neurologist: Treats nervous system disorders in children.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Cervical cancer.symptomDescription: Symptoms include bleeding in between periods and after sexual intercourse. Foul smelling white discharge and low back pain or lower abdominal pain may also occur. In some cases there may be no symptoms.

symptoms.Menstrual: abnormal menstruation, heavy menstruation, irregular menstruation, or spotting
symptoms.Groin: abnormal vaginal bleeding or abnormal vaginal discharge
symptoms.Also common: fatigue, nausea, or weight loss

Cervical cancer.overview:
Description
A malignant tumour of the cervix, the lowermost part of the uterus.
A malignant tumour of the lower-most part of the uterus (womb) that can be prevented by PAP smear screening and a HPV vaccine.
Symptoms include bleeding in between periods and after sexual intercourse. Foul smelling white discharge and low back pain or lower abdominal pain may also occur. In some cases there may be no symptoms.
Treatments include surgery, radiation and chemotherapy.
Cervical cancer.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medical procedure.Teletherapy: Radiation therapy that uses x-rays or other high-energy beams to destroy cancer cells and shrink tumours.
Medical procedure.Brachytherapy: Placing radioactive material inside the body to treat cancer.
Medical procedure.Loop electrosurgical excision procedure: Using a wire loop heated by electric current to remove abnormal cells and tissue from the cervix and vagina.
Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.
Medical procedure.Cervical conization: Surgical removal of a cone-shaped tissue sample from the cervix. Also known as cone biopsy.

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.

Surgery.Cervicectomy: Surgical removal of the cervix, the lower part of the womb (uterus) that connects to the vagina.
Surgery.Cryosurgery: Surgery that uses extreme cold to destroy diseased tissue.
Surgery.Lymph node dissection: Surgical removal of a lymph node.
Surgery.Retroperitoneal lymph node dissection: Surgical removal of lymph nodes at the back of the abdomen to see whether cancers in the pelvis or abdomen have spread.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Radiation Oncologist: Treats and manages cancer by prescribing radiation therapy.

Chalazion.symptomDescription: A chalazion may feel like a small, painless bead in the eyelid at first. Over a few days, it may get bigger, red and rubbery, but remain painless.

symptoms.Common symptoms: lump on the eyelid or eyelid redness

Chalazion.overview:
Description
A slow-growing, inflammatory lump in the tear gland of the eyelid.
A chalazion is most common in adults between the ages of 30 to 50 who also have rosacea or blepharitis.
A chalazion may feel like a small, painless bead in the eyelid at first. Over a few days, it may get bigger, red and rubbery, but remain painless.
Some chalazions may not need treatment. Hot compresses may help larger ones. A lasting chalazion may need to be removed by a doctor.
Chalazion.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Warm compress: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
