Charcot-Marie-Tooth disorder.extraName: Also called: CMT, hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy
Charcot-Marie-Tooth disorder.symptomDescription: Muscle weakness, decreased muscle size, decreased sensation, hammer toes and high arches are symptoms.

symptoms.Muscular: abnormality walking, flaccid muscles, instability, lack of coordination, muscle weakness, rhythmic muscle contractions, or loss of muscle
symptoms.Foot: hammer toe, high foot arches, constantly walking on tip toe, or difficulty raising the foot
symptoms.Sensory: pins and needles or reduced sensation of touch
symptoms.Also common: hand contractures, slow reflexes, or tremor

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disorder.overview:
Description
A group of hereditary disorders that damage the nerves in the arms and legs.
Charcot-Marie-Tooth is a degenerative nerve disease that usually appears in adolescence or early adulthood.
Muscle weakness, decreased muscle size, decreased sensation, hammer toes and high arches are symptoms.
The main treatments are physiotherapy and occupational therapy. Medication may reduce pain.
Charcot-Marie-Tooth disorder.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.

Devices.Splint: A rigid accessory used to stabilise and protect an injured joint.
Devices.Brace: A device applied to the body to help stabilise, protect or limit movement of a damaged joint.

specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Occupational Medicine Doctor: Prevents and treats illness in the workplace.
specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.

Chiari malformation.symptomDescription: Symptoms include pain and trouble swallowing.

symptoms.Muscular: muscle weakness, problems with coordination, stiff muscles, or overactive reflexes
symptoms.Sensory: pins and needles, reduced sensation of touch, or uncomfortable tingling and burning
symptoms.Visual: blurred vision, double vision, or sensitivity to light
symptoms.Also common: difficulty swallowing, headache, impaired voice, nausea, rapid involuntary eye movement, ringing in the ears, or vertigo

Chiari malformation.overview:
Description
A condition in which brain tissue extends into the spinal canal, present at birth.
It occurs when part of the skull is abnormally small or misshapen.
Symptoms include pain and trouble swallowing.
Treatment may involve monitoring and surgery. Medication may be given to manage symptoms such as pain.
Chiari malformation.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Surgery.Laminectomy: Surgical removal of the back part of the vertebra to relieve pressure on the spine or nerve.
Surgery.Decompressive craniectomy: Surgical removal of part of the skull so that an injured brain can swell without being squeezed.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Chickenpox.symptomDescription: The most characteristic symptom is an itchy, blister-like rash on the skin.

symptoms.Skin: blister, scab, ulcers, or red spots
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, fever, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: headache, itching, sore throat, or swollen lymph nodes

Chickenpox.overview:
Description
A highly contagious viral infection which causes an itchy, blister-like rash on the skin.
Chickenpox is highly contagious to those who haven't had the disease or been vaccinated against it.
The most characteristic symptom is an itchy, blister-like rash on the skin.
Chickenpox can be prevented by a vaccine. Treatment usually involves relieving symptoms, although high-risk groups may receive antiviral medication.
Chickenpox.notes:
Preventable by vaccine
Usually self-treatable
Spreads easily
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).
By mother to baby by pregnancy, labour or nursing.

Self-care.Oatmeal bath: A mixture of oatmeal and water that soothes irritated skin.
Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.

Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Chilblains.symptomDescription: Common symptoms include itching, bumps and red to violet-coloured patches on the hands or feet.

symptoms.Skin: rashes, redness, blister, or ulcers
symptoms.Also common: itching or swelling

Chilblains.overview:
Description
Skin sores or bumps that occur after exposure to very cold temperatures.
Chilblains may be an abnormal blood vessel response. Women, underweight people and those with Raynaud's phenomenon are at increased risk.
Common symptoms include itching, bumps and red to violet-coloured patches on the hands or feet.
The skin usually clears up on its own within one to three weeks, although it may recur for years. Medication can help and so can dressing appropriately for cold weather.
Chilblains.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Heating pad: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Childhood obesity.symptomDescription: There may be no symptoms other than weight that's above normal.

symptoms.Common symptoms: overweight, binge eating, pot belly, or shortness of breath

Childhood obesity.overview:
Description
A condition in which a child is significantly overweight for his or her age and height.
Childhood obesity can lead to diabetes, high blood pressure and high cholesterol.
There may be no symptoms other than weight that's above normal.
Improving the entire family's diet and exercise habits is one of the best ways to achieve a healthy weight in the child.
Childhood obesity.notes:
Medium-term: resolves within months
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required

Self-care.Low carbohydrate diet: A diet that limits grains, starchy vegetables and fruit and emphasises foods high in protein and fat.
Self-care.Low fat diet: Reducing intake of high-fat foods such as dairy, oil and red meat to improve cardiovascular health.
Self-care.Low calorie diet: A diet that restricts calories to 1,200 to 1,500 calories per day for women and 1,500 to 1,800 calories per day for men. Eating fewer calories promotes weight loss.
Self-care.Limiting screen time: Limiting the amount of time children spend watching TV, playing video games and using computers, tablets and smartphones.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Chlamydia.symptomDescription: Many who have chlamydia don't develop symptoms, but they can still infect others through sexual contact. Symptoms may include genital pain and discharge from the vagina or penis.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the eyes, lower abdomen, pelvis, testicle, or vagina
symptoms.Pain circumstances: can occur during sexual intercourse or during urination
symptoms.Groin: abnormal vaginal discharge, discharge from penis, or vaginal bleeding
symptoms.Also common: eye discharge or spotting

Chlamydia.overview:
Description
A common, sexually transmitted infection that may not cause symptoms.
Chlamydia affects people of all ages but is most common in young women.
Many who have chlamydia don't develop symptoms, but they can still infect others through sexual contact. Symptoms may include genital pain and discharge from the vagina or penis.
Antibiotic therapy for the affected patient and the sexual partners of patients is recommended. Screening for other common sexually transmitted infections should also be performed.
Chlamydia.notes:
Spreads by sexual contact
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
HOW IT SPREADS
By having unprotected vaginal, anal or oral sex.
By mother to baby by pregnancy, labour or nursing.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.

Cholecystitis.symptomDescription: Severe pain in the upper-right belly and bloating are symptoms.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the abdomen, shoulder, or upper-right abdomen
symptoms.Whole body: chills, fever, or sweating
symptoms.Also common: abdominal cramping from gallstones or yellow skin and eyes

Cholecystitis.overview:
Description
Inflammation of the gallbladder, a small digestive organ beneath the liver.
Cholecystitis is often caused by stones that block the tube leading from the gallbladder to the small intestine.
Severe pain in the upper-right belly and bloating are symptoms.
Treatment includes a hospital stay and surgical removal.
Cholecystitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Self-care.Fasting from food and drink: Rests the bowel and reduces the risk of complications prior to procedures or surgeries.

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.

specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS/ME).symptomDescription: The main symptom is fatigue for over six months. The fatigue often worsens with activity, but doesn't improve with rest.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, inability to exercise, or malaise
symptoms.Cognitive: confusion, forgetfulness, or lack of concentration
symptoms.Mood: anxiety or apprehension
symptoms.Also common: depression, headache, muscle weakness, sensitivity to pain, or sore throat

Chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS/ME).overview:
Description
A disease characterised by profound fatigue, sleep abnormalities, pain and other symptoms that are made worse by exertion.
Chronic fatigue syndrome occurs more commonly in women. The cause of this condition is unknown, but may include environmental or genetic factors.
The main symptom is fatigue for over six months. The fatigue often worsens with activity, but doesn't improve with rest.
There is no cure or approved treatment for this condition. However, some symptoms can be treated or managed to provide relief.
Chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS/ME).notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Self-care.Stress management: Pursuing an enjoyable activity or verbalising frustration to reduce stress and improve mental health.
Self-care.Relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, meditation, yoga, rhythmic exercise and other activities that reduce symptoms of stress

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.

Medication.Antidepressant: Taking medications designed to help relieve symptoms of depression. Some antidepressants also have other uses, such as treating chronic pain and certain anxiety disorders.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Chronic kidney disease.symptomDescription: Symptoms develop slowly and aren't specific to the disease. Some people have no symptoms at all and are diagnosed by a lab test.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, high blood pressure, loss of appetite, malaise, or water-electrolyte imbalance
symptoms.Also common: kidney damage, abnormal heart rhythm, failure to thrive, fluid in the lungs, insufficient urine production, itching, kidney failure, severe unintentional weight loss, or swelling

Chronic kidney disease.overview:
Description
Longstanding disease of the kidneys leading to renal failure.
The kidneys filter waste and excess fluid from the blood. As kidneys fail, waste builds up.
Symptoms develop slowly and aren't specific to the disease. Some people have no symptoms at all and are diagnosed by a lab test.
Medication helps manage symptoms. In later stages, filtering the blood with a machine (dialysis) or a transplant may be required.
Chronic kidney disease.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medical procedure.Peritoneal dialysis: A home-based therapy that uses the natural lining of the abdomen as a filter to clean the blood when the kidneys can no longer do so.
Medical procedure.Hemofiltration: Using filters outside the body to clean the blood when the kidneys are injured.
Medical procedure.Dialysis: Using a machine to clean the blood when the kidneys can no longer do so.

Self-care.Low protein diet: A diet that reduces consumption of meats, fish and cheese used to treat certain kidney and metabolic diseases.

Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.
Medication.Calcium reducer: Decreases the amount of calcium in the blood.
Medication.Bone marrow stimulant: Helps bone marrow produce new blood cells.
Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

Surgery.Kidney transplantation: Surgical replacement of a diseased kidney with one from a living or deceased donor.

specialists.Transplant Surgeon: Transfers an organ from one body to another.

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia.symptomDescription: CLL may not cause any symptoms for years. When symptoms do occur, they may include swollen lymph nodes, fatigue and easy bruising.

symptoms.Common symptoms: swollen lymph nodes or fatigue

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia.overview:
Description
A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow.
B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) develops from a type of white blood cell called B cells. It progresses slowly, usually affecting older adults.
CLL may not cause any symptoms for years. When symptoms do occur, they may include swollen lymph nodes, fatigue and easy bruising.
Treatment isn't always initially necessary, but may include chemotherapy. Stem-cell transplant is used in rare cases for aggressive types.
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.

specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.

Chronic myeloid leukemia.symptomDescription: Many people don't develop symptoms until later stages and the diagnosis is only made through routine blood work. When symptoms do occur, they include bleeding easily, feeling run down or tired, weight loss, pale skin and night sweats.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, anaemia, malaise, or night sweats
symptoms.Also common: bleeding, bruising, pallor, reduced ability to exercise, shortness of breath, or weight loss

Chronic myeloid leukemia.overview:
Description
A slowly progressing and uncommon type of blood-cell cancer that begins in the bone marrow.
Chronic myeloid leukaemia typically affects older adults. It's caused by a chromosome mutation that occurs spontaneously. Doctors aren't sure what causes the mutation.
Many people don't develop symptoms until later stages and the diagnosis is only made through routine blood work. When symptoms do occur, they include bleeding easily, feeling run down or tired, weight loss, pale skin and night sweats.
Treatments include targeted drugs, stem-cell transplant, chemotherapy and biological therapy.
Chronic myeloid leukemia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.

Medical procedure.Haematopoietic stem cell transplantation: Transplanting stem cells to restore a person's immune system. The transplanted cells can come from a donor or be the person's own cells.

specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.
specialists.Transfusion Medicine: Manages the transfusion of blood products and potential complications.

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.symptomDescription: Symptoms include shortness of breath, wheezing or a chronic cough.

symptoms.Cough: can be dry or with phlegm
symptoms.Respiratory: frequent respiratory infections, shortness of breath, or wheezing
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or inability to exercise
symptoms.Also common: chest pressure, loss of muscle, or weight loss

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.overview:
Description
A group of lung diseases that block airflow and make it difficult to breathe.
Emphysema and chronic bronchitis are the most common conditions that make up COPD. Damage to the lungs from COPD can't be reversed.
Symptoms include shortness of breath, wheezing or a chronic cough.
Rescue inhalers and inhaled or oral steroids can help control symptoms and minimise further damage.
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Bronchodilator: Helps open the airways of the lungs to make breathing easier.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Diaphragmatic breathing: Using the large muscle between the lungs and abdomen (diaphragm) to inhale and exhale more deeply.

Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.

Therapies.Pulmonary rehabilitation: Exercise, nutritional counselling, education and support to help people with chronic breathing problems improve their fitness.

Chronic pain.symptomDescription: The primary symptom is persistent pain that lasts weeks to years.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the back, joints, mouth and face, muscles and bones, or neck
symptoms.Pain types: can be caused by psychological factors
symptoms.Sensory: pins and needles or sensitivity to pain
symptoms.Also common: anxiety, fatigue, headache, or sleep deprivation

Chronic pain.overview:
Description
Persistent pain that lasts weeks to years.
The pain may be be caused by inflammation or dysfunctional nerves.
The primary symptom is persistent pain that lasts weeks to years.
Treatments include medication, acupuncture, electrical stimulation, cognitive behavioural therapy and surgery.
Chronic pain.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Stress management: Pursuing an enjoyable activity or verbalising frustration to reduce stress and improve mental health.
Self-care.Relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, meditation, yoga, rhythmic exercise and other activities that reduce symptoms of stress

Therapies.Biofeedback: Controlling the body's heartbeat, brainwaves, breathing and blood pressure by monitoring them with sensors.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Behaviour therapy: A therapy focused on modifying harmful behaviours associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Brief psychotherapy: Short-term counselling that focuses on achieving specific goals.

Medication.Nerve pain medication: Blocks pain caused by damaged nerves.
Medication.Narcotic: Relieves pain, dulls the senses and causes drowsiness. May become addictive.

Medical procedure.Nerve block: Numbing medication injected near a nerve to relieve pain.

specialists.Palliative Medicine: Focuses on improving quality of life for those with severe illnesses.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Pain Management: Eases suffering and improves quality of life for those in pain.
specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Cirrhosis.symptomDescription: Initially patients may experience fatigue, weakness and weight loss. During later stages, patients may develop jaundice (yellowing of the skin), gastrointestinal bleeding, abdominal swelling and confusion.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: bleeding, dark stool from digested blood, fluid in the abdomen, nausea, passing excessive amounts of gas, vomiting blood, or water retention
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, loss of appetite, or reduced hormone production
symptoms.Skin: web of swollen blood vessels in the skin or yellow skin and eyes
symptoms.Also common: bleeding, breast augmentation, bruising, dark urine, enlarged veins around belly button, itching, mental confusion, muscle weakness, shortness of breath, swelling, swelling in extremities, or swollen veins in the lower oesophagus

Cirrhosis.overview:
Description
Chronic liver damage from a variety of causes leading to scarring and liver failure.
Hepatitis and chronic alcohol abuse are frequent causes. Liver damage caused by cirrhosis can't be undone, but further damage can be limited.
Initially patients may experience fatigue, weakness and weight loss. During later stages, patients may develop jaundice (yellowing of the skin), gastrointestinal bleeding, abdominal swelling and confusion.
Treatments focus on the underlying cause. In advanced cases, a liver transplant may be required.
Cirrhosis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Low sodium diet: A diet that restricts salt (sodium chloride) and other forms of sodium to no more than 2,000 mg per day
Self-care.Avoid alcohol: May be harmful and aggravate certain conditions.

Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.
Medication.Ammonia reducer: Reduces the amount of ammonia in the body.
Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

Medical procedure.Rubber band ligation: Tying off a dilated or bleeding blood vessel with a rubber band to block its blood supply. This causes it to dry up and fall off.
Medical procedure.Therapeutic endoscopy: Using a lighted medical instrument to see inside the body and provide treatment. For example, to stop bleeding or remove a foreign object.
Medical procedure.Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic: Placing a tube (stent) in the liver to relieve a backup of blood in the veins.

Surgery.Liver transplantation: Surgical replacement of a diseased liver with some or all of a healthy liver from a donor.

specialists.Transplant Hepatologist: Focuses on end stage liver disease and liver transplant patients.
specialists.Hepatologist: Focuses on liver, gallbladder and biliary tree disorders.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Cleft lip and cleft palate.symptomDescription: Symptoms arise from the opening in the mouth. They include difficulty speaking and feeding.

symptoms.Speech: speech disorder, stuttering, or impaired voice
symptoms.Also common: physical deformity, baby feeding difficulties, hearing loss, mouth breathing, nasal congestion, or snoring

Cleft lip and cleft palate.overview:
Description
Openings or splits in the roof of the mouth and lip.
Cleft palate is a common birth condition. It can occur alone or as part of a genetic condition or syndrome.
Symptoms arise from the opening in the mouth. They include difficulty speaking and feeding.
Surgery restores normal function with minimal scarring. If required, speech therapy helps correct speaking difficulties.
Cleft lip and cleft palate.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required

Surgery.Palatoplasty: Plastic surgery to repair a split in the roof of the mouth (cleft palate). This is a common birth defect.
Surgery.Orthognathic surgery: Surgery to correct deformities of the jaw such as for an overbite or underbite.
Surgery.Bone grafting: Surgical placement of new bone around fractures to help them heal.
Surgery.Flap surgery: Surgically moving tissue from one part of the body to another. Often done to repair a wound or rebuild damaged tissue.

Medical procedure.Dental implant: An artifical tooth root surgically implanted to support a replacement tooth.

specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Dentist: Specialises in diseases of the oral cavity, especially the teeth.
specialists.Neonatologist: Provides medical care for newborn infants.
specialists.Paediatric surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries for infants and children.
specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Plastic Surgeon: Reconstructs defective, damaged or missing body parts.

Clinical depression.symptomDescription: The persistent feeling of sadness or loss of interest that characterises major depression can lead to a range of behavioural and physical symptoms. These may include changes in sleep, appetite, energy level, concentration, daily behaviour or self-esteem. Depression can also be associated with thoughts of suicide.

symptoms.Mood: anxiety, apathy, general discontent, guilt, hopelessness, loss of interest, loss of interest or pleasure in activities, mood swings, or sadness
symptoms.Behavioural: agitation, excessive crying, irritability, restlessness, or social isolation
symptoms.Sleep: early awakening, excess sleepiness, insomnia, or restless sleep
symptoms.Whole body: excessive hunger, fatigue, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Cognitive: lack of concentration, slowness in activity, or thoughts of suicide
symptoms.Also common: poor appetite or repeatedly going over thoughts

Clinical depression.overview:
Description
A mental health disorder characterised by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life.
Possible causes include a combination of biological, psychological and social sources of distress. Increasingly, research suggests that these factors may cause changes in brain function, including altered activity of certain neural circuits in the brain.
The persistent feeling of sadness or loss of interest that characterises major depression can lead to a range of behavioural and physical symptoms. These may include changes in sleep, appetite, energy level, concentration, daily behaviour or self-esteem. Depression can also be associated with thoughts of suicide.
The mainstay of treatment is usually medication, talk therapy or a combination of the two. Increasingly, research suggests that these treatments may normalise brain changes associated with depression.
Clinical depression.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Medium-term: resolves within months
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Behaviour therapy: A therapy focused on modifying harmful behaviours associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.

Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.
Medication.Antidepressant: Taking medications designed to help relieve symptoms of depression. Some antidepressants also have other uses, such as treating chronic pain and certain anxiety disorders.
Medication.Anxiolytic: Relieves anxiety and tension. May promote sleep.

Medical procedure.Electroconvulsive therapy: Treating mental illness by sending electric currents through the brain to trigger a seizure. Also known as shock treatment.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Club foot.symptomDescription: In clubfoot, the foot appears twisted and can even look as if it's upside down. Despite its appearance, clubfoot itself doesn't cause any discomfort or pain.

symptoms.Common symptoms: foot deformity, abnormality walking, callus, knock knees, or shortened legs

Club foot.overview:
Description
A birth defect in which the foot is twisted out of shape or position.
The cause of clubfoot is unknown. Babies with clubfoot are usually otherwise healthy.
In clubfoot, the foot appears twisted and can even look as if it's upside down. Despite its appearance, clubfoot itself doesn't cause any discomfort or pain.
Treatment is usually successful. It includes stretching and casting (Ponseti method) or stretching and taping (French method). Sometimes, surgery is required.
Club foot.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Devices.Brace: A device applied to the body to help stabilise, protect or limit movement of a damaged joint.

Medical procedure.French functional method: A process where the foot is stretched and taped in position multiple times over a period of months to realign the foot.
Medical procedure.Serial stretching and casting: A process where the foot is stretched and cast in position multiple times over a period of months to realign the foot.

Surgery.Achilles tenotomy: A surgical procedure to lengthen the tendon that inserts into the heel.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.

Cluster headaches.symptomDescription: Pain is severe on one side of the head, accompanied by symptoms such as nasal discharge or red or tearing eyes.

symptoms.Eyes: drooping of upper eyelid, small pupils, watery eyes, puffy eyes, or redness
symptoms.Whole body: flushing, nervous system dysfunction, or sweating
symptoms.Also common: headache, agitation, or runny nose

Cluster headaches.overview:
Description
Headaches that occur in patterns or clusters.
Bouts of frequent attacks, known as cluster periods, may last from weeks to months, usually followed by long periods of relief (remission). During remission, attacks may stop for months or years.
Pain is severe on one side of the head, accompanied by symptoms such as nasal discharge or red or tearing eyes.
Injected medication, inhaled oxygen, steroids and preventive medication can help.
Cluster headaches.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.

Medication.Triptan: Relieves pain and symptoms associated with migraines and cluster headaches.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Nerve pain medication: Blocks pain caused by damaged nerves.

Coarctation of the aorta.symptomDescription: Many people have no symptoms and the condition often isn't detected until adulthood. The most common symptom in adults is high blood pressure. Rarely, severe cases can cause heart failure in babies.

symptoms.Whole body: high blood pressure or low blood pressure
symptoms.Heart: enlarged heart or murmur
symptoms.Also common: blue skin from poor circulation, diminished pulses, failure to thrive, or shortness of breath

Coarctation of the aorta.overview:
Description
A narrowing of the large blood vessel (aorta) that leads from the heart.
Coarctation of the aorta is usually present at birth (congenital) and may occur with other heart defects.
Many people have no symptoms and the condition often isn't detected until adulthood. The most common symptom in adults is high blood pressure. Rarely, severe cases can cause heart failure in babies.
Treatment involves surgery or a catheter-based procedure to fix the narrowing.
Coarctation of the aorta.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medical procedure.Stenting: Holding an artery, blood vessel or other passageway in the body open with a tube.
Medical procedure.Cardiac catheterization: Inserting a long tube into the groin, neck or arm and then threading it through the blood vessels to the heart.
Medical procedure.Angioplasty: Unblocking an artery by inflating a balloon inside it. A stent may also be inserted to hold the artery open.

Surgery.Surgical coarctation repair: Surgery to fix an abnormal narrowing of the major blood vessel leaving the heart (aorta).

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Maternal-Foetal Medicine Specialist: Focuses on the medical management of high-risk pregnancies.
specialists.Vascular Surgeon: Specialises in surgery for vascular system diseases.
specialists.Cardiothoracic Surgeon: Surgically treats diseases affecting organs inside the chest.
specialists.Neonatologist: Provides medical care for newborn infants.

Coeliac disease.symptomDescription: The classic symptom is diarrhoea. Other symptoms include bloating, wind, fatigue, low blood count (anaemia) and osteoporosis. Many people have no symptoms.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: belching, diarrhoea, fat in stool, heartburn, indigestion, nausea, vomiting, or flatulence
symptoms.Whole body: bone loss, fatigue, or malnutrition
symptoms.Also common: cramping, itching, lactose intolerance, skin rash, or weight loss

Coeliac disease.overview:
Description
An immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley and rye.
Over time, the immune reaction to eating gluten creates inflammation that damages the small intestine's lining, leading to medical complications. It also prevents absorption of some nutrients (malabsorption).
The classic symptom is diarrhoea. Other symptoms include bloating, wind, fatigue, low blood count (anaemia) and osteoporosis. Many people have no symptoms.
The mainstay of treatment is a strict gluten-free diet that can help manage symptoms and promote intestinal healing.
Coeliac disease.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Gluten-free diet: A diet that eliminates wheat, barley, rye and other grains that contain gluten.

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.
Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Cold sores.symptomDescription: Oral herpes causes tiny, fluid-filled lesions called cold sores or fever blisters, which can recur.

symptoms.Mouth: sore lip, tingling, tingling lips, or ulcers
symptoms.Skin: blister, rashes, ulcers, or redness
symptoms.Also common: burning sensation

Cold sores.overview:
Description
Infection with the herpes simplex virus around the border of the lips.
Oral herpes spreads through close personal contact, such as kissing.
Oral herpes causes tiny, fluid-filled lesions called cold sores or fever blisters, which can recur.
Medication can speed up healing and reduce recurrence.
Cold sores.notes:
Spreads easily
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
HOW IT SPREADS
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).
By having unprotected vaginal, anal or oral sex.
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Self-care.Cool compress: Soothes painful muscles or joints and may help reduce inflammation.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.Dentist: Specialises in diseases of the oral cavity, especially the teeth.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Colon cancer.symptomDescription: Colorectal cancer symptoms depend on the size and location of the cancer. Some commonly experienced symptoms include changes in bowel habits, changes in stool consistency, blood in the stool and abdominal discomfort.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: blood in stool, change in bowel habits, constipation, narrow stools, or passing excessive amounts of gas
symptoms.Whole body: anaemia or fatigue
symptoms.Also common: abdominal discomfort or weight loss

Colon cancer.overview:
Description
A cancer of the colon or rectum, located at the digestive tract's lower end.
Early cases can begin as non-cancerous polyps. These often have no symptoms but can be detected by screening. For this reason, doctors recommend screenings for those at high risk or over the age of 50.
Colorectal cancer symptoms depend on the size and location of the cancer. Some commonly experienced symptoms include changes in bowel habits, changes in stool consistency, blood in the stool and abdominal discomfort.
Colorectal cancer treatment depends on the size, location and how far the cancer has spread. Common treatments include surgery to remove the cancer, chemotherapy and radiation therapy.
Colon cancer.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Surgery.Lymph node dissection: Surgical removal of a lymph node.
Surgery.Colectomy: Surgical removal of all or part of the colon.

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Chemotherapy protective drugs: Reduces the side effects of chemotherapy treatment.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Pathologist: Diagnoses disease by examining body cells, fluids and tissues.

Colorectal polyp.symptomDescription: Colon polyps often don't cause symptoms.

symptoms.Common symptoms: blood in stool

Colorectal polyp.overview:
Description
A small clump of cells that forms on the lining of the colon or rectum.
Most are harmless, but some can develop into cancer.
Colon polyps often don't cause symptoms.
Regular screening tests, such as colonoscopy, can help ensure that polyps are identified and removed before they can develop into cancer.
Colorectal polyp.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Dietary fiber: The parts of plant foods that the body can't digest. Helps to control blood sugar, soften stools and maintain bowel health.

Medical procedure.Cauterization: Burning or freezing a part of the body to remove tissue or stop bleeding. For example, to seal off a wound and prevent blood loss.
Medical procedure.Polypectomy: Surgical removal of an abnormal growth (polyp) on the lining of a body cavity. For example, inside the nose or colon.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Common cold.symptomDescription: Symptoms include a runny nose, sneezing and congestion. High fever or severe symptoms are reasons to see a doctor, especially in children.

symptoms.Nasal: congestion, runny nose, sneezing, loss of smell, redness, or post-nasal drip
symptoms.Whole body: chills, fatigue, fever, malaise, or body ache
symptoms.Eyes: watery eyes, itchiness, or redness
symptoms.Head: congestion or sinus pressure
symptoms.Also common: chest pressure, headache, swollen lymph nodes, or throat irritation

Common cold.overview:
Description
A common viral infection of the nose and throat.
In contrast to the flu, a common cold can be caused by many different types of viruses. The condition is generally harmless and symptoms usually resolve within two weeks.
Symptoms include a runny nose, sneezing and congestion. High fever or severe symptoms are reasons to see a doctor, especially in children.
Most people recover on their own within two weeks. Over-the-counter products and home remedies can help control symptoms.
Common cold.notes:
Spreads easily
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Self-care.Nasal washing: Rinsing the inside of the nose with warm salt water to flush out irritants and excess mucus. Often done using a neti pot or squeeze bottle.
Self-care.Menthol: An oil made from mint that soothes sore throats and relieves itching.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.
Medication.Cough medicine: Blocks the cough reflex. Some may thin and loosen mucus, making it easier to clear from the airways.
Medication.Decongestant: Relieves nasal congestion, swelling and runny nose.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Complex regional pain syndrome.symptomDescription: Complex regional pain is characterised by pain that is greater than would be expected from the injury that causes it.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the nerves, arms or legs, back, foot, or hands
symptoms.Pain types: can be chronic
symptoms.Muscular: rhythmic muscle contractions, loss of muscle, or muscle spasms
symptoms.Sensory: pins and needles, sensitivity to pain, or uncomfortable tingling and burning
symptoms.Whole body: nervous system dysfunction or sweating
symptoms.Also common: depression, headache, redness, stiffness, swelling, or tenderness

Complex regional pain syndrome.overview:
Description
Chronic arm or leg pain developing after injury, surgery, stroke or heart attack.
The exact cause of complex regional pain syndrome isn't well understood but may involve abnormal inflammation or nerve dysfunction.
Complex regional pain is characterised by pain that is greater than would be expected from the injury that causes it.
Treatment usually consists of medication, heat or cold therapy, physiotherapy and biofeedback.
Complex regional pain syndrome.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Heating pad: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.

Therapies.Biofeedback: Controlling the body's heartbeat, brainwaves, breathing and blood pressure by monitoring them with sensors.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
Therapies.Acupuncture: Insertion of needles into specific points on the body to relieve pain and treat other conditions. A form of traditional Chinese medicine.

Medication.Nerve pain medication: Blocks pain caused by damaged nerves.
Medication.Muscle relaxant: Reduces muscle tension and helps relieve muscle pain and discomfort.
Medication.Sedative: Causes drowsiness, calmness and dulled senses. Some types may become addictive.
Medication.Local anesthetic: Blocks pain at and near the site where it's given, or along the nerve that's blocked.
Medication.Narcotic: Relieves pain, dulls the senses and causes drowsiness. May become addictive.

Medical procedure.Nerve block: Numbing medication injected near a nerve to relieve pain.

specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Pain Management: Eases suffering and improves quality of life for those in pain.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Concussion.extraName: Also called: MTBI, mild traumatic brain injury
Concussion.symptomDescription: Symptoms may include headache, confusion, lack of coordination, memory loss, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, ringing in the ears, sleepiness and excessive fatigue.

symptoms.Whole body: blackout, fatigue, or poor balance
symptoms.Cognitive: amnesia, disorientation, or mental confusion
symptoms.Also common: irritability, mild depression, ringing in the ears, or sensitivity to light

Concussion.overview:
Description
A brain injury caused by a blow to the head or a violent shaking of the head and body.
This occurs from a mild blow to the head, either with or without loss of consciousness, and can lead to temporary cognitive symptoms.
Symptoms may include headache, confusion, lack of coordination, memory loss, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, ringing in the ears, sleepiness and excessive fatigue.
There's no specific cure for concussion. Rest and restricting activities allow the brain to recover. This means that one should temporarily reduce time spent on sports, video games, TV or too much socialising. Medication for headache pain or ondansetron or other anti-nausea medication can be used for symptoms.
Concussion.notes:
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging always required
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Rest: Reducing activity for a short period of time following an injury to promote healing.

Supportive care.Close monitoring: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Therapies.Rehabilitation: Retraining the brain's pathways to improve mental and physical functioning after an illness or injury. For example, after a blow to the head (concussion).

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia.symptomDescription: Symptoms in infants may include ambiguous genitalia in girls and an enlarged penis in boys.

symptoms.Whole body: dehydration, low blood pressure, low blood sugar, or water-electrolyte imbalance
symptoms.Developmental: failure to thrive or short stature
symptoms.Also common: enlarged clitoris, inappropriate male features, insufficient amount of cortisol hormones, irregular menstruation, or vomiting

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia.overview:
Description
A group of genetic conditions limiting hormone production in the adrenal glands.
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia affects a child's normal growth and development. Although it can be life-threatening, most people can lead normal lives with proper treatment.
Symptoms in infants may include ambiguous genitalia in girls and an enlarged penis in boys.
Treatment involves replacement hormone medication. Reconstructive surgery is an option for girls.
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Surgery.Genital reconstructive surgery: Surgery performed to correct genital abnormalities.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Paediatric urologist: A surgical subspecialty of medicine dealing with the disorders of children's genitourinary systems.
specialists.Neonatologist: Provides medical care for newborn infants.

Conjunctivitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include redness, itching and tearing of the eyes. It can also lead to discharge or crusting around the eyes.

symptoms.Eyes: redness, irritation, redness of eyelid, discharge, dryness, itchiness, puffy eyes, swollen lining of the eye, or watery eyes
symptoms.Also common: sensitivity to light

Conjunctivitis.overview:
Description
Inflammation or infection of the outer membrane of the eyeball and the inner eyelid.
Conjunctivitis, or pink eye, is an irritation or inflammation of the conjunctiva, which covers the white part of the eyeball. It can be caused by allergies or a bacterial or viral infection. Conjunctivitis can be extremely contagious and is spread by contact with eye secretions from someone who is infected.
Symptoms include redness, itching and tearing of the eyes. It can also lead to discharge or crusting around the eyes.
It's important to stop wearing contact lenses whilst affected by conjunctivitis. It often resolves on its own, but treatment can speed the recovery process. Allergic conjunctivitis can be treated with antihistamines. Bacterial conjunctivitis can be treated with antibiotic eye drops.
Conjunctivitis.notes:
Spreads easily
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Self-care.Cold compress: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Artificial tears: Moistens eyes to provide soothing relief.

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Contact dermatitis.symptomDescription: The main symptom is a red rash wherever the skin came into contact with the irritant.

symptoms.Skin: rashes, redness, blister, fissures, hives, peeling, or ulcers
symptoms.Also common: itching or swelling

Contact dermatitis.overview:
Description
A skin rash caused by contact with a certain substance.
The substance might irritate the skin or trigger an allergic reaction. Some common culprits include soap, cosmetics, fragrances, jewellery and poison ivy.
The main symptom is a red rash wherever the skin came into contact with the irritant.
Avoiding the irritant or allergen should allow the rash to clear in two to four weeks. Creams or medication can help reduce itching.
Contact dermatitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Cold compress: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Sunblock: Protects against the sun's UV rays, which can damage the skin over time.
Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.
Self-care.Barrier cream: A cream that soothes and protects irritated skin.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Topical antiseptic: Destroys or prevents the growth of microorganisms on the skin that may cause infection.
Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.
Medication.Local anesthetic: Blocks pain at and near the site where it's given, or along the nerve that's blocked.
Medication.Antifungal: Kills or prevents growth of fungi.

Medical procedure.Desensitization: Reducing allergic reactions by injecting gradually increasing doses of the substance causing the reaction.

specialists.Allergy & Immunology Doctor: Treats allergy and immune system disorders.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Corn.symptomDescription: Symptoms include hardened, raised bumps surrounded by inflamed skin. They can be painful when pressed.

symptoms.Skin: thickness or dryness

Corn.overview:
Description
Thick, hardened layers of skin caused by friction and pressure.
Corns most often develop on the tops and sides of feet and between the toes. They're benign and can also be found in weight-bearing areas.
Symptoms include hardened, raised bumps surrounded by inflamed skin. They can be painful when pressed.
Self-care measures include wearing properly fitting shoes and using protective pads. Medicated patches can help remove corns or a doctor can trim them.
Corn.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Well-Fitting shoes: Relieves pressure points on the foot.

Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.

Medical procedure.Removal of unhealthy tissue: Removal of dead, damaged or infected tissue from wounds to promote healing.

Devices.Brace: A device applied to the body to help stabilise, protect or limit movement of a damaged joint.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Coronary heart disease.extraName: Also called: CAD, atherosclerotic heart disease
Coronary heart disease.symptomDescription: Coronary artery disease can range from no symptoms, to chest pain, to a heart attack.

symptoms.Whole body: light-headedness or sweating
symptoms.Also common: fast heart rate or shortness of breath

Coronary heart disease.overview:
Description
Damage or disease in the heart's major blood vessels.
The usual cause is the build-up of plaque. This causes coronary arteries to narrow, limiting blood flow to the heart.
Coronary artery disease can range from no symptoms, to chest pain, to a heart attack.
Treatments include lifestyle changes, medication, angioplasty and surgery.
Coronary heart disease.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Low fat diet: Reducing intake of high-fat foods such as dairy, oil and red meat to improve cardiovascular health.

Medication.Statin: Decreases the liver's production of harmful cholesterol.
Medication.Anticoagulant: Unwanted reactions from taking drugs that inhibit blood clotting. The most common problem is too much bleeding, which can be very serious.
Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.
Medication.Antianginal: Helps reduce chest pain or pressure caused by blockages in the arteries of the heart.

Medical procedure.Coronary stent: A tube placed in the arteries of the heart to keep them open.
Medical procedure.Angioplasty: Unblocking an artery by inflating a balloon inside it. A stent may also be inserted to hold the artery open.

Surgery.Coronary artery bypass surgery: Surgery that restores blood flow to the heart by using a healthy artery or vein to bypass a blocked artery.

specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Cardiac Surgeon: Performs surgery on the heart or great vessels.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Costochondritis.symptomDescription: Costochondritis causes pain and tenderness on the breastbone, pain in more than one rib or pain that gets worse with deep breaths or coughing.

symptoms.Also common: tenderness

Costochondritis.overview:
Description
An inflammation of the cartilage that connects a rib to the breastbone.
The cause usually isn't known. In some circumstances, it develops after trauma or a muscle strain.
Costochondritis causes pain and tenderness on the breastbone, pain in more than one rib or pain that gets worse with deep breaths or coughing.
Treatments include injections to relieve pain, medication and therapy.
Costochondritis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Cradle cap.symptomDescription: The main symptom is scales on the scalp.

symptoms.Skin: rashes, oily skin, dryness, flakiness, or redness
symptoms.Also common: white or yellow scales on scalp or dandruff

Cradle cap.overview:
Description
Crusting and white or yellow scales on a baby's scalp.
Cradle cap may occur as a result of excessive oil production by skin glands surrounding hair follicles.
The main symptom is scales on the scalp.
Cradle cap usually clears up on its own within a few months. A mild shampoo can help loosen and remove the scales. A medicated shampoo can help in severe cases.
Cradle cap.notes:
Medium-term: resolves within months
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required

Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.
Self-care.Mineral oil: It can treat constipation when taken orally. It can be used as a moisturiser when applied to the skin.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Crohn's disease.symptomDescription: Crohn's disease can cause abdominal pain, diarrhoea, weight loss, anaemia and fatigue. Some people may be symptom-free most of their lives, while others can have severe chronic symptoms that never go away.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the abdomen, lower abdomen, or rectum
symptoms.Pain types: can be mild or severe
symptoms.Gastrointestinal: bloating, bowel obstruction, diarrhoea, nausea, vomiting, or flatulence
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, fever, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: cramping, depression, flare, mouth ulcer, slow growth, or weight loss

Crohn's disease.overview:
Description
A chronic inflammatory bowel disease that affects the lining of the digestive tract.
Crohn's disease can sometimes cause life-threatening complications.
Crohn's disease can cause abdominal pain, diarrhoea, weight loss, anaemia and fatigue. Some people may be symptom-free most of their lives, while others can have severe chronic symptoms that never go away.
Crohn's disease cannot be cured. Medications such as steroids and immunosuppressants are used to slow the progression of disease. If these aren't effective, a patient may require surgery. Additionally, patients with Crohn's disease may need to receive regular screening for colorectal cancer due to increased risk.
Crohn's disease.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

Surgery.Bowel resection: Surgical removal of part of the intestine.

Self-care.Dietary fiber: The parts of plant foods that the body can't digest. Helps to control blood sugar, soften stools and maintain bowel health.

Medical procedure.Enema: Fluid injected into the anus to stimulate a bowel movement.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Crossed eye.symptomDescription: The main symptom is eyes that don't look in exactly the same direction at the same time.

symptoms.Visual: blurred vision or double vision
symptoms.Also common: both eyes not focused on same object at same time, eye strain, or headache

Crossed eye.overview:
Description
Disorder in which the eyes don't look in exactly the same direction at the same time.
Causes of strabismus can include nerve injury or dysfunction of the muscles controlling the eye.
The main symptom is eyes that don't look in exactly the same direction at the same time.
Crossed eyes can usually be corrected with early treatment. Several treatment options exist to align the eyes. They include special eye wear, use of an eye patch and rarely surgery.
Crossed eye.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Devices.Bifocals: Eyeglasses with a lens that enables both near and far vision.
Devices.Eyepatch: A covering used to protect the eye from injury.
Devices.Glasses: A frame worn on the nose that holds a set of lenses to correct vision or protect the eyes.
Devices.Contact lenses: A lens placed directly on the eye to correct or assist with vision.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Croup.symptomDescription: In addition to a barking cough, symptoms include fever, hoarseness and laboured or noisy breathing.

symptoms.Respiratory: difficulty breathing, fast breathing, noisy breathing, shortness of breath, or wheezing
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or fever
symptoms.Also common: agitation, drooling, phlegm, or sore throat

Croup.overview:
Description
An upper airway infection that blocks breathing and has a distinctive barking cough.
Croup generally occurs in children.
In addition to a barking cough, symptoms include fever, hoarseness and laboured or noisy breathing.
Most cases clear up with home care in three to five days. A doctor may prescribe a steroid for a persistent case. Rarely, a severe case may need hospital care.
Croup.notes:
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Treatable by a medical professional
Spreads easily
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Cough medicine: Blocks the cough reflex. Some may thin and loosen mucus, making it easier to clear from the airways.

Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.
Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.
Supportive care.Airway management: Clearing a blocked airway of food, foreign objects, fluid and other obstructions. A top priority in emergency situations.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Cystic fibrosis.symptomDescription: Symptoms vary and can include cough, repeated lung infections, inability to gain weight and fatty stools.

symptoms.Cough: can be chronic, with blood, or with phlegm
symptoms.Gastrointestinal: diarrhoea, fat in stool, heartburn, severe constipation, or bulky stools
symptoms.Respiratory: pulmonary hypertension, shortness of breath, sinusitis, or wheezing
symptoms.Developmental: delayed development, delayed puberty, or slow growth
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or inability to exercise
symptoms.Also common: acute bronchitis, deformity of nails, infection, male infertility, nasal polyps, pneumonia, salty sweat, or weight loss

Cystic fibrosis.overview:
Description
An inherited life-threatening disorder that damages the lungs and digestive system.
Cystic fibrosis affects the cells that produce mucus, sweat and digestive juices. It causes these fluids to become thick and sticky. They then plug up tubes, ducts and passageways.
Symptoms vary and can include cough, repeated lung infections, inability to gain weight and fatty stools.
Treatments may ease symptoms and reduce complications. Newborn screening helps with early diagnosis.
Cystic fibrosis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Sodium chloride: A salt solution taken by mouth or injected into a vein to treat low levels of sodium in the body.

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Cough medicine: Blocks the cough reflex. Some may thin and loosen mucus, making it easier to clear from the airways.

Self-care.Postural drainage: Getting into positions that make it easier for mucus to drain from the lungs.

Medical procedure.Chest wall oscillation: Using a device that rhythmically presses on the chest to remove mucus from the lungs.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Respiratory Therapist: Treats and provides emergency care for patients who have trouble breathing.

Cystocele.symptomDescription: Symptoms include feeling pressure in the pelvis and vagina, discomfort when straining and feeling that the bladder hasn't fully emptied after urinating.

symptoms.Urinary: frequent urge to urinate, leaking of urine, or urinary retention
symptoms.Also common: pelvic pressure or vaginal bulge

Cystocele.overview:
Description
A bulge of the bladder into the vagina.
A cystocele can result from childbirth, constipation, violent coughing, heavy lifting or other pelvic muscle strain.
Symptoms include feeling pressure in the pelvis and vagina, discomfort when straining and feeling that the bladder hasn't fully emptied after urinating.
Mild cases don't need treatment. When required, treatment includes a flexible ring to support the bladder or surgery. In rare cases, oestrogen may also be used.
Cystocele.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Therapies.Kegel exercise: Contracting the pelvic muscles as if to stop the flow of urine. Done to strengthen these muscles.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Devices.Pessary: A ring inserted into the vagina to support the pelvic organs (uterus, bladder, rectum).

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Surgery.Colporrhaphy: Surgical repair of a defect in the wall of the vagina.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

De Quervain's tenosynovitis.symptomDescription: The main symptoms are pain and tenderness in the wrist, often below the base of the thumb.

symptoms.Also common: tenderness, difficulty gripping, or swelling

De Quervain's tenosynovitis.overview:
Description
A painful condition affecting the tendons on the thumb side of the wrist.
Repetitive hand or wrist movements can make the condition worse.
The main symptoms are pain and tenderness in the wrist, often below the base of the thumb.
Treatment may include medication, physiotherapy or in rare cases, surgery. Treatment is generally successful when begun early.
De Quervain's tenosynovitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.RICE (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation): Rest, ice, compression and elevation. A first-aid treatment for sprains and strains.

Devices.Splint: A rigid accessory used to stabilise and protect an injured joint.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Therapies.Occupational Therapy: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.

Deep vein thrombosis.extraName: Also called: DVT, deep vein thrombophlebitis
Deep vein thrombosis.symptomDescription: Leg pain or swelling may occur, but there may be no symptoms.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the calf, foot, or leg
symptoms.Also common: swelling in extremities, tenderness, or warm skin

Deep vein thrombosis.overview:
Description
A blood clot in a deep vein, usually in the legs.
This condition is serious because blood clots can loosen and lodge in the lungs.
Leg pain or swelling may occur, but there may be no symptoms.
Treatments include medication and use of compression stockings.
Deep vein thrombosis.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Treatable by a medical professional
Medium-term: resolves within months
Critical: needs emergency care

Devices.Compression stockings: Elastic hosiery that squeeze blood up the legs to prevent swelling and blood clots.

Medication.Anticoagulant: Unwanted reactions from taking drugs that inhibit blood clotting. The most common problem is too much bleeding, which can be very serious.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.
specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.

Degenerative disc disease.extraName: Also called: DDD, degeneration of the intervertebral disc
Degenerative disc disease.symptomDescription: There may be no symptoms. In some cases, the spine loses flexibility and bone spurs may pinch a nerve root, causing pain or weakness.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the legs, thighs and buttocks that worsens with standing, lower back, or neck
symptoms.Sensory: pins and needles or reduced sensation of touch
symptoms.Also common: muscle spasms, nerve injury, physical deformity, or stiffness

Degenerative disc disease.overview:
Description
Osteoarthritis of the spine, usually in the neck or lower back.
This is a condition of the discs between vertebrae with loss of cushioning, fragmentation and herniation related to ageing.
There may be no symptoms. In some cases, the spine loses flexibility and bone spurs may pinch a nerve root, causing pain or weakness.
Treatment can include exercise, medication and physiotherapy.
Degenerative disc disease.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Heating pad: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.

Therapies.Chiropractic treatment techniques: Adjusting the spine and massaging the back muscles to relieve pain.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Medical procedure.Epidural steroid injection: Injection of cortisone and a numbing agent into the spine. Can relieve back, neck, arm and leg pain.

Surgery.Spinal surgery: Correcting abnormalities of the spinal cord or its surrounding bones through surgical methods.
Surgery.Discectomy: Surgical removal of a bulging (herniated) disc that presses on a nerve or the spinal cord.
Surgery.Laminectomy: Surgical removal of the back part of the vertebra to relieve pressure on the spine or nerve.
Surgery.Laminotomy: Surgical removal of the bony arch of a vertebra to relieve pressure on the spine or nerve.
Surgery.Intervertebral disc annuloplasty: Surgery to repair the outside of a bulging disc in the spine before it ruptures.
Surgery.Intervertebral disc arthroplasty: Surgical replacement of damaged discs in the spine with artificial ones.
Surgery.Laminoplasty: Surgery to relieve pressure (stenosis) on the spinal cord in the neck.
Surgery.Facetectomy: Open back surgery to remove a damaged vertebral joint and relieve pressure on the spinal nerves.
Surgery.Annuloplasty: Surgical reconstruction of the ring (annulus) of a heart valve.
Surgery.Foraminotomy: Back surgery to widen the opening where nerves leave the spine, relieving pinched nerves.
Surgery.Spinal fusion: Surgery to join together two or more bones in the spine (vertebrae) so there is no movement between them.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Pain Management: Eases suffering and improves quality of life for those in pain.
specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Dementia.symptomDescription: Symptoms include forgetfulness, limited social skills and thinking abilities so impaired that it interferes with daily functioning.

symptoms.Cognitive: mental decline, confusion in the evening hours, disorientation, inability to speak or understand language, making things up, mental confusion, or inability to recognise common things
symptoms.Behavioural: irritability, personality changes, restlessness, lack of restraint, or wandering and getting lost
symptoms.Mood: anxiety, loneliness, mood swings, or nervousness
symptoms.Muscular: inability to combine muscle movements or unsteady walking
symptoms.Also common: memory loss, falling, jumbled speech, or sleep disorder

Dementia.overview:
Description
A group of thinking and social symptoms that interferes with daily functioning.
Not a specific disease, dementia is a group of conditions characterised by impairment of at least two brain functions, such as memory loss and judgement.
