Symptoms include forgetfulness, limited social skills and thinking abilities so impaired that it interferes with daily functioning.
Medication and therapies may help manage symptoms. Some causes are reversible.
Dementia.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required

Therapies.Rehabilitation: Retraining the brain's pathways to improve mental and physical functioning after an illness or injury. For example, after a blow to the head (concussion).
Therapies.Occupational Therapy: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.

Medication.Cognition-enhancing medication: Improves mental function, lowers blood pressure and may balance mood.

specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Dental abscess.symptomDescription: Symptoms include pain, bad breath and fever.

symptoms.Mouth: toothache, bad breath, dental cavities, or tooth loss
symptoms.Also common: pus, fever, or swollen lymph nodes

Dental abscess.overview:
Description
A pocket of pus in a tooth caused by an infection.
The infection can result from an untreated cavity, injury or old dental work.
Symptoms include pain, bad breath and fever.
The abscess must be drained. A root canal or antibiotics may be required. Sometimes, the tooth needs to be pulled.
Dental abscess.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medical procedure.Root canal: Removal of the infected pulp in a tooth's root canal. The cavity is then filled with a protective substance to save the tooth.
Medical procedure.Incision and drainage: Cutting or puncturing the skin to drain an infection such as an abscess or boil.
Medical procedure.Dental filling: Fillings, inlays, bonding and crowns used to restore decayed or damaged teeth.
Medical procedure.Tooth extraction: Surgical removal of a tooth because of decay, disease or trauma.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.

specialists.Dentist: Specialises in diseases of the oral cavity, especially the teeth.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Dermatitis herpetiformis.symptomDescription: The main symptom is an off-and-on skin rash.

symptoms.Skin: rashes, blister, darkening of the skin, small bump, or redness
symptoms.Also common: itching

Dermatitis herpetiformis.overview:
Description
A chronic, very itchy skin rash made up of bumps and blisters.
The exact cause of dermatitis herpetiformis isn't known. Genetics, gluten sensitivity and disorders in which the immune system attacks healthy cells (auto-immune disorders) may play a role.
The main symptom is an off-and-on skin rash.
Antibiotics and a gluten-free diet are treatments.
Dermatitis herpetiformis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Gluten-free diet: A diet that eliminates wheat, barley, rye and other grains that contain gluten.

Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Diabetic ketoacidosis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include thirst, frequent urination, nausea, abdominal pain, weakness, fruity-scented breath and confusion.

symptoms.Whole body: dehydration, excessive thirst, fatigue, loss of appetite, malaise, or weakness
symptoms.Respiratory: rapid breathing or shortness of breath
symptoms.Also common: blurred vision, mental confusion, sleepiness, or weight loss

Diabetic ketoacidosis.overview:
Description
A serious diabetes complication where the body produces excess blood acids (ketones).
This condition occurs when there isn't enough insulin in the body. It can be triggered by infection or other illness.
Symptoms include thirst, frequent urination, nausea, abdominal pain, weakness, fruity-scented breath and confusion.
Hospital treatment to replace fluids and electrolytes and provide insulin therapy may be required.
Diabetic ketoacidosis.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.Cardiac monitoring: Using an electronic device to monitor heart rate and rhythm. Can be done in the hospital or at home.
Supportive care.Fluid replacement: Replacing fluids lost through sweating, bleeding, vomiting or diarrhoea to treat or prevent dehydration.

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Diabetic neuropathy.symptomDescription: Symptoms include pain and numbness in the legs. In more severe cases, symptoms include issues with digestion, the bladder and controlling heart rate.

symptoms.Sensory: pins and needles, reduced sensation of touch, uncomfortable tingling and burning, or oversensitivity
symptoms.Also common: sexual dysfunction, skin ulcer, or slow reflexes

Diabetic neuropathy.overview:
Description
A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes.
The condition most often affects the legs and feet. For some people, symptoms are mild. For others, symptoms can be painful, debilitating and even fatal.
Symptoms include pain and numbness in the legs. In more severe cases, symptoms include issues with digestion, the bladder and controlling heart rate.
Treatment includes managing blood sugar and using medication to control symptoms.
Diabetic neuropathy.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Diabetes management: Improving control of blood sugar to reduce the risk of developing complications related to diabetes.

Medication.Nerve pain medication: Blocks pain caused by damaged nerves.
Medication.Anticonvulsant: Prevents or controls seizures, relieves pain and treats symptoms of certain psychiatric disorders.
Medication.Narcotic: Relieves pain, dulls the senses and causes drowsiness. May become addictive.
Medication.Local anesthetic: Blocks pain at and near the site where it's given, or along the nerve that's blocked.

specialists.Pain Management: Eases suffering and improves quality of life for those in pain.

Diabetic retinopathy.symptomDescription: Early symptoms include floaters, blurriness, dark areas of vision and difficulty perceiving colours. Blindness can occur.

symptoms.Visual: vision disorder, blurred vision, distorted vision, impaired colour vision, seeing spots, or vision loss
symptoms.Also common: new and abnormal blood vessels

Diabetic retinopathy.overview:
Description
A complication of diabetes that affects the eyes.
Diabetic retinopathy is caused by damage to the blood vessels in the tissue at the back of the eye (retina). Poorly controlled blood sugar is a risk factor.
Early symptoms include floaters, blurriness, dark areas of vision and difficulty perceiving colours. Blindness can occur.
Mild cases may be treated with careful diabetes management. Advanced cases may require laser treatment or surgery.
Diabetic retinopathy.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Blood glucose management: Working to keep blood sugars in the normal range through diet, exercise or medications.
Self-care.Diabetic diet: Diet that helps diabetics control their blood sugar (glucose) by reducing sugar and carbohydrates. For example, drinking less soda and eating less bread.

Surgery.Vitrectomy: Surgical removal of the clear, jelly-like substance (vitreous gel) that fills the inside of the eye.
Surgery.Laser coagulation: Using heat from a laser to seal off bleeding blood vessels.
Surgery.Laser surgery: Surgery using an intensely hot and focused beam of light to remove tissue and control bleeding.

Medication.VEGFR inhibitor: Prevents the growth of abnormal blood vessels.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Diaper rash.symptomDescription: The main symptom is a red rash on the buttocks. In severe cases, symptoms such as fever and widespread rash can occur.

symptoms.Skin: rashes, blister, peeling, pimples, or redness
symptoms.Also common: itchiness around anus

Diaper rash.overview:
Description
A patchwork of inflamed, bright red skin on the buttocks.
Nappy rash is linked to wet or infrequently changed nappies, diarrhoea, new foods and antibiotics.
The main symptom is a red rash on the buttocks. In severe cases, symptoms such as fever and widespread rash can occur.
Most rashes start to improve after a few days of at-home care with over-the-counter ointment and more frequent nappy changes. If it doesn't start to improve or if fever and rash develop, a visit to a doctor is required.
Diaper rash.notes:
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required

Self-care.Frequent diaper changes: Reduces skin exposure to moisture that can cause irritation.
Self-care.Expose baby's bottom to the air: Reduces moisture to prevent skin irritation.
Self-care.Petroleum jelly: A thick, topical ointment made from crude oil that moisturises and protects the skin. Commonly known as Vaseline.
Self-care.Barrier cream: A cream that soothes and protects irritated skin.
Self-care.Petrolatum / Zinc oxide: A cream that moisturises dry or rough skin and soothes minor skin irritations.
Self-care.Dimethicone / Petrolatum: A topical cream that moisturises dry, rough skin and soothes minor skin irritations.
Self-care.Aloe: A plant whose gel may help heal burns and other injuries when applied to the skin.

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.
Medication.Antifungal: Kills or prevents growth of fungi.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Dislocated shoulder.symptomDescription: Symptoms include an out-of-place shoulder, swelling, pain and inability to move the joint.

symptoms.Also common: limited joint mobility, physical deformity, swelling, or bruising

Dislocated shoulder.overview:
Description
An injury in which the upper arm bone comes out of the shoulder blade socket.
A dislocated shoulder requires prompt medical care.
Symptoms include an out-of-place shoulder, swelling, pain and inability to move the joint.
Treatments include moving the bone in place, splinting, medication and rehabilitation. Surgery is required only in rare cases.
Dislocated shoulder.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Medical procedure.Reduction: Surgery to fix a broken or dislocated bone by putting it back into place.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Devices.Splint: A rigid accessory used to stabilise and protect an injured joint.

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Dissociative identity disorder.extraName: Also called: DID, multiple personality disorder
Dissociative identity disorder.symptomDescription: Dissociative identity disorder is characterised by the presence of two or more distinct personality identities. Each may have a unique name, personal history and characteristics.

symptoms.Behavioural: impulsivity, self-destructive behaviour, or self-harm
symptoms.Mood: anxiety, feeling detached from self, or mood swings
symptoms.Also common: amnesia or blackout

Dissociative identity disorder.overview:
Description
A disorder characterised by the presence of two or more distinct personality states.
Dissociative identity disorder, previously called multiple personality disorder, is usually a reaction to trauma as a way to help a person avoid bad memories.
Dissociative identity disorder is characterised by the presence of two or more distinct personality identities. Each may have a unique name, personal history and characteristics.
Treatment is talk therapy.
Dissociative identity disorder.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required

Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Family therapy: Psychological counselling that helps families resolve conflicts and communicate more effectively.
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Psychoanalyst: Uses psychotherapy to treat mental disorders.

Diverticulosis.symptomDescription: Usually, no symptoms occur, unless the diverticula become inflamed or infected (diverticulitis), which can result in fever and abdominal pain.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: change in bowel habits or constipation

Diverticulosis.overview:
Description
A condition in which small, bulging pouches develop in the digestive tract.
It's common in people over the age of 40.
Usually, no symptoms occur, unless the diverticula become inflamed or infected (diverticulitis), which can result in fever and abdominal pain.
Treatment generally isn't required unless there is inflammation (diverticulitis).
Diverticulosis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Self-care.Dietary fiber: The parts of plant foods that the body can't digest. Helps to control blood sugar, soften stools and maintain bowel health.

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

Dog attack.symptomDescription: Symptoms of infection include redness, swelling, increased pain and oozing. A doctor should look at these symptoms right away.

symptoms.Common symptoms: bleeding, bruising, infection, redness, or swelling

Dog attack.overview:
Description
Bites from a pet or wild dog.
A dog bite can lead to rabies or tetanus infection. Immediate medical care is required when the bite is from a dog that has, or might have, rabies.
Symptoms of infection include redness, swelling, increased pain and oozing. A doctor should look at these symptoms right away.
Bite wounds from dogs can range from minor to life-threatening and need to be treated quickly to prevent infection or traumatic complications. Not having had a tetanus shot in five or more years increases tetanus risk and a booster shot may be recommended.
Dog attack.notes:
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.Wound irrigation: Using sterile water to clean a wound.
Supportive care.Wound dressing: Protects damaged skin and helps control bleeding.

Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Down syndrome.symptomDescription: Down's syndrome causes a distinct facial appearance, intellectual disability and developmental delays. It may be associated with thyroid or heart disease.

symptoms.Developmental: delayed development, learning disability, short stature, or speech delay in a child
symptoms.Eyes: lazy eye or spots
symptoms.Also common: difficulty thinking and understanding, brachycephaly, upslanting palpebral fissures, atlantoaxial instability, bent little finger, congenital heart disease, displacement of the tongue, excess skin on the back of the neck, flaccid muscles, hearing loss, immune deficiency, low-set ears, mouth breathing, obesity, obstructive sleep apnea, polycythemia, seborrheic dermatitis, single line on palm, thickening of the skin of the palms and soles, or vision disorder

Down syndrome.overview:
Description
A genetic chromosome 21 disorder causing developmental and intellectual delays.
Down's syndrome is a genetic disorder caused when abnormal cell division results in extra genetic material from chromosome 21.
Down's syndrome causes a distinct facial appearance, intellectual disability and developmental delays. It may be associated with thyroid or heart disease.
Early intervention programmes with a team of therapists and special educators who can treat each child's specific situation are helpful in managing Down's syndrome.
Down syndrome.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Special education: An approach to education that focuses on addressing the unique needs of individual students.

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Speech therapy: Treats people with speech and language problems.
Therapies.Occupational Therapy: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Devices.Glasses: A frame worn on the nose that holds a set of lenses to correct vision or protect the eyes.

specialists.Dentist: Specialises in diseases of the oral cavity, especially the teeth.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Maternal-Foetal Medicine Specialist: Focuses on the medical management of high-risk pregnancies.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Drug allergy.symptomDescription: Hives, rash and fever are common symptoms.

symptoms.Skin: hives or rashes
symptoms.Also common: fever, itching, nausea, runny nose, swelling, watery eyes, or wheezing

Drug allergy.overview:
Description
An abnormal reaction of the immune system to a medication.
In many cases, the allergic reaction is mild. Severe cases can lead to shock and may be life-threatening.
Hives, rash and fever are common symptoms.
Treatment involves discontinuing the medication that’s causing the reaction. Other medication can reduce the allergy symptoms, such as antihistamines. In severe cases, bronchodilators or adrenalin may be required.
Drug allergy.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Self-care.Avoid allergen: Staying away from triggers that can cause allergic reactions, such as pollen or certain foods.

Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Allergy & Immunology Doctor: Treats allergy and immune system disorders.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Dry eyes.symptomDescription: The eye may become dry, red and inflamed. The main symptoms are discomfort and sensitivity to light.

symptoms.Eyes: dryness, eye discomfort, feeling of something in eye, or redness
symptoms.Also common: sensitivity to light

Dry eyes.overview:
Description
Dry eye that occurs when tears aren't able to provide adequate moisture.
Risk of acquiring this condition increases with age. It's also seen more commonly among post-menopausal women.
The eye may become dry, red and inflamed. The main symptoms are discomfort and sensitivity to light.
Prescription and lubricating eye drops can reduce dryness.
Dry eyes.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Artificial tears: Moistens eyes to provide soothing relief.

Devices.Tear duct plug: A device used to block tear ducts in the eye to increase lubrication.
Devices.Glasses: A frame worn on the nose that holds a set of lenses to correct vision or protect the eyes.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy.symptomDescription: Symptoms include frequent falls, trouble getting up or running, waddling gait, big calves and learning disabilities.

symptoms.Muscular: abnormality walking, difficulty standing, muscle weakness, loss of muscle, or permanent shortening of muscle
symptoms.Also common: constantly walking on tip toe, difficulty swallowing, enlarged calves, fatigue, frequent falls, or scoliosis

Duchenne muscular dystrophy.overview:
Description
An inherited disorder of progressive muscular weakness, typically in boys.
Many people with muscular dystrophy have Duchenne syndrome. Girls can be carriers and mildly affected, but the disease typically affects boys.
Symptoms include frequent falls, trouble getting up or running, waddling gait, big calves and learning disabilities.
There is no cure, but physiotherapy and medication, such as corticosteroids, can help control symptoms and improve quality of life.
Duchenne muscular dystrophy.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Therapies.Occupational Therapy: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.

Dupuytren's contracture.symptomDescription: Over time, Dupuytren's contracture can cause one or more fingers to stay bent toward the palm. This can complicate everyday activities.

symptoms.Common symptoms: lump in the palm or bent finger

Dupuytren's contracture.overview:
Description
A gradual thickening and tightening of tissue under the skin in the hand.
The condition most often affects the 4th (ring) and 5th (little) fingers.
Over time, Dupuytren's contracture can cause one or more fingers to stay bent toward the palm. This can complicate everyday activities.
Treatment, if required, includes using a needle to break the tissue that's keeping the finger bent, enzyme injections to soften the tissue and surgery.
Dupuytren's contracture.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Devices.Splint: A rigid accessory used to stabilise and protect an injured joint.

Medication.Collagenase clostridium histolyticum: It can treat some skin disorders.

Medical procedure.Needle aponeurotomy: Using needles to straighten out fingers stuck in a bent position.

Surgery.Partial fasciectomy: Surgical removal of tightened tissue from the hand to straighten out the fingers.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Hand Surgeon: Performs surgery to treat hand conditions.

Dyslexia.symptomDescription: Symptoms include late talking, learning new words slowly and a delay in learning to read.

symptoms.Cognitive: difficulty memorising, difficulty spelling, or difficulty thinking and understanding
symptoms.Developmental: learning disability or speech delay in a child
symptoms.Also common: delayed reading ability, headache, or speech impairment

Dyslexia.overview:
Description
A learning disorder characterised by difficulty reading.
Dyslexia occurs in children with normal vision and intelligence.
Symptoms include late talking, learning new words slowly and a delay in learning to read.
Most children with dyslexia can succeed in school with tutoring or a specialised education programme.
Dyslexia.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required

Therapies.Individualized educational interventions: Tailoring education to an individual's learning needs, such as by making changes to their learning environment.
Therapies.Rehabilitation: Retraining the brain's pathways to improve mental and physical functioning after an illness or injury. For example, after a blow to the head (concussion).
Therapies.Occupational Therapy: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
Therapies.Counseling psychology: A branch of psychology that treats personal problems related to school, work, family and social life.

specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Dystonia.symptomDescription: The main symptom is involuntary muscle contractions that result in slow repetitive movements, cramps or abnormal posture.

symptoms.Muscular: cramping or involuntary movements
symptoms.Also common: eyelid twitching, torticollis, twisting movements, or voice box spasms

Dystonia.overview:
Description
Involuntary muscle contractions that cause repetitive or twisting movements.
Dystonia may affect one or more parts of the body and sometimes the entire body. The condition can be mild or severe.
The main symptom is involuntary muscle contractions that result in slow repetitive movements, cramps or abnormal posture.
Treatments may include drugs, injections and physiotherapy.
Dystonia.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Therapies.Sensory manoeuvres to interrupt dystonia: A position, manoeuvre or applied touch that can reduce the symptoms of dystonia.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medication.Muscle relaxant: Reduces muscle tension and helps relieve muscle pain and discomfort.
Medication.Neurotoxin: Reduces or eliminates muscle activity and spasms by paralysing muscles.
Medication.Dopamine promoter: Stimulates dopamine receptors in the brain.
Medication.Anti-Tremor: Helps control tremor, shaking and unsteadiness.
Medication.Sedative: Causes drowsiness, calmness and dulled senses. Some types may become addictive.

specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Ear infections.symptomDescription: Ear pain and fever are common symptoms. Less commonly, there may be drainage of fluid from the ear or hearing loss.

symptoms.Whole body: fever, loss of appetite, or vertigo
symptoms.Also common: crying, headache, nasal congestion, or nausea

Ear infections.overview:
Description
An infection of the air-filled space behind the eardrum (the middle ear).
An ear infection is usually caused by bacteria or viruses.
Ear pain and fever are common symptoms. Less commonly, there may be drainage of fluid from the ear or hearing loss.
Most ear infections go away on their own. Some require antibiotics.
Ear infections.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Local anesthetic: Blocks pain at and near the site where it's given, or along the nerve that's blocked.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

Devices.Tympanostomy tube: A tube inserted into the eardrum to equalise pressure and prevent fluid from accumulating.

specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Early menopause.symptomDescription: Symptoms include irregular periods, hot flushes, irritability and infertility.

symptoms.Menstrual: absence of menstruation, irregular menstruation, or infrequent menstruation
symptoms.Whole body: hot flashes, fatigue, or night sweats
symptoms.Also common: infertility, insomnia, irritability, mood swings, sexual dysfunction, or vaginal dryness

Early menopause.overview:
Description
A loss of normal function of the ovaries before the age 40.
In early menopause, the ovaries don't produce normal amounts of the hormone oestrogen or release eggs regularly. Infertility is common. However, it's possible a woman with this condition could get pregnant with treatment.
Symptoms include irregular periods, hot flushes, irritability and infertility.
Treatment includes hormone therapy and supplements to help prevent osteoporosis.
Early menopause.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.
Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Eclampsia.symptomDescription: Symptoms that signal an increasing risk of eclampsia include upper-right abdominal pain, severe headache and vision and mental status changes.

symptoms.Also common: seizures, pregnancy-induced hypertension, fainting, fetal distress, headache, mental status changes, overactive reflexes, swelling, swelling in extremities, or vision disorder

Eclampsia.overview:
Description
Seizures that occur during a woman's pregnancy or shortly after giving birth.
Eclampsia can follow a condition of high blood pressure and excess protein in the urine during pregnancy (preeclampsia).
Symptoms that signal an increasing risk of eclampsia include upper-right abdominal pain, severe headache and vision and mental status changes.
Medication can treat and prevent seizures and reduce high blood pressure. The baby may need to be delivered early.
Eclampsia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Surgery.Caesarean section: Surgical delivery of a baby through the mother's abdomen. Often done when vaginal delivery would be difficult or dangerous.

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.
Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Medical procedure.Labor induction: Artificially bringing on labour (uterine contractions) so that a pregnant woman delivers her baby.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Maternal-Foetal Medicine Specialist: Focuses on the medical management of high-risk pregnancies.
specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Ectopic pregnancy.symptomDescription: Symptoms include pelvic pain and vaginal bleeding.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the pelvis, abdomen, or side part of the body
symptoms.Also common: abnormal vaginal bleeding or cramping

Ectopic pregnancy.overview:
Description
A pregnancy in which the fertilised egg implants outside the uterus.
The fertilised egg can't survive outside the uterus. If left to grow, it may damage nearby organs and cause life-threatening loss of blood.
Symptoms include pelvic pain and vaginal bleeding.
To prevent complications, treatment is required. In the early stages, medication may be sufficient. Later stages require surgery.
Ectopic pregnancy.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.

Surgery.Laparoscopic surgery: Surgery that uses a video camera and thin tubes inserted into small cuts on the body to repair or remove tissue.

Medical procedure.Vacuum aspiration: Removing the contents of the womb (uterus) through a hollow needle or narrow tube.
Medical procedure.Dilation and evacuation: Expanding the entrance to the womb (cervix) and then removing the womb's contents by scraping and vacuuming.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Ehlers-Danlos syndromes.symptomDescription: Symptoms include overly flexible joints that can dislocate, and skin that's translucent, elastic and bruises easily. In some cases, there may be dilation and even rupture of major blood vessels.

symptoms.Also common: bleeding, double jointed, easy bruising, heart murmur, joint dislocation, muscle weakness, physical deformity, poor wound healing, or wrinkles

Ehlers-Danlos syndromes.overview:
Description
A group of inherited disorders that mostly affect the skin, joints and blood vessels.
Ehlers-Danlos syndrome affects connective tissue, primarily the skin, joints and blood vessel walls.
Symptoms include overly flexible joints that can dislocate, and skin that's translucent, elastic and bruises easily. In some cases, there may be dilation and even rupture of major blood vessels.
Treatment helps manage symptoms and monitor for complications. Options include drugs, physiotherapy and sometimes surgery.
Ehlers-Danlos syndromes.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Vascular Surgeon: Specialises in surgery for vascular system diseases.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Encephalitis.extraName: Also called: inflammation of the brain
Encephalitis.symptomDescription: Mild cases may cause no symptoms or mild flu-like symptoms. Severe cases can be life-threatening. Immediate medical attention is required for symptoms such as confusion, hallucinations, seizures, weakness and loss of sensation.

symptoms.Muscular: muscle weakness, problems with coordination, rhythmic muscle contractions, or unsteady gait
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, fever, loss of appetite, or malaise
symptoms.Cognitive: altered level of consciousness, disorientation, or mental confusion
symptoms.Also common: irritability, light sensitivity, headache, stiff neck, reduced sensation of touch, or seizures

Encephalitis.overview:
Description
Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection.
The infection may be bacterial or viral. In some cases, encephalitis may be the result of an immune system disorder.
Mild cases may cause no symptoms or mild flu-like symptoms. Severe cases can be life-threatening. Immediate medical attention is required for symptoms such as confusion, hallucinations, seizures, weakness and loss of sensation.
In addition to addressing the underlying cause, treatments include symptomatic relief and supportive care.
Encephalitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Spreads by animals or insects
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care
HOW IT SPREADS
By animal or insect bites or stings.

Medication.Anticonvulsant: Prevents or controls seizures, relieves pain and treats symptoms of certain psychiatric disorders.

Supportive care.Fluid replacement: Replacing fluids lost through sweating, bleeding, vomiting or diarrhoea to treat or prevent dehydration.
Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.

specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Encephalopathy.symptomDescription: Declining ability to reason and concentrate, memory loss, personality change, seizures and twitching are common symptoms.

symptoms.Cognitive: altered level of consciousness, amnesia, inability to speak or understand language, lack of concentration, mental confusion, or slowness in activity
symptoms.Muscular: problems with coordination, rhythmic muscle contractions, rhythmic muscle spasm, or overactive reflexes
symptoms.Whole body: fainting or fatigue
symptoms.Also common: abnormal breathing pattern, coma, delirium, flapping hand tremor, personality change, rapid involuntary eye movement, or seizures with no outward symptoms

Encephalopathy.overview:
Description
A broad term for any brain disease that alters brain function or structure.
Causes include infection, tumour and stroke.
Declining ability to reason and concentrate, memory loss, personality change, seizures and twitching are common symptoms.
Treatment, such as anti-seizure medication, may help manage some symptoms. Antiviral medication may be used to treat encephalitis caused by a viral infection.
Encephalopathy.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Ammonia reducer: Reduces the amount of ammonia in the body.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.

Medical procedure.Hemodialysis: Using a machine and a special filter to clean the blood when the kidneys can no longer do it.

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Hepatologist: Focuses on liver, gallbladder and biliary tree disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Endocarditis.extraName: Also called: inflammation of the heart valve
Endocarditis.symptomDescription: Symptoms vary based on the severity of the infection, but may include fevers, chills and fatigue.

symptoms.Whole body: fever, chills, fatigue, malaise, or night sweats
symptoms.Also common: heart murmur

Endocarditis.overview:
Description
An infection of the heart's inner lining, usually involving the heart valves.
Endocarditis usually occurs when germs from elsewhere in the body travel through the blood and attach to damaged areas of the heart. People with damaged or artificial heart valves or other heart conditions are most at risk.
Symptoms vary based on the severity of the infection, but may include fevers, chills and fatigue.
The main treatment is antibiotics. Sometimes surgery is required.
Endocarditis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.

Surgery.Valve replacement: Surgical replacement of a diseased or damaged heart valve. The new valve may be mechanical or biological tissue from an animal or human donor.

specialists.Cardiothoracic Surgeon: Surgically treats diseases affecting organs inside the chest.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.

Endometriosis.symptomDescription: The most common symptoms are pain and menstrual irregularities.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the lower abdomen, lower back, pelvis, rectum, or vagina
symptoms.Pain circumstances: can occur during sexual intercourse or while defecating
symptoms.Menstrual: abnormal menstruation, heavy menstruation, irregular menstruation, painful menstruation, or spotting
symptoms.Also common: infertility

Endometriosis.overview:
Description
A disorder in which tissue that normally lines the uterus grows outside the uterus.
With endometriosis, the tissue can be found on the ovaries, fallopian tubes or the intestines.
The most common symptoms are pain and menstrual irregularities.
Effective treatments, such as hormones and excision surgery, are available.
Endometriosis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

Self-care.Heating pad: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.

Surgery.Electrosurgery: Using electric current to cut tissue and control bleeding during surgery.
Surgery.Laparoscopic surgery: Surgery that uses a video camera and thin tubes inserted into small cuts on the body to repair or remove tissue.

Medical procedure.Cauterization: Burning or freezing a part of the body to remove tissue or stop bleeding. For example, to seal off a wound and prevent blood loss.
Medical procedure.Ablation: Removal of tissue using lasers, radiofrequency (RF) waves, focused ultrasound, heat or cold.
Medical procedure.Electrocoagulation: Using electric current to seal blood vessels and stop bleeding.
Medical procedure.Endometrial ablation: Surgical removal of the lining of womb (uterus) to reduce heavy menstrual flow.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Epilepsy.symptomDescription: During a seizure, a person experiences abnormal behaviour, symptoms and sensations, sometimes including loss of consciousness. There are few symptoms between seizures.

symptoms.Whole body: fainting or fatigue
symptoms.Muscular: rhythmic muscle contractions or muscle spasms
symptoms.Sensory: aura or pins and needles
symptoms.Also common: seizures, amnesia, anxiety, depression, or staring spells

Epilepsy.overview:
Description
A disorder in which nerve cell activity in the brain is disturbed, causing seizures.
Epilepsy may occur as a result of a genetic disorder or an acquired brain injury, such as a trauma or stroke.
During a seizure, a person experiences abnormal behaviour, symptoms and sensations, sometimes including loss of consciousness. There are few symptoms between seizures.
Epilepsy is usually treated by medication and in some cases by surgery, devices or dietary changes.
Epilepsy.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging often required

Medication.Nerve pain medication: Blocks pain caused by damaged nerves.
Medication.Sedative: Causes drowsiness, calmness and dulled senses. Some types may become addictive.
Medication.Anticonvulsant: Prevents or controls seizures, relieves pain and treats symptoms of certain psychiatric disorders.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Erectile dysfunction (impotence).symptomDescription: The main symptom is a man's inability to get or keep an erection firm enough for sexual intercourse.

symptoms.Sexual: sexual dysfunction or reduced sex drive
symptoms.Also common: soft erections, trouble getting an erection, trouble maintaining an erection, or anxiety

Erectile dysfunction (impotence).overview:
Description
Occurs when a man can't get or keep an erection firm enough for sexual intercourse.
Erectile dysfunction can be a sign of a physical or psychological condition. It can cause stress, relationship strain and low self-confidence.
The main symptom is a man's inability to get or keep an erection firm enough for sexual intercourse.
Patients suffering from erectile dysfunction should first be evaluated for any underlying physical and psychological conditions. If treatment of the underlying conditions doesn't help, medication and assistive devices, such as pumps, can be prescribed.
Erectile dysfunction (impotence).notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Erythema nodosum.symptomDescription: Symptoms include flat, firm, hot, red and painful lumps that usually appear on the shins. Later, they may fade and look more like a bruise and then resolve on their own.

symptoms.Whole body: fever or malaise
symptoms.Also common: flat, firm, hot, red, and painful lumps or inflammatory nodules of the leg

Erythema nodosum.overview:
Description
A painful disorder characterised by tender bumps (nodules) under the skin.
Erythema nodosum is an inflammatory disorder. In many cases, the cause is unknown. In some cases, it may be triggered by strep throat or other infections.
Symptoms include flat, firm, hot, red and painful lumps that usually appear on the shins. Later, they may fade and look more like a bruise and then resolve on their own.
Any underlying infections or conditions need to be treated. Medication can treat pain associated with the rash.
Erythema nodosum.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Rest: Reducing activity for a short period of time following an injury to promote healing.

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Esophageal cancer.symptomDescription: Symptoms include trouble swallowing, unintentional weight loss, chest pain, worsening indigestion or heartburn and coughing or hoarseness.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: dark stool from digested blood, heartburn, indigestion, nausea, or vomiting blood
symptoms.Also common: difficulty swallowing, iron deficiency anaemia, loss of appetite, or weight loss

Esophageal cancer.overview:
Description
Cancer of the tube that runs from the throat to the stomach (oesophagus).
Smoking and poorly controlled acid reflux are significant risk factors for oesophageal cancer.
Symptoms include trouble swallowing, unintentional weight loss, chest pain, worsening indigestion or heartburn and coughing or hoarseness.
Treatment focuses on removing the cancer through surgery. Chemotherapy and radiation may also be used.
Esophageal cancer.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Surgery.Esophagogastrectomy: Surgical removal of part of the oesophagus and stomach.
Surgery.Gastrostomy: Surgical insertion of a tube through the abdomen and into the stomach. Used for feeding or drainage.
Surgery.Esophagectomy: Surgical removal of all or part of the oesophagus.

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.

Medical procedure.Teletherapy: Radiation therapy that uses x-rays or other high-energy beams to destroy cancer cells and shrink tumours.
Medical procedure.PEG: Using a lighted medical instrument (endoscope) to insert a feeding tube through the abdominal wall and into the stomach.

Supportive care.Palliative care: Works to improve quality of life while adjusting or recovering from a serious illness.

specialists.Palliative Medicine: Focuses on improving quality of life for those with severe illnesses.
specialists.Radiation Oncologist: Treats and manages cancer by prescribing radiation therapy.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Esophageal varices.symptomDescription: Usually there are no symptoms unless the veins bleed. Symptoms of bleeding oesophageal varices include vomiting blood, tar-like or bloody stools and, in severe cases, shock.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: bloating, blood in stool, dark stool from digested blood, or vomiting blood
symptoms.Also common: bleeding, difficulty swallowing, enlarged veins around belly button, flapping hand tremor, or web of swollen blood vessels in the skin

Esophageal varices.overview:
Description
Abnormal veins in the lower part of the tube running from the throat to the stomach.
Oesophageal varices usually develop when blood flow to the liver is blocked. They often occur in people with advanced liver disease.
Usually there are no symptoms unless the veins bleed. Symptoms of bleeding oesophageal varices include vomiting blood, tar-like or bloody stools and, in severe cases, shock.
Treatments include beta blockers, medical procedures to stop bleeding, and in rare cases, liver transplant.
Esophageal varices.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.
Medication.Synthetic hormones: Regulates the activity of the organs and tissues in the body.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.

Medical procedure.Nasogastric intubation: Inserting a tube in the nose to carry food and medicine down the throat and into the stomach.
Medical procedure.Rubber band ligation: Tying off a dilated or bleeding blood vessel with a rubber band to block its blood supply. This causes it to dry up and fall off.
Medical procedure.Sclerotherapy: Injecting a salt water solution into abnormal blood vessels or tissues. This causes them to collapse and fade away.
Medical procedure.Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic: Placing a tube (stent) in the liver to relieve a backup of blood in the veins.
Medical procedure.Balloon tamponade: Using an inflated balloon to stop bleeding inside the throat, stomach or womb.
Medical procedure.Therapeutic endoscopy: Using a lighted medical instrument to see inside the body and provide treatment. For example, to stop bleeding or remove a foreign object.

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

specialists.Hepatologist: Focuses on liver, gallbladder and biliary tree disorders.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Interventional Radiologist: Uses image-guided procedures to diagnose and treat diseases.

Esophagitis.symptomDescription: Oesophagitis often causes painful, difficult swallowing and chest pain with eating. Emergency symptoms include food stuck in the oesophagus and chest pain that lasts more than a few minutes.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the chest or upper abdomen
symptoms.Gastrointestinal: heartburn, belching, nausea, regurgitation, or vomiting
symptoms.Also common: coughing

Esophagitis.overview:
Description
Inflammation that damages the tube running from the throat to the stomach (oesophagus).
Causes include stomach acids backing up into the tube, infection, some medication and allergies.
Oesophagitis often causes painful, difficult swallowing and chest pain with eating. Emergency symptoms include food stuck in the oesophagus and chest pain that lasts more than a few minutes.
Treatment depends on the cause, and can include medication and surgery. In some cases, lifestyle changes may also help.
Esophagitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Antifungal: Kills or prevents growth of fungi.
Medication.Proton-pump inhibitor: Decreases acid release in the stomach.
Medication.Antacid: Counteracts the effects of stomach acid.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Eye injury.symptomDescription: Symptoms vary depending on the type of injury, but may include eye pain, eye redness or discomfort when moving the eye.

symptoms.Visual: vision disorder or vision loss
symptoms.Eyes: dilated pupil or redness
symptoms.Also common: black eye, bleeding, or swelling

Eye injury.overview:
Description
A broad term used to describe a physical or chemical wound to the eye or eye socket.
Most commonly, this occurs when something scratches the eye. Exposure of the eye to toxic chemicals or major trauma can cause more severe eye injury.
Symptoms vary depending on the type of injury, but may include eye pain, eye redness or discomfort when moving the eye.
Treatment varies based on the severity and type of injury. Most cases should be evaluated by a doctor. Chemical injuries require immediate attention.
Eye injury.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Medical procedure.Removal of foreign body: Reduces risk of infection or long-term damage.

Self-care.Eye flushing: Removes toxins and soothes the eye.

Devices.Eyepatch: A covering used to protect the eye from injury.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Eye web.symptomDescription: The painless growth may be slightly raised and contain obvious blood vessels. It may cause irritation and possibly affect vision.

symptoms.Eyes: eye discomfort, growth in the eye, irritation, or redness
symptoms.Also common: blurred vision

Eye web.overview:
Description
A growth that starts on the clear tissue of the eye that can spread to the cornea.
The noncancerous, triangular growth may occur on one or both eyes. It's more common in people who spend a lot of time in the sun, such as those who work outdoors.
The painless growth may be slightly raised and contain obvious blood vessels. It may cause irritation and possibly affect vision.
Treatment usually isn't necessary. Eye drops or surgery may help in severe cases.
Eye web.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Artificial tears: Moistens eyes to provide soothing relief.
Self-care.Sunglasses: Protects the eyes from sunlight, which can cause or worsen some eye conditions.

Farsighted.symptomDescription: People with hyperopia must squint to see nearby objects. Reading, writing, computer work or drawing for long periods of time may cause eye strain and headache.

symptoms.Visual: blurred vision, vision disorder, or distorted vision
symptoms.Eyes: eye strain or squinting
symptoms.Also common: headache

Farsighted.overview:
Description
A vision condition in which nearby objects are blurry.
Hyperopia is a common vision condition in adults.
People with hyperopia must squint to see nearby objects. Reading, writing, computer work or drawing for long periods of time may cause eye strain and headache.
Treatment options include glasses, contact lenses and surgery such as LASIK.
Farsighted.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Devices.Glasses: A frame worn on the nose that holds a set of lenses to correct vision or protect the eyes.
Devices.Contact lenses: A lens placed directly on the eye to correct or assist with vision.

Medical procedure.LASIK: Laser surgery that reshapes and removes tissue from the front of the eye (cornea) to correct vision.

Fetal alcohol syndrome.extraName: Also called: FAS, fetal alcohol effects
Fetal alcohol syndrome.symptomDescription: Distinctive facial features, learning disabilities, bone and joint deformities, heart defects and hyperactivity are some symptoms.

symptoms.Developmental: delayed development, failure to thrive, learning disability, low birth weight, short stature, or slow growth
symptoms.Behavioural: aggression, antisocial behaviour, hyperactivity, impulsivity, or irritability
symptoms.Also common: misshapen face, anxiety, congenital heart disease, hearing loss, intellectual disability, malnutrition, poor coordination, single line on palm, speech impairment, or vision disorder

Fetal alcohol syndrome.overview:
Description
Physical and mental damage in a child due to alcohol exposure while in the womb.
This condition can be prevented by abstaining from alcohol during pregnancy.
Distinctive facial features, learning disabilities, bone and joint deformities, heart defects and hyperactivity are some symptoms.
The syndrome is irreversible. Treatment, especially if early, can help reduce some symptoms.
Fetal alcohol syndrome.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Counseling psychology: A branch of psychology that treats personal problems related to school, work, family and social life.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Paediatric Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats children in intensive care.
specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Maternal-Foetal Medicine Specialist: Focuses on the medical management of high-risk pregnancies.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Fibrocystic breast disease.symptomDescription: Symptoms include a change in breast texture, pain, tenderness and lumpiness. These may be more bothersome before a period.

symptoms.Also common: change in breast texture or swelling

Fibrocystic breast disease.overview:
Description
Non-cancerous changes that give a breast a lumpy or ropelike texture.
The condition is likely to be due to hormone changes during the menstrual cycle that affect breast tissue.
Symptoms include a change in breast texture, pain, tenderness and lumpiness. These may be more bothersome before a period.
Most fibrocystic breast changes are normal. Medical evaluation is required for new changes.
Fibrocystic breast disease.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Self-care.Warm compress: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.
Self-care.Support bra: An undergarment that supports a women's breasts.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Fibroids.symptomDescription: Symptoms include heavy menstrual bleeding, prolonged periods and pelvic pain. In some cases, there are no symptoms.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the abdomen, lower back, or pelvis
symptoms.Menstrual: abnormal menstruation, heavy menstruation, irregular menstruation, painful menstruation, or spotting
symptoms.Also common: abdominal distension or cramping

Fibroids.overview:
Description
Non-cancerous growths in the uterus that can develop during a woman's childbearing years.
The cause of fibroids isn't well understood. Risk factors include a family history of fibroids, obesity or early onset of puberty.
Symptoms include heavy menstrual bleeding, prolonged periods and pelvic pain. In some cases, there are no symptoms.
Treatments include medication and removal of the fibroid.
Fibroids.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Devices.Progestin IUD: A small plastic device placed inside the womb (uterus) that releases a hormone (progestogen) to prevent pregnancy.

Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.
Medication.Sex hormone suppression: Stops or slows the production of hormones involved in sexual health.

Surgery.Uterine myomectomy: Surgical removal of non-cancerous tumours (fibroids) in the womb (uterus).
Surgery.Laparoscopic surgery: Surgery that uses a video camera and thin tubes inserted into small cuts on the body to repair or remove tissue.

Medical procedure.Ablation: Removal of tissue using lasers, radiofrequency (RF) waves, focused ultrasound, heat or cold.
Medical procedure.Uterine artery embolization: Procedure to seal off blood vessels in the womb (uterus) to control heavy bleeding and shrink abnormal growths.
Medical procedure.Endometrial ablation: Surgical removal of the lining of womb (uterus) to reduce heavy menstrual flow.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Fibromyalgia.symptomDescription: Widespread muscle pain and tenderness are the most common symptoms.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the muscles, abdomen, back, or neck
symptoms.Pain types: can be chronic, diffuse, sharp, or severe
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, feeling tired, or malaise
symptoms.Muscular: muscle tenderness, delayed onset muscle soreness, or muscle spasms
symptoms.Gastrointestinal: constipation, nausea, or passing excessive amounts of gas
symptoms.Mood: anxiety, mood swings, or nervousness
symptoms.Cognitive: forgetfulness or lack of concentration
symptoms.Sensory: pins and needles or sensitivity to pain
symptoms.Sleep: difficulty falling asleep or sleep disturbances
symptoms.Also common: depression, flare, headache, irritability, joint stiffness, painful menstruation, sensitivity to cold, or tingling feet

Fibromyalgia.overview:
Description
Widespread muscle pain and tenderness.
Fibromyalgia is often accompanied by fatigue and altered sleep, memory and mood.
Widespread muscle pain and tenderness are the most common symptoms.
Medication, talk therapy and stress reduction may help in controlling the symptoms.
Fibromyalgia.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Stress management: Pursuing an enjoyable activity or verbalising frustration to reduce stress and improve mental health.
Self-care.Relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, meditation, yoga, rhythmic exercise and other activities that reduce symptoms of stress
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Biofeedback: Controlling the body's heartbeat, brainwaves, breathing and blood pressure by monitoring them with sensors.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Hydrotherapy: Using water to relieve pain, treat diseases and maintain health. For example, mineral baths and hot tubs.
Therapies.Chiropractic treatment techniques: Adjusting the spine and massaging the back muscles to relieve pain.
Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Graded exercise therapy: Physical exercise that starts very slowly and gradually increases over time.
Therapies.Acupuncture: Insertion of needles into specific points on the body to relieve pain and treat other conditions. A form of traditional Chinese medicine.

Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Nerve pain medication: Blocks pain caused by damaged nerves.
Medication.Muscle relaxant: Reduces muscle tension and helps relieve muscle pain and discomfort.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Flat feet.symptomDescription: Most people have no symptoms associated with flat feet. But some people with flat feet experience foot pain, particularly in the heel or arch area.
Flat feet.overview:
Description
A condition in which the entire sole of the foot touches the floor when standing.
Flat feet can occur during childhood if the arches of the feet don't develop, after an injury or from the wear and tear of ageing.
Most people have no symptoms associated with flat feet. But some people with flat feet experience foot pain, particularly in the heel or arch area.
For painful flat feet, treatments include arch supports for the shoes, stretching or a structurally supportive shoe.
Flat feet.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Devices.Brace: A device applied to the body to help stabilise, protect or limit movement of a damaged joint.

Supportive care.Monitoring: Regular follow-up to evaluate for improvement.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.

specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Flu.symptomDescription: Symptoms include fever, chills, muscle aches, cough, congestion, runny nose, headaches and fatigue.

symptoms.Cough: can be dry or with phlegm
symptoms.Whole body: chills, dehydration, fatigue, fever, flushing, loss of appetite, body ache, or sweating
symptoms.Also common: chest pressure, head congestion, headache, nausea, shortness of breath, sore throat, or swollen lymph nodes

Flu.overview:
Description
A common viral infection that can be deadly, especially in high-risk groups.
The flu attacks the lungs, nose and throat. Young children, older adults, pregnant women and people with chronic disease or weak immune systems are at high risk.
Symptoms include fever, chills, muscle aches, cough, congestion, runny nose, headaches and fatigue.
Flu is primarily treated with rest and fluid intake to allow the body to fight the infection on its own. Paracetamol may help cure the symptoms but NSAIDs should be avoided. An annual vaccine can help prevent the flu and limit its complications.
Flu.notes:
Spreads easily
Partly preventable by vaccine
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Supportive care.Fluid replacement: Replacing fluids lost through sweating, bleeding, vomiting or diarrhoea to treat or prevent dehydration.

Self-care.Bed rest: Reducing activity for a short period of time following injury or illness to promote healing.

Medication.Decongestant: Relieves nasal congestion, swelling and runny nose.
Medication.Cough medicine: Blocks the cough reflex. Some may thin and loosen mucus, making it easier to clear from the airways.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Folliculitis.extraName: Also called: inflammation of hair follicles
Folliculitis.symptomDescription: Small, white-headed pimples appear around the hair follicles. They may itch or be painful. Severe infections can cause permanent hair loss and scarring.

symptoms.Skin: blister, rashes, stinging, pimples, or redness
symptoms.Also common: itching, pus, or swelling

Folliculitis.overview:
Description
Infection of one or more of the pockets from which hair grows (follicles).
Folliculitis may be more common among those with acne. Shaving and use of topical steroid creams can also increase the risk of developing this condition.
Small, white-headed pimples appear around the hair follicles. They may itch or be painful. Severe infections can cause permanent hair loss and scarring.
Mild cases often clear on their own. Antibiotics or other drugs may be required for severe cases.
Folliculitis.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Antibacterial soap: Cleanses skin and reduces risk of infection.
Self-care.Warm compress: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.
Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Topical antiseptic: Destroys or prevents the growth of microorganisms on the skin that may cause infection.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Fragile X syndrome.symptomDescription: Symptoms include delays in talking, anxiety and hyperactive behaviour. Some people have seizures. Physical features might include large ears, a long face, a prominent jaw and forehead and flat feet.

symptoms.Behavioural: aggression, hyperactivity, impulsivity, nonsense word repetition, repetitive movements, self-harm, or persistent repetition of words or actions
symptoms.Developmental: learning disability or speech delay in a child
symptoms.Muscular: flaccid muscles or problems with coordination
symptoms.Also common: large ears, speech impairment, anxiety, double jointed, enlarged head, enlarged testicles, flat feet, lazy eye, long thin face, prominent jaw, scoliosis, single line on palm, sleep disorder, sunken chest, or tremor

Fragile X syndrome.overview:
Description
A genetic condition causing intellectual disability.
Fragile X syndrome causes mild to severe intellectual disability. It affects both males and females, but females usually have milder symptoms.
Symptoms include delays in talking, anxiety and hyperactive behaviour. Some people have seizures. Physical features might include large ears, a long face, a prominent jaw and forehead and flat feet.
Therapy can be used to treat learning disabilities. Medication may be used to treat anxiety and mood disorders.
Fragile X syndrome.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Therapies.Behaviour therapy: A therapy focused on modifying harmful behaviours associated with psychological distress.

Medication.Sedative: Causes drowsiness, calmness and dulled senses. Some types may become addictive.
Medication.Muscle relaxant: Reduces muscle tension and helps relieve muscle pain and discomfort.
Medication.Antipsychotic: Reduces or improves the symptoms of certain psychiatric conditions.
Medication.Cognition-enhancing medication: Improves mental function, lowers blood pressure and may balance mood.
Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Frostbite.symptomDescription: With frostbite, the skin gets very cold, then numb, hard and pale.

symptoms.Sensory: pins and needles, reduced sensation of touch, or stinging sensation
symptoms.Skin: blue skin from poor circulation, stinging, or redness
symptoms.Also common: blistering, feeling cold, or waxy skin

Frostbite.overview:
Description
A condition in which skin and the tissue just below the skin freeze.
Frostbite mostly affects small, exposed body parts such as fingers and toes.
With frostbite, the skin gets very cold, then numb, hard and pale.
Mild cases can be treated with gradual warming. Severe cases require medical care to prevent complications.
Frostbite.notes:
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Self-care.Warm soak: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.

Medical procedure.Skin rewarming: Improves blood flow to oxygen-deprived tissue.
Medical procedure.Removal of unhealthy tissue: Removal of dead, damaged or infected tissue from wounds to promote healing.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Supportive care.Warm IV fluids: Fluids that are warmed before injecting them into a vein to help raise the body temperature.
Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.
Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.

Surgery.Skin grafting: Surgically removing skin from one part of the body and transplanting it to another part. For example, to treat a serious burn or wound.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.
specialists.Hand Surgeon: Performs surgery to treat hand conditions.
specialists.Plastic Surgeon: Reconstructs defective, damaged or missing body parts.

Frozen shoulder.extraName: Also called: adhesive capsulitis of shoulder
Frozen shoulder.symptomDescription: Symptoms may start gradually and resolve within one or two years.

symptoms.Also common: decreased range of shoulder motion or joint stiffness

Frozen shoulder.overview:
Description
A condition characterised by stiffness and pain in the shoulder joint.
The condition occurs more commonly in people with diabetes and in people who've kept their arm immobilised for a long period of time.
Symptoms may start gradually and resolve within one or two years.
Treatment involves stretching and sometimes injecting corticosteroids and numbing medication into the joint capsule. In some cases, surgery is used to loosen the joint capsule.
Frozen shoulder.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Joint manipulation: Stretching a joint past its current restricted range of motion to restore movement and reduce pain.
Therapies.Chiropractic treatment techniques: Adjusting the spine and massaging the back muscles to relieve pain.
Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Medical procedure.Therapeutic ultrasound: Using heat and vibrations from sound waves to treat sprains, strains and other injuries.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
