specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.

Fungal infection.symptomDescription: Symptoms depend on the area affected, but can include skin rash or vaginal infection resulting in abnormal discharge.

symptoms.Skin: darkening of the skin, loss of colour, peeling, rashes, or small bump
symptoms.Also common: deformed toenail, itching, or vaginal discharge

Fungal infection.overview:
Description
Any disease caused by a fungus.
A fungus that invades the tissue can cause a disease that's confined to the skin, spreads into tissue, bones and organs or affects the whole body.
Symptoms depend on the area affected, but can include skin rash or vaginal infection resulting in abnormal discharge.
Treatments include antifungal medication.
Fungal infection.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Antifungal: Kills or prevents growth of fungi.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Medical Microbiologist: Focuses on the diagnosis and spread of infectious diseases.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Fungal nail infection.symptomDescription: The main symptoms are changes in the appearance of nails. Rarely, the condition causes pain or a slightly foul odour.
Fungal nail infection.overview:
Description
A nail fungus causing thickened, brittle, crumbly or ragged nails.
Usually, the problems caused by this condition are cosmetic.
The main symptoms are changes in the appearance of nails. Rarely, the condition causes pain or a slightly foul odour.
Treatments include oral anti-fungal drugs, medicated nail polish or cream or nail removal.
Fungal nail infection.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Antifungal: Kills or prevents growth of fungi.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

G6PD deficiency.symptomDescription: When symptoms are triggered, they include fever, dark urine, abdominal and back pain, fatigue and pale skin.

symptoms.Whole body: anaemia or fatigue
symptoms.Also common: dark urine, pallor, or yellow skin and eyes

G6PD deficiency.overview:
Description
A condition causing red blood cells to break down in response to certain medication, infections or other stresses.
Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is an inherited condition usually occurring in males. It's more common in those of African and Mediterranean descent. Triggers include infections, stress, fava beans, aspirin and other drugs.
When symptoms are triggered, they include fever, dark urine, abdominal and back pain, fatigue and pale skin.
Most people recover in a few days without treatment. However, patients are at risk of recurrent episodes, so avoidance of triggers is critical.
G6PD deficiency.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Avoidance of triggers: Reducing exposure to environmental factors that can contribute to disease.

specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.
specialists.Neonatologist: Provides medical care for newborn infants.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Gallstones.symptomDescription: Gallstones can vary in size and number and may or may not cause symptoms.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the back or upper-right abdomen
symptoms.Pain types: can be severe

Gallstones.overview:
Description
A hardened deposit within the fluid in the gallbladder, a small organ under the liver.
Gallstones are hardened deposits of digestive fluid.
Gallstones can vary in size and number and may or may not cause symptoms.
People who experience symptoms usually require gallbladder removal surgery. Gallstones that don't cause symptoms usually don't need treatment.
Gallstones.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Low fat diet: Reducing intake of high-fat foods such as dairy, oil and red meat to improve cardiovascular health.

Medication.Cholesterol medication: Lowers levels of harmful cholesterol in the blood or increases levels of beneficial cholesterol.

Surgery.Laparoscopic surgery: Surgery that uses a video camera and thin tubes inserted into small cuts on the body to repair or remove tissue.

specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Ganglion cyst.symptomDescription: A ganglion cyst is round, small and usually painless. Although rare, it can be painful if it presses a nerve. In a few cases, the cyst can interfere with joint movement.

symptoms.Also common: lump or pain in the affected area

Ganglion cyst.overview:
Description
A non-cancerous lump, often on the tendons or joints of wrists and hands.
The cause of ganglion cysts is unknown.
A ganglion cyst is round, small and usually painless. Although rare, it can be painful if it presses a nerve. In a few cases, the cyst can interfere with joint movement.
A ganglion cyst often clears on its own. If troublesome, it can be drained or removed.
Ganglion cyst.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Medical procedure.Fine-needle aspiration: Inserting a thin needle into the body to get a sample of cells or fluid. The sample is then examined under a microscope to check for disease.

Surgery.Ganglionectomy: Surgical removal of a ganglion cyst.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Hand Surgeon: Performs surgery to treat hand conditions.

Gangrene.symptomDescription: Symptoms include discoloured skin, severe pain followed by numbness and foul discharge.

symptoms.Skin: blister, blue skin from poor circulation, dark scab, discolouration, or ulcers
symptoms.Whole body: fever or low blood pressure
symptoms.Also common: creaky joints, foul-smelling discharge, pus, or reduced sensation of touch

Gangrene.overview:
Description
Dead tissue caused by an infection or lack of blood flow.
The death of tissue often occurs in the extremities or skin from loss of blood supply. The condition often affects toes, fingers and limbs, but can affect muscles and organs.
Symptoms include discoloured skin, severe pain followed by numbness and foul discharge.
Gangrene requires urgent care. Treatment includes antibiotics and removing dead tissue.
Gangrene.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.
Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.

Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

Medical procedure.Removal of unhealthy tissue: Removal of dead, damaged or infected tissue from wounds to promote healing.

Surgery.Skin grafting: Surgically removing skin from one part of the body and transplanting it to another part. For example, to treat a serious burn or wound.
Surgery.Fasciotomy: Surgical cutting of the connective tissue covering muscles (fascia) to relieve tension or pressure.

specialists.Vascular Surgeon: Specialises in surgery for vascular system diseases.
specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Vascular Medicine Doctor: Specialises in circulatory and lymphatic diseases.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Gastritis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include upper stomach pain, nausea and vomiting. Sometimes, there are no symptoms.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the abdomen or upper abdomen
symptoms.Gastrointestinal: belching, heartburn, indigestion, nausea, or vomiting
symptoms.Also common: loss of appetite

Gastritis.overview:
Description
Any of a group of conditions in which the stomach lining is inflamed.
Causes include infection, injury, regular use of pain pills called NSAIDs and too much alcohol.
Symptoms include upper stomach pain, nausea and vomiting. Sometimes, there are no symptoms.
Treatment depends on the cause. Antibiotics and antacids might help.
Gastritis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Antacid: Counteracts the effects of stomach acid.
Medication.Proton-pump inhibitor: Decreases acid release in the stomach.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Antidiarrhoeal: Reduces frequency and urgency of bowel movements.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Gastroparesis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include nausea and a full feeling after little food is eaten.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: nausea, belching, bloating, heartburn, indigestion, regurgitation, or vomiting
symptoms.Whole body: feeling full sooner than normal or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: postprandial fullness

Gastroparesis.overview:
Description
A condition that affects the stomach muscles and prevents proper stomach emptying.
Gastroparesis can affect digestion. The cause might be damage to a nerve that controls stomach muscles.
Symptoms include nausea and a full feeling after little food is eaten.
Diet changes and medication may offer relief.
Gastroparesis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Diet modification: Adjusting diet to reduce triggers causing disease or address dietary deficiencies.

Medication.Gut motility stimulator: Helps speed the movement of food through the stomach and intestines.
Medication.Antiemetic: Prevents or relieves nausea or vomiting.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Generalised anxiety disorder in adults.symptomDescription: The condition has symptoms similar to panic disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder and other types of anxiety. These symptoms include constant worry, restlessness and trouble with concentration.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, light-headedness, or sweating
symptoms.Behavioural: hypervigilance, irritability, or restlessness
symptoms.Cognitive: lack of concentration or unwanted thoughts
symptoms.Also common: emotional distress, excessive worry, difficulty falling asleep, headache, nausea, palpitations, repeatedly going over thoughts, or trembling

Generalised anxiety disorder in adults.overview:
Description
Severe, ongoing anxiety that interferes with daily activities.
Generalised anxiety disorder can occur at any age.
The condition has symptoms similar to panic disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder and other types of anxiety. These symptoms include constant worry, restlessness and trouble with concentration.
Treatment may include counselling and medication, such as antidepressants.
Generalised anxiety disorder in adults.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.
Medication.Anxiolytic: Relieves anxiety and tension. May promote sleep.
Medication.Antidepressant: Taking medications designed to help relieve symptoms of depression. Some antidepressants also have other uses, such as treating chronic pain and certain anxiety disorders.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, meditation, yoga, rhythmic exercise and other activities that reduce symptoms of stress
Self-care.Stress management: Pursuing an enjoyable activity or verbalising frustration to reduce stress and improve mental health.

Therapies.Mindfulness therapies: The act of turning your attention internally to help manage physical and mental symptoms.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Psychoanalysis: Uses psychotherapy to treat mental disorders.
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.

specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.

Genital herpes.symptomDescription: Pain, itching and small sores appear first. They form ulcers and scabs. After initial infection, genital herpes lies dormant in the body. Symptoms can recur for years.

symptoms.Also common: genital sores, sensation of pins and needles, or skin rash

Genital herpes.overview:
Description
A common sexually transmitted infection marked by genital pain and sores.
Caused by the herpes simplex virus, the disease can affect both men and women.
Pain, itching and small sores appear first. They form ulcers and scabs. After initial infection, genital herpes lies dormant in the body. Symptoms can recur for years.
Medication can be used to manage outbreaks.
Genital herpes.notes:
Spreads by sexual contact
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging often required
HOW IT SPREADS
By having unprotected vaginal, anal or oral sex.
By mother to baby by pregnancy, labour or nursing.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.

Genital warts.symptomDescription: The characteristic symptom is a small bump on the genitals.

symptoms.Common symptoms: warts and verrucas, itchiness around anus, itching, itching of vagina, or skin burning sensation

Genital warts.overview:
Description
A small bump on the genitals caused by a common sexually transmitted infection.
Genital warts are a common sexually transmitted infection caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV).
The characteristic symptom is a small bump on the genitals.
Vaccines can protect against many genital-wart-causing strains of HPV. Genital warts can be treated with prescription medication applied directly to the warts or can be surgically removed.
Genital warts.notes:
Spreads by sexual contact
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
HOW IT SPREADS
By having unprotected vaginal, anal or oral sex.
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Medical procedure.Cauterization: Burning or freezing a part of the body to remove tissue or stop bleeding. For example, to seal off a wound and prevent blood loss.
Medical procedure.Freezing: Using liquid nitrogen to freeze and remove a wart.

Medication.Topical anti-tumor medication: Treats skin cancer and other skin conditions.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Gestational diabetes.symptomDescription: In most cases, there are no symptoms. A blood sugar test during pregnancy is used for diagnosis.

symptoms.Whole body: excessive hunger, excessive thirst, or fatigue
symptoms.Also common: fetal macrosomia, frequent urination, or thrush in men and women

Gestational diabetes.overview:
Description
A form of high blood sugar affecting pregnant women.
Those who develop gestational diabetes are at higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes later in life.
In most cases, there are no symptoms. A blood sugar test during pregnancy is used for diagnosis.
Treatment strategies include daily blood sugar monitoring, a healthy diet, exercise and monitoring the baby. If blood sugar is too high, medication is required.
Gestational diabetes.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Healthy diet: A diet that provides essential nutrients and adequate calories, while avoiding excess sugar, carbohydrates and fatty foods.
Self-care.Diabetic diet: Diet that helps diabetics control their blood sugar (glucose) by reducing sugar and carbohydrates. For example, drinking less soda and eating less bread.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Medication.Anti-diabetic medication: Controls the amount of sugar (glucose) in the blood.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Maternal-Foetal Medicine Specialist: Focuses on the medical management of high-risk pregnancies.

Giardiasis.symptomDescription: Symptoms might include watery diarrhoea alternating with greasy stools. Fatigue, cramps and belching wind may also occur. Some people have no symptoms.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: diarrhoea, belching, bloating, fat in stool, indigestion, nausea, or passing excessive amounts of gas
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, loss of appetite, malaise, or malnutrition
symptoms.Also common: cramping, foul-smelling stool, or weight loss

Giardiasis.overview:
Description
An intestinal infection caused by a giardia parasite.
Giardiasis spreads through contaminated food or water or by person-to-person contact. It's most common in areas with poor sanitation and unsafe water.
Symptoms might include watery diarrhoea alternating with greasy stools. Fatigue, cramps and belching wind may also occur. Some people have no symptoms.
Most cases clear up on their own within a few weeks. Severe cases are treated with antibiotics.
Giardiasis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Spreads easily
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
Through contaminated food or water.
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.

Gilbert's syndrome.symptomDescription: The syndrome may cause the skin and the whites of the eyes to have a yellow tinge due to the build-up of bilirubin.

symptoms.Common symptoms: yellow skin and eyes

Gilbert's syndrome.overview:
Description
A mild condition in which the liver doesn't properly process bilirubin.
Gilbert's syndrome is an inherited condition that's often discovered by accident, such as when someone has a blood test. It occurs due to a defect in the processing of bilirubin by the liver.
The syndrome may cause the skin and the whites of the eyes to have a yellow tinge due to the build-up of bilirubin.
Gilbert's syndrome is typically harmless and treatment isn't required.
Gilbert's syndrome.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring: Regular follow-up to evaluate for improvement.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Glandular fever.symptomDescription: Symptoms include fatigue, fever, rash and swollen glands. The elderly may not have typical symptoms.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, fever, chills, malaise, or body ache
symptoms.Also common: sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, swollen tonsils, headache, or nausea

Glandular fever.overview:
Description
Often called mono or kissing disease, an infection with the Epstein-Barr virus.
Mono (glandular fever) is transmitted by saliva.
Symptoms include fatigue, fever, rash and swollen glands. The elderly may not have typical symptoms.
Treatment involves rest, fluids and over-the-counter pain and fever-reducing medicines to ease symptoms.
Glandular fever.notes:
Spreads by saliva
Usually self-treatable
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).

Supportive care.Fluid replacement: Replacing fluids lost through sweating, bleeding, vomiting or diarrhoea to treat or prevent dehydration.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Self-care.Bed rest: Reducing activity for a short period of time following injury or illness to promote healing.
Self-care.Activity restriction: Limiting activity to promote healing following illness or injury.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Glaucoma.symptomDescription: The most common type of glaucoma (open-angle glaucoma) often has no symptoms other than slow vision loss. Angle-closure glaucoma, although rare, is a medical emergency and its symptoms include eye pain with nausea and sudden visual disturbance.

symptoms.Visual: blurred vision, distorted vision, or vision loss

Glaucoma.overview:
Description
A group of eye conditions that can cause blindness.
With all types of glaucoma, the nerve connecting the eye to the brain is damaged, usually due to high eye pressure.
The most common type of glaucoma (open-angle glaucoma) often has no symptoms other than slow vision loss. Angle-closure glaucoma, although rare, is a medical emergency and its symptoms include eye pain with nausea and sudden visual disturbance.
Treatment includes eye drops, medication and surgery.
Glaucoma.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required

Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.

Surgery.Laser surgery: Surgery using an intensely hot and focused beam of light to remove tissue and control bleeding.

Medical procedure.Trabeculoplasty: Using a laser to improve fluid drainage in the eye and reduce eye pressure.

Goiter.symptomDescription: Not all goitres cause symptoms. Symptoms that do occur might include swelling and coughing. Rarely, symptoms may include throat tightness or trouble breathing.

symptoms.Also common: coughing, fast heart rate, inability to tolerate heat, shortness of breath, throat tightness, underactive thyroid, or weight gain

Goiter.overview:
Description
Abnormal enlargement of the butterfly-shaped gland below the Adam's apple (thyroid).
A goitre commonly develops as a result of iodine deficiency or inflammation of the thyroid gland.
Not all goitres cause symptoms. Symptoms that do occur might include swelling and coughing. Rarely, symptoms may include throat tightness or trouble breathing.
A small goitre that doesn't cause symptoms may not need treatment. In some cases, medication or surgery is required.
Goiter.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medical procedure.Radioactive iodine therapy: A radioactive medicine taken by mouth to reduce the functioning of the thyroid gland or completely destroy it.

Medication.Antithyroid agent: Prevents the thyroid gland from making or releasing thyroid hormone.
Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

Surgery.Thyroid removal: Surgical removal of all or part of the thyroid gland.
Surgery.Partial thyroidectomy: Surgical removal of part of the thyroid.

specialists.Nuclear Medicine Doctor: Applies radioactive substances to diagnose and treat disease.
specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.

Gonorrhoea.symptomDescription: Symptoms include painful urination and abnormal discharge from the penis or vagina. Men may experience testicular pain and women may experience pain in the lower stomach. In some cases, gonorrhoea has no symptoms.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the lower abdomen, pelvis, testicle, or vagina
symptoms.Pain circumstances: can occur during sexual intercourse or during urination
symptoms.Groin: abnormal vaginal discharge, discharge from penis, or increased vaginal discharge
symptoms.Also common: fever, frequent urge to urinate, irregular menstruation, pus, or sore throat

Gonorrhoea.overview:
Description
A sexually transmitted bacterial infection that, if untreated, may cause infertility.
Regular screening can help detect instances when an infection is present despite having no symptoms.
Symptoms include painful urination and abnormal discharge from the penis or vagina. Men may experience testicular pain and women may experience pain in the lower stomach. In some cases, gonorrhoea has no symptoms.
Gonorrhoea can be treated with antibiotics.
Gonorrhoea.notes:
Spreads by sexual contact
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
HOW IT SPREADS
By having unprotected vaginal, anal or oral sex.
By mother to baby by pregnancy, labour or nursing.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.

Gout.symptomDescription: Symptoms of gout include severe pain, redness and swelling in joints, often the big toe. Attacks can come suddenly, often at night.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the joints, ankle, foot, knee, or toe
symptoms.Also common: physical deformity or redness

Gout.overview:
Description
A form of arthritis characterised by severe pain, redness and tenderness in joints.
Pain and inflammation occur when too much uric acid crystallises and deposits in the joints.
Symptoms of gout include severe pain, redness and swelling in joints, often the big toe. Attacks can come suddenly, often at night.
During an acute attack, anti-inflammatory medication (NSAIDs) can help to relieve pain and shorten the duration of the attack. Patients with chronic gout can use behavioural modification such as diet, exercise and decreased intake of alcohol to help minimise the frequency of attacks. Additionally, patients with chronic gout are often put on medication to reduce uric acid levels.
Gout.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.
Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.

Medication.Uric acid reducer: Helps reduce production or increase elimination of uric acid.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms may include sinus pain, cough, fever, joint aches, blood in urine and hearing loss.

symptoms.Nasal: bleeding, congestion, or flattening of the nose
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or fever
symptoms.Respiratory: sinusitis or shortness of breath
symptoms.Also common: blood in urine, hearing loss, kidney failure, mouth ulcer, or unintentional weight loss

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis.overview:
Description
A condition that causes inflammation of the blood vessels.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis can affect the ears, nose, throat, lungs and kidneys. Blood flow to organs and tissues may be reduced, causing damage.
Symptoms may include sinus pain, cough, fever, joint aches, blood in urine and hearing loss.
Treatments include drugs that suppress the immune system and monitoring for recurring symptoms.
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Medical procedure.Hemodialysis: Using a machine and a special filter to clean the blood when the kidneys can no longer do it.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.

Graves' disease.symptomDescription: Symptoms include anxiety, hand tremor, heat sensitivity, weight loss, puffy eyes and enlarged thyroid.

symptoms.Whole body: excess sweating, fatigue, heat intolerance, or high blood pressure
symptoms.Heart: fast heart rate, irregular heart rate, or palpitations
symptoms.Mood: anxiety or nervousness
symptoms.Eyes: abnormal protrusion of eyes or puffy eyes
symptoms.Also common: absence of menstruation, diarrhoea, enlarged thyroid, hair loss, hand tremor, insomnia, irritability, muscle weakness, puffy skin changes on the shin, or weight loss

Graves' disease.overview:
Description
An immune system disorder of the butterfly-shaped gland in the throat (thyroid).
The thyroid overproduces hormones. The condition is more common in women under the age of 40.
Symptoms include anxiety, hand tremor, heat sensitivity, weight loss, puffy eyes and enlarged thyroid.
Treatment includes medication, radioiodine therapy and surgery
Graves' disease.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Antithyroid agent: Prevents the thyroid gland from making or releasing thyroid hormone.
Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.

Medical procedure.Radioactive iodine therapy: A radioactive medicine taken by mouth to reduce the functioning of the thyroid gland or completely destroy it.
Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

Surgery.Thyroid removal: Surgical removal of all or part of the thyroid gland.

specialists.Nuclear Medicine Doctor: Applies radioactive substances to diagnose and treat disease.

Groin hernia.symptomDescription: Symptoms include pain, especially when a person coughs, bends or lifts a heavy object.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the groin, pelvis, or testicle
symptoms.Pain circumstances: can occur while coughing or while lifting heavy objects
symptoms.Also common: swollen lymph nodes in the groin

Groin hernia.overview:
Description
A condition in which soft tissue bulges through a weak point in the abdominal muscles.
The soft tissue is often part of the intestine. It's easy to see and feel the bulge, although not all are visible by the patient, especially when obese.
Symptoms include pain, especially when a person coughs, bends or lifts a heavy object.
Treatment may not be necessary. If the hernia is growing or painful, surgery can repair it.
Groin hernia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Surgery.Hernia repair: Surgical repair of a weak spot on the abdominal wall so that the intestines can't push through.

Devices.Supportive device: A device applied over a hernia to reduce discomfort and push the bulging tissue back into the abdomen.

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.

Group B streptococcal infection.extraName: Also called: GBS, group B strep
Group B streptococcal infection.symptomDescription: Symptoms in newborns include fever, trouble feeding and lethargy. Adults who are immunocompromised may get a urinary tract or blood infection or pneumonia.

symptoms.Whole body: fever or lethargy
symptoms.Also common: low birth weight, pneumonia, skin rash, urinary tract infections (utis), or vaginal discharge

Group B streptococcal infection.overview:
Description
An infection caused by a common bacterium (group B streptococcus).
The infection is usually harmless in adults, but can be dangerous in newborns and adults with chronic conditions, such as diabetes or liver disease.
Symptoms in newborns include fever, trouble feeding and lethargy. Adults who are immunocompromised may get a urinary tract or blood infection or pneumonia.
Treatment includes antibiotics.
Group B streptococcal infection.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Spreads from mother to baby
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By mother to baby by pregnancy, labour or nursing.

Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Neonatologist: Provides medical care for newborn infants.

Gum disease.symptomDescription: Symptoms include swollen, red and tender gums.

symptoms.Mouth: bad breath, toothache, bright red gums, loose teeth, receding gums, tender gums, or tooth loss
symptoms.Also common: swelling or bleeding

Gum disease.overview:
Description
A serious gum infection that damages gums and can destroy the jawbone.
Periodontitis is common but fairly preventable. The cause is usually poor oral hygiene. Periodontitis can lead to tooth loss. It's a risk factor for heart and lung diseases.
Symptoms include swollen, red and tender gums.
Treatment includes professionally cleaning the pockets around teeth to prevent damage to surrounding bone. Advanced cases may require surgery.
Gum disease.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Tooth polishing: Using a gritty paste and rotating brush to remove stains on the surface of the teeth.
Self-care.Oral hygiene: Keeping the mouth clean by regularly brushing teeth, flossing and using mouthwash.

Medication.Topical antiseptic: Destroys or prevents the growth of microorganisms on the skin that may cause infection.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

Medical procedure.Removal of unhealthy tissue: Removal of dead, damaged or infected tissue from wounds to promote healing.

Surgery.Gingivectomy: Surgical removal of diseased gum tissue.
Surgery.Gingivoplasty: Surgery to reshape healthy gum tissue around the teeth.

specialists.Dentist: Specialises in diseases of the oral cavity, especially the teeth.

Gynecomastia.symptomDescription: Symptoms are breast tissue swelling and tenderness.

symptoms.Also common: overweight

Gynecomastia.overview:
Description
Swollen male breast tissue caused by a hormone imbalance.
Male breast tissue swells due to reduced male hormones (testosterone) or increased female hormones (oestrogen). Causes include puberty, ageing, medication and health conditions that affect hormones.
Symptoms are breast tissue swelling and tenderness.
Treatment may not be required in some cases. In other cases, treatment focuses on managing the underlying condition. Rarely, medical or surgical treatment is necessary.
Gynecomastia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

specialists.Adolescent Medicine Doctor: Provides comprehensive health care for adolescents.

HIV/AIDS.extraName: Also called: human immunodeficiency virus, acquired immunodeficiency syndrome
HIV/AIDS.symptomDescription: Within a few weeks of HIV infection, flu-like symptoms such as fever, sore throat and fatigue can occur. Then the disease is usually asymptomatic until it progresses to AIDS. AIDS symptoms include weight loss, fever or night sweats, fatigue and recurrent infections.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, fever, loss of appetite, malaise, night sweats, or sweating
symptoms.Gastrointestinal: nausea, persistent diarrhoea, vomiting, or watery diarrhoea
symptoms.Also common: opportunistic infection, headache, oral thrush (mouth thrush), pneumonia, red blotches, severe unintentional weight loss, skin rash, or swollen lymph nodes

HIV/AIDS.overview:
Description
HIV causes AIDS and interferes with the body's ability to fight infections.
The virus can be transmitted through contact with infected blood, semen or vaginal fluids.
Within a few weeks of HIV infection, flu-like symptoms such as fever, sore throat and fatigue can occur. Then the disease is usually asymptomatic until it progresses to AIDS. AIDS symptoms include weight loss, fever or night sweats, fatigue and recurrent infections.
No cure exists for AIDS, but strict adherence to antiretroviral regimens (ARVs) can dramatically slow the disease's progress as well as prevent secondary infections and complications.
HIV/AIDS.notes:
Spreads by sexual contact
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
HOW IT SPREADS
By blood products (unclean needles or unscreened blood).
By having unprotected vaginal, anal or oral sex.
By mother to baby by pregnancy, labour or nursing.

Medication.HIV antiviral: Suppresses HIV to slow progression of infection. Reduces the risk of infecting others.

specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.

Haemophilia.symptomDescription: Symptoms include many large or deep bruises, joint pain and swelling, unexplained bleeding and blood in urine or stool.

symptoms.Also common: bleeding, blood in stool, blood in urine, bruising, heavy or prolonged periods, internal bleeding, nosebleed, or swollen joint

Haemophilia.overview:
Description
A disorder in which blood doesn't clot normally.
When blood can't clot properly, excessive bleeding (external and internal) occurs after any injury or damage.
Symptoms include many large or deep bruises, joint pain and swelling, unexplained bleeding and blood in urine or stool.
Treatment includes injections of a clotting factor or plasma.
Haemophilia.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Clotting promoter: Helps form blood clots to reduce risk of excess bleeding.

specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.
specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Transfusion Medicine: Manages the transfusion of blood products and potential complications.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Hand, foot and mouth disease.symptomDescription: Symptoms include fever, sore throat, feeling unwell, irritability and loss of appetite.

symptoms.Whole body: dehydration, fatigue, fever, loss of appetite, or malaise
symptoms.Skin: blister, peeling, rashes, or red spots
symptoms.Also common: canker sore, coughing, headache, irritability, or sore throat

Hand, foot and mouth disease.overview:
Description
A common children's virus causing sores in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet.
The condition is spread by direct contact with saliva or mucus.
Symptoms include fever, sore throat, feeling unwell, irritability and loss of appetite.
The virus usually clears up on its own within 10 days. Pain medication may help to relieve symptoms.
Hand, foot and mouth disease.notes:
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Usually self-treatable
Spreads easily
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
HOW IT SPREADS
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Hashimoto's disease.symptomDescription: Symptoms include fatigue and unexplained weight gain.

symptoms.Skin: dryness or roughness
symptoms.Also common: constipation, depression, enlarged thyroid, fatigue, joint stiffness, muscle weakness, puffy eyes, sensitivity to cold, slow heart rate, swelling in extremities, or weight gain

Hashimoto's disease.overview:
Description
When the immune system attacks the butterfly-shaped gland in the neck (thyroid).
Initially, inflammation of the thyroid causes a leak resulting in excess thyroid hormones (hyperthyroidism). Over time, the inflammation prevents the thyroid from producing enough hormones (hypothyroidism).
Symptoms include fatigue and unexplained weight gain.
Treatment with synthetic hormone medication is usually effective.
Hashimoto's disease.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

Head and neck cancer.symptomDescription: Symptoms can occur in mouth, sinuses, nose or throat and include a sore or lump that doesn't heal, a persistent sore throat, trouble swallowing and changes in the voice.

symptoms.Also common: enlarged neck lymph nodes, hoarseness, or mouth ulcer

Head and neck cancer.overview:
Description
A group of cancers of the mouth, sinuses, nose or throat.
Smoking is a significant risk factor.
Symptoms can occur in mouth, sinuses, nose or throat and include a sore or lump that doesn't heal, a persistent sore throat, trouble swallowing and changes in the voice.
Treatments include surgery, radiation and chemotherapy.
Head and neck cancer.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.

Medical procedure.PEG: Using a lighted medical instrument (endoscope) to insert a feeding tube through the abdominal wall and into the stomach.
Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

Surgery.Laryngectomy: Surgical removal of all or part of the voice box (larynx) in the throat.
Surgery.Neck dissection: Surgical removal of lymph nodes in the neck.
Surgery.Flap surgery: Surgically moving tissue from one part of the body to another. Often done to repair a wound or rebuild damaged tissue.

specialists.Radiation Oncologist: Treats and manages cancer by prescribing radiation therapy.
specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.
specialists.Plastic Surgeon: Reconstructs defective, damaged or missing body parts.

Head lice and nits.symptomDescription: Symptoms include itching, visible lice on the scalp and lice eggs (nits) on the hair shafts.

symptoms.Common symptoms: itching or skin bumps

Head lice and nits.overview:
Description
A condition in which tiny insects infest the scalp.
Head lice most often affect children who are in direct contact with one another or who share personal items, such as brushes, hats or scarves.
Symptoms include itching, visible lice on the scalp and lice eggs (nits) on the hair shafts.
Medicated shampoos or combing and removing the nits from the hair is helpful.
Head lice and nits.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Wet combing: Using a specialised comb to remove lice from hair.

Hearing loss.symptomDescription: The chief symptom is an inability to hear sound.

symptoms.Common symptoms: hearing problem, ringing in the ears, sensitivity to sound, social isolation, or speech delay in a child

Hearing loss.overview:
Description
Total or significant loss of hearing.
Deafness is usually the result of inner ear or nerve damage. It may be caused by a congenital defect, injury, disease, certain medication, exposure to loud noise or age-related wear and tear.
The chief symptom is an inability to hear sound.
For some, hearing may be possible with surgery or a hearing device. Lip-reading skills, written or printed text and sign language may help with communication.
Hearing loss.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
COMMON CAUSES
Hearing loss can have causes that aren't due to underlying disease. Examples include too much ear wax, loud or prolonged noise exposure, ageing, getting an object stuck in the ear or medication side effects.

Devices.Cochlear implant: A device surgically implanted in the ear that enables a deaf person to hear sounds.
Devices.Hearing aid: A device applied to the outer ear to amplify sound and improve hearing.

specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.
specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.

Heart attack.symptomDescription: Symptoms include tightness or pain in the chest, neck, back or arms, as well as fatigue, lightheadedness, abnormal heartbeat and anxiety. Women are more likely to have atypical symptoms than men.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the area between shoulder blades, arm, chest, jaw, left arm, or upper abdomen
symptoms.Pain types: can be like a clenched fist in the chest
symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, light-headedness, clammy skin, cold sweat, or sweating
symptoms.Also common: anxiety, chest pressure, feeling of impending doom, palpitations, shortness of breath, or shoulder discomfort

Heart attack.overview:
Description
A blockage of blood flow to the heart muscle.
A heart attack is a medical emergency. A heart attack usually occurs when a blood clot blocks blood flow to the heart. Without blood, tissue loses oxygen and dies.
Symptoms include tightness or pain in the chest, neck, back or arms, as well as fatigue, lightheadedness, abnormal heartbeat and anxiety. Women are more likely to have atypical symptoms than men.
Treatment ranges from lifestyle changes and cardiac rehabilitation to medication, stents and bypass surgery.
Heart attack.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.Defibrillation: Using an electrical shock to correct a rapid, irregular heartbeat and restore the heart's normal rhythm.
Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.

Medication.Anticoagulant: Unwanted reactions from taking drugs that inhibit blood clotting. The most common problem is too much bleeding, which can be very serious.
Medication.Antianginal: Helps reduce chest pain or pressure caused by blockages in the arteries of the heart.
Medication.Narcotic: Relieves pain, dulls the senses and causes drowsiness. May become addictive.
Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.
Medication.Statin: Decreases the liver's production of harmful cholesterol.
Medication.ACE inhibitor: Relaxes blood vessels, lowers blood pressure and prevents diabetes-related kidney damage.

Medical procedure.Coronary stent: A tube placed in the arteries of the heart to keep them open.
Medical procedure.Coronary angioplasty: Unblocking an artery by inflating a balloon inside it. A stent may also be inserted to hold the artery open.

Therapies.Cardiac rehabilitation: A supervised programme that includes exercise, lifestyle changes, education and emotional support for people with heart problems.

Surgery.Coronary artery bypass surgery: Surgery that restores blood flow to the heart by using a healthy artery or vein to bypass a blocked artery.

specialists.Cardiac Surgeon: Performs surgery on the heart or great vessels.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Heart failure.symptomDescription: Symptoms include shortness of breath, fatigue, swollen legs and rapid heartbeat.

symptoms.Cough: can be dry or with phlegm
symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, inability to exercise, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Respiratory: fast breathing, shortness of breath at night, shortness of breath on exercise, or shortness of breath on lying down
symptoms.Also common: excess urination at night, palpitations, swollen feet, swollen legs, or weight gain

Heart failure.overview:
Description
A chronic condition in which the heart doesn't pump blood as well as it should.
Heart failure can occur if the heart cannot pump (systolic) or fill (diastolic) adequately.
Symptoms include shortness of breath, fatigue, swollen legs and rapid heartbeat.
Treatments can include eating less salt, limiting fluid intake and taking prescription medication. In some cases a defibrillator or pacemaker may be implanted.
Heart failure.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.
Self-care.Low sodium diet: A diet that restricts salt (sodium chloride) and other forms of sodium to no more than 2,000 mg per day

Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.
Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.
Medication.ACE inhibitor: Relaxes blood vessels, lowers blood pressure and prevents diabetes-related kidney damage.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.
Medication.Blood pressure support: Helps increase blood pressure when it's too low.
Medication.Antianginal: Helps reduce chest pain or pressure caused by blockages in the arteries of the heart.

Medical procedure.Cardiac resynchronization therapy: A special kind of pacemaker that keeps the left and right sides of the heart pumping together.

Devices.Implantable cardioverter defibrillator: A small device placed in the chest or abdomen that shocks the heart if it develops a dangerously irregular heartbeat.

Surgery.Coronary artery bypass surgery: Surgery that restores blood flow to the heart by using a healthy artery or vein to bypass a blocked artery.

specialists.Cardiac Electrophysiologist: Treats patients with electrical and heart rhythm problems.
specialists.Cardiothoracic Surgeon: Surgically treats diseases affecting organs inside the chest.

Heat rash (prickly heat).symptomDescription: The rash may appear as blisters or red lumps. Heat rash may cause itchiness or a prickly feeling.

symptoms.Skin: rashes, blister, bumps, or red rashes
symptoms.Also common: flushing or itching

Heat rash (prickly heat).overview:
Description
A skin condition caused by blocked sweat ducts and trapped sweat beneath the skin.
Heat rash is common during hot, humid weather.
The rash may appear as blisters or red lumps. Heat rash may cause itchiness or a prickly feeling.
Heat rash usually goes away on its own. Use of fans and lightweight clothing can help.
Heat rash (prickly heat).notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Menthol: An oil made from mint that soothes sore throats and relieves itching.

Supportive care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Hemangioma.symptomDescription: A haemangioma is a birthmark that grows during the first year of life and fades over time. It can appear on the face, scalp, chest or back.

symptoms.Common symptoms: birthmark or bleeding

Hemangioma.overview:
Description
A birthmark often appearing as a rubbery, bright red nodule of extra blood vessels.
Haemangiomas are seen more frequently among premature infants.
A haemangioma is a birthmark that grows during the first year of life and fades over time. It can appear on the face, scalp, chest or back.
Most haemangiomas disappear on their own. In rare cases, a haemangioma can interfere with vision or cause other symptoms, and can be treated with drugs or laser surgery.
Hemangioma.notes:
Medium-term: resolves within months
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Surgery.Laser surgery: Surgery using an intensely hot and focused beam of light to remove tissue and control bleeding.

specialists.Paediatric Dermatologist: Focuses on childhood disorders of skin, nails and hair.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Hemorrhagic stroke.symptomDescription: Symptoms can vary based on the location of the haemorrhage in the brain, but may include numbness or weakness in part of the face, difficulty speaking or difficulty walking.

symptoms.Muscular: weakness of one side of the body or paralysis of one side of the body
symptoms.Also common: bleeding, decreased level of consciousness, altered level of consciousness, difficulty speaking, ekg abnormalities, fainting, headache, seizures, sensitivity to light, or unequal pupils

Hemorrhagic stroke.overview:
Description
An emergency condition in which a ruptured blood vessel causes bleeding inside the brain.
High blood pressure and trauma are two leading causes. Taking blood-thinning drugs may also increase a person's risk.
Symptoms can vary based on the location of the haemorrhage in the brain, but may include numbness or weakness in part of the face, difficulty speaking or difficulty walking.
Emergency treatment is required for cerebral haemorrhage. It usually involves medication and close monitoring in an intensive care unit. In rare cases, surgery may be required to relieve pressure around the brain.
Hemorrhagic stroke.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Critical: needs emergency care

Self-care.Elevate head of bed: Reduces the likelihood of acid reflux or developing a pneumonia from saliva entering the airways.

Supportive care.Hyperventilation: Using a machine to increase the rate of breathing above normal. This can lower carbon dioxide in the blood and reduce swelling of the brain.
Supportive care.Reversal of anticoagulation: Giving a medication to counteract a blood thinner to decrease the risk of bleeding.
Supportive care.Monitoring in the intensive care unit: Care provided in a specialised hospital unit that can deliver medications to support blood pressure and manage breathing machines.
Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.

Medical procedure.Clipping: Surgically placing a clip to seal off a bulge in the artery wall (aneurysm) to keep it from bleeding.

Therapies.Rehabilitation: Retraining the brain's pathways to improve mental and physical functioning after an illness or injury. For example, after a blow to the head (concussion).

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Henoch-Sch\u00f6nlein purpura.symptomDescription: Symptoms include reddish-purple spots on the lower extremities, swollen and sore joints, abdominal pain or bloody urine.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: blood in stool, diarrhoea, or vomiting
symptoms.Also common: rash of small purplish spots, blood in urine, or fever

Henoch-Sch\u00f6nlein purpura.overview:
Description
A disorder causing inflammation and bleeding in the small blood vessels.
Henoch-Schönlein purpura affects the small blood vessels of the skin, joints, intestines and kidneys. It's most common before the age of seven but can affect anyone.
Symptoms include reddish-purple spots on the lower extremities, swollen and sore joints, abdominal pain or bloody urine.
The condition is often treated with steroids.
Henoch-Sch\u00f6nlein purpura.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.
Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Hepatitis A.symptomDescription: Symptoms include fatigue, nausea, abdominal pain, loss of appetite and low-grade fever.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the abdomen, joints, or muscles
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, fever, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: dark urine, itching, weight loss, or yellow skin and eyes

Hepatitis A.overview:
Description
A highly contagious liver infection caused by the hepatitis A virus.
Hepatitis A is preventable by vaccine. It spreads from contaminated food or water or contact with someone who is infected.
Symptoms include fatigue, nausea, abdominal pain, loss of appetite and low-grade fever.
The condition clears up on its own in one or two months. Rest and adequate hydration can help.
Hepatitis A.notes:
Preventable by vaccine
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Spreads through contaminated food or water
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care
HOW IT SPREADS
Through contaminated food or water.

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.
Supportive care.Rehydration: Replacing lost body fluid by drinking more fluids or administering fluids by intravenous therapy (IV).

Self-care.Avoid alcohol: May be harmful and aggravate certain conditions.
Self-care.Rest: Reducing activity for a short period of time following an injury to promote healing.

specialists.Hepatologist: Focuses on liver, gallbladder and biliary tree disorders.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Hepatitis B.symptomDescription: Symptoms are variable and include yellowing of the eyes, abdominal pain and dark urine. Some people, particularly children, don't experience any symptoms. In chronic cases, liver failure, cancer or scarring can occur.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or malaise
symptoms.Skin: web of swollen blood vessels in the skin or yellow skin and eyes
symptoms.Also common: fluid in the abdomen

Hepatitis B.overview:
Description
A serious liver infection caused by the hepatitis B virus that's easily preventable by a vaccine.
This disease is most commonly spread by exposure to infected bodily fluids.
Symptoms are variable and include yellowing of the eyes, abdominal pain and dark urine. Some people, particularly children, don't experience any symptoms. In chronic cases, liver failure, cancer or scarring can occur.
The condition often clears up on its own. Chronic cases require medication and possibly a liver transplant.
Hepatitis B.notes:
Spreads by sexual contact
Preventable by vaccine
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
HOW IT SPREADS
By blood products (unclean needles or unscreened blood).
By having unprotected vaginal, anal or oral sex.
By mother to baby by pregnancy, labour or nursing.

Self-care.Avoid alcohol: May be harmful and aggravate certain conditions.

specialists.Hepatologist: Focuses on liver, gallbladder and biliary tree disorders.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.

Hepatitis C.symptomDescription: Most people have no symptoms. Those who do develop symptoms may have fatigue, nausea, loss of appetite and yellowing of the eyes and skin.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: bleeding, bloating, fluid in the abdomen, or nausea
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, fever, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Skin: web of swollen blood vessels in the skin or yellow skin and eyes
symptoms.Also common: depression or weight loss

Hepatitis C.overview:
Description
An infection caused by a virus that attacks the liver and leads to inflammation.
The virus is spread by contact with contaminated blood; for example, from sharing needles or from unsterile tattoo equipment.
Most people have no symptoms. Those who do develop symptoms may have fatigue, nausea, loss of appetite and yellowing of the eyes and skin.
Hepatitis C is treated with antiviral medication. In some people, newer medicines can eradicate the virus.
Hepatitis C.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Spreads easily
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
HOW IT SPREADS
By blood products (unclean needles or unscreened blood).
By mother to baby by pregnancy, labour or nursing.

Self-care.Avoid alcohol: May be harmful and aggravate certain conditions.

Surgery.Liver transplantation: Surgical replacement of a diseased liver with some or all of a healthy liver from a donor.

specialists.Hepatologist: Focuses on liver, gallbladder and biliary tree disorders.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.

Hepatitis E.symptomDescription: Symptoms include jaundice, lack of appetite and nausea. In rare cases, it may progress to acute liver failure.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, fever, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: dark urine or yellow skin and eyes

Hepatitis E.overview:
Description
A liver disease caused by the hepatitis E virus.
The hepatitis E virus is mainly transmitted through drinking water contaminated with faecal matter.
Symptoms include jaundice, lack of appetite and nausea. In rare cases, it may progress to acute liver failure.
Hepatitis E usually resolves on its own within four to six weeks. Treatment focuses on supportive care, rehydration and rest.
Hepatitis E.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Spreads through contaminated food or water
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
Through contaminated food or water.

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.
Supportive care.Rehydration: Replacing lost body fluid by drinking more fluids or administering fluids by intravenous therapy (IV).

Self-care.Rest: Reducing activity for a short period of time following an injury to promote healing.
Self-care.Avoid alcohol: May be harmful and aggravate certain conditions.

specialists.Hepatologist: Focuses on liver, gallbladder and biliary tree disorders.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.

Hepatocellular carcinoma.symptomDescription: Symptoms often don't appear in the early stages of the cancer. Later, symptoms include weight loss, upper abdominal pain or yellowing of the skin (jaundice).

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: bloating or fluid in the abdomen
symptoms.Also common: weight loss, liver failure, loss of appetite, or yellow skin and eyes

Hepatocellular carcinoma.overview:
Description
The most common form of liver cancer.
Hepatocellular carcinoma most commonly occurs in people with liver disease, particularly in people with chronic hepatitis B and C.
Symptoms often don't appear in the early stages of the cancer. Later, symptoms include weight loss, upper abdominal pain or yellowing of the skin (jaundice).
Treatments may include surgery, transplant, freezing or heating the cancer cells and chemotherapy.
Hepatocellular carcinoma.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.

Medical procedure.Percutaneous ethanol injection: Injecting 100% alcohol (ethanol) into tissue to kill abnormal cells.
Medical procedure.Transarterial chemoembolization: Injecting anti-cancer drugs into the blood vessels of a tumour and then blocking them off to trap the medication in the tumour.
Medical procedure.SIR-Spheres: Tiny radioactive beads inserted into tumours to kill cancer cells.
Medical procedure.Radiofrequency ablation: Removal of tissue using the heat from an electric current produced by a radio wave.

Surgery.Hepatectomy: Surgical removal of all or part of the liver.

specialists.Hepatologist: Focuses on liver, gallbladder and biliary tree disorders.
specialists.Transplant Surgeon: Transfers an organ from one body to another.
specialists.Interventional Radiologist: Uses image-guided procedures to diagnose and treat diseases.

Hernia.symptomDescription: Symptoms include a bulge, swelling or pain. In some cases, there are no symptoms.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the abdomen, pelvis, or testicle
symptoms.Pain types: can be dull
symptoms.Also common: abdominal discomfort, abdominal distension, groin discomfort, or tenderness

Hernia.overview:
Description
A bulging of an organ or tissue through an abnormal opening.
Typically, a hernia involves the stomach or intestine.
Symptoms include a bulge, swelling or pain. In some cases, there are no symptoms.
Treatment includes monitoring the condition. If required, surgery can return tissue to its normal location and close the opening.
Hernia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Surgery.Laparoscopic surgery: Surgery that uses a video camera and thin tubes inserted into small cuts on the body to repair or remove tissue.
Surgery.Hernia repair: Surgical repair of a weak spot on the abdominal wall so that the intestines can't push through.

Devices.Supportive device: A device applied over a hernia to reduce discomfort and push the bulging tissue back into the abdomen.

specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.

Herpangina.symptomDescription: Sores appear in the mouth and throat, as well as on the feet, hands and buttocks. They usually have a white base and a red border and may be very painful. Fever, headache, sore throat or difficulty swallowing may also occur.

symptoms.Whole body: fever, loss of appetite, or malaise
symptoms.Also common: headache or irritability

Herpangina.overview:
Description
A common childhood illness often caused by group A coxsackie viruses.
Herpangina is a viral illness that's most often seen in children aged three to 10, but it can occur at any age.
Sores appear in the mouth and throat, as well as on the feet, hands and buttocks. They usually have a white base and a red border and may be very painful. Fever, headache, sore throat or difficulty swallowing may also occur.
Treatment involves rest, drinking fluids and pain relievers.
Herpangina.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Spreads easily
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
Through contaminated food or water.
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Supportive care.Oral rehydration therapy: Giving fluid by mouth to treat dehydration caused by diarrhoea.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Hiatus hernia.symptomDescription: Hiatus hernias can have no symptoms. In some cases, they may be associated with heartburn and abdominal discomfort.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: belching, heartburn, hiccup, nausea, regurgitation, or vomiting
symptoms.Also common: throat irritation

Hiatus hernia.overview:
Description
A condition in which part of the stomach pushes up through the diaphragm muscle.
In hiatus hernia, part of the stomach pushes into the chest cavity. It enters via an opening where the food tube (oesophagus) passes on its way to the stomach.
Hiatus hernias can have no symptoms. In some cases, they may be associated with heartburn and abdominal discomfort.
Hiatus hernias may not require any treatment. Some are treated with drugs and a few types need surgical repair.
Hiatus hernia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.

Medication.Proton-pump inhibitor: Decreases acid release in the stomach.
Medication.Antacid: Counteracts the effects of stomach acid.

Surgery.Nissen fundoplication: Surgery to strengthen the valve between the stomach and the esophagus. Makes it harder for stomach acid to go up the oesophagus.
Surgery.Hernia repair: Surgical repair of a weak spot on the abdominal wall so that the intestines can't push through.
Surgery.Laparoscopic surgery: Surgery that uses a video camera and thin tubes inserted into small cuts on the body to repair or remove tissue.

specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Hidradenitis suppurativa.symptomDescription: This condition features pea- to marble-sized lumps under the skin that can be painful and tend to enlarge and drain pus. They usually occur where skin rubs together, such as in the armpits, groin and buttocks.

symptoms.Skin: lumps, rashes, rashes that look like acne, small bump, or ulcers
symptoms.Also common: abscess, body odour, excess sweating, itching, pimple or blackhead, pus, or swelling

Hidradenitis suppurativa.overview:
Description
A chronic skin condition featuring lumps in places such as the armpits or groin.
The skin lesions develop as a result of inflammation and infection of sweat glands.
This condition features pea- to marble-sized lumps under the skin that can be painful and tend to enlarge and drain pus. They usually occur where skin rubs together, such as in the armpits, groin and buttocks.
Medication, corticosteroid injections and sometimes surgery can help manage symptoms.
Hidradenitis suppurativa.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

Medical procedure.Incision and drainage: Cutting or puncturing the skin to drain an infection such as an abscess or boil.
Medical procedure.Carbon dioxide laser: A laser used to treat abnormal growths on the skin.

Surgery.Wide local excision: Surgical removal of a small area of tissue, along with a margin of normal tissue beyond the border of disease

specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.
specialists.Plastic Surgeon: Reconstructs defective, damaged or missing body parts.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

symptoms.Common symptoms: heart attack, peripheral artery disease, or stroke

High cholesterol.overview:
Description
High amounts of cholesterol in the blood.
High cholesterol can limit blood flow, increasing the risk of a heart attack or stroke. It's detected by a blood test.
High cholesterol has no symptoms.
Treatments include medication, a healthy diet and exercise.
High cholesterol.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Low fat diet: Reducing intake of high-fat foods such as dairy, oil and red meat to improve cardiovascular health.

Medication.Statin: Decreases the liver's production of harmful cholesterol.
Medication.Cholesterol medication: Lowers levels of harmful cholesterol in the blood or increases levels of beneficial cholesterol.

specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.

Hip dislocation.symptomDescription: The hip may be swollen, painful and visibly out of place. The leg may be hard to move or may feel tingly or numb.

symptoms.Muscular: abnormality walking, muscle weakness, or permanent shortening of muscle
symptoms.Also common: physical deformity, bruising, or swelling

Hip dislocation.overview:
Description
An injury in which the hip bone is displaced from its normal position.
Motor vehicle accidents are a common cause of hip dislocation. In infants, this condition may occur as a result of congenital looseness in the joint. Once a hip is dislocated, chances increase that it will happen again.
The hip may be swollen, painful and visibly out of place. The leg may be hard to move or may feel tingly or numb.
Immediate medical treatment is required and involves pushing the bone into place by hand or surgery, and rehabilitation.
Hip dislocation.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Medical procedure.Procedural sedation and analgesia: Giving tranquilisers and painkillers before a painful or unpleasant medical procedure. Although not fully conscious, the person can still breathe on their own.
Medical procedure.Reduction: Surgery to fix a broken or dislocated bone by putting it back into place.
Medical procedure.Traction: Using weights and pulleys to put a broken bone or damaged joint back in position and hold it still.

Devices.Orthopedic cast: A protective device applied to an injured joint or limb to limit motion and promote healing.
Devices.Prosthesis: An artificial replacement for a missing body part, such as a leg, tooth or eye.

Surgery.Arthroplasty: Surgery to repair or replace a joint.
Surgery.Arthrodesis: Surgical fusion of the bones that form a joint.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Trauma Surgeon: Performs surgery to repair damage caused by injuries.
specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
