Hip fracture.symptomDescription: Symptoms include the inability to move after a fall and severe hip or groin pain.

symptoms.Also common: abnormality walking, bruising, swelling, or visible deformity of lower extremity

Hip fracture.overview:
Description
A break in the upper quarter of the thighbone, near the hip joint.
A hip fracture can cause life-threatening complications. People over the age 65 are most at risk because bones weaken and the risk of falling increases with age.
Symptoms include the inability to move after a fall and severe hip or groin pain.
A hip fracture almost always requires surgery and physiotherapy. Taking steps to maintain bone density and avoid falls can help prevent hip fracture.
Hip fracture.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Critical: needs emergency care

Surgery.Hip replacement: A surgery to replace a hip using an implant.
Surgery.Surgery to connect broken bones (Interna: A surgery to repair a broken bone using implants.
Surgery.Arthroplasty: Surgery to repair or replace a joint.

Medical procedure.Reduction: Surgery to fix a broken or dislocated bone by putting it back into place.
Medical procedure.Traction: Using weights and pulleys to put a broken bone or damaged joint back in position and hold it still.

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Trauma Surgeon: Performs surgery to repair damage caused by injuries.
specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Hirschsprung's disease.symptomDescription: The main symptom is a newborn's failure to have a bowel movement within 48 hours after birth. Other symptoms include a swollen stomach and vomiting.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: bloating, constipation, newborn unable to pass first stool, leaking of stool, vomiting, or flatulence
symptoms.Also common: failure to thrive

Hirschsprung's disease.overview:
Description
A condition of the large intestine (colon) that causes difficulty passing stool.
Hirschsprung's disease involves missing nerve cells in the muscles of part or all of the large intestine (colon). Present at birth, it causes difficulty passing stool.
The main symptom is a newborn's failure to have a bowel movement within 48 hours after birth. Other symptoms include a swollen stomach and vomiting.
Surgery is required to bypass the affected part of the colon or remove it entirely.
Hirschsprung's disease.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Critical: needs emergency care

Surgery.Bowel resection: Surgical removal of part of the intestine.

specialists.Paediatric surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries for infants and children.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Neonatologist: Provides medical care for newborn infants.

Hives.symptomDescription: Symptoms include itchy, raised, red or skin-coloured welts on the skin's surface.

symptoms.Skin: raised area of skin, swelling, or inflammation in response to touch
symptoms.Also common: swelling, itching, or flare

Hives.overview:
Description
A skin rash triggered by a reaction to food, medicine or other irritants.
Hives is a common skin rash triggered by many things, including certain foods, medication and stress.
Symptoms include itchy, raised, red or skin-coloured welts on the skin's surface.
Hives usually go away without treatment, but antihistamine medication is often helpful in improving symptoms.
Hives.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Cold compress: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.

Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.

Medical procedure.Desensitization: Reducing allergic reactions by injecting gradually increasing doses of the substance causing the reaction.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Hodgkin's lymphoma.symptomDescription: Lymph nodes in the neck, armpits or groin may swell. Fatigue, fever and chills are some symptoms.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, fever, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: itching, night sweats, swollen lymph nodes, or weight loss

Hodgkin's lymphoma.overview:
Description
Cancer of part of the immune system called the lymphatic system.
As the cancer progresses, it limits the body's ability to fight infection.
Lymph nodes in the neck, armpits or groin may swell. Fatigue, fever and chills are some symptoms.
Treatments include chemotherapy, radiation and in rare cases, stem-cell transplant.
Hodgkin's lymphoma.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.

Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

specialists.Radiation Oncologist: Treats and manages cancer by prescribing radiation therapy.
specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.

Horner's syndrome.symptomDescription: Symptoms include a smaller pupil, drooping eyelid and little or no sweating on the affected side.

symptoms.Eyes: drooping of upper eyelid or unequal pupils
symptoms.Also common: inability to sweat normally, nerve injury, or blurred vision

Horner's syndrome.overview:
Description
A disrupted nerve pathway on one side from the brain to the face and eye.
Horner's syndrome is the result of another medical condition, such as a stroke, tumour or spinal cord injury.
Symptoms include a smaller pupil, drooping eyelid and little or no sweating on the affected side.
There's no specific treatment for Horner's syndrome, but treatment for the underlying cause may restore normal nerve function.
Horner's syndrome.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Treatment of the underlying cause: Identifying the underlying cause of a symptom or condition so that it can be properly evaluated and treated.

specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.

Human papillomavirus (HPV).symptomDescription: Many people with HPV don't develop any symptoms but can still infect others through sexual contact. Symptoms may include warts on the genitals or surrounding skin.

symptoms.Common symptoms: itching or warts and verrucas

Human papillomavirus (HPV).overview:
Description
An infection that causes warts in various parts of the body, depending on the strain.
Human papillomavirus (HPV) is the most common sexually transmitted infection (STI).
Many people with HPV don't develop any symptoms but can still infect others through sexual contact. Symptoms may include warts on the genitals or surrounding skin.
There's no cure for the virus and warts may go away on their own. Treatment focuses on removing the warts. A vaccine that prevents the HPV strains most likely to cause genital warts and cervical cancer is recommended for boys and girls.
Human papillomavirus (HPV).notes:
Spreads by sexual contact
Some types preventable by vaccine
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
HOW IT SPREADS
By having unprotected vaginal, anal or oral sex.
By mother to baby by pregnancy, labour or nursing.

Medical procedure.Loop electrosurgical excision procedure: Using a wire loop heated by electric current to remove abnormal cells and tissue from the cervix and vagina.
Medical procedure.Freezing: Using extreme cold during surgery or medical treatment.
Medical procedure.Cervical conization: Surgical removal of a cone-shaped tissue sample from the cervix. Also known as cone biopsy.

Medication.Topical anti-tumor medication: Treats skin cancer and other skin conditions.

Surgery.Electrosurgery: Using electric current to cut tissue and control bleeding during surgery.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Huntington's disease.symptomDescription: Usually, Huntington's disease results in progressive movement, thinking (cognitive) and psychiatric symptoms.

symptoms.Muscular: abnormality walking, increased muscle activity, involuntary movements, problems with coordination, loss of muscle, or muscle spasms
symptoms.Cognitive: amnesia, delusion, lack of concentration, mental confusion, slowness in activity, or difficulty thinking and understanding
symptoms.Behavioural: compulsive behaviour, fidgeting, irritability, or lack of restraint
symptoms.Mood: anxiety, apathy, or mood swings
symptoms.Also common: difficulty speaking, memory loss, tremor, or weight loss

Huntington's disease.overview:
Description
An inherited condition in which nerve cells in the brain break down over time.
It typically starts in a person's 30s or 40s.
Usually, Huntington's disease results in progressive movement, thinking (cognitive) and psychiatric symptoms.
No cure exists, but drugs, physiotherapy and talk therapy can help manage some symptoms.
Huntington's disease.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
Therapies.Counseling: Professional advice and support that help people solve problems, make decisions and change their behaviour.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Hydrocele.symptomDescription: Hydroceles are usually painless, but may become large and inconvenient. An ultrasound may be required to diagnose the condition.

symptoms.Common symptoms: swollen testicle or testicular discomfort

Hydrocele.overview:
Description
A fluid-filled sac around a testicle, often first noticed as swelling of the scrotum.
Hydrocele is common in newborns and usually disappears without treatment within the first year. Older men can develop hydroceles, sometimes due to inflammation or injury.
Hydroceles are usually painless, but may become large and inconvenient. An ultrasound may be required to diagnose the condition.
Treatment usually involves watchful waiting. In rare circumstances, surgery is required.
Hydrocele.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Hydrocephalus.extraName: Also called: water on the brain
Hydrocephalus.symptomDescription: Hydrocephalus is characterised by head enlargement in infants. Adults and older children experience headache, impaired vision, cognitive difficulties, loss of coordination and incontinence.

symptoms.Muscular: abnormality walking, instability, problems with coordination, or stiff muscles
symptoms.Also common: blurred vision, bulging soft spot on a baby's head, delayed development, enlargement of head, headache, high pitched cry, irritability, leaking of urine, mental confusion, or sleepiness

Hydrocephalus.overview:
Description
A build-up of fluid in the cavities deep within the brain.
The extra fluid puts pressure on the brain and can cause brain damage. It's most common in infants and older adults.
Hydrocephalus is characterised by head enlargement in infants. Adults and older children experience headache, impaired vision, cognitive difficulties, loss of coordination and incontinence.
Treatment is often a tube (shunt) inserted surgically into a ventricle to drain excess fluid.
Hydrocephalus.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.

Medical procedure.Ventriculoperitoneal shunt: A tube (shunt) inserted through a small hole in the skull to drain excess fluid and relieve pressure on the brain.

Surgery.Ventriculostomy: Surgery to create an opening in the skull so that an inserted tube can drain excess fluid from the brain.

specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Hydronephrosis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include difficulty urinating and pain in the side, abdomen or groin.

symptoms.Urinary: insufficient urine production or blood in urine
symptoms.Also common: high blood pressure

Hydronephrosis.overview:
Description
A condition characterised by excess fluid in a kidney due to a back-up of urine.
Hydronephrosis is caused by a blockage in the tube that connects the kidney to the bladder (ureter). Possible causes include a kidney stone, an infection, an enlarged prostate, a blood clot or a tumour.
Symptoms include difficulty urinating and pain in the side, abdomen or groin.
Treatment may include antibiotics if there's an infection. In severe cases, the urine may need to be drained from the bladder or kidney.
Hydronephrosis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Devices.Ureteral stent: A thin tube inserted into the muscular duct that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder. Typically used when the flow of urine is blocked.

Medical procedure.Urinary catheterization: Inserting a tube into the bladder to drain urine.
Medical procedure.Nephrostomy: Insertion of a tube, stent or catheter through the skin and into the kidney to drain urine.
Medical procedure.Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy: Using shock waves to break up kidney stones and gallstones so they pass more easily.

Hypercalcemia.symptomDescription: Symptoms of hypercalcaemia range from mild to severe. They may include increased thirst and urination, stomach pain, nausea, bone pain, muscle weakness, confusion and fatigue.

symptoms.Whole body: dehydration, fatigue, loss of appetite, or thirst
symptoms.Also common: excess urination, mental confusion, muscle weakness, or weight loss

Hypercalcemia.overview:
Description
Too much calcium in the blood.
Hypercalcaemia is most often caused by overactivity in the four tiny glands in the neck (parathyroid glands) or from cancer. Extra calcium in the blood affects many bodily systems.
Symptoms of hypercalcaemia range from mild to severe. They may include increased thirst and urination, stomach pain, nausea, bone pain, muscle weakness, confusion and fatigue.
Treatment may include drugs or surgical removal of an overactive gland.
Hypercalcemia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Surgery.Parathyroidectomy: Surgical removal of one or more parathyroid glands in the neck. These glands make a hormone that balances the level of calcium in the blood.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Hyperdontia.symptomDescription: Extra teeth don't usually cause symptoms.

symptoms.Mouth: crowded teeth, misaligned teeth, or toothache

Hyperdontia.overview:
Description
Extra teeth in the mouth.
Hyperdontia is more common with permanent teeth than baby teeth.
Extra teeth don't usually cause symptoms.
In some cases, extra teeth may need to be removed to prevent crowding or displacing of other teeth. In other cases, extra teeth may be left alone and observed over time if they're not causing any problems.
Hyperdontia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Devices.Prosthodontics: Artificial replacements for teeth and other parts of the mouth. For example, bridges and dentures.

Medical procedure.Tooth extraction: Surgical removal of a tooth because of decay, disease or trauma.

specialists.Dentist: Specialises in diseases of the oral cavity, especially the teeth.
specialists.Mouth and Face Surgeon: Performs surgery on the mouth, jaw and face.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Hyperthyroidism.symptomDescription: Symptoms include unexpected weight loss, rapid or irregular heartbeat, sweating and irritability, although the elderly often experience no symptoms.

symptoms.Whole body: excess sweating, excessive hunger, fatigue, or heat intolerance
symptoms.Behavioural: hyperactivity, irritability, or restlessness
symptoms.Heart: abnormal heart rhythm, fast heart rate, or palpitations
symptoms.Mood: mood swings, nervousness, or panic attack
symptoms.Eyes: abnormal protrusion of eyes or puffy eyes
symptoms.Menstrual: irregular menstruation or short and light menstruation
symptoms.Also common: weight loss, diarrhoea, hair loss, muscle weakness, tremor, or warm skin

Hyperthyroidism.overview:
Description
The overproduction of a hormone by the butterfly-shaped gland in the neck (thyroid).
Hyperthyroidism is the production of too much thyroxine hormone. It can increase metabolism.
Symptoms include unexpected weight loss, rapid or irregular heartbeat, sweating and irritability, although the elderly often experience no symptoms.
Treatments include radioactive iodine, medication and sometimes surgery.
Hyperthyroidism.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Antithyroid agent: Prevents the thyroid gland from making or releasing thyroid hormone.
Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.

specialists.Nuclear Medicine Doctor: Applies radioactive substances to diagnose and treat disease.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.extraName: Also called: HCM, hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.symptomDescription: Most people with the condition have no symptoms and experience no significant problems. For some, it can cause shortness of breath, chest pain or abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias).

symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, or inability to exercise
symptoms.Heart: enlarged heart, murmur, or palpitations
symptoms.Also common: shortness of breath

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.overview:
Description
A condition in which the heart muscle becomes abnormally thick.
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy makes it hard for the heart to pump blood. It often goes undiagnosed.
Most people with the condition have no symptoms and experience no significant problems. For some, it can cause shortness of breath, chest pain or abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias).
Treatment may include surgery, an implantable device or medication to slow or regulate the heart rate.
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Exercise restrictions: Limiting physical activity to avoid aggravating disease.

Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.

Devices.Pacemaker: A small device placed in the chest or abdomen that sends out electrical signals to keep the heart beating normally.
Devices.Implantable cardioverter defibrillator: A small device placed in the chest or abdomen that shocks the heart if it develops a dangerously irregular heartbeat.

specialists.Cardiac Electrophysiologist: Treats patients with electrical and heart rhythm problems.
specialists.Cardiothoracic Surgeon: Surgically treats diseases affecting organs inside the chest.

Hypogonadism.symptomDescription: If the onset is before puberty, growth and sexual development may be affected. After puberty, there may be sexual difficulties, reduced fertility and absence of menstruation.

symptoms.Sexual: reduced sex drive, sexual dysfunction, or erectile dysfunction
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or hot flashes
symptoms.Muscular: muscle weakness or loss of muscle
symptoms.Also common: absence of menstruation, delayed puberty, depression, infertility, irritability, mood swings, pot belly, or weight gain

Hypogonadism.overview:
Description
A failure of the gonads, testes in men and ovaries in women, to function properly.
Production of a man's testosterone and a woman's oestrogen are inhibited.
If the onset is before puberty, growth and sexual development may be affected. After puberty, there may be sexual difficulties, reduced fertility and absence of menstruation.
Treatments may include hormone replacement therapy and assisted reproduction.
Hypogonadism.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.
Medication.Estrogen modulator: Mimics the effect of oestrogen on various tissues, including the breast, bones and reproductive organs.

Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.

Medical procedure.Assisted reproductive technology: Medical procedures that help women become pregnant. Examples include artificial insemination (AI) and in vitro fertilization (IVF).

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Hyponatremia.symptomDescription: Symptoms include nausea, headache, confusion and fatigue.

symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, lethargy, malaise, or thirst
symptoms.Also common: headache, insufficient urine production, mental confusion, or nausea

Hyponatremia.overview:
Description
A condition that occurs when the level of sodium in the blood is too low.
With this condition, the body holds onto too much water. This dilutes the amount of sodium in the blood and causes levels to be low.
Symptoms include nausea, headache, confusion and fatigue.
Limited fluid intake, medication and hospitalisation may be required.
Hyponatremia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Water restriction: A reduction in water intake to treat fluid overload.

Supportive care.Saline solution: Salt water used to replace bodily fluids, clean wounds, irrigate the sinuses and rinse contact lenses.
Supportive care.Sodium chloride: A salt solution taken by mouth or injected into a vein to treat low levels of sodium in the body.
Supportive care.Oral rehydration therapy: Giving fluid by mouth to treat dehydration caused by diarrhoea.

Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Ichthyosis.symptomDescription: Symptoms depend on the type of ichthyosis. The most common symptoms include pain and dry, scaly skin.

symptoms.Skin: flakiness, dryness, fissures, or peeling
symptoms.Also common: hyperlinearity of palms and soles, itching, or thickened skin on palms and soles

Ichthyosis.overview:
Description
A group of skin disorders characterised by dry, scaly or thickened skin.
Most cases of ichthyosis are inherited, but some types develop in association with genetic syndromes or diseases, such as Hodgkin's lymphoma.
Symptoms depend on the type of ichthyosis. The most common symptoms include pain and dry, scaly skin.
Medication containing salicylic acid or urea may relieve dryness and ease scaliness. Severe cases may need vitamin A derivatives called retinoids.
Ichthyosis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.

Therapies.Hydrotherapy: Using water to relieve pain, treat diseases and maintain health. For example, mineral baths and hot tubs.

Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.
Medication.Vitamin A derivative: Unplugs blocked hair follicles and helps prevent new blockages from forming. Slows skin cell growth.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension.symptomDescription: Symptoms mimic a brain tumour, but no tumour is present. They may include headache behind the eyes, ringing in the ears in time with the heartbeat and brief episodes of blindness.

symptoms.Visual: blurred vision, double vision, or partial loss of vision
symptoms.Also common: headache, dizziness, or ringing in the ears

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension.overview:
Description
A condition that occurs when pressure inside the skull increases for no obvious reason.
Idiopathic intracranial hypertension is most common in obese women of childbearing age.
Symptoms mimic a brain tumour, but no tumour is present. They may include headache behind the eyes, ringing in the ears in time with the heartbeat and brief episodes of blindness.
The first drug usually tried is a type of diuretic that may reduce the production of spinal fluid. Surgery may relieve pressure.
Idiopathic intracranial hypertension.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.

Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.

Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura.extraName: Also called: ITP, immune thrombocytopenic purpura
Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura.symptomDescription: Symptoms may include easy bruising, bleeding and pinpoint-sized reddish-purple spots on the lower legs.

symptoms.Skin: red spots or rash of small purplish spots
symptoms.Also common: bleeding, bruising, heavy or prolonged periods, or nosebleed

Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura.overview:
Description
Low levels of the blood cells that prevent bleeding (platelets).
Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) may occur when the immune system mistakenly attacks platelets. In children, it may follow a viral infection. In adults, it may be chronic.
Symptoms may include easy bruising, bleeding and pinpoint-sized reddish-purple spots on the lower legs.
In children, ITP usually resolves without any treatment. Adults commonly need treatment with medication for bleeding. Rarely the spleen may need to be removed.
Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.

Iliotibial band syndrome.extraName: Also called: ITBS, iliotibial band friction syndrome
Iliotibial band syndrome.symptomDescription: The main symptom is pain between the hip and knees that worsens with activity.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the hip, knee, or leg
symptoms.Also common: swelling

Iliotibial band syndrome.overview:
Description
A painful condition in which connective tissue rubs against the thighbone.
Iliotibial band syndrome occurs when the connective tissue (ligament) extending from the pelvic bone to the shinbone becomes so tight that it rubs against the thighbone. Distance runners are especially susceptible to it.
The main symptom is pain between the hip and knees that worsens with activity.
Treatments such as physiotherapy and sometimes corticosteroid injections may help. In rare cases, surgery may be required.
Iliotibial band syndrome.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Self-care.Rest: Reducing activity for a short period of time following an injury to promote healing.
Self-care.RICE (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation): Rest, ice, compression and elevation. A first-aid treatment for sprains and strains.
Self-care.Cold compress: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.

Impetigo.symptomDescription: The main symptom is red sores that form around the nose and mouth. The sores rupture, ooze for a few days, then form a yellow-brown crust.

symptoms.Skin: red rashes or blister
symptoms.Also common: itching

Impetigo.overview:
Description
A highly contagious skin infection that causes red sores on the face.
Impetigo mainly affects infants and children.
The main symptom is red sores that form around the nose and mouth. The sores rupture, ooze for a few days, then form a yellow-brown crust.
Antibiotics shorten the infection and can help prevent spread to others.
Impetigo.notes:
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Treatable by a medical professional
Spreads by skin-to-skin contact
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
HOW IT SPREADS
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Infant respiratory distress syndrome.symptomDescription: Symptoms include rapid, shallow breathing and a sharp, pulling-in of the chest below and between the ribs with each breath.

symptoms.Respiratory: fast breathing, shortness of breath, or episodes of no breathing
symptoms.Also common: respiratory distress syndrome, blue skin from poor circulation, insufficient urine production, or low birth weight

Infant respiratory distress syndrome.overview:
Description
A breathing disorder in newborns caused by immature lungs.
Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) is more common in premature babies born six weeks or more before their due dates. It usually develops within the first 24 hours after birth.
Symptoms include rapid, shallow breathing and a sharp, pulling-in of the chest below and between the ribs with each breath.
Treatment includes medication to keep the lungs open, breathing support and oxygen therapy.
Infant respiratory distress syndrome.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.Tracheal intubation: Inserting a tube into the windpipe (trachea) through the mouth or nose to keep the airway open. Done when someone cannot breathe on their own.
Supportive care.Mechanical ventilation: Using a machine to move air in and out of the lungs when a person cannot breathe on their own.
Supportive care.Continuous positive airway pressure (CPA: A machine that relieves nighttime breathing problems by pumping a steady flow of air through the nose.
Supportive care.Intubation: Inserting a tube into the lungs to protect or open the airway.
Supportive care.High-Frequency ventilation: Using a breathing machine with a respiratory rate much faster than normal. Helps prevent lung damage in premature babies and adults who can't breathe on their own.
Supportive care.Surfactant therapy: Improves the ability of the lungs to stay open.
Supportive care.Mouth-To-Mouth resuscitation: Assisting with breathing using a machine or device.
Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.

specialists.Neonatologist: Provides medical care for newborn infants.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Paediatric Pulmonologist: Treats lung disorders in children and infants.

Infertility.symptomDescription: The main symptom is an inability to get pregnant. In many cases, there are no additional symptoms.

symptoms.Common symptoms: inability to get pregnant or anxiety

Infertility.overview:
Description
Not getting pregnant, despite having carefully timed, unprotected sex for one year.
The cause of infertility may be difficult to determine but may include inadequate levels of certain hormones in both men and women, and trouble with ovulation in women.
The main symptom is an inability to get pregnant. In many cases, there are no additional symptoms.
Many treatments significantly improve the chances of getting pregnant. They include hormone treatments, fertility drugs and surgery. In addition, assisted reproduction uses various medical techniques to fertilise an egg.
Infertility.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Timed intercourse: Planning intercourse within 5 days of ovulation to improve likelihood of becoming pregnant.

Medication.Estrogen modulator: Mimics the effect of oestrogen on various tissues, including the breast, bones and reproductive organs.
Medication.Anti-diabetic medication: Controls the amount of sugar (glucose) in the blood.
Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.
Medication.Sex hormone suppression: Stops or slows the production of hormones involved in sexual health.

Medical procedure.Artificial insemination: Insertion of sperm directly into a woman's womb so she can get pregnant.
Medical procedure.Assisted reproductive technology: Medical procedures that help women become pregnant. Examples include artificial insemination (AI) and in vitro fertilization (IVF).
Medical procedure.Ovulation induction: Using medication to make the ovaries release eggs (ovulation).
Medical procedure.IVF: Mixing a woman's egg with a man's sperm in a test tube or lab dish.

Therapies.Counseling psychology: A branch of psychology that treats personal problems related to school, work, family and social life.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Inflammatory breast cancer.symptomDescription: The breasts become red, swollen and tender. Other symptoms include a rapid change in breast appearance, thickness or heaviness, along with unusual warmth.

symptoms.Breast: enlargement, discomfort, inverted nipple, lumps, or nipple discharge
symptoms.Skin: rashes, redness, or dimpled skin like an orange peel
symptoms.Also common: swelling or swollen lymph nodes

Inflammatory breast cancer.overview:
Description
A rare, rapidly developing cancer that makes the breast red, swollen and tender.
Inflammatory breast cancer blocks certain vessels in the skin covering the breast.
The breasts become red, swollen and tender. Other symptoms include a rapid change in breast appearance, thickness or heaviness, along with unusual warmth.
Treatments include chemotherapy, surgery and radiation.
Inflammatory breast cancer.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Surgery.Mastectomy: Surgical removal of some or all of the breast.

Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Estrogen modulator: Mimics the effect of oestrogen on various tissues, including the breast, bones and reproductive organs.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Nuclear Medicine Doctor: Applies radioactive substances to diagnose and treat disease.

Ingrown toenail.symptomDescription: Pain, redness,and swelling can occur at the affected nail.

symptoms.Common symptoms: redness, swelling, tenderness, or limping

Ingrown toenail.overview:
Description
A condition in which the corner or side of a toenail grows into the flesh.
The condition usually affects the big toe. People who have diabetes are at greater risk of complications.
Pain, redness,and swelling can occur at the affected nail.
Lifting or removing the toenail can help. Antibiotics might be required.
Ingrown toenail.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Warm soak: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.
Self-care.Better fitting footwear: Relieves pressure points on the foot.

Surgery.Matricectomy: Procedure to destroy all or some of the cells at the base of the nail to prevent the nail from growing.
Surgery.Nail surgery: Removal of all or part of the nail.

Medication.Narcotic: Relieves pain, dulls the senses and causes drowsiness. May become addictive.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Insect bites and stings.symptomDescription: Most bites cause mild stinging or itching. Some bites can trigger a life-threatening allergic reaction that requires emergency care. Breathing difficulty, facial swelling, dizziness, confusion and hives are symptoms of such a reaction.

symptoms.Skin: rashes or redness
symptoms.Also common: itching, stinging sensation, or swelling

Insect bites and stings.overview:
Description
The bite of an insect, such as a bee or mosquito, which usually causes mild symptoms.
While insect bites or stings alone may be harmless, in some cases they may transmit other diseases such as malaria or Lyme.
Most bites cause mild stinging or itching. Some bites can trigger a life-threatening allergic reaction that requires emergency care. Breathing difficulty, facial swelling, dizziness, confusion and hives are symptoms of such a reaction.
Most bites go away on their own. Common treatments are for symptom relief and include pain relievers, ice packs and soothing lotions. Bites that trigger a severe allergic reaction may require emergency care.
Insect bites and stings.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Supportive care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.

Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Aloe: A plant whose gel may help heal burns and other injuries when applied to the skin.
Self-care.Menthol: An oil made from mint that soothes sore throats and relieves itching.

Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Insomnia.symptomDescription: Symptoms may include difficulty falling or staying asleep and not feeling well-rested.

symptoms.Cognitive: lack of concentration or slowness in activity
symptoms.Also common: sleeping difficulty, depression, headache, or irritability

Insomnia.overview:
Description
Persistent problems falling and staying asleep.
Most cases of insomnia are related to poor sleeping habits, depression, anxiety, lack of exercise, chronic illness or certain medication.
Symptoms may include difficulty falling or staying asleep and not feeling well-rested.
Treatment for insomnia consists of improving sleep habits, behaviour therapy and identifying and treating underlying causes. Sleeping pills may also be used, but should be monitored for side effects.
Insomnia.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Self-care.Improved sleep habits: Good sleep practices include having a regular bedtime schedule and avoiding naps, caffeine and TV before bedtime.
Self-care.Light therapy: Exposure to bright light using a device called a light box. Mimics natural sunlight.

Therapies.Light therapy: Exposure to bright light using a device called a light box. Mimics natural sunlight.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.

Medication.Sedative: Causes drowsiness, calmness and dulled senses. Some types may become addictive.
Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.
Medication.Antidepressant: Taking medications designed to help relieve symptoms of depression. Some antidepressants also have other uses, such as treating chronic pain and certain anxiety disorders.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Insulin resistance.symptomDescription: Insulin resistance typically has no symptoms.

symptoms.Common symptoms: obesity, absence of menstruation, excessive hairiness, lipodystrophy, or skin tags

Insulin resistance.overview:
Description
A resistance to the hormone insulin, resulting in increasing blood sugar.
The hormone insulin helps control the amount of sugar (glucose) in the blood. With insulin resistance, the body's cells don't respond normally to insulin. Glucose can't enter the cells as easily, so it builds up in the blood. This can eventually lead to type 2 diabetes.
Insulin resistance typically has no symptoms.
Weight loss and exercise can help reverse insulin resistance.
Insulin resistance.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.
Self-care.Low carbohydrate diet: A diet that limits grains, starchy vegetables and fruit and emphasises foods high in protein and fat.
Self-care.Mediterranean diet: A diet that emphasises fruits, vegetables, whole grains, legumes, nuts, fish and olive oil.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Interstitial cystitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include bladder and pelvic pain or pressure and a frequent urge to urinate.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the bladder, pelvis, penis, or testicle
symptoms.Pain circumstances: can occur during urination or during sexual intercourse
symptoms.Urinary: frequent urge to urinate, frequent urination, bladder spasm, or excessive urination at night

Interstitial cystitis.overview:
Description
A chronic, painful bladder condition.
It's often mistaken for a urinary tract infection (UTI), but there is no infection.
Symptoms include bladder and pelvic pain or pressure and a frequent urge to urinate.
Painful bladder syndrome is often difficult to treat. Therapies may include medication, physiotherapy and biofeedback. Antibiotics haven't been shown to help with painful bladder syndrome.
Interstitial cystitis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Dietary modification: Adjusting diet to prevent or treat disease.
Self-care.Bladder training: Gradually increasing the amount of time from the point where an urge to urinate develops to urinating.
Self-care.Stress management: Pursuing an enjoyable activity or verbalising frustration to reduce stress and improve mental health.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Nerve pain medication: Blocks pain caused by damaged nerves.
Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.

Therapies.Biofeedback: Controlling the body's heartbeat, brainwaves, breathing and blood pressure by monitoring them with sensors.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Interstitial lung disease.symptomDescription: Symptoms include a dry cough. Shortness of breath can occur either at rest or after exertion.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or inability to exercise
symptoms.Respiratory: shortness of breath or fast breathing
symptoms.Also common: deformity of nails or weight loss

Interstitial lung disease.overview:
Description
A group of disorders that cause progressive scarring of lung tissue.
Interstitial lung disease may be caused by long-term exposure to hazardous materials, such as asbestos or coal dust, or it can be caused by an auto-immune disease such as rheumatoid arthritis. Once lung scarring occurs, it's generally irreversible.
Symptoms include a dry cough. Shortness of breath can occur either at rest or after exertion.
Treatment depends on the underlying cause but often includes steroids.
Interstitial lung disease.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.

Therapies.Pulmonary rehabilitation: Exercise, nutritional counselling, education and support to help people with chronic breathing problems improve their fitness.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.

Intrauterine growth restriction.symptomDescription: With this condition, a baby is born weighing less than 90 percent of other babies at the same gestational age.

symptoms.Common symptoms: low birth weight

Intrauterine growth restriction.overview:
Description
A condition in which a baby doesn't grow to normal weight during pregnancy.
Causes of intrauterine growth restriction vary but include placenta abnormalities, high blood pressure in the mother, infections and smoking or alcohol abuse.
With this condition, a baby is born weighing less than 90 percent of other babies at the same gestational age.
Ultrasounds during pregnancy help monitor a baby's weight. Depending on the results, the baby may need to be delivered early.
Intrauterine growth restriction.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required

Medical procedure.Preterm birth: A birth that occurs before the 37th week of pregnancy.
Medical procedure.Premature rupture of membranes: A condition in which a pregnant woman has a tear in the membranes surrounding the foetus (or her 'water breaks') well before labour has begun.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Maternal-Foetal Medicine Specialist: Focuses on the medical management of high-risk pregnancies.
specialists.Neonatologist: Provides medical care for newborn infants.

Iron deficiency.symptomDescription: Fatigue is the most common symptom.

symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, or light-headedness
symptoms.Heart: fast heart rate or palpitations
symptoms.Also common: brittle nails, pallor, or shortness of breath

Iron deficiency.overview:
Description
A condition of too little iron in the body.
Iron deficiency is a common cause of too few healthy red blood cells in the body (anaemia). In a pregnant woman, iron deficiency puts the baby at risk of developmental delays.
Fatigue is the most common symptom.
Treatment includes iron supplements and a focus on any underlying causes.
Iron deficiency.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.
Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Iron deficiency anaemia.symptomDescription: Iron deficiency often causes low blood cell levels (anaemia) and can delay the development of unborn babies.

symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, lethargy, light-headedness, or malaise
symptoms.Also common: brittle nails, hair loss, headache, irritability, restless legs syndrome, or shortness of breath

Iron deficiency anaemia.overview:
Description
Too few healthy red blood cells due to too little iron in the body.
Without enough iron, red blood cells can't carry enough oxygen to body tissues.
Iron deficiency often causes low blood cell levels (anaemia) and can delay the development of unborn babies.
Treatment includes iron supplements and a focus on any underlying causes.
Iron deficiency anaemia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.
Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Iron overload.symptomDescription: Symptoms are related to conditions that arise from iron overload such as diabetes, darkening of the skin, abnormal heart rhythm or arthritis.

symptoms.Pain types: can be arthritic
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, lethargy, or reduced hormone production
symptoms.Also common: abnormal heart rhythm, diabetes, erectile dysfunction (impotence), or hepatitis

Iron overload.overview:
Description
Too much iron in the body.
Iron overload is usually caused by an inherited condition called haemochromatosis. Excess iron can poison organs, which can lead to conditions such as cancer, irregular heartbeat and cirrhosis of the liver.
Symptoms are related to conditions that arise from iron overload such as diabetes, darkening of the skin, abnormal heart rhythm or arthritis.
Iron can be dropped to safe levels by regularly removing blood from the body.
Iron overload.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medical procedure.Bloodletting: Removal of blood to treat or prevent disease. Used rarely in modern times.

specialists.Hepatologist: Focuses on liver, gallbladder and biliary tree disorders.
specialists.Transfusion Medicine: Manages the transfusion of blood products and potential complications.
specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).symptomDescription: Symptoms include abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhoea and constipation.

symptoms.Pain types: can be recurrent in the abdomen
symptoms.Gastrointestinal: change in bowel habits, constipation, diarrhoea, inability to empty bowels, indigestion, nausea, passing excessive amounts of gas, or urgent need to defecate
symptoms.Also common: anxiety, depression, discomfort, loss of appetite, or symptoms alleviated by defecation

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).overview:
Description
An intestinal disorder causing pain in the stomach, wind, diarrhoea and constipation.
The cause of irritable bowel syndrome isn't well understood. A diagnosis is often made based on symptoms.
Symptoms include abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhoea and constipation.
Some people can control their symptoms by managing diet, lifestyle and stress. Others will need medication and counselling.
Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.High fiber diet: A diet rich in high-fibre foods, such as whole grains, beans, fruits and vegetables.
Self-care.Dietary fiber: The parts of plant foods that the body can't digest. Helps to control blood sugar, soften stools and maintain bowel health.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Stress management: Pursuing an enjoyable activity or verbalising frustration to reduce stress and improve mental health.
Self-care.Relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, meditation, yoga, rhythmic exercise and other activities that reduce symptoms of stress

Therapies.Biofeedback: Controlling the body's heartbeat, brainwaves, breathing and blood pressure by monitoring them with sensors.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Brief psychotherapy: Short-term counselling that focuses on achieving specific goals.

Medication.Antidiarrhoeal: Reduces frequency and urgency of bowel movements.
Medication.Gut antispasmodic: Helps reduce muscle contractions and slow the movement of food in the intestines. May decrease stomach acid.
Medication.Laxative: Loosens stools, increases bowel movements and relieves constipation.
Medication.Nerve pain medication: Blocks pain caused by damaged nerves.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Jet lag.symptomDescription: Fatigue and difficulty concentrating are symptoms.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or malaise
symptoms.Also common: headache, indigestion, irritability, or lack of concentration

Jet lag.overview:
Description
A sleep disorder that can affect those who travel quickly across multiple time zones.
Jet lag is a temporary sleep disorder. It occurs when the body's internal clock is out of sync with cues from a new time zone. Cues can include light exposure and eating times.
Fatigue and difficulty concentrating are symptoms.
Medication and light therapy may help.
Jet lag.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

Therapies.Light therapy: Exposure to bright light using a device called a light box. Mimics natural sunlight.

Jock itch.symptomDescription: Jock itch (a fungal infection of the groin area) causes an itchy, red, often ring-shaped rash.

symptoms.Common symptoms: itching, groin rash, or redness

Jock itch.overview:
Description
Fungal infection in the skin of the genitals, inner thighs and buttocks.
The condition most often occurs when people wear tight-fitting clothing that traps in moisture.
Jock itch (a fungal infection of the groin area) causes an itchy, red, often ring-shaped rash.
Treatment includes keeping the groin area clean and dry as well as applying topical antifungal medication.
Jock itch.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Antifungal: Kills or prevents growth of fungi.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Keratitis.symptomDescription: Eye redness, pain and blurred or decreased vision are symptoms.

symptoms.Visual: vision disorder, blurred vision, or sensitivity to light
symptoms.Eyes: redness, feeling of something in eye, or watery eyes

Keratitis.overview:
Description
Inflammation of the clear tissue on the front of the eye (cornea).
Keratitis is caused by infection, injury, disease or wearing contact lenses too long.
Eye redness, pain and blurred or decreased vision are symptoms.
Prompt medical attention is required to avoid loss of vision. Treatment includes medication such as antibiotics. In rare cases, antifungal drugs may be used.
Keratitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Artificial tears: Moistens eyes to provide soothing relief.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

Keratoconus.symptomDescription: Symptoms first appear during puberty or the late teens and include blurred vision and sensitivity to light and glare.

symptoms.Visual: blurred vision, distorted vision, astigmatism, double vision, inability to see in dim light, nearsightedness, sensitivity to light, or vision loss
symptoms.Also common: a rim of discolouration around the front of the eye (fleischer ring)

Keratoconus.overview:
Description
A condition in which the clear tissue on the front of the eye (cornea) bulges outward.
With keratoconus, the clear, dome-shaped tissue that covers the eye (cornea) thins and bulges outward into a cone shape. Its cause is unknown.
Symptoms first appear during puberty or the late teens and include blurred vision and sensitivity to light and glare.
Vision can be corrected with glasses or contact lenses early on. Advanced cases may require a cornea transplant.
Keratoconus.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Artificial tears: Moistens eyes to provide soothing relief.

Devices.Corneal implant: Small pieces of plastic placed in the front part of the eye to flatten it and correct vision.
Devices.Corrective lens: Corrective lenses placed over the eyes to improve vision.
Devices.Contact lenses: A lens placed directly on the eye to correct or assist with vision.

Surgery.Corneal transplantation: Surgical replacement of the clear outer layer of the eye (cornea) with a donated one.

Keratosis pilaris.symptomDescription: The bumps are usually on the arms, thighs, cheeks and buttocks. They're white, sometimes red, and typically don't hurt or itch.

symptoms.Skin: darkening of the skin, dryness, pimples, or redness
symptoms.Also common: follicular papules

Keratosis pilaris.overview:
Description
A condition that causes rough patches and small, acne-like bumps on the skin.
This condition develops when the skin produces too much of a protein called keratin, which can block hair follicles and cause bumps to develop.
The bumps are usually on the arms, thighs, cheeks and buttocks. They're white, sometimes red, and typically don't hurt or itch.
The condition isn't often serious and usually disappears by the age of 30. Medicated creams may help skin appearance.
Keratosis pilaris.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Kidney infection.symptomDescription: Fever, frequent urination and pain in the back, side or groin are symptoms.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the flank, back, or pelvis
symptoms.Urinary: urinary tract infection, cloudy urine, foul smelling urine, frequent urge to urinate, frequent urination, or blood in urine
symptoms.Whole body: chills, fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, or malaise
symptoms.Also common: fast heart rate

Kidney infection.overview:
Description
Inflammation of the kidney due to a bacterial infection.
The inflammation of the kidney is due to a specific type of urinary tract infection (UTI). The UTI usually begins in the urethra or bladder and travels to the kidneys.
Fever, frequent urination and pain in the back, side or groin are symptoms.
Treatment includes antibiotics and often requires hospitalisation.
Kidney infection.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Kidney stone.symptomDescription: The most common symptom is severe pain, usually in the side of the abdomen, that's often associated with nausea.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the back or side part of the body
symptoms.Pain types: can be severe, sharp, or sudden in the abdomen
symptoms.Urinary: blood in urine or frequent urination
symptoms.Also common: sweating

Kidney stone.overview:
Description
A small, hard deposit that forms in the kidneys and is often painful when passed.
Kidney stones are hard deposits of minerals and acid salts that stick together in concentrated urine. They can be painful when passing through the urinary tract, but usually don't cause permanent damage.
The most common symptom is severe pain, usually in the side of the abdomen, that's often associated with nausea.
Treatment includes pain relievers and drinking lots of water to help pass the stone. Medical procedures may be required to remove or break up larger stones.
Kidney stone.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.
Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Medical procedure.Extracorporeal shockwave therapy: Using shock waves to break up kidney stones and gallstones so they pass more easily.
Medical procedure.Ureteroscopic stone removal: Using a small camera inserted into the urethra to remove a kidney stone.
Medical procedure.Laser lithotripsy: Using heat from a laser to break up and remove stones in the kidney, gallbladder and urinary tract,

Medication.Narcotic: Relieves pain, dulls the senses and causes drowsiness. May become addictive.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Klinefelter syndrome.symptomDescription: Males born with Klinefelter's syndrome may have low testosterone and reduced muscle mass, facial hair and body hair. Most males with this condition produce little or no sperm.

symptoms.Common symptoms: breast enlargement in men, delayed puberty, flaccid muscles, infertility, low-set ears, osteoporosis, reduced sex drive, small penis, or adhd predominantly inattentive

Klinefelter syndrome.overview:
Description
A genetic condition in which a male is born with an extra copy of the X chromosome
Klinefelter's syndrome isn't inherited, but rather occurs only as a result of a random genetic error after conception.
Males born with Klinefelter's syndrome may have low testosterone and reduced muscle mass, facial hair and body hair. Most males with this condition produce little or no sperm.
Treatment may include testosterone replacement and fertility treatment.
Klinefelter syndrome.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

Medical procedure.Assisted reproductive technology: Medical procedures that help women become pregnant. Examples include artificial insemination (AI) and in vitro fertilization (IVF).

specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Kyphosis.symptomDescription: Some people with kyphosis have back pain and stiffness. Others have no symptoms other than an exaggerated forward rounding of the back.

symptoms.Muscular: instability or muscle weakness
symptoms.Also common: physical deformity, compression fracture, falling, short stature, stiffness, or mobility disability

Kyphosis.overview:
Description
A forward rounding of the back.
Hunchback (kyphosis) usually refers to an abnormally curved spine. It's most common in older women and often related to osteoporosis.
Some people with kyphosis have back pain and stiffness. Others have no symptoms other than an exaggerated forward rounding of the back.
Severe kyphosis can cause pain and be disfiguring. Treatment may include medication for pain, physiotherapy and sometimes surgery.
Kyphosis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Devices.Back brace: A device used to support and stabilise the back. In some cases, may be used to correct an abnormal curvature of the spine.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Surgery.Spinal surgery: Correcting abnormalities of the spinal cord or its surrounding bones through surgical methods.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Labyrinthitis.symptomDescription: Hearing loss, dizziness and a spinning sensation (vertigo) are common symptoms. Diagnosing labyrinthitis is challenging because these symptoms are also common in many other conditions.

symptoms.Also common: dizziness, hearing loss, or rapid involuntary eye movement

Labyrinthitis.overview:
Description
Inflammation of the inner ear or the nerves that connect the inner ear to the brain.
Labyrinthitis is usually triggered by an infection, such as a cold or flu.
Hearing loss, dizziness and a spinning sensation (vertigo) are common symptoms. Diagnosing labyrinthitis is challenging because these symptoms are also common in many other conditions.
Labyrinthitis usually goes away on its own. Medication can help manage symptoms. Vestibular rehabilitation therapy may help in some cases.
Labyrinthitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Therapies.Vestibular rehabilitation: A type of therapy focused on improving balance and stability for conditions affecting the inner ear.

Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.
Medication.Involuntary nervous system blocker: Used to diagnose and treat certain neurologic and cardiovascular conditions.
Medication.Antiemetic: Prevents or relieves nausea or vomiting.
Medication.Sedative: Causes drowsiness, calmness and dulled senses. Some types may become addictive.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.

Lactose intolerance.symptomDescription: Symptoms can include abdominal cramps, bloating and diarrhoea.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: belching, bloating, diarrhoea, fat in stool, indigestion, flatulence, or stomach cramps
symptoms.Also common: baby colic or malaise

Lactose intolerance.overview:
Description
The inability to fully digest sugar (lactose) in dairy products.
Lactose intolerance is usually caused by a deficiency of an enzyme in the body called lactase.
Symptoms can include abdominal cramps, bloating and diarrhoea.
Treatment focuses on avoidance of dairy products, use of lactose-free products or the use of lactase supplements.
Lactose intolerance.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Avoid lactose: Limiting lactose intake, found in dairy products, to reduce risk of stomach irritation.

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Laryngitis.symptomDescription: Laryngitis may last for a short time (acute) or be ongoing (chronic). The main symptoms are hoarseness and loss of voice.

symptoms.Whole body: fever or malaise
symptoms.Also common: phlegm, sleeping difficulty, or swollen lymph nodes

Laryngitis.overview:
Description
An inflammation of the voice box from overuse, irritation or infection.
A viral infection is the most common cause of laryngitis.
Laryngitis may last for a short time (acute) or be ongoing (chronic). The main symptoms are hoarseness and loss of voice.
Acute laryngitis usually resolves on its own. With chronic laryngitis, treatment is aimed at the underlying condition, such as heartburn or smoking.
Laryngitis.notes:
Spreads easily
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).

Self-care.Resting the voice: Allows for healing of irritated vocal cords.

Medication.Antacid: Counteracts the effects of stomach acid.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Proton-pump inhibitor: Decreases acid release in the stomach.

specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.

Latex allergy.symptomDescription: Symptoms range from minor skin irritation to life-threatening shock.

symptoms.Skin: blister, rashes, or redness
symptoms.Also common: itching, throat irritation, or watery eyes

Latex allergy.overview:
Description
An allergic reaction to certain proteins found in natural rubber latex.
A latex allergy is an immune system reaction to proteins in natural rubber latex, a product made from rubber tree fluids.
Symptoms range from minor skin irritation to life-threatening shock.
A person who is allergic to latex should avoid it. Antihistamine drugs can help minor reactions. Severe reactions may require emergency care.
Latex allergy.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Avoid allergen: Staying away from triggers that can cause allergic reactions, such as pollen or certain foods.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Allergy & Immunology Doctor: Treats allergy and immune system disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Lazy eye.symptomDescription: Symptoms include a wandering eye, eyes that may not appear to work together or poor depth perception. Both eyes may be affected.

symptoms.Visual: blurred vision or double vision
symptoms.Also common: eye misalignment

Lazy eye.overview:
Description
Decreased eyesight due to abnormal visual development.
Amblyopia occurs in early childhood. When nerve pathways between the brain and an eye aren't properly stimulated, the brain favours the other eye.
Symptoms include a wandering eye, eyes that may not appear to work together or poor depth perception. Both eyes may be affected.
Treatment includes eye patches, drops, glasses or contact lenses and sometimes surgery.
Lazy eye.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required

Devices.Bifocals: Eyeglasses with a lens that enables both near and far vision.
Devices.Corrective lens: Corrective lenses placed over the eyes to improve vision.
Devices.Contact lenses: A lens placed directly on the eye to correct or assist with vision.
Devices.Occlusion therapy: May be used to protect the eye following injury or can help align the eyes in childhood.

Medication.Involuntary nervous system blocker: Used to diagnose and treat certain neurologic and cardiovascular conditions.

Surgery.Eye surgery: Surgery to correct an abnormality of the eye.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Lead poisoning.symptomDescription: Symptoms include developmental delays, abdominal pain, neurological changes and irritability. At very high levels, it can be fatal.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or loss of appetite
symptoms.Behavioural: hyperactivity or irritability
symptoms.Also common: baby colic, headache, insomnia, or memory loss

Lead poisoning.overview:
Description
A build-up of lead in the body, usually over months or years.
Lead-based paint and its dust, usually found in older buildings, are common sources of exposure. Young children are especially at risk. Occupational exposure, such as welding, is a more common cause for adults.
Symptoms include developmental delays, abdominal pain, neurological changes and irritability. At very high levels, it can be fatal.
Treatment always involves avoiding further exposure to lead or lead-based products and may include medication to help remove lead from the body.
Lead poisoning.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Heavy metal toxicity medication: Attaches to and carries metals out of the body through urine or stool.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Toxicologist: Focuses on the effects of chemicals on health.
specialists.Occupational Medicine Doctor: Prevents and treats illness in the workplace.

Leukemia.symptomDescription: Many patients with slow-growing types of leukaemia don't have symptoms. Rapidly growing types of leukaemia may cause symptoms that include fatigue, weight loss, frequent infections and easy bleeding or bruising.

symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, fever, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: bleeding, easy bruising, frequent infections, mouth ulcer, nosebleed, pallor, red spots on skin, shortness of breath, swollen lymph nodes, unintentional weight loss, or weakness

Leukemia.overview:
Description
A cancer of blood-forming tissues, hindering the body's ability to fight infection.
Leukaemia is cancer of blood-forming tissues, including bone marrow. Many types exist such as acute lymphoblastic leukaemia, acute myeloid leukaemia and chronic lymphocytic leukaemia.
Many patients with slow-growing types of leukaemia don't have symptoms. Rapidly growing types of leukaemia may cause symptoms that include fatigue, weight loss, frequent infections and easy bleeding or bruising.
Treatment is highly variable. For slow-growing leukaemias, treatment may include monitoring. For aggressive leukaemias, treatment includes chemotherapy that's sometimes followed by radiation and stem-cell transplant.
Leukemia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
