Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.

Medical procedure.Haematopoietic stem cell transplantation: Transplanting stem cells to restore a person's immune system. The transplanted cells can come from a donor or be the person's own cells.

specialists.Paediatric haematologist-oncologist: Treats blood disorders and cancer in children.
specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.

Leukoplakia.symptomDescription: Thickened, white patches form on the gums, the insides of the cheeks, the bottom of the mouth and, sometimes, the tongue. The patches can't be scraped off.

symptoms.Common symptoms: mouth lesion or redness

Leukoplakia.overview:
Description
Thickened, white patches inside the mouth.
Most leukoplakia patches are non-cancerous, but some show early signs of cancer. They may be caused by tobacco products.
Thickened, white patches form on the gums, the insides of the cheeks, the bottom of the mouth and, sometimes, the tongue. The patches can't be scraped off.
For most people, stopping tobacco or alcohol use clears the condition. In rare cases when patches are persistent, surgery can remove them.
Leukoplakia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Smokeless tobacco cessation: Discontinuation of chewed or snuffed tobacco, which can aggravate or cause disease.

Medical procedure.Freezing: Using extreme cold during surgery or medical treatment.

specialists.Dentist: Specialises in diseases of the oral cavity, especially the teeth.
specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Lichen planus.symptomDescription: On skin, lichen planus appears as purplish, itchy, flat-topped bumps. On mucous membranes, such as in the mouth, it forms lacy, white patches, sometimes with painful sores.

symptoms.Skin: blister, darkening of the skin, loss of colour, peeling, rashes, small bump, ulcers, or redness
symptoms.Also common: hair loss, itching, or mouth ulcer

Lichen planus.overview:
Description
An inflammatory condition of the skin and mucous membranes.
Lichen planus occurs when the immune system mistakenly attacks cells of the skin or mucous membranes.
On skin, lichen planus appears as purplish, itchy, flat-topped bumps. On mucous membranes, such as in the mouth, it forms lacy, white patches, sometimes with painful sores.
Lichen planus usually goes away on its own. If symptoms are bothersome, topical creams and oral antihistamines may help.
Lichen planus.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Lichen sclerosus.extraName: Also called: LS, white spot disease
Lichen sclerosus.symptomDescription: Lichen sclerosus can cause discomfort, itching and easy bruising or tearing of the skin.

symptoms.Skin: loss of colour, rashes, or redness
symptoms.Also common: bruising, itching, skin tears, or vulval itch

Lichen sclerosus.overview:
Description
A chronic condition that causes thin, white patches of skin, usually in the genital area.
This condition occurs primarily in girls who haven't started menstruating and in postmenopausal women. Lichen sclerosus is thought to be related to genetics, immune disorders, trauma or infection.
Lichen sclerosus can cause discomfort, itching and easy bruising or tearing of the skin.
Treatment is usually topical corticosteroid ointments or creams used to reduce itching and complications.
Lichen sclerosus.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Liver cancer.symptomDescription: Symptoms are uncommon in the early stages of liver cancer. Later, symptoms may include weight loss, stomach pain, vomiting and yellowed skin.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: bloating, fluid in the abdomen, nausea, or vomiting
symptoms.Whole body: cancer-related fatigue, fatigue, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: itching, weight loss, or yellow skin and eyes

Liver cancer.overview:
Description
Cancer that begins in the cells of the liver.
The liver is the football-sized organ in the upper-right area of the stomach.
Symptoms are uncommon in the early stages of liver cancer. Later, symptoms may include weight loss, stomach pain, vomiting and yellowed skin.
Treatments vary but may include removal of part of the liver, transplant, chemotherapy and in some cases, radiation.
Liver cancer.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.

Medical procedure.Cryoablation: Using extreme cold to freeze and destroy diseased tissue, such as cancer cells.
Medical procedure.Percutaneous ethanol injection: Injecting 100% alcohol (ethanol) into tissue to kill abnormal cells.
Medical procedure.Embolization: Deliberately clogging abnormal blood vessels to block the flow of blood.
Medical procedure.Transarterial chemoembolization: Injecting anti-cancer drugs into the blood vessels of a tumour and then blocking them off to trap the medication in the tumour.
Medical procedure.SIR-Spheres: Tiny radioactive beads inserted into tumours to kill cancer cells.
Medical procedure.Radiofrequency ablation: Removal of tissue using the heat from an electric current produced by a radio wave.

Surgery.Liver transplantation: Surgical replacement of a diseased liver with some or all of a healthy liver from a donor.
Surgery.Hepatectomy: Surgical removal of all or part of the liver.

specialists.Palliative Medicine: Focuses on improving quality of life for those with severe illnesses.
specialists.Hepatologist: Focuses on liver, gallbladder and biliary tree disorders.
specialists.Transplant Surgeon: Transfers an organ from one body to another.
specialists.Interventional Radiologist: Uses image-guided procedures to diagnose and treat diseases.

Liver failure.symptomDescription: Yellowed skin and eyes (jaundice) along with stomach pain and swelling are symptoms of liver failure.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, loss of appetite, or water-electrolyte imbalance
symptoms.Also common: mental confusion, yellow skin and eyes, bad breath from liver disease, bleeding, bruising, flapping hand tremor, itching, or swelling

Liver failure.overview:
Description
Loss of liver function.
Liver failure occurs either suddenly (acute) or gradually (chronic). Causes include a reaction to medication, high doses of acetaminophen or paracetamol, hepatitis infection, alcohol abuse and advanced fatty liver.
Yellowed skin and eyes (jaundice) along with stomach pain and swelling are symptoms of liver failure.
Treatment options include medication, dietary changes or possibly a liver transplant.
Liver failure.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Self-care.Avoid alcohol: May be harmful and aggravate certain conditions.

Medication.Ammonia reducer: Reduces the amount of ammonia in the body.

specialists.Hepatologist: Focuses on liver, gallbladder and biliary tree disorders.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Long QT syndrome.symptomDescription: People with this condition may not develop symptoms for a long time. When symptoms do occur, they can be severe and may include sudden fainting, seizures or even sudden death.

symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fainting, or feeling faint
symptoms.Heart: abnormal heart rhythm, cardiac arrest, or palpitations
symptoms.Also common: seizures

Long QT syndrome.overview:
Description
A heart rhythm disorder that can potentially cause fast, chaotic heartbeats.
Long QT syndrome can be inherited or caused by a medication or condition. It often goes undiagnosed or is misdiagnosed as a seizure disorder, such as epilepsy.
People with this condition may not develop symptoms for a long time. When symptoms do occur, they can be severe and may include sudden fainting, seizures or even sudden death.
Treatment can involve medical devices, lifestyle changes or medication, such as beta blockers.
Long QT syndrome.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Cardiac monitoring: Using an electronic device to monitor heart rate and rhythm. Can be done in the hospital or at home.

Medication.Antiarrhythmic: Helps control abnormal or irregular heart rhythms.
Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.
Medication.Blood pressure support: Helps increase blood pressure when it's too low.

Self-care.Avoid strenuous exercise: Reduces the likelihood of exacerbating certain medical conditions.

Devices.Pacemaker: A small device placed in the chest or abdomen that sends out electrical signals to keep the heart beating normally.
Devices.Implantable cardioverter defibrillator: A small device placed in the chest or abdomen that shocks the heart if it develops a dangerously irregular heartbeat.

specialists.Cardiac Electrophysiologist: Treats patients with electrical and heart rhythm problems.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Lordosis.symptomDescription: Lordosis causes an unusually large, inward arch on the lower back, just above the buttocks. The condition may cause lower back pain.

symptoms.Also common: large inward arch in the lower back or physical deformity

Lordosis.overview:
Description
A curving inward of the lower back.
Some lordosis is normal. Too much is referred to as sway-back. It may be inherited or caused by conditions such as arthritis, muscular dystrophy and dwarfism.
Lordosis causes an unusually large, inward arch on the lower back, just above the buttocks. The condition may cause lower back pain.
In children, lordosis often fixes itself. Some adults with lordosis may need physiotherapy.
Lordosis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Devices.Back brace: A device used to support and stabilise the back. In some cases, may be used to correct an abnormal curvature of the spine.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Chiropractic treatment techniques: Adjusting the spine and massaging the back muscles to relieve pain.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Low back pain.symptomDescription: Often, the only symptom is pain in the lower back.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the back, muscles and bones, hip, or leg
symptoms.Sensory: leg numbness or pins and needles
symptoms.Also common: back joint dysfunction or muscle spasms

Low back pain.overview:
Description
A common, painful condition affecting the lower portion of the spine.
Low back pain is caused by injury to a muscle (strain) or ligament (sprain). Common causes include improper lifting, poor posture, lack of regular exercise, a fracture, a ruptured disc or arthritis.
Often, the only symptom is pain in the lower back.
Most low back pain goes away on its own in two to four weeks. Physiotherapy and pain relievers can help. A few cases may require surgery.
Low back pain.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
COMMON CAUSES
Lower back pain can have causes that aren't due to underlying disease. Examples include overuse such as working out or lifting too much, prolonged sitting and laying down, sleeping in an uncomfortable position, wearing a poorly fitting backpack.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Muscle relaxant: Reduces muscle tension and helps relieve muscle pain and discomfort.
Medication.Narcotic: Relieves pain, dulls the senses and causes drowsiness. May become addictive.

Self-care.Heating pad: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Joint manipulation: Stretching a joint past its current restricted range of motion to restore movement and reduce pain.
Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Acupuncture: Insertion of needles into specific points on the body to relieve pain and treat other conditions. A form of traditional Chinese medicine.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medical procedure.Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulat: Applying a small electrical current to a part of the body to dull the sensation of pain.
Medical procedure.Epidural steroid injection: Injection of cortisone and a numbing agent into the spine. Can relieve back, neck, arm and leg pain.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Pain Management: Eases suffering and improves quality of life for those in pain.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Low blood sugar (hypoglycaemia).symptomDescription: Confusion, heart palpitations, shakiness and anxiety are symptoms.

symptoms.Whole body: excess sweating, excessive hunger, fainting, fatigue, light-headedness, or shakiness
symptoms.Cognitive: mental confusion or unresponsiveness
symptoms.Also common: anxiety, blurred vision, headache, irritability, pallor, palpitations, sensation of pins and needles, sleepiness, slurred speech, tremor, or unsteadiness

Low blood sugar (hypoglycaemia).overview:
Description
Low blood sugar, the body's main source of energy.
Diabetes treatment and other conditions can cause hypoglycaemia.
Confusion, heart palpitations, shakiness and anxiety are symptoms.
Consuming high-sugar foods or drinks, such as orange juice or regular fizzy drinks, can treat this condition. Alternatively, medication can be used to raise blood sugar levels. It's also important that a doctor identifies and treats the underlying cause.
Low blood sugar (hypoglycaemia).notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Consume food or drink that is high in su: Relieves symptoms related to low blood sugar.

Supportive care.Glucose: Form of sugar injected or taken by mouth when a person's blood sugar level falls too low.

Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Lumbar spinal stenosis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include pain or cramping in the legs when standing for long periods or when walking. The discomfort usually eases when bending forward or sitting down.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the back and leg, legs, thighs and buttocks that worsens with standing, lower back, or leg
symptoms.Pain circumstances: can occur in the leg while exercising
symptoms.Muscular: cramping or muscle weakness
symptoms.Sensory: leg numbness or pins and needles
symptoms.Also common: stiffness

Lumbar spinal stenosis.overview:
Description
A narrowing of the open spaces in the lower (lumbar) spine.
Lumbar spinal stenosis can put pressure on the spinal cord and the nerves that travel through the spine. Age-related changes are the most common cause.
Symptoms include pain or cramping in the legs when standing for long periods or when walking. The discomfort usually eases when bending forward or sitting down.
Treatments include medication such as anti-inflammatories, physiotherapy, injections and surgery.
Lumbar spinal stenosis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Surgery.Spinal surgery: Correcting abnormalities of the spinal cord or its surrounding bones through surgical methods.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Pain Management: Eases suffering and improves quality of life for those in pain.

Lung cancer.symptomDescription: Symptoms include a cough (often with blood), chest pain, wheezing and weight loss. These symptoms often don't appear until the cancer is advanced.

symptoms.Cough: can be chronic, dry, with phlegm, or with blood
symptoms.Respiratory: frequent respiratory infections, shortness of breath, or wheezing
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: hoarseness, swollen lymph nodes, weakness, or weight loss

Lung cancer.overview:
Description
A cancer that begins in the lungs and most often occurs in people who smoke.
Two major types of lung cancer are non-small cell lung cancer and small cell lung cancer. Causes of lung cancer include smoking, second-hand smoke, exposure to certain toxins and family history.
Symptoms include a cough (often with blood), chest pain, wheezing and weight loss. These symptoms often don't appear until the cancer is advanced.
Treatments vary but may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, targeted drug therapy and immunotherapy.
Lung cancer.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Targeted therapy: Slows cancer cell growth by targeting a cancer cell's distinguishing features or factors.

Surgery.Pulmonary lobectomy: Surgical removal of a part (lobe) of a lung.
Surgery.Wedge resection: Surgical removal of a triangular piece of tissue from the lung.
Surgery.Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery: Surgery using a tiny camera inserted in the chest through a small cut. Allows doctors to see inside the chest and lungs without making a big opening.

Medical procedure.Thoracotomy: A large surgical opening in the chest that provides access to the throat, heart and lungs.
Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

Supportive care.Palliative care: Works to improve quality of life while adjusting or recovering from a serious illness.

specialists.Palliative Medicine: Focuses on improving quality of life for those with severe illnesses.
specialists.Cardiothoracic Surgeon: Surgically treats diseases affecting organs inside the chest.

Lupus.extraName: Also called: SLE, systemic lupus erythematosus
Lupus.symptomDescription: Symptoms vary but can include fatigue, joint pain, rash and fever. These can periodically get worse (flare up) and then improve.

symptoms.Pain types: can be sharp in the chest
symptoms.Whole body: anaemia, fatigue, fever, or malaise
symptoms.Hair: hair loss or loss of scalp hair
symptoms.Skin: red rashes or scaly rashes
symptoms.Also common: anxiety, blood in urine, clinical depression, face rash, flare, headache, joint stiffness, raynaud's, sensitivity to light, swelling, water retention, or weight loss

Lupus.overview:
Description
An inflammatory disease caused when the immune system attacks its own tissues.
Lupus (SLE) can affect the joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart and lungs.
Symptoms vary but can include fatigue, joint pain, rash and fever. These can periodically get worse (flare up) and then improve.
While there's no cure for lupus, current treatments focus on improving quality of life through controlling symptoms and minimising flare-ups. This begins with lifestyle modifications, including sun protection and diet. Further disease management includes medication such as anti-inflammatories and steroids.
Lupus.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Self-care.Sunblock: Protects against the sun's UV rays, which can damage the skin over time.
Self-care.Sun protective clothing: Reduces exposure to the sun's UV rays, which can damage the skin over time.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.

Lymphedema.symptomDescription: The main symptom is swelling in an arm or leg that may be accompanied by pain or discomfort.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the arms or legs or skin
symptoms.Skin: dimpled skin like an orange peel or rashes
symptoms.Also common: swelling in extremities, frequent skin infections of affected limb, swollen lymph nodes, or water retention

Lymphedema.overview:
Description
Swelling in an arm or leg caused by a lymphatic system blockage.
The condition is caused by a blockage in the lymphatic system, part of the immune and circulatory systems. Lymphoedema is most commonly caused by lymph node removal or damage due to cancer treatment.
The main symptom is swelling in an arm or leg that may be accompanied by pain or discomfort.
Exercise, wrapping, massage and compression can help.
Lymphedema.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Devices.Elastic bandage: Stretchy bandages used to wrap sprains and strains. Provides support and compression during recovery.
Devices.Compression stockings: Elastic hosiery that squeeze blood up the legs to prevent swelling and blood clots.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.

specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Macular degeneration.symptomDescription: Blurred vision is a key symptom.

symptoms.Visual: partial loss of vision, abnormality where straight lines appear wavy, blurred vision, distorted vision, inability to see in dim light, or seeing spots
symptoms.Also common: new and abnormal blood vessels

Macular degeneration.overview:
Description
An eye disease that causes vision loss.
Macular degeneration causes loss in the centre of the field of vision. In dry macular degeneration, the centre of the retina deteriorates. With wet macular degeneration, leaky blood vessels grow under the retina.
Blurred vision is a key symptom.
A special combination of vitamins and minerals (AREDS formula) may reduce disease progression. Surgery may also be an option.
Macular degeneration.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Surgery.Laser surgery: Surgery using an intensely hot and focused beam of light to remove tissue and control bleeding.

Medication.VEGFR inhibitor: Prevents the growth of abnormal blood vessels.
Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

Devices.Corrective lens: Corrective lenses placed over the eyes to improve vision.
Devices.Glasses: A frame worn on the nose that holds a set of lenses to correct vision or protect the eyes.
Devices.Contact lenses: A lens placed directly on the eye to correct or assist with vision.

specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.

Malabsorption.symptomDescription: Symptoms include weight loss, bloating and sometimes diarrhoea. Eventually, the brain, nervous system, bones, liver and other organs can be affected.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: diarrhoea, flatulence, bloating, or fat in stool
symptoms.Also common: weight loss or cramping

Malabsorption.overview:
Description
A condition that prevents absorption of nutrients through the small intestine.
Malabsorption may be caused by infection, medication, small intestine surgery and disorders such as coeliac disease.
Symptoms include weight loss, bloating and sometimes diarrhoea. Eventually, the brain, nervous system, bones, liver and other organs can be affected.
Treatment depends on the underlying disorder causing malabsorption, but may include nutritional supplements.
Malabsorption.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required

Supportive care.Electrolyte repletion: Low levels of electrolytes like potassium or magnesium can cause symptoms like palpitations or muscle cramps.
Supportive care.Vitamin repletion: Replacing low levels of vitamins that can cause or contribute to disease.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Malaria.symptomDescription: Symptoms are chills, fever and sweating, usually occurring a few weeks after being bitten.

symptoms.Whole body: chills, fatigue, fever, night sweats, shivering, or sweating
symptoms.Also common: fast heart rate, headache, mental confusion, or pallor

Malaria.overview:
Description
A disease caused by a plasmodium parasite, transmitted by the bite of infected mosquitoes.
The severity of malaria varies based on the species of plasmodium.
Symptoms are chills, fever and sweating, usually occurring a few weeks after being bitten.
People travelling to areas where malaria is common typically take protective drugs before, during and after their trip. Treatment includes antimalarial drugs.
Malaria.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Spreads by animals or insects
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care
HOW IT SPREADS
By animal or insect bites or stings.
By blood products (unclean needles or unscreened blood).

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Male or Female pattern baldness.symptomDescription: With male pattern baldness, hair loss typically occurs on the top and front of the head. With female pattern baldness, thinning occurs on the top and crown of the head. This thinning in women often starts as a widening of the centre hair part that leaves the front hairline unaffected.

symptoms.Common symptoms: hair loss

Male or Female pattern baldness.overview:
Description
Permanent hair loss from the scalp, causing baldness.
While the patterns of baldness for men and women differ, they both have a common genetic cause.
With male pattern baldness, hair loss typically occurs on the top and front of the head. With female pattern baldness, thinning occurs on the top and crown of the head. This thinning in women often starts as a widening of the centre hair part that leaves the front hairline unaffected.
Medication may prevent further hair loss. In some cases, surgeons can transplant hair or reduce the area of bald skin. Natural-looking wigs and hairpieces can help cover hair loss.
Male or Female pattern baldness.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Devices.Wig: Head covering made from real or artificial hair.
Devices.Hair extensions: Attaching hair extensions to one's own hair to increase length and fullness.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Malnutrition.symptomDescription: Symptoms are fatigue, dizziness and weight loss. Untreated malnutrition can cause physical or mental disability.

symptoms.Developmental: failure to thrive, short stature, or slow growth
symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, or water-electrolyte imbalance
symptoms.Muscular: muscle weakness or loss of muscle
symptoms.Also common: weight loss

Malnutrition.overview:
Description
Lack of sufficient nutrients in the body.
Malnutrition occurs when the body doesn't get enough nutrients. Causes include a poor diet, digestive conditions or another disease.
Symptoms are fatigue, dizziness and weight loss. Untreated malnutrition can cause physical or mental disability.
Treatment must address any underlying conditions and replace missing nutrients.
Malnutrition.notes:
Medium-term: resolves within months
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Supportive care.Rehydration: Replacing lost body fluid by drinking more fluids or administering fluids by intravenous therapy (IV).

Self-care.Breastfeeding: Feeding a baby with milk from the mother's breast.
Self-care.High-protein diet: A diet high in meat, fish, chicken, dairy, soy and other protein sources.

Marfan syndrome.symptomDescription: People with Marfan syndrome are tall and thin with long arms, legs, fingers and toes.

symptoms.Heart: mitral valve prolapse or murmur
symptoms.Mouth: abnormally raised roof of the mouth or crowded teeth
symptoms.Visual: blurred vision or nearsightedness
symptoms.Also common: abnormally long fingers, collapsed lung, disproportionately long arms and legs, double jointed, fatigue, flat feet, scoliosis, small pupils, stretch marks, or tall and slender build

Marfan syndrome.overview:
Description
An inherited disorder that affects connective tissue.
Marfan syndrome affects the heart, eyes, blood vessels and bones.
People with Marfan syndrome are tall and thin with long arms, legs, fingers and toes.
Treatment includes medication to keep blood pressure low, glasses or contact lenses and surgery.
Marfan syndrome.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Devices.Back brace: A device used to support and stabilise the back. In some cases, may be used to correct an abnormal curvature of the spine.
Devices.Glasses: A frame worn on the nose that holds a set of lenses to correct vision or protect the eyes.
Devices.Contact lenses: A lens placed directly on the eye to correct or assist with vision.

Surgery.Vitrectomy: Surgical removal of the clear, jelly-like substance (vitreous gel) that fills the inside of the eye.
Surgery.Endovascular aneurysm repair: Surgical repair of a bulge (aneurysm) in the main blood vessel of the body (aorta) to prevent bleeding or rupture.
Surgery.Vascular grafting: Surgery to bypass a blocked or diseased blood vessel using a vein or a synthetic tube (graft).
Surgery.Heart valve repair: Surgical repair of a damaged heart valve. An alternative to heart valve replacement.

Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Cardiothoracic Surgeon: Surgically treats diseases affecting organs inside the chest.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Mastoiditis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include redness, swelling and tenderness around the bone. Fever, ear pain and discharge are possible.

symptoms.Also common: tenderness, fever, headache, pus, redness, or swelling

Mastoiditis.overview:
Description
An infection that affects the mastoid bone, located behind the ear.
Mastoiditis is usually caused by a middle ear infection. This infection can result in damage to the mastoid bone and the formation of pus-filled cysts.
Symptoms include redness, swelling and tenderness around the bone. Fever, ear pain and discharge are possible.
Antibiotics can usually clear the infection. In severe cases, surgery may be required.
Mastoiditis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medical procedure.Incision and drainage: Cutting or puncturing the skin to drain an infection such as an abscess or boil.

Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.

specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.

Melasma.symptomDescription: The brown or grey-brown patches of melasma appear most often on the cheeks, forehead, nose and chin.

symptoms.Common symptoms: darkening of the skin

Melasma.overview:
Description
A condition in which brown patches appear on the face.
Melasma can be due to hormonal changes during pregnancy or from sun exposure. Women are much more likely than men to develop this condition.
The brown or grey-brown patches of melasma appear most often on the cheeks, forehead, nose and chin.
In women, melasma often fades on its own after pregnancy or after an affected woman stops taking contraceptive pills. Skin lightening creams can help lasting melasma.
Melasma.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Depigmenting agent: Bleaches or fades skin colour. Some also reduce swelling and acne.
Medication.Vitamin A derivative: Unplugs blocked hair follicles and helps prevent new blockages from forming. Slows skin cell growth.
Medication.Topical antiseptic: Destroys or prevents the growth of microorganisms on the skin that may cause infection.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Meningitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include headache, fever and stiff neck.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the back, muscles, or neck
symptoms.Whole body: fever, chills, fatigue, lethargy, loss of appetite, malaise, or shivering
symptoms.Skin: blotchy rashes or red rashes
symptoms.Also common: irritability, light sensitivity, headache, stiff neck, mental confusion, bulging fontanelle, fast breathing, fast heart rate, fear of loud sounds, headache, lack of interest in feeding in infants, sleepiness, sluggishness, or stiff back

Meningitis.overview:
Description
Inflammation of brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection.
Meningitis is usually caused by a viral infection but can also be bacterial or fungal. Vaccines can prevent some forms of meningitis.
Symptoms include headache, fever and stiff neck.
Depending on the cause, meningitis may get better on its own or it can be life-threatening, requiring urgent antibiotic treatment.
Meningitis.notes:
Some types preventable by vaccine
Treatable by a medical professional
Spreads by airborne droplets
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.

Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.
Supportive care.Hospitalization: A higher level of care whereby patients are closely monitored and may be given medications that would not be available at home.

specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Menopause.symptomDescription: Common symptoms include hot flashes and vaginal dryness. There may also be sleep disturbances. The combination of these symptoms can cause anxiety or depression.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, night sweats, osteoporosis, hot flashes, or sweating
symptoms.Menstrual: absence of menstruation or irregular menstruation
symptoms.Hair: dryness or loss of scalp hair
symptoms.Also common: anxiety, dry skin, irritability, moodiness, reduced sex drive, or vaginal dryness

Menopause.overview:
Description
A natural decline in reproductive hormones when a woman reaches her 40s or 50s.
Menopause is signalled by 12 months since last menstruation.
Common symptoms include hot flashes and vaginal dryness. There may also be sleep disturbances. The combination of these symptoms can cause anxiety or depression.
Menopause is a natural process with treatments that focus on symptomatic relief. Vaginal dryness is treated with topical lubricants or oestrogen. Medications can reduce the severity and frequency of hot flushes. In special circumstances, oral hormone therapy may be used.
Menopause.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging often required

Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

Self-care.Relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, meditation, yoga, rhythmic exercise and other activities that reduce symptoms of stress

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Metabolic syndrome.symptomDescription: Aside from a large waist circumference, most of the disorders associated with metabolic syndrome have no symptoms.

symptoms.Also common: diabetes, high blood pressure, or pot belly

Metabolic syndrome.overview:
Description
A cluster of conditions that increase the risk of heart disease, stroke and diabetes.
Metabolic syndrome includes high blood pressure, high blood sugar, excess body fat around the waist and abnormal cholesterol levels. The syndrome increases a person's risk of heart attack and stroke.
Aside from a large waist circumference, most of the disorders associated with metabolic syndrome have no symptoms.
Weight loss, exercise, a healthy diet and smoking cessation can help. Medication may also be prescribed.
Metabolic syndrome.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.
Self-care.Dietary modification: Adjusting diet to prevent or treat disease.
Self-care.Blood glucose monitoring: Using an electronic device to check the amount of sugar in a drop of blood.

Medication.Anti-diabetic medication: Controls the amount of sugar (glucose) in the blood.

Microcephaly.symptomDescription: Symptoms vary and include intellectual disability and speech delay. In severe cases, there may be seizures and abnormal muscle functionality.

symptoms.Developmental: delayed development, failure to thrive, learning disability, short stature, or slow growth
symptoms.Behavioural: hyperactivity, impulsivity, or irritability
symptoms.Also common: misshapen face, hearing loss, intellectual disability, malnutrition, poor coordination, speech impairment, or vision disorder

Microcephaly.overview:
Description
A condition in which a baby's head is significantly smaller than expected, often due to abnormal brain development.
Causes of microcephaly include infections, malnutrition or exposure to toxins.
Symptoms vary and include intellectual disability and speech delay. In severe cases, there may be seizures and abnormal muscle functionality.
There is no cure for microcephaly. Treatment involves supportive care, symptom management and close monitoring.
Microcephaly.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Occupational Therapy: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.

specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Neonatologist: Provides medical care for newborn infants.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Paediatric Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats children in intensive care.
specialists.Maternal-Foetal Medicine Specialist: Focuses on the medical management of high-risk pregnancies.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Migraine.symptomDescription: Migraine headaches can cause throbbing in one particular area that can vary in intensity. Nausea and sensitivity to light and sound are also common symptoms.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the eyes, face, or neck
symptoms.Pain types: can be dull
symptoms.Headache: can be acute, frequent, or throbbing
symptoms.Visual: sensitivity to light, distorted vision, or seeing flashes of light
symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, light-headedness, or malaise
symptoms.Sensory: aura or sensitivity to sound
symptoms.Also common: irritability, nasal congestion, or scalp tenderness

Migraine.overview:
Description
A headache of varying intensity, often accompanied by nausea and sensitivity to light and sound.
Migraine headaches are sometimes preceded by warning symptoms. Triggers include hormonal changes, certain food and drink, stress and exercise.
Migraine headaches can cause throbbing in one particular area that can vary in intensity. Nausea and sensitivity to light and sound are also common symptoms.
Preventive and pain-relieving medication can help manage migraine headaches.
Migraine.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Stress management: Pursuing an enjoyable activity or verbalising frustration to reduce stress and improve mental health.
Self-care.Improved sleep habits: Good sleep practices include having a regular bedtime schedule and avoiding naps, caffeine and TV before bedtime.
Self-care.Avoid migraine triggers: Common triggers include alcohol, caffeine or poor sleep.
Self-care.Diet modification: Adjusting diet to reduce triggers causing disease or address dietary deficiencies.

Medication.Antipsychotic: Reduces or improves the symptoms of certain psychiatric conditions.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Stimulant: Increases neurotransmitter levels, heart rate and blood pressure. Decreases appetite and sleep.
Medication.Nerve pain medication: Blocks pain caused by damaged nerves.
Medication.Triptan: Relieves pain and symptoms associated with migraines and cluster headaches.
Medication.Neurotoxin: Reduces or eliminates muscle activity and spasms by paralysing muscles.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

Therapies.Progressive muscle relaxation: Tensing and then relaxing muscle groups from head to toe or vice versa.
Therapies.Acupuncture: Insertion of needles into specific points on the body to relieve pain and treat other conditions. A form of traditional Chinese medicine.

Misaligned teeth.symptomDescription: In addition to misaligned teeth, symptoms may include discomfort or difficulty while chewing.

symptoms.Also common: misaligned teeth or physical deformity

Misaligned teeth.overview:
Description
The abnormal alignment of the upper and lower teeth.
Misaligned teeth can happen as teeth develop or from childhood habits, such as thumb sucking. The most common cause is when the jaw is too small compared with the size of the teeth.
In addition to misaligned teeth, symptoms may include discomfort or difficulty while chewing.
Treatments might include braces and repair of irregular teeth.
Misaligned teeth.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Devices.Dentures: False teeth used to replace missing teeth.
Devices.Clear aligners: Transparent device used to straighten teeth. An alternative to traditional metal braces.
Devices.Braces: Wires connecting brackets glued to the teeth to fix problems with tooth alignment.

Surgery.Orthognathic surgery: Surgery to correct deformities of the jaw such as for an overbite or underbite.
Surgery.Maxillomandibular advancement: Surgery to move the upper and lower jaw forward. Done to expand the airway and improve breathing.

specialists.Dentist: Specialises in diseases of the oral cavity, especially the teeth.

Miscarriage.symptomDescription: Symptoms include fluid, blood or tissue passing from the vagina and pain in the stomach or lower back. It’s also common to feel sadness or grief.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the abdomen, lower back, or pelvis
symptoms.Groin: vaginal bleeding, uterine contraction, or vaginal discharge
symptoms.Also common: cramping, irregular uterine bleeding, or fatigue

Miscarriage.overview:
Description
The spontaneous loss of a woman's pregnancy before the 20th week that can be both physically and emotionally painful.
Miscarriage is the most common type of pregnancy loss and often occurs because the foetus isn't developing normally.
Symptoms include fluid, blood or tissue passing from the vagina and pain in the stomach or lower back. It’s also common to feel sadness or grief.
Unfortunately, the miscarriage process can’t be reversed once it has started. However, medication or procedures such as a dilation and curettage can prevent certain types of complications. In addition, counselling and support are widely available.
Miscarriage.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Medication.Progesterone blocker: Blocks progesterone, a hormone that regulates menstruation and pregnancy.
Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

Medical procedure.Medical abortion: Abortion induced by medication instead of surgery. Often called the abortion pill.
Medical procedure.Dilation and curettage: Surgical removal of the lining of the womb (uterus) by scraping and scooping.
Medical procedure.Vacuum aspiration: Removing the contents of the womb (uterus) through a hollow needle or narrow tube.
Medical procedure.Dilation and evacuation: Expanding the entrance to the womb (cervix) and then removing the womb's contents by scraping and vacuuming.

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Misophonia.symptomDescription: People with misophonia can become irritated, enraged or even panicked when they hear their trigger sounds.

symptoms.Mood: anger or anxiety
symptoms.Psychological: fear of loud sounds or depression
symptoms.Also common: aggression or irritation

Misophonia.overview:
Description
A strong reaction to specific sounds.
Misophonia may cause a reaction to sounds such as dripping water, chewing, snapping gum or repetitive noises, such as pencil tapping.
People with misophonia can become irritated, enraged or even panicked when they hear their trigger sounds.
Treatment might involve therapy or lifestyle recommendations, such as using sound protection or creating "noise-free" zones within living spaces.
Misophonia.notes:
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Noise avoidance: Reducing exposure to high volume areas like busy streets or concerts.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Improved sleep habits: Good sleep practices include having a regular bedtime schedule and avoiding naps, caffeine and TV before bedtime.

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Music therapy: Applying music to improve physical or mental health with the help of a music therapist.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.

specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.

Mitral valve prolapse.symptomDescription: Symptoms may include an irregular heartbeat, palpitations and shortness of breath.

symptoms.Heart: abnormal heart rhythm, irregular heart rate, murmur, or palpitations
symptoms.Also common: chest pressure, regurgitation, or shortness of breath

Mitral valve prolapse.overview:
Description
Improper closure of the valve between the heart's upper and lower-left chambers.
Mitral valve prolapse can develop at any age. It can run in families and may be linked to other conditions, such as infection and connective tissue disease.
Symptoms may include an irregular heartbeat, palpitations and shortness of breath.
Most people don't require treatment, but some cases may need medication or surgery.
Mitral valve prolapse.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.

Surgery.Mitral valve repair: Surgery to improve blood flow through the mitral valve of the heart. Done when the valve is too narrow or leaking.

Molar pregnancy.symptomDescription: The pregnancy may seem normal at first, but when symptoms develop they include dark brown to bright red vaginal bleeding during the first trimester, along with severe nausea and vomiting.

symptoms.Also common: absence of menstruation, vaginal bleeding, fast heart rate, or high blood pressure

Molar pregnancy.overview:
Description
A non-cancerous tumour that develops in the uterus as a result of a non-viable pregnancy.
There may or may not be an embryo or placental tissue present. If there is an embryo, it unfortunately won't be able to survive.
The pregnancy may seem normal at first, but when symptoms develop they include dark brown to bright red vaginal bleeding during the first trimester, along with severe nausea and vomiting.
The tumour must be removed to avoid serious complications.
Molar pregnancy.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medical procedure.Dilation and curettage: Surgical removal of the lining of the womb (uterus) by scraping and scooping.

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Molluscum contagiosum.symptomDescription: Though painless, the small bumps might itch. Scratched bumps can spread infection to surrounding skin.

symptoms.Skin: small bump, lumps, or redness

Molluscum contagiosum.overview:
Description
A viral skin infection that results in round, firm, painless bumps.
The condition spreads through contact with an infected person or a contaminated object.
Though painless, the small bumps might itch. Scratched bumps can spread infection to surrounding skin.
The bumps usually disappear on their own. In rare cases, the bumps can be removed using medication or other procedures.
Molluscum contagiosum.notes:
Spreads easily
Usually self-treatable
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months
HOW IT SPREADS
By having unprotected vaginal, anal or oral sex.
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.

Medical procedure.Freezing: Using extreme cold during surgery or medical treatment.
Medical procedure.Tissue scraping: Removal of tissue by scraping or scooping with a surgical instrument called a curette.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Morton's neuroma.symptomDescription: Morton's neuroma may feel like a pebble in a shoe or a fold in a sock. There may be sharp, burning pain or numbness in the ball of the foot or toes.

symptoms.Sensory: pins and needles or reduced sensation of touch
symptoms.Also common: lump in the sole of the foot or sensation of walking on a marble

Morton's neuroma.overview:
Description
A thickening of the tissue around a nerve leading to the toes.
Morton's neuroma may be caused by pressure or injury, such as from running or use of high heels.
Morton's neuroma may feel like a pebble in a shoe or a fold in a sock. There may be sharp, burning pain or numbness in the ball of the foot or toes.
Treatment might include arch supports and foot pads, corticosteroid injections, strength exercises, wide-toe shoes or surgery.
Morton's neuroma.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Padding area: Using soft cotton or fabric to reduce pressure on the affected area.
Self-care.Taping area: Applying tape to stabilise or pad an injury.
Self-care.Well-Fitting shoes: Relieves pressure points on the foot.
Self-care.Activity modifications: Adjusting amount or type of physical activity to avoid aggravating a condition.
Self-care.Rest: Reducing activity for a short period of time following an injury to promote healing.
Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.

Devices.Brace: A device applied to the body to help stabilise, protect or limit movement of a damaged joint.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Local anesthetic: Blocks pain at and near the site where it's given, or along the nerve that's blocked.

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Motion sickness.symptomDescription: Symptoms include fatigue, uneasiness, dizziness and vomiting.

symptoms.Whole body: balance disorder, dizziness, or malaise
symptoms.Also common: headache, pallor, or palpitations

Motion sickness.overview:
Description
Illness caused by motion during travel.
Travel by car, air or boat can all cause motion sickness. Motion sickness usually goes away when the motion stops.
Symptoms include fatigue, uneasiness, dizziness and vomiting.
Focusing the eyes on objects straight ahead may help. Avoid overeating, alcohol and smoking before travel. Oral or patch medications can prevent or treat symptoms.
Motion sickness.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Supportive care.Avoidance of triggers: Reducing exposure to environmental factors that can contribute to disease.

Medication.Involuntary nervous system blocker: Used to diagnose and treat certain neurologic and cardiovascular conditions.
Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.

Multiple myeloma.symptomDescription: Symptoms may not be present or may be non-specific, such as loss of appetite, bone pain and fever.

symptoms.Whole body: anaemia, fatigue, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: constipation, hypercalcemia, increased risk of infection, kidney damage, or weight loss

Multiple myeloma.overview:
Description
A cancer of plasma cells.
The plasma cells are a type of white blood cell in the bone marrow. With this condition, a group of plasma cells becomes cancerous and multiplies. The disease can damage the bones, immune system, kidneys and red blood cell count.
Symptoms may not be present or may be non-specific, such as loss of appetite, bone pain and fever.
Treatments include medication, chemotherapy, corticosteroids, radiation or a stem-cell transplant.
Multiple myeloma.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Surgery.Autotransplantation: Transfer of organs or tissue from one part of the body to another in the same person.

Multiple sclerosis.symptomDescription: Multiple sclerosis causes many different symptoms, including vision loss, pain, fatigue and impaired coordination. The symptoms, severity and duration can vary from person to person. Some people may be symptom free for most of their lives, while others can have severe, chronic symptoms that never go away.

symptoms.Pain circumstances: can occur in the back due to head nod or with eye movement
symptoms.Tremor: can occur during precise movements, in the hands, or limbs
symptoms.Muscular: cramping, difficulty walking, inability to rapidly change motions, involuntary movements, muscle paralysis, muscle rigidity, muscle weakness, problems with coordination, stiff muscles, clumsiness, muscle spasms, or overactive reflexes
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, dizziness, heat intolerance, poor balance, or vertigo
symptoms.Urinary: excessive urination at night, leaking of urine, persistent urge to urinate, or urinary retention
symptoms.Sensory: pins and needles, abnormality of taste, reduced sensation of touch, or uncomfortable tingling and burning
symptoms.Visual: blurred vision, double vision, or vision loss
symptoms.Mood: anxiety or mood swings
symptoms.Also common: constipation, depression, difficulty raising the foot, difficulty swallowing, difficulty thinking and understanding, flare, headache, heavy legs, numbness of face, rapid involuntary eye movement, sleep deprivation, tongue numbness, or weakness

Multiple sclerosis.overview:
Description
A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves.
In MS, resulting nerve damage disrupts communication between the brain and the body.
Multiple sclerosis causes many different symptoms, including vision loss, pain, fatigue and impaired coordination. The symptoms, severity and duration can vary from person to person. Some people may be symptom free for most of their lives, while others can have severe, chronic symptoms that never go away.
Physiotherapy and medication that suppress the immune system can help with symptoms, and slow disease progression.
Multiple sclerosis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Therapies.Counseling: Professional advice and support that help people solve problems, make decisions and change their behaviour.
Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Acupuncture: Insertion of needles into specific points on the body to relieve pain and treat other conditions. A form of traditional Chinese medicine.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Muscular dystrophy.symptomDescription: Damaged muscles become progressively weaker. Most people who have the condition eventually need a wheelchair. Other symptoms include trouble breathing or swallowing.

symptoms.Muscular: abnormality walking, flaccid muscles, muscle weakness, loss of muscle, or permanent shortening of muscle
symptoms.Also common: cardiomyopathy, constantly walking on tip toe, constipation, difficulty swallowing, fatigue, scoliosis, or shallow breathing

Muscular dystrophy.overview:
Description
A group of genetic diseases that cause progressive weakness and loss of muscle mass.
In muscular dystrophies, abnormal genes (mutations) lead to muscle degeneration. Most forms begin in childhood.
Damaged muscles become progressively weaker. Most people who have the condition eventually need a wheelchair. Other symptoms include trouble breathing or swallowing.
Medication, therapy, breathing aids or surgery may help maintain function, but life span is often shortened.
Muscular dystrophy.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required

Devices.Splint: A rigid accessory used to stabilise and protect an injured joint.

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.

Myasthenia gravis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include weakness in the arm and leg muscles, double vision and difficulties with speech and chewing.

symptoms.Muscular: muscle weakness or weakness of the arms and legs
symptoms.Facial: drooping of upper eyelid or muscle weakness
symptoms.Also common: difficulty speaking, difficulty swallowing, double vision, fatigue, or shortness of breath

Myasthenia gravis.overview:
Description
A weakness and rapid fatigue of muscles under voluntary control.
The condition is caused by a breakdown in communication between nerves and muscles.
Symptoms include weakness in the arm and leg muscles, double vision and difficulties with speech and chewing.
Medication, therapy and surgery can help.
Myasthenia gravis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.
Medication.Muscle strengthener: Improves muscle function. Dilates pupil when used in eye-drop form.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Surgery.Thymectomy: Surgical removal of the thymus gland.

specialists.Cardiothoracic Surgeon: Surgically treats diseases affecting organs inside the chest.

Myelodysplastic syndrome.symptomDescription: Symptoms may include shortness of breath, fatigue, easy bruising and paleness.

symptoms.Whole body: anaemia, fatigue, or malaise
symptoms.Also common: bleeding, bruising, infection, pallor, red spots on skin, or shortness of breath on exercise

Myelodysplastic syndrome.overview:
Description
A group of disorders caused when something disrupts the production of blood cells.
Some types have no known cause. Others occur in response to cancer treatments or chemical exposure.
Symptoms may include shortness of breath, fatigue, easy bruising and paleness.
Myelodysplastic syndrome may progress to leukaemia. Transfusions and medication help manage symptoms. Medication or bone marrow transplants may lessen transfusion needs and slow or prevent progression to leukaemia.
Myelodysplastic syndrome.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.
Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.
Medication.Bone marrow stimulant: Helps bone marrow produce new blood cells.

Medical procedure.Haematopoietic stem cell transplantation: Transplanting stem cells to restore a person's immune system. The transplanted cells can come from a donor or be the person's own cells.

specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.

Myocarditis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include chest pain, abnormal heartbeat and shortness of breath.

symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, or malaise
symptoms.Heart: abnormal heart rhythm, murmur, or palpitations
symptoms.Respiratory: fast breathing, shortness of breath, or shortness of breath on lying down
symptoms.Also common: swelling in extremities

Myocarditis.overview:
Description
Inflammation of the middle layer of the heart wall.
Myocarditis is usually caused by a viral infection. A severe case can weaken the heart, which can lead to heart failure, abnormal heartbeat and sudden death.
Symptoms include chest pain, abnormal heartbeat and shortness of breath.
Treatment may include medication to regulate the heartbeat and improve heart function. In rare but severe cases, a device may be required to help the heart function.
Myocarditis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.

Self-care.Low sodium diet: A diet that restricts salt (sodium chloride) and other forms of sodium to no more than 2,000 mg per day

Medication.ACE inhibitor: Relaxes blood vessels, lowers blood pressure and prevents diabetes-related kidney damage.
Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.
Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.
Medication.Antiarrhythmic: Helps control abnormal or irregular heart rhythms.

specialists.Cardiac Surgeon: Performs surgery on the heart or great vessels.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

M\u00e9ni\u00e8re's disease.symptomDescription: Symptoms include a spinning sensation (vertigo), hearing loss, ear ringing (tinnitus) and ear pressure. The vertigo may cause severe nausea and imbalance. Hearing loss may become permanent.

symptoms.Whole body: vertigo or dizziness
symptoms.Ears: feeling of fullness in the ear or ringing
symptoms.Also common: hearing loss, imbalance, motion sickness, nausea, or rapid involuntary eye movement

M\u00e9ni\u00e8re's disease.overview:
Description
An inner ear disorder that causes episodes of vertigo (spinning).
Ménière's disease usually starts in one ear, but later may involve both. Smoking, infections or a high-salt diet may worsen the disease.
Symptoms include a spinning sensation (vertigo), hearing loss, ear ringing (tinnitus) and ear pressure. The vertigo may cause severe nausea and imbalance. Hearing loss may become permanent.
Drugs for motion sickness or nausea may help manage symptoms.
M\u00e9ni\u00e8re's disease.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Therapies.Vestibular rehabilitation: A type of therapy focused on improving balance and stability for conditions affecting the inner ear.

Self-care.Low sodium diet: A diet that restricts salt (sodium chloride) and other forms of sodium to no more than 2,000 mg per day
Self-care.Avoid caffeine: Reduces risk of aggravating certain conditions.
Self-care.Avoid tobacco: Reduces risk of developing or worsening certain medical conditions.
Self-care.Avoid chocolate: Reduces risk of aggravating certain conditions.

Devices.Hearing aid: A device applied to the outer ear to amplify sound and improve hearing.

Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.
Medication.Antiemetic: Prevents or relieves nausea or vomiting.
Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.
Medication.Sedative: Causes drowsiness, calmness and dulled senses. Some types may become addictive.

specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.

Narcissistic personality disorder.symptomDescription: Symptoms include an excessive need for admiration, disregard for others' feelings, an inability to handle any criticism and a sense of entitlement.

symptoms.Common symptoms: grandiosity, callous and unemotional traits, disregard for others' feelings, excessive need for admiration, or social isolation

Narcissistic personality disorder.overview:
Description
A disorder in which a person has an inflated sense of self-importance.
Narcissistic personality disorder is found more commonly in men. The cause is unknown but likely involves a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Symptoms include an excessive need for admiration, disregard for others' feelings, an inability to handle any criticism and a sense of entitlement.
The disorder needs to be diagnosed by a professional. Treatment involves talk therapy.
Narcissistic personality disorder.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring: Regular follow-up to evaluate for improvement.

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Counseling psychology: A branch of psychology that treats personal problems related to school, work, family and social life.
Therapies.Family therapy: Psychological counselling that helps families resolve conflicts and communicate more effectively.
Therapies.Group psychotherapy: Talk therapy where the therapist works with clients in a group instead of one-on-one.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Psychoanalyst: Uses psychotherapy to treat mental disorders.

Narcolepsy.extraName: Also called: excessive uncontrollable daytime sleepiness
Narcolepsy.symptomDescription: Narcolepsy causes sudden attacks of sleep. Sudden loss of muscle tone and hallucinations might occur.

symptoms.Muscular: loss of muscle control, muscle paralysis, or muscle weakness
symptoms.Also common: fatigue or hallucination

Narcolepsy.overview:
Description
A chronic sleep disorder that causes overwhelming daytime drowsiness.
The cause of narcolepsy isn't well understood but may involve genetic factors and abnormal signalling in the brain.
Narcolepsy causes sudden attacks of sleep. Sudden loss of muscle tone and hallucinations might occur.
Stimulants, antidepressants and other medication can help.
Narcolepsy.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required

Medication.Stimulant: Increases neurotransmitter levels, heart rate and blood pressure. Decreases appetite and sleep.
Medication.Cognition-enhancing medication: Improves mental function, lowers blood pressure and may balance mood.
Medication.Antidepressant: Taking medications designed to help relieve symptoms of depression. Some antidepressants also have other uses, such as treating chronic pain and certain anxiety disorders.
Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.

specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Nasal polyps.symptomDescription: Symptoms may include a runny nose, stuffiness or post-nasal drip. In some cases, there may be no symptoms.

symptoms.Nasal: congestion, distorted sense of smell, runny nose, post-nasal drip, or sneezing
symptoms.Respiratory: breathing through the mouth or sinusitis
symptoms.Also common: abnormality of taste, headache, or snoring

Nasal polyps.overview:
Description
A painless benign growth on the lining of the nose or sinuses.
Causes are chronic inflammation due to infection, allergies, drug sensitivity or immune disorders.
Symptoms may include a runny nose, stuffiness or post-nasal drip. In some cases, there may be no symptoms.
The condition can be treated with corticosteroids, other medication or surgery.
Nasal polyps.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Allergy & Immunology Doctor: Treats allergy and immune system disorders.
specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.

Nasal septum deviation.symptomDescription: In many cases, there may be no symptoms. When symptoms occur, they include a congested nostril, nosebleeds and noisy breathing during sleep.

symptoms.Nasal: bleeding, congestion, loss of smell, runny nose, or post-nasal drip
symptoms.Also common: headache, mouth breathing, physical deformity, or snoring

Nasal septum deviation.overview:
Description
Sideways displacement of the wall between the nostrils.
A nose injury is a common cause of septum deviation.
In many cases, there may be no symptoms. When symptoms occur, they include a congested nostril, nosebleeds and noisy breathing during sleep.
Treatments include decongestants, antihistamines, nasal steroids, use of an adhesive strip to open nasal passages and surgery.
Nasal septum deviation.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Devices.Nasal strip: An adhesive bandage with plastic ribs applied across the bridge of the nose to improve breathing.

Medication.Decongestant: Relieves nasal congestion, swelling and runny nose.
Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.

Self-care.Nasal washing: Rinsing the inside of the nose with warm salt water to flush out irritants and excess mucus. Often done using a neti pot or squeeze bottle.

Surgery.Nose job: Plastic surgery to change the shape or size of the nose. Often called a nose job.
