Surgery.Septoplasty: Surgery to straighten the bone and cartilage (septum) that separates the nostrils.

specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.
specialists.Plastic Surgeon: Reconstructs defective, damaged or missing body parts.

Nearsighted.symptomDescription: Faraway objects appear blurry. The condition may develop gradually or rapidly.

symptoms.Visual: blurred vision or distorted vision
symptoms.Eyes: squinting or eye strain
symptoms.Also common: headache

Nearsighted.overview:
Description
A condition in which close objects appear clearly, but far ones don't.
Near-sightedness tends to run in families.
Faraway objects appear blurry. The condition may develop gradually or rapidly.
Treatment options include glasses, contact lenses and surgery such as LASIK.
Nearsighted.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Devices.Bifocals: Eyeglasses with a lens that enables both near and far vision.
Devices.Glasses: A frame worn on the nose that holds a set of lenses to correct vision or protect the eyes.
Devices.Contact lenses: A lens placed directly on the eye to correct or assist with vision.

Medical procedure.LASIK: Laser surgery that reshapes and removes tissue from the front of the eye (cornea) to correct vision.

Surgery.Refractive surgery: Surgery to reshape the front of the eye (cornea) to correct or improve vision. LASIK is the most popular type.
Surgery.Laser surgery: Surgery using an intensely hot and focused beam of light to remove tissue and control bleeding.

Neuroendocrine tumor.symptomDescription: Many people do not develop symptoms and the tumour is detected incidentally. When symptoms occur, they can vary based on the location of the tumour. In rare cases, skin flushing or fluctuating blood sugar levels may occur.

symptoms.Whole body: flushing or low blood sugar

Neuroendocrine tumor.overview:
Description
A condition in which the neuroendocrine cells develop into tumours.
A neuroendocrine tumour may grow slowly or aggressively and spread to other parts of the body.
Many people do not develop symptoms and the tumour is detected incidentally. When symptoms occur, they can vary based on the location of the tumour. In rare cases, skin flushing or fluctuating blood sugar levels may occur.
Treatment depends on the type of tumour. Some approaches may include surgery, radiation and chemotherapy.
Neuroendocrine tumor.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medical procedure.Transarterial chemoembolization: Injecting anti-cancer drugs into the blood vessels of a tumour and then blocking them off to trap the medication in the tumour.
Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.
Medical procedure.Radiofrequency ablation: Removal of tissue using the heat from an electric current produced by a radio wave.

Supportive care.Palliative care: Works to improve quality of life while adjusting or recovering from a serious illness.

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Synthetic hormones: Regulates the activity of the organs and tissues in the body.

Surgery.Endocrine surgery: Surgical treatment of the glands that produce hormones in the body. For example, to remove a tumour on the gland.
Surgery.Surgery to remove pancreatic tumours: A complex surgery to remove certain types of cancer whereby part of the pancreas, stomach and gut is removed.
Surgery.Pancreatectomy: Surgical removal of all or part of the pancreas, the gland that produces insulin.
Surgery.Hepatectomy: Surgical removal of all or part of the liver.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Neurofibromatosis.symptomDescription: Type 1 can cause bone deformities, learning disabilities and high blood pressure. Type 2 can cause hearing loss, vision loss and difficulty with balance. Type 3 can cause chronic pain throughout the body.

symptoms.Pain types: can be chronic
symptoms.Skin: brown spot on skin, armpit freckles, or lumps
symptoms.Whole body: balance disorder or high blood pressure
symptoms.Also common: attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (adhd), bone deformities, enlarged head, hearing loss, ringing in the ears, scoliosis, seizures, sensation of pins and needles, or vision disorder

Neurofibromatosis.overview:
Description
A condition that causes tumours to form in the brain, spinal cord and nerves.
Neurofibromatosis is usually non-cancerous. There are three types of this condition. Type 1 usually appears in childhood, while Types 2 and 3 appear in early adulthood.
Type 1 can cause bone deformities, learning disabilities and high blood pressure. Type 2 can cause hearing loss, vision loss and difficulty with balance. Type 3 can cause chronic pain throughout the body.
Some cases may not require treatment other than careful observation. Other cases may require chemotherapy, radiation therapy or surgery.
Neurofibromatosis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Genetic counseling: Professional advice given when considering performing a genetic test.

Devices.Cochlear implant: A device surgically implanted in the ear that enables a deaf person to hear sounds.

Surgery.Laminectomy: Surgical removal of the back part of the vertebra to relieve pressure on the spine or nerve.
Surgery.Spinal fusion: Surgery to join together two or more bones in the spine (vertebrae) so there is no movement between them.

Neutropenia.symptomDescription: There can be no symptoms other than an increased vulnerability to infection.

symptoms.Common symptoms: fever, mouth ulcer, sore throat, or susceptibility to infection

Neutropenia.overview:
Description
An abnormally low count of a type of white blood cell (neutrophils).
It can be caused by diseases that damage the bone marrow, infections or certain medication.
There can be no symptoms other than an increased vulnerability to infection.
Management of this condition includes treating the underlying cause, as well as medication that increases neutrophil counts. Avoiding anyone who is sick and practising good hygiene can help reduce the risk of infection.
Neutropenia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medication.Bone marrow stimulant: Helps bone marrow produce new blood cells.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma.symptomDescription: Symptoms include swollen lymph nodes, fever, stomach ache, night sweats, weight loss, chest pain and loss of appetite.

symptoms.Whole body: anaemia, fatigue, loss of appetite, or night sweats
symptoms.Also common: b symptoms, night sweats, swollen lymph nodes, or weight loss

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma.overview:
Description
Cancer that starts in the lymphatic system.
The condition occurs when the body produces too many abnormal lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell.
Symptoms include swollen lymph nodes, fever, stomach ache, night sweats, weight loss, chest pain and loss of appetite.
Treatments may include chemotherapy, radiation therapy, stem-cell transplant or medication.
Non-Hodgkin lymphoma.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Bone marrow stimulant: Helps bone marrow produce new blood cells.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Radiation Oncologist: Treats and manages cancer by prescribing radiation therapy.
specialists.Nuclear Medicine Doctor: Applies radioactive substances to diagnose and treat disease.
specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD.symptomDescription: Most people have no symptoms. In rare cases, people may experience fatigue, pain or weight loss. Over time, inflammation and scarring of the liver (cirrhosis) can occur.

symptoms.Common symptoms: fatigue

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD.overview:
Description
The accumulation of liver fat in people who drink little or no alcohol.
The cause of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is unknown. Risk factors include obesity, gastric bypass surgery, high cholesterol and type 2 diabetes.
Most people have no symptoms. In rare cases, people may experience fatigue, pain or weight loss. Over time, inflammation and scarring of the liver (cirrhosis) can occur.
No standard treatment exists. Instead, doctors will treat the underlying condition, such as obesity.
Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.
Self-care.Low carbohydrate diet: A diet that limits grains, starchy vegetables and fruit and emphasises foods high in protein and fat.
Self-care.Low fat diet: Reducing intake of high-fat foods such as dairy, oil and red meat to improve cardiovascular health.

Medication.Anti-diabetic medication: Controls the amount of sugar (glucose) in the blood.
Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

specialists.Hepatologist: Focuses on liver, gallbladder and biliary tree disorders.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Nummular dermatitis.symptomDescription: The sores may spread, ooze, itch and crust over. The condition can last for months.

symptoms.Skin: dryness, flakiness, rashes, redness, coin shaped rashes, or darkening of the skin
symptoms.Also common: lesion or itching

Nummular dermatitis.overview:
Description
Coin-shaped rashes or sores.
With nummular dermatitis, coin-shaped rashes or sores appear on the skin. It may occur after an injury.
The sores may spread, ooze, itch and crust over. The condition can last for months.
Treatments can include lotions and bandages. Antihistamines can help with itching. It also helps to avoid irritants such as excess bathing.
Nummular dermatitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.

Self-care.Petroleum jelly: A thick, topical ointment made from crude oil that moisturises and protects the skin. Commonly known as Vaseline.
Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.
Self-care.Barrier cream: A cream that soothes and protects irritated skin.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Obesity.symptomDescription: Obesity occurs when a person's body mass index is 25 or greater. The excessive body fat increases the risk of serious health problems.

symptoms.Also common: overweight, binge eating, fatigue, pot belly, or snoring

Obesity.overview:
Description
A disorder involving excessive body fat that increases the risk of health problems.
Obesity often results from taking in more calories than are burned by exercise and normal daily activities.
Obesity occurs when a person's body mass index is 25 or greater. The excessive body fat increases the risk of serious health problems.
The mainstay of treatment is lifestyle changes such as diet and exercise.
Obesity.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.
Self-care.Low carbohydrate diet: A diet that limits grains, starchy vegetables and fruit and emphasises foods high in protein and fat.
Self-care.Low fat diet: Reducing intake of high-fat foods such as dairy, oil and red meat to improve cardiovascular health.

Therapies.Behaviour therapy: A therapy focused on modifying harmful behaviours associated with psychological distress.

Obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).symptomDescription: OCD often centres on themes such as a fear of germs or the need to arrange objects in a specific manner. Symptoms usually begin gradually and vary throughout life.

symptoms.Behavioural: compulsive behaviour, agitation, compulsive hoarding, hypervigilance, impulsivity, meaningless repetition of own words, repetitive movements, ritualistic behaviour, social isolation, or persistent repetition of words or actions
symptoms.Mood: anxiety, apprehension, guilt, or panic attack
symptoms.Also common: food aversion, nightmares, or repeatedly going over thoughts

Obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).overview:
Description
Excessive thoughts (obsessions) that lead to repetitive behaviours (compulsions).
Obsessive-compulsive disorder is characterised by unreasonable thoughts and fears (obsessions) that lead to compulsive behaviours.
OCD often centres on themes such as a fear of germs or the need to arrange objects in a specific manner. Symptoms usually begin gradually and vary throughout life.
Treatment includes talk therapy, medication or both.
Obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Aversion therapy: Suppressing unwanted behaviour, like smoking, by associating it with a negative experience, like an electric shock.
Therapies.Psychoeducation: Education about mental health that also serves to support, validate and empower patients.
Therapies.Rational emotive behavior therapy: Psychological treatment that helps people change negative, irrational thoughts and improve emotional well-being.
Therapies.Exposure and response prevention: A talk therapy based on exposing feared or traumatic experiences within a safe setting in order to help reduce any associated psychological distress.
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.
Therapies.Systematic desensitization: Psychological treatment that helps people overcome fears by gradually exposing them to the things they're afraid of.
Therapies.Group psychotherapy: Talk therapy where the therapist works with clients in a group instead of one-on-one.

Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.
Medication.Anxiolytic: Relieves anxiety and tension. May promote sleep.
Medication.Antidepressant: Taking medications designed to help relieve symptoms of depression. Some antidepressants also have other uses, such as treating chronic pain and certain anxiety disorders.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Opioid addiction and dependence.symptomDescription: Symptoms of addiction include uncontrollable cravings and inability to control opioid use even though it's having negative effects on personal relationships or finances.

symptoms.Whole body: craving or sweating
symptoms.Mood: euphoria or general discontent
symptoms.Also common: physical substance dependence, chronic constipation, small pupils, nausea, reduced sex drive, sensitivity to pain, shallow breathing, or slurred speech

Opioid addiction and dependence.overview:
Description
Physical and psychological reliance on opioids, a substance found in certain prescription pain medications and illegal drugs such as heroin.
Opioids are prescribed to treat pain. With prolonged use, pain-relieving effects may lessen and pain can become worse. In addition, the body can develop dependence. Opioid dependence causes withdrawal symptoms, which makes it difficult to stop taking them. Addiction occurs when dependence interferes with daily life. Taking more than the prescribed amount or using illegal opioids such as heroin may result in death.
Symptoms of addiction include uncontrollable cravings and inability to control opioid use even though it's having negative effects on personal relationships or finances.
Treatment varies but may include discontinuing the drug. Medication such as methadone can help alleviate the symptoms of withdrawal and cravings. Pairing medication with inpatient or support programmes generally has the most success.
Opioid addiction and dependence.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Medical procedure.Drug detoxification: Medical management of the serious withdrawal symptoms that occur when a person addicted to drugs stops using them. Often requires prescription medications.

Therapies.Counseling: Professional advice and support that help people solve problems, make decisions and change their behaviour.

Medication.Narcotic: Relieves pain, dulls the senses and causes drowsiness. May become addictive.

specialists.Pain Management: Eases suffering and improves quality of life for those in pain.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Oppositional defiant disorder.symptomDescription: Symptoms generally begin before a child is eight years old. They include irritable mood, argumentative and defiant behaviour, aggression and vindictiveness that last longer than six months and cause significant problems at home or school.

symptoms.Behavioural: aggression, antisocial behaviour, impulsivity, irritability, screaming, or self-harm
symptoms.Mood: anger or anxiety
symptoms.Also common: depression or problem paying attention

Oppositional defiant disorder.overview:
Description
A disorder in a child marked by defiant and disobedient behaviour to authority figures.
The cause of oppositional defiant disorder is unknown but likely involves a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Symptoms generally begin before a child is eight years old. They include irritable mood, argumentative and defiant behaviour, aggression and vindictiveness that last longer than six months and cause significant problems at home or school.
Treatment involves individual and family therapy.
Oppositional defiant disorder.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required

Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Counseling psychology: A branch of psychology that treats personal problems related to school, work, family and social life.
Therapies.Family therapy: Psychological counselling that helps families resolve conflicts and communicate more effectively.
Therapies.Applied behavior analysis: A teaching method that helps autistic children learn socially significant skills by encouraging positive behaviour.
Therapies.Group psychotherapy: Talk therapy where the therapist works with clients in a group instead of one-on-one.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Optic neuritis.symptomDescription: Pain and temporary vision loss are common symptoms.

symptoms.Visual: blurred vision, vision disorder, inability to distinguish certain colours, partial loss of vision, or vision loss
symptoms.Also common: headache

Optic neuritis.overview:
Description
Inflammation of the optic nerve.
Optic neuritis is often associated with multiple sclerosis and can be an early sign of the disease.
Pain and temporary vision loss are common symptoms.
Optic neuritis usually gets better on its own. In some cases, steroid medications are used to reduce inflammation.
Optic neuritis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.

Oral cancer.symptomDescription: Symptoms include a sore that doesn't heal, a lump or a white or red patch on the inside of the mouth.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the ear, mouth, or mouth and face
symptoms.Mouth: ulcers, bad breath, or red and white plaques
symptoms.Also common: coughing or enlarged neck lymph nodes

Oral cancer.overview:
Description
Cancer that develops in any part of the mouth.
Risk factors include tobacco use, heavy alcohol use and human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.
Symptoms include a sore that doesn't heal, a lump or a white or red patch on the inside of the mouth.
Treatment includes surgery and radiation therapy. In some cases, chemotherapy may be required.
Oral cancer.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.

Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

Surgery.Laryngectomy: Surgical removal of all or part of the voice box (larynx) in the throat.
Surgery.Neck dissection: Surgical removal of lymph nodes in the neck.
Surgery.Glossectomy: Surgical removal of all or part of the tongue.

specialists.Radiation Oncologist: Treats and manages cancer by prescribing radiation therapy.
specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.

Oral thrush (mouth thrush).symptomDescription: Oral thrush causes white lesions on the tongue or inner cheeks.

symptoms.Mouth: bad breath, burning mouth syndrome, dryness, or white tongue
symptoms.Also common: abnormality of taste, difficulty swallowing, or redness

Oral thrush (mouth thrush).overview:
Description
An infection in which the fungus Candida albicans accumulates in the mouth.
It's common in babies, people with immune deficiency and those who use steroid sprays for asthma.
Oral thrush causes white lesions on the tongue or inner cheeks.
Unsweetened yoghurt or an anti-fungal medication can help.
Oral thrush (mouth thrush).notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Antifungal: Kills or prevents growth of fungi.
Medication.Topical antiseptic: Destroys or prevents the growth of microorganisms on the skin that may cause infection.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Osgood-Schlatter disease.symptomDescription: The disease causes a painful lump below the kneecap.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the knee or leg below the knee
symptoms.Also common: limping or lump below knee

Osgood-Schlatter disease.overview:
Description
A childhood repetitive-use injury that causes a painful lump below the kneecap.
Osgood-Schlatter disease affects children experiencing growth spurts. Children who play sports in which they regularly run and jump are most at risk.
The disease causes a painful lump below the kneecap.
The condition usually resolves on its own, once the child's bones stop growing.
Osgood-Schlatter disease.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.

Self-care.RICE (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation): Rest, ice, compression and elevation. A first-aid treatment for sprains and strains.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Osteoarthritis.extraName: Also called: OA, degenerative joint disease
Osteoarthritis.symptomDescription: Joint pain in the hands, neck, lower back, knees or hips is the most common symptom.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the joints, hands, hip, knee, lower back, or neck
symptoms.Pain types: can be severe in the joints
symptoms.Hand: bump on the finger or bony outgrowth in fingers or toes
symptoms.Also common: joint deformity or limping

Osteoarthritis.overview:
Description
A type of arthritis that occurs when flexible tissue at the ends of bones wears down.
The wearing down of the protective tissue at the ends of bones (cartilage) occurs gradually and worsens over time.
Joint pain in the hands, neck, lower back, knees or hips is the most common symptom.
Medication, physiotherapy and sometimes surgery can help reduce pain and maintain joint movement.
Osteoarthritis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.
Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Menthol: An oil made from mint that soothes sore throats and relieves itching.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.
Medication.Narcotic: Relieves pain, dulls the senses and causes drowsiness. May become addictive.

Therapies.Hydrotherapy: Using water to relieve pain, treat diseases and maintain health. For example, mineral baths and hot tubs.
Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
Therapies.Acupuncture: Insertion of needles into specific points on the body to relieve pain and treat other conditions. A form of traditional Chinese medicine.

Surgery.Arthroscopy: Procedure to diagnose and treat joint problems using a tiny camera inserted through a small surgical opening.
Surgery.Joint replacement: Removing a damaged or defective joint and inserting a new, functioning one in its place.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Osteoporosis.symptomDescription: Many people have no symptoms until they have a bone fracture.

symptoms.Common symptoms: bone fracture or loss of height

Osteoporosis.overview:
Description
A condition in which bones become weak and brittle.
The body constantly absorbs and replaces bone tissue. With osteoporosis, new bone creation doesn't keep up with old bone removal.
Many people have no symptoms until they have a bone fracture.
Treatment includes medication, a healthy diet and weight-bearing exercise to help prevent bone loss or strengthen already weak bones.
Osteoporosis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Healthy diet: A diet that provides essential nutrients and adequate calories, while avoiding excess sugar, carbohydrates and fatty foods.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.
Medication.Antacid: Counteracts the effects of stomach acid.
Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Ovarian cancer.symptomDescription: Ovarian cancer often has no symptoms in the early stages. Later stages are associated with symptoms, but they can be non-specific, such as loss of appetite and weight loss.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: bloating, change in bowel habits, indigestion, or nausea
symptoms.Abdominal: abdominal fullness, fluid in the abdomen, or lump in the abdomen
symptoms.Whole body: cancer-related fatigue or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: weight loss

Ovarian cancer.overview:
Description
A cancer that begins in the female organs that produce eggs (ovaries).
Ovarian cancer often goes undetected until it has spread within the pelvis and stomach. At this late stage, ovarian cancer is more difficult to treat and can be fatal.
Ovarian cancer often has no symptoms in the early stages. Later stages are associated with symptoms, but they can be non-specific, such as loss of appetite and weight loss.
Surgery and chemotherapy are generally used to treat ovarian cancer.
Ovarian cancer.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Surgery.Omentectomy: Surgical removal of all or part of the abdominal lining.
Surgery.Salpingoophorectomy: Surgical removal of an ovary and its fallopian tube.
Surgery.Laparotomy: Surgical opening made in the abdomen to diagnose or treat various diseases.
Surgery.Pelvic lymph node dissection: Surgical removal of one or more lymph nodes in the pelvis to see if there is cancer.
Surgery.Lymph node dissection: Surgical removal of a lymph node.
Surgery.Retroperitoneal lymph node dissection: Surgical removal of lymph nodes at the back of the abdomen to see whether cancers in the pelvis or abdomen have spread.

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.

Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Pathologist: Diagnoses disease by examining body cells, fluids and tissues.
specialists.Palliative Medicine: Focuses on improving quality of life for those with severe illnesses.
specialists.Radiation Oncologist: Treats and manages cancer by prescribing radiation therapy.

Ovarian cyst.symptomDescription: Most ovarian cysts don't cause symptoms. In some cases, menstrual irregularities, pain during intercourse or irregular bowel movements can occur.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the back, pelvis, or side part of the body
symptoms.Menstrual: abnormal menstruation, irregular menstruation, painful menstruation, or spotting
symptoms.Also common: cramping or excessive hairiness

Ovarian cyst.overview:
Description
A solid or fluid-filled sac or pocket (cyst) within or on the surface of an ovary.
Ovarian cysts usually disappear in a few months but can cause complications if they don't.
Most ovarian cysts don't cause symptoms. In some cases, menstrual irregularities, pain during intercourse or irregular bowel movements can occur.
Many cysts go away on their own. If not, treatments are contraceptive pills or surgery.
Ovarian cyst.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

Surgery.Laparoscopic surgery: Surgery that uses a video camera and thin tubes inserted into small cuts on the body to repair or remove tissue.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Overactive bladder.extraName: Also called: OAB, hypertonicity of bladder
Overactive bladder.symptomDescription: The urge to urinate may be difficult to control and lead to the involuntary loss of urine (incontinence). It may be embarrassing or limit activity.

symptoms.Urinary: frequent urge to urinate, frequent urination, bed wetting, bladder spasm, or leaking of urine

Overactive bladder.overview:
Description
A problem with bladder function that causes the sudden need to urinate.
Overactive bladder happens mostly in women but may occur in men. Ageing, an enlarged prostate and diabetes are all risk factors.
The urge to urinate may be difficult to control and lead to the involuntary loss of urine (incontinence). It may be embarrassing or limit activity.
Treatments such as pelvic floor muscle exercises, medication and nerve stimulation can reduce or eliminate symptoms.
Overactive bladder.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Absorbent pads: Manages outward symptoms of incontinence by absorbing moisture.
Self-care.Scheduled toileting: Regularly scheduling times to urinate to reduce the likelihood of leaking urine.
Self-care.Double voiding: Urinating twice within a few minutes helps empty the bladder better and reduces the likelihood of leaking urine.
Self-care.Bladder training: Gradually increasing the amount of time from the point where an urge to urinate develops to urinating.

Therapies.Biofeedback: Controlling the body's heartbeat, brainwaves, breathing and blood pressure by monitoring them with sensors.
Therapies.Kegel exercise: Contracting the pelvic muscles as if to stop the flow of urine. Done to strengthen these muscles.

Medication.Bladder relaxant: Helps control and relax the bladder muscles.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

PMS (premenstrual syndrome).symptomDescription: Symptoms include mood swings, tender breasts, food cravings, fatigue, irritability and depression.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the breast, abdomen, back, joints, muscles, or pelvis
symptoms.Gastrointestinal: constipation, diarrhoea, nausea, passing excessive amounts of gas, or water retention
symptoms.Whole body: appetite changes, excessive hunger, fatigue, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Mood: anxiety or general discontent
symptoms.Also common: acne, depression, headache, insomnia, irritability, lack of concentration, moodiness, painful menstruation, or weight gain

PMS (premenstrual syndrome).overview:
Description
A group of symptoms that occur in women, typically between ovulation and a period.
The cause isn't fully understood but likely involves changes in hormones during the menstrual cycle.
Symptoms include mood swings, tender breasts, food cravings, fatigue, irritability and depression.
Lifestyle changes and medication may reduce symptoms.
PMS (premenstrual syndrome).notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.
Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Paget's disease of bone.symptomDescription: This condition can be symptomless for a long period of time. When symptoms do occur, they may include bone deformities, broken bones and pain in the affected area.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the back, bones, hip, joints, or neck
symptoms.Also common: bone deformities, abnormality walking, bone fracture, bow legs, headache, joint stiffness, or sensation of pins and needles

Paget's disease of bone.overview:
Description
A disease that disrupts the replacement of old bone tissue with new bone tissue.
Paget's disease of bone most commonly occurs in the pelvis, skull, spine and legs. Risk factors include increasing age and a family history of the condition. Over time, affected bones may become fragile and misshapen.
This condition can be symptomless for a long period of time. When symptoms do occur, they may include bone deformities, broken bones and pain in the affected area.
Treatment involves medication that reduces the breakdown of bone.
Paget's disease of bone.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Nuclear Medicine Doctor: Applies radioactive substances to diagnose and treat disease.
specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.

Pancreatic cancer.symptomDescription: There are no symptoms in the early stages. Later stages are associated with symptoms, but these can be non-specific, such as lack of appetite and weight loss.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the abdomen or middle back
symptoms.Gastrointestinal: fluid in the abdomen or nausea
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: dark urine, weight loss, or yellow skin and eyes

Pancreatic cancer.overview:
Description
Cancer that begins in the organ lying behind the lower part of the stomach (pancreas).
The pancreas secretes enzymes that aid digestion and hormones that help regulate the metabolism of sugars. This type of cancer is often detected late, spreads rapidly and has a poor prognosis.
There are no symptoms in the early stages. Later stages are associated with symptoms, but these can be non-specific, such as lack of appetite and weight loss.
Treatment may include surgically removing the pancreas, radiation and chemotherapy.
Pancreatic cancer.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Chemotherapy protective drugs: Reduces the side effects of chemotherapy treatment.

Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

Surgery.Surgery to remove pancreatic tumours: A complex surgery to remove certain types of cancer whereby part of the pancreas, stomach and gut is removed.
Surgery.Pancreatectomy: Surgical removal of all or part of the pancreas, the gland that produces insulin.

Supportive care.Palliative care: Works to improve quality of life while adjusting or recovering from a serious illness.

specialists.Palliative Medicine: Focuses on improving quality of life for those with severe illnesses.
specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Pancreatitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include upper abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting.

symptoms.Pain types: can be sudden in the abdomen
symptoms.Gastrointestinal: bloating, fat in stool, indigestion, nausea, or vomiting
symptoms.Whole body: loss of appetite or sweating
symptoms.Also common: fast heart rate or weight loss

Pancreatitis.overview:
Description
An inflammation of the organ lying behind the lower part of the stomach (pancreas).
Pancreatitis may start suddenly and last for days or it can occur over many years. It has many causes, including gallstones and chronic, heavy alcohol use.
Symptoms include upper abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting.
Treatment usually requires hospitalisation. Once they stabilise the patient, doctors treat the underlying cause.
Pancreatitis.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.
Supportive care.Fluid replacement: Replacing fluids lost through sweating, bleeding, vomiting or diarrhoea to treat or prevent dehydration.

Self-care.Low fat diet: Reducing intake of high-fat foods such as dairy, oil and red meat to improve cardiovascular health.
Self-care.Clear liquid diet: Reduces the risk of developing an upset stomach during certain illnesses. Clear liquids include water, clear fizzy drinks like ginger ale and tea.
Self-care.Fasting from food and drink: Rests the bowel and reduces the risk of complications prior to procedures or surgeries.

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Parkinson's disease.symptomDescription: Parkinson's often starts with a tremor in one hand. Other symptoms are slow movement, stiffness and loss of balance.

symptoms.Tremor: can occur at rest, in the hands, limbs, or can be postural
symptoms.Muscular: stiff muscles, difficulty standing, difficulty walking, difficulty with bodily movements, involuntary movements, muscle rigidity, problems with coordination, rhythmic muscle contractions, slow bodily movement, or slow shuffling gait
symptoms.Sleep: early awakening, nightmares, restless sleep, or sleep disturbances
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, dizziness, poor balance, or restlessness
symptoms.Cognitive: amnesia, confusion in the evening hours, dementia, or difficulty thinking and understanding
symptoms.Speech: difficulty speaking, soft speech, or voice box spasms
symptoms.Nasal: distorted sense of smell or loss of smell
symptoms.Urinary: dribbling of urine or leaking of urine
symptoms.Mood: anxiety or apathy
symptoms.Facial: jaw stiffness or reduced facial expression
symptoms.Also common: blank stare, constipation, depression, difficulty swallowing, drooling, falling, fear of falling, loss in contrast sensitivity, neck tightness, small handwriting, trembling, unintentional writhing, or weight loss

Parkinson's disease.overview:
Description
A disorder of the central nervous system that affects movement, often including tremors.
Nerve cell damage in the brain causes dopamine levels to drop, leading to the symptoms of Parkinson's.
Parkinson's often starts with a tremor in one hand. Other symptoms are slow movement, stiffness and loss of balance.
Medication can help control the symptoms of Parkinson's.
Parkinson's disease.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Dopamine promoter: Stimulates dopamine receptors in the brain.
Medication.Antidepressant: Taking medications designed to help relieve symptoms of depression. Some antidepressants also have other uses, such as treating chronic pain and certain anxiety disorders.
Medication.Cognition-enhancing medication: Improves mental function, lowers blood pressure and may balance mood.
Medication.Anti-Tremor: Helps control tremor, shaking and unsteadiness.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.

Patellofemoral pain syndrome.extraName: Also called: anterior knee pain syndrome
Patellofemoral pain syndrome.symptomDescription: The most common symptom is knee pain that increases with stair climbing or squatting movements.

symptoms.Muscular: abnormality walking or muscle weakness
symptoms.Also common: stiffness

Patellofemoral pain syndrome.overview:
Description
A condition in which the cartilage under the kneecap is damaged due to injury or overuse.
Patellofemoral pain syndrome is the most common cause of knee pain seen by doctors. It's common in people who participate in sports, especially women and young adults.
The most common symptom is knee pain that increases with stair climbing or squatting movements.
The primary treatment is rest. Pain relievers or physiotherapy can also reduce pain.
Patellofemoral pain syndrome.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Rest: Reducing activity for a short period of time following an injury to promote healing.
Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.

Devices.Brace: A device applied to the body to help stabilise, protect or limit movement of a damaged joint.

specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.

Pectus excavatum.symptomDescription: In severe cases, pectus excavatum can look as if the centre of the chest has been scooped out, leaving a deep dent.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or inability to exercise
symptoms.Also common: physical deformity, coughing, palpitations, or shortness of breath

Pectus excavatum.overview:
Description
A condition in which the breastbone sinks into the chest.
Pectus excavatum is often noticeable shortly after birth and typically worsens during the adolescent growth spurt. It's more common in boys. It may be associated with genetic or connective tissue diseases.
In severe cases, pectus excavatum can look as if the centre of the chest has been scooped out, leaving a deep dent.
Pectus excavatum doesn't usually require treatment, although physiotherapy may help if symptoms develop. Rarely, surgery is required to correct the condition.
Pectus excavatum.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Surgery.Bone surgery: Surgery to realign, lengthen or shorten a bone.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Cardiothoracic Surgeon: Surgically treats diseases affecting organs inside the chest.
specialists.Paediatric surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries for infants and children.
specialists.Plastic Surgeon: Reconstructs defective, damaged or missing body parts.

Pelvic inflammatory disease.symptomDescription: Common symptoms include pelvic pain and fever. There may be vaginal discharge.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the pelvis, abdomen, lower back, or vagina
symptoms.Pain circumstances: can occur during sexual intercourse or during urination
symptoms.Whole body: chills, fatigue, or fever
symptoms.Groin: cervical motion tenderness, vaginal discharge, or vaginal odour
symptoms.Also common: cramping or painful menstruation

Pelvic inflammatory disease.overview:
Description
An infection of the female reproductive organs.
It usually occurs when sexually transmitted bacteria spread from the vagina to the womb (uterus), fallopian tubes or ovaries.
Common symptoms include pelvic pain and fever. There may be vaginal discharge.
Treatment includes antibiotics.
Pelvic inflammatory disease.notes:
Spreads by sexual contact
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
HOW IT SPREADS
By having unprotected vaginal, anal or oral sex.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Perforated eardrum.symptomDescription: Symptoms include sharp ear pain that subsides quickly, drainage, ringing in the ear (tinnitus) or hearing loss.

symptoms.Whole body: dizziness or vertigo
symptoms.Also common: drainage, hearing loss, pus, or ringing in the ears

Perforated eardrum.overview:
Description
A hole in the tissue that separates the ear canal from the middle ear.
A perforated eardrum may be caused by loud sounds, a foreign object in the ear, head trauma, a middle ear infection or rapid pressure changes, such as from air travel.
Symptoms include sharp ear pain that subsides quickly, drainage, ringing in the ear (tinnitus) or hearing loss.
The condition usually heals on its own within a few weeks. Antibiotics, an eardrum patch or surgery may be necessary.
Perforated eardrum.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

Medical procedure.Cauterization: Burning or freezing a part of the body to remove tissue or stop bleeding. For example, to seal off a wound and prevent blood loss.

specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Pericarditis.symptomDescription: The most common symptom is sharp, stabbing chest pain that may travel to the left shoulder and neck. Pericarditis usually begins suddenly but doesn't last long.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or fever
symptoms.Also common: chest pressure or shortness of breath

Pericarditis.overview:
Description
A swelling and irritation of the thin, sac-like membrane surrounding the heart (pericardium).
Pericarditis may be caused by a viral infection or heart attack. In many cases, the cause is unknown.
The most common symptom is sharp, stabbing chest pain that may travel to the left shoulder and neck. Pericarditis usually begins suddenly but doesn't last long.
Most cases are mild and usually improve on their own. Treatment for more severe cases may include medication and (rarely) surgery.
Pericarditis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Peripheral artery disease.symptomDescription: Symptoms may include leg pain, particularly when walking.

symptoms.Pain circumstances: can occur in the leg and improved with rest or in the leg while exercising
symptoms.Skin: cool skin, loss of hair on the legs, thinning of skin on the legs, or ulcers

Peripheral artery disease.overview:
Description
A circulatory condition in which narrowed blood vessels reduce blood flow to the limbs.
Peripheral vascular disease is a sign of fatty deposits and calcium building up in the walls of the arteries (atherosclerosis). Risk factors include ageing, diabetes and smoking.
Symptoms may include leg pain, particularly when walking.
Tobacco cessation, exercise and a healthy diet are often successful treatments. When these changes aren't enough, medication or surgery can help.
Peripheral artery disease.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Heart-Healthy diet: A broad category of diets that reduce fat, sugar and red meat while increasing fruits, vegetables, white meat and fish.

Medication.Statin: Decreases the liver's production of harmful cholesterol.
Medication.Anticoagulant: Unwanted reactions from taking drugs that inhibit blood clotting. The most common problem is too much bleeding, which can be very serious.

Medical procedure.Angioplasty: Unblocking an artery by inflating a balloon inside it. A stent may also be inserted to hold the artery open.

specialists.Vascular Surgeon: Specialises in surgery for vascular system diseases.
specialists.Vascular Medicine Doctor: Specialises in circulatory and lymphatic diseases.

Peripheral neuropathy.symptomDescription: Symptoms include pain, a pins-and-needles sensation, numbness and weakness.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the back, face, foot, hands, or thigh
symptoms.Pain types: can be burning and tingling or sharp
symptoms.Muscular: cramping, difficulty walking, muscle weakness, problems with coordination, or loss of muscle
symptoms.Sensory: pins and needles, uncomfortable tingling and burning, oversensitivity, reduced sensation of touch, or sensitivity to pain
symptoms.Also common: poor balance, slow reflexes, tingling feet, tingling fingers, or weakness

Peripheral neuropathy.overview:
Description
Weakness, numbness and pain from nerve damage, usually in the hands and feet.
A common cause of peripheral neuropathy is diabetes, but it can also result from injuries, infections and exposure to toxins.
Symptoms include pain, a pins-and-needles sensation, numbness and weakness.
Treatments include antidepressants such as amitriptyline, pain medication such as oxycodone, anti-seizure medication and pain-relieving creams. It's also important to treat the underlying condition.
Peripheral neuropathy.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Anticonvulsant: Prevents or controls seizures, relieves pain and treats symptoms of certain psychiatric disorders.
Medication.Nerve pain medication: Blocks pain caused by damaged nerves.
Medication.Local anesthetic: Blocks pain at and near the site where it's given, or along the nerve that's blocked.
Medication.Narcotic: Relieves pain, dulls the senses and causes drowsiness. May become addictive.

specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Peritonitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms usually include pain, tenderness, rigid abdominal muscles, fever, nausea and vomiting.

symptoms.Whole body: chills, fever, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Abdominal: abdominal guarding or fluid in the abdomen
symptoms.Also common: organ dysfunction

Peritonitis.overview:
Description
Inflammation of the membrane lining the abdominal wall and covering the abdominal organs.
Peritonitis is usually infectious and often life-threatening. It's caused by leakage or a hole in the intestines, such as from a burst appendix. Even if the fluid is sterile, inflammation can occur.
Symptoms usually include pain, tenderness, rigid abdominal muscles, fever, nausea and vomiting.
Antibiotics are almost always required, along with surgery or drainage.
Peritonitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Self-care.Fasting from food and drink: Rests the bowel and reduces the risk of complications prior to procedures or surgeries.

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

Medical procedure.Surgical drain: A tube inserted in a wound or surgical opening to remove pus, blood or other fluids.
Medical procedure.Nasogastric intubation: Inserting a tube in the nose to carry food and medicine down the throat and into the stomach.

Surgery.Laparoscopic surgery: Surgery that uses a video camera and thin tubes inserted into small cuts on the body to repair or remove tissue.
Surgery.Exploratory laparotomy: Surgical opening of the abdomen so doctors can examine the internal organs for injury or disease.

specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.

Peritonsillar abscess.symptomDescription: Symptoms include fever, difficulty swallowing and severe throat pain.

symptoms.Whole body: fever, chills, or malaise
symptoms.Also common: abscess, pus, swelling, swollen lymph nodes, deviated uvula, or muffled voice

Peritonsillar abscess.overview:
Description
A complication of tonsillitis in which the infection spreads behind the tonsils.
A peritonsillar abscess occurs when a collection of pus forms and infection spreads beyond the tonsils into the neck and chest. Swollen tissues can block the airway.
Symptoms include fever, difficulty swallowing and severe throat pain.
Antibiotics can treat an early infection. Sometimes a collection of pus needs to be drained by a procedure called incision and drainage.
Peritonsillar abscess.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Medical procedure.Incision and drainage: Cutting or puncturing the skin to drain an infection such as an abscess or boil.

Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or light-headedness
symptoms.Also common: inflamed stomach, pallor, sensation of pins and needles, shortness of breath, or weight loss

Pernicious anemia.overview:
Description
A decrease in red blood cells when the body can't absorb enough vitamin B12.
Common causes include a weakened stomach lining or an auto-immune condition.
Symptoms include fatigue and weakness.
Untreated pernicious anaemia can cause heart and nerve damage. Treatment involves vitamin B-12 shots or pills.
Pernicious anemia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.

Persistent depressive disorder.symptomDescription: Examples of symptoms include lost interest in normal activities, hopelessness, low self-esteem, low appetite, low energy, sleep changes and poor concentration.

symptoms.Mood: sadness, anger, general discontent, guilt, hopelessness, or loss of interest
symptoms.Whole body: excessive hunger, fatigue, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Cognitive: lack of concentration or slowness in activity
symptoms.Also common: indecisiveness, irritability, or low self-esteem

Persistent depressive disorder.overview:
Description
A mild but long-term form of depression.
Dysthymia is defined as a low mood occurring for at least two years, along with at least two other symptoms of depression.
Examples of symptoms include lost interest in normal activities, hopelessness, low self-esteem, low appetite, low energy, sleep changes and poor concentration.
Treatment includes medication and talk therapy.
Persistent depressive disorder.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.

Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.
Medication.Antidepressant: Taking medications designed to help relieve symptoms of depression. Some antidepressants also have other uses, such as treating chronic pain and certain anxiety disorders.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Peyronie's disease.symptomDescription: Penises vary in shape and size and having a curved erection isn't necessarily a cause for concern. In Peyronie's disease, the bend is significant, and may occur along with pain or interfere with sexual function.

symptoms.Also common: physical deformity or penis shortening

Peyronie's disease.overview:
Description
Fibrous scar tissue inside the penis that causes curved, painful erections.
Peyronie's disease is caused by repeated penile injury, typically during sex or physical activity.
Penises vary in shape and size and having a curved erection isn't necessarily a cause for concern. In Peyronie's disease, the bend is significant, and may occur along with pain or interfere with sexual function.
Medication or surgery may be recommended if symptoms persist or worsen.
Peyronie's disease.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

specialists.Plastic Surgeon: Reconstructs defective, damaged or missing body parts.

Piles (haemorrhoids).symptomDescription: Discomfort is a common symptom, especially during bowel movements or when sitting. Other symptoms include itching and bleeding.

symptoms.Also common: constipation

Piles (haemorrhoids).overview:
Description
Swollen and inflamed veins in the rectum and anus that cause discomfort and bleeding.
Haemorrhoids are usually caused by straining during bowel movements, obesity or pregnancy.
Discomfort is a common symptom, especially during bowel movements or when sitting. Other symptoms include itching and bleeding.
A high-fibre diet can be effective, along with stool softeners. In some cases, a medical procedure to remove the haemorrhoid may be needed to provide relief.
Piles (haemorrhoids).notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medical procedure.Freezing: Using extreme cold during surgery or medical treatment.
Medical procedure.Sclerotherapy: Injecting a salt water solution into abnormal blood vessels or tissues. This causes them to collapse and fade away.
Medical procedure.Stapled hemorrhoidopexy: Surgical removal of enlarged hemorrhoids. The remaining haemorrhoidal tissue is then stapled back into place.

Pilonidal sinus.symptomDescription: Symptoms of an infected cyst include pain, reddened skin or drainage of pus or blood.

symptoms.Skin: lumps, swelling, or redness
symptoms.Also common: abscess, pus, or tenderness

Pilonidal sinus.overview:
Description
An abnormal skin growth located at the tailbone that contains hair and skin.
The cyst is usually located near the tailbone and can become easily infected.
Symptoms of an infected cyst include pain, reddened skin or drainage of pus or blood.
Treatment involves drainage and surgical removal of the cyst.
Pilonidal sinus.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medical procedure.Incision and drainage: Cutting or puncturing the skin to drain an infection such as an abscess or boil.
Medical procedure.Removal of unhealthy tissue: Removal of dead, damaged or infected tissue from wounds to promote healing.

Surgery.Surgically turning a cavity into a pouch: Surgically opening a cyst or abscess and then sewing the edges to form a pouch. Done to allow ongoing drainage.

specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.
specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.

Piriformis syndrome.symptomDescription: Symptoms include pain, tingling or numbness in the buttocks and down the leg, which may worsen after sitting for a long time, climbing stairs, walking or running.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the back and leg or buttocks
symptoms.Also common: sensation of pins and needles

Piriformis syndrome.overview:
Description
A disorder in which the piriformis muscle in the buttocks irritates the sciatic nerve.
Piriformis syndrome is a disorder of a narrow muscle located in the buttocks.
Symptoms include pain, tingling or numbness in the buttocks and down the leg, which may worsen after sitting for a long time, climbing stairs, walking or running.
Treatments include stretching exercises, massage, anti-inflammatory drugs or surgery.
Piriformis syndrome.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.

Pityriasis rosea.symptomDescription: The condition causes a widespread, minimally itchy, skin rash on the torso, upper legs and upper arms.

symptoms.Skin: rashes, loss of colour, small bump, or redness
symptoms.Also common: red, scaly rash in patches or itching

Pityriasis rosea.overview:
Description
A skin rash that sometimes begins as a large spot on the chest, abdomen or back, followed by a pattern of smaller lesions.
The cause of pityriasis rosea isn't well understood, but it may be triggered by a viral infection.
The condition causes a widespread, minimally itchy, skin rash on the torso, upper legs and upper arms.
Pityriasis rosea usually goes away on its own. Steroid cream, antihistamines and in rare cases antiviral drugs can help.
Pityriasis rosea.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.

Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Pityriasis versicolor.symptomDescription: Symptoms include patches of skin that are lighter or darker than the surrounding skin, often on the torso and shoulders.

symptoms.Skin: loss of colour, rashes, darkening of the skin, or redness

Pityriasis versicolor.overview:
Description
A common fungal infection that causes small, discoloured patches of skin.
Pityriasis versicolor is caused by an overgrowth of yeast on the skin. It most often affects teens and young adults. The condition isn't contagious.
Symptoms include patches of skin that are lighter or darker than the surrounding skin, often on the torso and shoulders.
Treatments such as anti-fungal creams, lotions or shampoos are usually effective. However, skin discolouration may last for weeks to months.
Pityriasis versicolor.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Medication.Antifungal: Kills or prevents growth of fungi.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Placenta previa.symptomDescription: The main symptom is bright red vaginal bleeding without pain during the second-half of pregnancy. The condition can also cause severe bleeding before or during delivery.

symptoms.Common symptoms: vaginal bleeding

Placenta previa.overview:
Description
When the placenta covers the opening in the mother's cervix.
Placenta praevia risk factors include a previous delivery, age older than 35 and a history of previous surgeries, such as a caesarean section (C-section) or uterine fibroid removal.
The main symptom is bright red vaginal bleeding without pain during the second-half of pregnancy. The condition can also cause severe bleeding before or during delivery.
Limited physical activity is recommended. A C-section is often required in severe cases.
Placenta previa.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Plagiocephaly.symptomDescription: It might be most noticeable when looking at a baby's head from above. The cheekbone and ear on the flat side might look pushed forward.

symptoms.Common symptoms: physical deformity

Plagiocephaly.overview:
Description
A flat spot on a baby's head.
Plagiocephaly develops when a baby spends too much time lying on his or her back. It doesn't cause brain damage or interfere with a baby's development.
It might be most noticeable when looking at a baby's head from above. The cheekbone and ear on the flat side might look pushed forward.
Varying a baby's head position can help. If it doesn't improve by the age of four months, a moulded helmet might be required.
Plagiocephaly.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Infant repositioning: Frequently repositioning an infant to help treat or prevent small deformities.

Therapies.Helmet therapy: Using a helmet to help reshape the skull as it develops.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Plantar fasciitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include stabbing pain near the heel. Pain might be worse in the morning and with prolonged standing, running or jumping.

symptoms.Pain types: can be sharp
symptoms.Also common: foot sole pain, limping, swelling, or tenderness

Plantar fasciitis.overview:
Description
An inflammation of a thick band of tissue that connects the heel bone to the toes.
The inflamed tissue runs across the bottom of the foot.
Symptoms include stabbing pain near the heel. Pain might be worse in the morning and with prolonged standing, running or jumping.
Treatments include physiotherapy, stretching exercises, shoe inserts, pain relievers, steroid injections and surgery.
Plantar fasciitis.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Pleurisy.overview:
Description
Inflammation of the tissues that line the lungs and chest cavity.
Infections, such as the flu, and certain medications can cause pleurisy.
Pleurisy causes chest pain that worsens during breathing.
Treatment might include anti-inflammatories (NSAIDs), pain relievers and rest.
Pleurisy.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Pneumonia.overview:
Description
Infection that inflames air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid.
With pneumonia, the air sacs may fill with fluid or pus. The infection can be life-threatening to anyone, but particularly to infants, children and people over 65.
Symptoms include a cough with phlegm or pus, fever, chills and difficulty breathing.
Antibiotics can treat many forms of pneumonia. Some forms of pneumonia can be prevented by vaccines.
Pneumonia.notes:
Some types preventable by vaccine
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Spreads by airborne droplets
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).

Pneumothorax.overview:
Description
A collapsed lung.
This condition occurs when air leaks into the space between the lungs and chest wall. A blunt or penetrating chest injury, certain medical procedures or lung disease can cause a pneumothorax.
Symptoms include shortness of breath.
When a pneumothorax is large, a needle or tube is used to remove excess air.

Polycystic kidney disease.symptomDescription: Symptoms include high blood pressure, back or side pain and a swollen abdomen.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue syndrome or high blood pressure
symptoms.Also common: kidney damage, blood in urine, or lump in the abdomen

Polycystic kidney disease.overview:
Description
An inherited disorder in which clusters of cysts develop in the kidneys.
The cysts in polycystic kidney disease are non-cancerous sacs containing water-like fluid. They can grow very large. Many people with this condition have kidney failure by age 60.
Symptoms include high blood pressure, back or side pain and a swollen abdomen.
Treatments include medication to control blood pressure, pain relievers and cyst removal. A kidney transplant may also be required.
Polycystic kidney disease.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.ACE inhibitor: Relaxes blood vessels, lowers blood pressure and prevents diabetes-related kidney damage.

Medical procedure.Hemodialysis: Using a machine and a special filter to clean the blood when the kidneys can no longer do it.
Medical procedure.Peritoneal dialysis: A home-based therapy that uses the natural lining of the abdomen as a filter to clean the blood when the kidneys can no longer do so.
Medical procedure.Renal replacement therapy: Using replacement treatments such as dialysis and haemofiltration to clean the blood when the kidneys can no longer do so naturally.

Surgery.Kidney transplantation: Surgical replacement of a diseased kidney with one from a living or deceased donor.

specialists.Transplant Surgeon: Transfers an organ from one body to another.

Polymyalgia rheumatica.symptomDescription: Symptoms usually develop quickly and include aching of the shoulders, neck or hips.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the shoulder, neck, or pelvic girdle
symptoms.Also common: joint stiffness, tenderness, or fatigue

Polymyalgia rheumatica.overview:
Description
An inflammatory disorder causing muscle pain and stiffness around the shoulders and hips.
Most people develop polymyalgia rheumatica after age 50. Sometimes this condition occurs with temporal arteritis, a more serious condition that causes inflammation of the lining of the arteries.
Symptoms usually develop quickly and include aching of the shoulders, neck or hips.
Treatment is usually a low dose of an oral corticosteroid, such as prednisone. Although treatment often lasts two to three years, most people start to feel better within a day or two.
Polymyalgia rheumatica.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).symptomDescription: Symptoms may include nightmares or flashbacks, avoidance of situations that bring back the trauma, heightened reactivity to stimuli, anxiety or depressed mood.

symptoms.Behavioural: agitation, irritability, hostility, hypervigilance, self-destructive behaviour, or social isolation
symptoms.Psychological: flashback, fear, severe anxiety, or mistrust
symptoms.Mood: loss of interest or pleasure in activities, guilt, or loneliness
