Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).overview:
Description
A disorder characterised by failure to recover after experiencing or witnessing a terrifying event.
The condition may last months or years, with triggers that can bring back memories of the trauma accompanied by intense emotional and physical reactions.
Symptoms may include nightmares or flashbacks, avoidance of situations that bring back the trauma, heightened reactivity to stimuli, anxiety or depressed mood.
Treatment includes different types of psychotherapy as well as medications to manage symptoms.
Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Medium-term: resolves within months
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required

Therapies.Eye movement desensitization and reproce: Psychological treatment that reduces the stress of traumatic events through eye movements.
Therapies.Exposure and response prevention: A talk therapy based on exposing feared or traumatic experiences within a safe setting in order to help reduce any associated psychological distress.

Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Postnatal depression.symptomDescription: Symptoms might include insomnia, loss of appetite, intense irritability and difficulty bonding with the baby.

symptoms.Mood: anger, anxiety, guilt, hopelessness, loss of interest or pleasure in activities, mood swings, or panic attack
symptoms.Behavioural: crying, irritability, or restlessness
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or loss of appetite
symptoms.Cognitive: lack of concentration or unwanted thoughts
symptoms.Also common: insomnia or repeatedly going over thoughts

Postnatal depression.overview:
Description
Depression that occurs after childbirth.
Those who develop postpartum depression are at greater risk of developing major depression later on in life.
Symptoms might include insomnia, loss of appetite, intense irritability and difficulty bonding with the baby.
Untreated, the condition may last months or longer. Treatment can include counselling, antidepressants or hormone therapy.
Postnatal depression.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Medium-term: resolves within months
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Psychoeducation: Education about mental health that also serves to support, validate and empower patients.
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.

Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.

Self-care.Relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, meditation, yoga, rhythmic exercise and other activities that reduce symptoms of stress

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Postpartum hemorrhage.symptomDescription: Symptoms include vaginal bleeding that doesn't slow or stop. This can lead to a drop in blood pressure.

symptoms.Common symptoms: vaginal bleeding, fast heart rate, or low blood pressure

Postpartum hemorrhage.overview:
Description
Excessive bleeding after childbirth.
Causes of postpartum bleeding include loss of tone in the uterine muscles, a bleeding disorder or the placenta failing to come out completely or tearing.
Symptoms include vaginal bleeding that doesn't slow or stop. This can lead to a drop in blood pressure.
Treatment often includes uterine massage and medication. In rare cases, blood transfusion, removal of residual placenta or a hysterectomy may be required.
Postpartum hemorrhage.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.
Medication.Uterotonic: Increases the rate and strength of uterine contractions to help shorten labour.

Medical procedure.Uterine compression: Pressing on or massaging the uterus to help shrink its size and control or prevent bleeding.
Medical procedure.Dilation and curettage: Surgical removal of the lining of the womb (uterus) by scraping and scooping.
Medical procedure.Balloon tamponade: Using an inflated balloon to stop bleeding inside the throat, stomach or womb.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Maternal-Foetal Medicine Specialist: Focuses on the medical management of high-risk pregnancies.

Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrom.symptomDescription: Symptoms include lightheadedness, fainting and rapid heartbeat, which are relieved by lying down again.

symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, inability to exercise, light-headedness, or fainting
symptoms.Also common: fast heart rate, nausea, anxiety, or blurred vision

Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrom.overview:
Description
Symptoms related to the reduced blood volume that occurs when standing up.
This syndrome is usually triggered when a person stands up after lying down. It most commonly affects women between the ages of 15 and 50.
Symptoms include lightheadedness, fainting and rapid heartbeat, which are relieved by lying down again.
Adding extra salt to the diet, increasing fluids and taking medication can help the disorder.
Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrom.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Staying hydrated: Drinking water regularly throughout the day to prevent dehydration.
Self-care.Increase salt intake: Increases amount of water absorbed, which can help with blood pressure.
Self-care.Increased water intake: Prevents dehydration and may help with blood pressure.

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Medication.Blood pressure support: Helps increase blood pressure when it's too low.
Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Devices.Compression stockings: Elastic hosiery that squeeze blood up the legs to prevent swelling and blood clots.

Pre-eclampsia.symptomDescription: There may be no symptoms. High blood pressure and protein in the urine are key features. There may also be swelling in the legs and water retention, but this can be hard to distinguish from normal pregnancy.

symptoms.Whole body: high blood pressure or fatigue
symptoms.Also common: blurred vision, headache, nausea, swelling in extremities, or weight gain

Pre-eclampsia.overview:
Description
A potentially dangerous pregnancy complication characterised by high blood pressure.
Pre-eclampsia usually begins after 20 weeks of pregnancy in a woman whose blood pressure had been normal. It can lead to serious, even fatal, complications for both mother and baby.
There may be no symptoms. High blood pressure and protein in the urine are key features. There may also be swelling in the legs and water retention, but this can be hard to distinguish from normal pregnancy.
Pre-eclampsia can often be managed with oral or IV medication until the baby is sufficiently mature to be delivered. This often requires weighing the risks of early delivery versus the risks of continued pre-eclampsia symptoms.
Pre-eclampsia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medical procedure.Labor induction: Artificially bringing on labour (uterine contractions) so that a pregnant woman delivers her baby.

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

Surgery.Caesarean section: Surgical delivery of a baby through the mother's abdomen. Often done when vaginal delivery would be difficult or dangerous.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Maternal-Foetal Medicine Specialist: Focuses on the medical management of high-risk pregnancies.
specialists.Neonatologist: Provides medical care for newborn infants.

Precocious puberty.symptomDescription: Symptoms in girls include breast development and a first period. Symptoms in boys include enlarged testicles and penis, a deepening voice and facial hair, often on the upper lip.

symptoms.Common symptoms: pubic hair, acne, body odour, breast enlargement in men, deepening of voice, early onset of menstruation, facial hair, mammary gland, mood swings, short stature, or testicular enlargement in childhood

Precocious puberty.overview:
Description
A condition in which a child's body begins changing into that of an adult too soon.
Precocious puberty usually occurs before the age of eight in girls and before the age of nine in boys. The cause is often unknown.
Symptoms in girls include breast development and a first period. Symptoms in boys include enlarged testicles and penis, a deepening voice and facial hair, often on the upper lip.
Treatment typically involves medication to delay further development.
Precocious puberty.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Sex hormone suppression: Stops or slows the production of hormones involved in sexual health.
Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Prediabetes.symptomDescription: Many people with prediabetes have no symptoms.

symptoms.Whole body: excessive hunger, excessive thirst, or fatigue
symptoms.Also common: frequent urination or weight gain

Prediabetes.overview:
Description
A condition in which blood sugar is high, but not high enough to be type 2 diabetes.
Without intervention, it's likely to become type 2 diabetes within 10 years.
Many people with prediabetes have no symptoms.
Progression from prediabetes to type 2 diabetes isn't inevitable. With lifestyle changes, weight loss and medication, it's possible to bring a blood sugar level back to normal.
Prediabetes.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.
Self-care.Low carbohydrate diet: A diet that limits grains, starchy vegetables and fruit and emphasises foods high in protein and fat.
Self-care.Mediterranean diet: A diet that emphasises fruits, vegetables, whole grains, legumes, nuts, fish and olive oil.
Self-care.Low fat diet: Reducing intake of high-fat foods such as dairy, oil and red meat to improve cardiovascular health.
Self-care.Diabetic diet: Diet that helps diabetics control their blood sugar (glucose) by reducing sugar and carbohydrates. For example, drinking less soda and eating less bread.

Medication.Anti-diabetic medication: Controls the amount of sugar (glucose) in the blood.

Premenstrual dysphoric disorder.symptomDescription: PMDD causes extreme mood shifts that can disrupt work and damage relationships. Symptoms include extreme sadness, hopelessness, irritability or anger, plus common PMS symptoms such as breast tenderness and bloating.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the breast, muscles, or pelvis
symptoms.Mood: mood swings, sadness, anger, anxiety, hopelessness, or panic attack
symptoms.Behavioural: irritability or crying
symptoms.Also common: appetite changes, bloating, depression, diminished interest in usual activities, economic or social dysfunction due to symptoms, fatigue, feeling overwhelmed, food craving, headache, increased sensitivity to rejection, lack of concentration, self-critical thoughts, water retention, or weight gain

Premenstrual dysphoric disorder.overview:
Description
A severe, sometimes disabling extension of premenstrual syndrome (PMS).
Premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) is a severe form of PMS that includes physical and behavioural symptoms that usually resolve with the onset of menstruation.
PMDD causes extreme mood shifts that can disrupt work and damage relationships. Symptoms include extreme sadness, hopelessness, irritability or anger, plus common PMS symptoms such as breast tenderness and bloating.
Drugs and lifestyle changes may help.
Premenstrual dysphoric disorder.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Stress management: Pursuing an enjoyable activity or verbalising frustration to reduce stress and improve mental health.

Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.
Medication.Anxiolytic: Relieves anxiety and tension. May promote sleep.

Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.

Preterm birth.symptomDescription: Complications associated with a premature birth include immature lungs, difficulty regulating body temperature, poor feeding and slow weight gain.

symptoms.Common symptoms: disproportionately large head compared to body size, infant respiratory distress syndrome, low body temperature in newborn, or retinal damage in newborn

Preterm birth.overview:
Description
A birth that occurs before the 37th week of pregnancy.
A pregnancy normally lasts about 40 weeks. Some risk factors for a premature birth include having a previous premature birth and being pregnant with multiples.
Complications associated with a premature birth include immature lungs, difficulty regulating body temperature, poor feeding and slow weight gain.
Premature babies may need longer or more intense nursery care, medication and sometimes surgery.
Preterm birth.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.Tube feeding: Delivering nutrition through a tube inserted into the stomach.
Supportive care.Infant incubator: A device for infants that regulates temperature and humidity.
Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.
Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Devices.Medical ventilator: A device used to help with breathing.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Maternal-Foetal Medicine Specialist: Focuses on the medical management of high-risk pregnancies.
specialists.Neonatologist: Provides medical care for newborn infants.

Priapism.symptomDescription: Symptoms include an erection lasting more than four hours or off and on for several hours. The penis is usually painful or tender.

symptoms.Also common: prolonged erection or urinary retention

Priapism.overview:
Description
A prolonged erection of the penis, usually without sexual arousal.
Priapism is an unwanted, persistent erection. It may occur spontaneously or from certain antidepressants or erectile dysfunction drugs.
Symptoms include an erection lasting more than four hours or off and on for several hours. The penis is usually painful or tender.
Prompt treatment is required. Options include draining blood from the penis (aspiration) and medication to restrict blood flow to the penis.
Priapism.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.

Medical procedure.Cavernous aspiration: Removing blood from vessels in the penis.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Prolactinoma.symptomDescription: Common symptoms include breast discharge and irregular menstrual periods in women. Men may experience decreased sexual desire and breast enlargement. Prolactinoma can cause impaired vision and infertility.

symptoms.Menstrual: absence of menstruation, infrequent menstruation, or irregular menstruation
symptoms.Sexual: reduced sex drive or sexual dysfunction
symptoms.Also common: breast enlargement in men, headache, inappropriate breast milk production, or vision disorder

Prolactinoma.overview:
Description
A hormone-secreting tumour on the pituitary gland.
The hormone-producing gland in the brain (pituitary gland) overproduces prolactin, decreasing the levels of some sex hormones. It's caused by a non-cancerous tumour on the gland.
Common symptoms include breast discharge and irregular menstrual periods in women. Men may experience decreased sexual desire and breast enlargement. Prolactinoma can cause impaired vision and infertility.
Treatments include medication, surgery and radiation.
Prolactinoma.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Dopamine promoter: Stimulates dopamine receptors in the brain.

Surgery.Transsphenoidal surgery: Surgery performed through the nose and sinus cavity to remove brain tumours.

Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Prostate cancer.symptomDescription: Symptoms include difficulty with urination, but sometimes there are no symptoms at all.

symptoms.Urinary: difficulty starting and maintaining a steady stream of urine, dribbling of urine, excessive urination at night, frequent urination, urge to urinate and leaking, urinary retention, or weak urinary stream

Prostate cancer.overview:
Description
A cancer in a man's prostate, a small walnut-sized gland that produces seminal fluid.
A man's prostate produces the seminal fluid that nourishes and transports sperm.
Symptoms include difficulty with urination, but sometimes there are no symptoms at all.
Some types of prostate cancer grow slowly. In some of these cases, monitoring is recommended. Other types are aggressive and require radiation, surgery, hormone therapy, chemotherapy or other treatments.
Prostate cancer.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Supportive care.Palliative care: Works to improve quality of life while adjusting or recovering from a serious illness.
Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Medical procedure.Particle therapy: Radiation therapy that uses a beam of particles such as protons to treat cancer.
Medical procedure.Teletherapy: Radiation therapy that uses x-rays or other high-energy beams to destroy cancer cells and shrink tumours.
Medical procedure.Brachytherapy: Placing radioactive material inside the body to treat cancer.
Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

Surgery.Laparoscopic radical prostatectomy: Surgical removal of the prostate gland and surrounding tissue using several small cuts.
Surgery.Radiosurgery: Radiation therapy that focuses high-power energy on a particular area of the body. For example, a tumour.
Surgery.Prostatectomy: Surgical removal of all or part of the prostate gland.
Surgery.Radical retropubic prostatectomy: Surgical removal of the prostate gland through a cut in the abdomen.
Surgery.Laparoscopic surgery: Surgery that uses a video camera and thin tubes inserted into small cuts on the body to repair or remove tissue.

Medication.Hormone Associated Therapy: Stops or slows the production of hormones.
Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

specialists.Radiation Oncologist: Treats and manages cancer by prescribing radiation therapy.

Psoriasis.symptomDescription: The most common symptom is a rash on the skin, but sometimes the rash involves the nails or joints.

symptoms.Skin: rashes, dryness, fissures, flakiness, peeling, small bump, thickness, or redness
symptoms.Also common: depression, inflamed tendons, itching, joint stiffness, plaque, or small dents in nails

Psoriasis.overview:
Description
A condition in which skin cells build up and form scales and itchy, dry patches.
Psoriasis is thought to be an immune system problem. Triggers include infections, stress and cold.
The most common symptom is a rash on the skin, but sometimes the rash involves the nails or joints.
Treatment aims to remove scales and stop skin cells from growing so quickly. Topical ointments, light therapy and medication can offer relief.
Psoriasis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medical procedure.Photodynamic therapy: Treatment that uses special drugs (photosensitising agents) along with light to kill cancer cells. The drugs must be activated by the light.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Vitamin A derivative: Unplugs blocked hair follicles and helps prevent new blockages from forming. Slows skin cell growth.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.
Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.

Self-care.Stress management: Pursuing an enjoyable activity or verbalising frustration to reduce stress and improve mental health.
Self-care.Petroleum jelly: A thick, topical ointment made from crude oil that moisturises and protects the skin. Commonly known as Vaseline.
Self-care.Light therapy: Exposure to bright light using a device called a light box. Mimics natural sunlight.
Self-care.Ultraviolet light therapy: Ultraviolet light therapy for serious skin diseases. Used along with a special medication that increases light absorption.
Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Psoriatic arthritis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include joint pain, stiffness and swelling, which may flare and subside. Many people with the condition are affected by morning stiffness. Even mild skin psoriasis can have a significant degree of arthritis.

symptoms.Also common: skin rash, fatigue, inflamed fingers or toes, itching, physical deformity, small dents in nails, or tendonitis

Psoriatic arthritis.overview:
Description
A form of arthritis that affects some people who have the skin condition psoriasis.
Psoriatic arthritis is a type of inflammatory arthritis.
Symptoms include joint pain, stiffness and swelling, which may flare and subside. Many people with the condition are affected by morning stiffness. Even mild skin psoriasis can have a significant degree of arthritis.
Treatment may include medication to reduce inflammation, steroid injections and joint replacement surgery.
Psoriatic arthritis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Warm compress: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.
Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Ultraviolet light therapy: Ultraviolet light therapy for serious skin diseases. Used along with a special medication that increases light absorption.
Self-care.PUVA: Applying UV light to the skin, often with a topical medication, to treat certain skin conditions.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.

Surgery.Joint replacement: Removing a damaged or defective joint and inserting a new, functioning one in its place.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Psychosis.symptomDescription: Possible symptoms include delusions, hallucinations, talking incoherently and agitation. The person with the condition usually isn't aware of his or her behaviour.

symptoms.Behavioural: disorganised behaviour, aggression, agitation, hostility, hyperactivity, hypervigilance, nonsense word repetition, repetitive movements, restlessness, self-harm, social isolation, lack of restraint, or persistent repetition of words or actions
symptoms.Cognitive: thought disorder, confusion, belief that an ordinary event has special and personal meaning, belief that thoughts aren't one's own, disorientation, racing thoughts, slowness in activity, thoughts of suicide, unwanted thoughts, difficulty thinking and understanding, or false belief of superiority
symptoms.Mood: anger, anxiety, apathy, excitement, feeling detached from self, general discontent, limited range of emotions, loneliness, or nervousness
symptoms.Psychological: fear, hearing voices, depression, manic episode, paranoia, persecutory delusion, religious delusion, or visual hallucinations
symptoms.Speech: deficiency of speech, excessive wordiness, incoherent speech, or rapid and frenzied speaking
symptoms.Also common: memory loss, nightmares, or tactile hallucination

Psychosis.overview:
Description
A mental disorder characterised by a disconnection from reality.
Psychosis may occur as a result of a psychiatric illness such as schizophrenia. In other instances, it may be caused by a health condition, medication or drug use.
Possible symptoms include delusions, hallucinations, talking incoherently and agitation. The person with the condition usually isn't aware of his or her behaviour.
Treatment may include medication and talk therapy.
Psychosis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.Hospitalization: A higher level of care whereby patients are closely monitored and may be given medications that would not be available at home.

Medication.Antipsychotic: Reduces or improves the symptoms of certain psychiatric conditions.

Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Psychoeducation: Education about mental health that also serves to support, validate and empower patients.
Therapies.Family therapy: Psychological counselling that helps families resolve conflicts and communicate more effectively.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Psychoanalyst: Uses psychotherapy to treat mental disorders.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Pulmonary edema.symptomDescription: Depending on the cause, pulmonary oedema symptoms may appear suddenly or develop over time. Mild to extreme breathing difficulty can occur. Cough, chest pain and fatigue are other symptoms.

symptoms.Respiratory: shortness of breath on lying down, fast breathing, rapid breathing, shallow breathing, or wheezing
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or sweating
symptoms.Also common: coughing, water retention, or fast heart rate

Pulmonary edema.overview:
Description
A condition caused by excess fluid in the lungs.
Pulmonary oedema is usually caused by a heart condition. Other causes include pneumonia, exposure to certain toxins and drugs, and being at high elevations.
Depending on the cause, pulmonary oedema symptoms may appear suddenly or develop over time. Mild to extreme breathing difficulty can occur. Cough, chest pain and fatigue are other symptoms.
Treatment generally includes supplemental oxygen and medication.
Pulmonary edema.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Self-care.Low sodium diet: A diet that restricts salt (sodium chloride) and other forms of sodium to no more than 2,000 mg per day

Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.
Medication.Antianginal: Helps reduce chest pain or pressure caused by blockages in the arteries of the heart.

Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Pulmonary embolism.symptomDescription: Symptoms include shortness of breath, chest pain and cough.

symptoms.Pain circumstances: can occur in the chest while breathing
symptoms.Whole body: light-headedness or low oxygen in the body
symptoms.Heart: fast heart rate or palpitations
symptoms.Respiratory: fast breathing or shortness of breath
symptoms.Also common: dry cough

Pulmonary embolism.overview:
Description
A condition in which one or more arteries in the lungs become blocked by a blood clot.
Most times, a pulmonary embolism is caused by blood clots that travel from the legs, or rarely, other parts of the body (deep vein thrombosis or DVT).
Symptoms include shortness of breath, chest pain and cough.
Prompt treatment to break up the clot greatly reduces the risk of death. This can be done with blood thinners and drugs or procedures. Compression stockings and physical activity can help prevent clots from forming in the first place.
Pulmonary embolism.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Anticoagulant: Unwanted reactions from taking drugs that inhibit blood clotting. The most common problem is too much bleeding, which can be very serious.

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.
specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.

Pulmonary hypertension.symptomDescription: Shortness of breath, dizziness and chest pressure are symptoms.

symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, inability to exercise, or low blood pressure
symptoms.Also common: chest pressure, chronic cough, fast heart rate, shortness of breath, swelling, or swollen legs

Pulmonary hypertension.overview:
Description
A type of high blood pressure that affects arteries in the lungs and in the heart.
Pulmonary hypertension affects arteries in the lungs and the right side of the heart.
Shortness of breath, dizziness and chest pressure are symptoms.
The condition worsens over time, but medication and oxygen therapy can help lessen symptoms and improve quality of life.
Pulmonary hypertension.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.

Pyloric stenosis.symptomDescription: Pyloric stenosis can lead to forceful vomiting, dehydration and weight loss. Babies with this condition may seem to be always hungry.

symptoms.Whole body: water-electrolyte imbalance, dehydration, or lethargy
symptoms.Also common: severe vomiting, baby colic, failure to thrive, insufficient urine production, lump in the abdomen, or weight loss

Pyloric stenosis.overview:
Description
A condition in which the opening between the stomach and small intestine thickens.
Pyloric stenosis occurs most often in babies under six months old. In this condition, the pylorus muscles block food from entering the small intestine. It occurs more often in males.
Pyloric stenosis can lead to forceful vomiting, dehydration and weight loss. Babies with this condition may seem to be always hungry.
Pyloric stenosis can be fixed with surgery.
Pyloric stenosis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Surgery.Laparoscopic surgery: Surgery that uses a video camera and thin tubes inserted into small cuts on the body to repair or remove tissue.
Surgery.Pyloromyotomy: Surgery to cut the muscle around the lower stomach (pylorus). This widens the opening between the stomach and the small intestine, allowing food to pass.

Supportive care.Electrolyte repletion: Low levels of electrolytes like potassium or magnesium can cause symptoms like palpitations or muscle cramps.
Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

specialists.Paediatric surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries for infants and children.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Raynaud's.symptomDescription: The fingers, toes, ears and tip of the nose are commonly involved and feel numb and cool in response to cold temperatures or stress. It's often accompanied by changes in the colour of the skin.

symptoms.Common symptoms: sensitivity to cold, lack of blood supply, pallor, red fingers or toes, reduced sensation of touch, or throbbing pain in fingers or toes

Raynaud's.overview:
Description
A condition in which some areas of the body feel numb and cool in certain circumstances.
In Raynaud's phenomenon, smaller arteries that supply blood to the skin constrict excessively in response to cold, limiting blood supply to the affected area.
The fingers, toes, ears and tip of the nose are commonly involved and feel numb and cool in response to cold temperatures or stress. It's often accompanied by changes in the colour of the skin.
Treatment beyond self-care, such as dressing warmer, usually isn't required.
Raynaud's.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Rectal prolapse.symptomDescription: Rectal prolapse can create an inability to control bowel movements, causing stool to leak from the rectum.

symptoms.Also common: mass protruding through the anus

Rectal prolapse.overview:
Description
A condition that occurs when part of the large intestine slips outside the anus.
Rectal prolapse typically occurs in older women, but it can occur in men and women of any age. Risk factors include multiple births and vaginal delivery.
Rectal prolapse can create an inability to control bowel movements, causing stool to leak from the rectum.
Early management includes fluids and pelvic floor exercises. Most people will eventually need surgery.
Rectal prolapse.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Dietary fiber: The parts of plant foods that the body can't digest. Helps to control blood sugar, soften stools and maintain bowel health.

Therapies.Biofeedback: Controlling the body's heartbeat, brainwaves, breathing and blood pressure by monitoring them with sensors.
Therapies.Kegel exercise: Contracting the pelvic muscles as if to stop the flow of urine. Done to strengthen these muscles.

Surgery.Laparoscopic rectopexy: Surgery to anchor the rectum in the abdomen to treat rectal prolapse.
Surgery.Colporrhaphy: Surgical repair of a defect in the wall of the vagina.

specialists.Colon & Rectal Surgeon: Performs surgery on the intestinal tract.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Repetitive strain injury.symptomDescription: Symptoms include tenderness, stiffness or tingling in the affected area.

symptoms.Muscular: cramping or muscle weakness
symptoms.Also common: tenderness, joint stiffness, or sensation of pins and needles

Repetitive strain injury.overview:
Description
A term used to describe damage and pain caused by repetitive movement and overuse.
Repetitive strain injury impacts muscles, nerves, ligaments and tendons. These types of injuries can be caused by improper technique or overuse. The elderly are most commonly affected.
Symptoms include tenderness, stiffness or tingling in the affected area.
Treatment may include anti-inflammatory drugs, physiotherapy, ergonomic evaluation and rarely surgery.
Repetitive strain injury.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Self-care.Activity modifications: Adjusting amount or type of physical activity to avoid aggravating a condition.
Self-care.Warm compress: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.
Self-care.Cold compress: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.Occupational Medicine Doctor: Prevents and treats illness in the workplace.
specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Respiratory distress syndrome.symptomDescription: People with ARDS have severe shortness of breath and often are unable to breathe on their own without support from a ventilator.

symptoms.Respiratory: respiratory distress, fast breathing, shortness of breath, or rapid breathing
symptoms.Whole body: low oxygen in the body or fever
symptoms.Also common: blue skin from poor circulation, coughing, high carbon dioxide levels in blood, muscle weakness, or organ dysfunction

Respiratory distress syndrome.overview:
Description
Condition in which fluid collects in the air sacs of the lungs, depriving organs of oxygen.
Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) can occur in those who are critically ill or who have significant injuries. It is often fatal, the risk increasing with age and severity of illness.
People with ARDS have severe shortness of breath and often are unable to breathe on their own without support from a ventilator.
Treatment includes oxygen, fluid management and medication.
Respiratory distress syndrome.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Blood pressure support: Helps increase blood pressure when it's too low.

Supportive care.Continuous positive airway pressure (CPA: A machine that relieves nighttime breathing problems by pumping a steady flow of air through the nose.
Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.
Supportive care.Tracheal intubation: Inserting a tube into the windpipe (trachea) through the mouth or nose to keep the airway open. Done when someone cannot breathe on their own.
Supportive care.Mechanical ventilation: Using a machine to move air in and out of the lungs when a person cannot breathe on their own.

Medical procedure.Induced coma: A type of coma brought on with medication in order to protect the brain.

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Respiratory Therapist: Treats and provides emergency care for patients who have trouble breathing.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Restless legs syndrome.symptomDescription: The main symptom is a nearly irresistible urge to move the legs.

symptoms.Sleep: difficulty falling asleep, excessive daytime sleepiness, sleep deprivation, or sleep disturbances
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or restlessness
symptoms.Also common: charley horse, uncomfortable tingling and burning, or urge to move

Restless legs syndrome.overview:
Description
A condition characterised by a nearly irresistible urge to move the legs, typically in the evenings.
Restless legs syndrome typically occurs while sitting or lying down. It generally worsens with age and can disrupt sleep.
The main symptom is a nearly irresistible urge to move the legs.
Getting up and moving around helps the unpleasant feeling temporarily go away. Self-care steps, lifestyle changes or medication may help.
Restless legs syndrome.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Self-care.Discontinue caffeine: Reduces risk of aggravating certain conditions.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, meditation, yoga, rhythmic exercise and other activities that reduce symptoms of stress

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.
Medication.Dopamine promoter: Stimulates dopamine receptors in the brain.
Medication.Nerve pain medication: Blocks pain caused by damaged nerves.

Retinal detachment.symptomDescription: The appearance of many bits of debris (floaters), sudden flashes of light or a shadow in the vision field are symptoms.

symptoms.Visual: blurred vision, inability to see in dim light, partial loss of vision, seeing flashes of light, seeing spots, sensitivity to light, temporary loss of vision in one eye, tunnel vision, or vision loss
symptoms.Eyes: dilated pupil or redness

Retinal detachment.overview:
Description
An emergency when part of the eye (the retina) pulls away from supportive tissue.
Retinal detachment is an emergency. Tissue at the back of the eye pulls away from a layer of blood vessels that provide necessary oxygen and nourishment.
The appearance of many bits of debris (floaters), sudden flashes of light or a shadow in the vision field are symptoms.
Prompt medical treatment can often save vision in the eye.
Retinal detachment.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Surgery.Vitrectomy: Surgical removal of the clear, jelly-like substance (vitreous gel) that fills the inside of the eye.
Surgery.Replantation: Surgical reattachment of a body part that was completely cut off.
Surgery.Cryosurgery: Surgery that uses extreme cold to destroy diseased tissue.
Surgery.Scleral buckle: A piece of silicone sponge, rubber or plastic sewn onto the white of the eye (sclera) to repair a detached retina.
Surgery.Laser surgery: Surgery using an intensely hot and focused beam of light to remove tissue and control bleeding.

specialists.Neuroradiologist: Uses imaging techniques to diagnose nervous system conditions.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Rhabdomyolysis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include dark, reddish urine, a decreased amount of urine, weakness and muscle aches.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, inability to exercise, water-electrolyte imbalance, or body ache
symptoms.Muscular: cramping, muscle weakness, or delayed onset muscle soreness
symptoms.Urinary: dark urine or insufficient urine production
symptoms.Also common: kidney damage or muscle stiffness

Rhabdomyolysis.overview:
Description
A breakdown of muscle tissue that releases a damaging protein into the blood.
This muscle tissue breakdown results in the release of a protein (myoglobin) into the blood. Myoglobin can damage the kidneys.
Symptoms include dark, reddish urine, a decreased amount of urine, weakness and muscle aches.
Early treatment with aggressive fluid replacement reduces the risk of kidney damage.
Rhabdomyolysis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.
Supportive care.Fluid replacement: Replacing fluids lost through sweating, bleeding, vomiting or diarrhoea to treat or prevent dehydration.

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Rheumatoid arthritis.symptomDescription: Rheumatoid arthritis affects joint linings, causing painful swelling. Over long periods of time, the inflammation associated with rheumatoid arthritis can cause bone erosion and joint deformity.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the joints, back, or muscles
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, anaemia, or malaise
symptoms.Skin: lumps or redness
symptoms.Hand: bump on the finger or swelling
symptoms.Also common: flare, dry mouth, physical deformity, or sensation of pins and needles

Rheumatoid arthritis.overview:
Description
A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet.
In rheumatoid arthritis, the body's immune system attacks its own tissue, including joints. In severe cases, it attacks internal organs.
Rheumatoid arthritis affects joint linings, causing painful swelling. Over long periods of time, the inflammation associated with rheumatoid arthritis can cause bone erosion and joint deformity.
While there's no cure for rheumatoid arthritis, physiotherapy and medication can help slow the disease's progression. Most cases can be managed with a class of medications called anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDS)
Rheumatoid arthritis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Heating pad: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medical procedure.Arthrocentesis: Using a syringe to collect fluid from around a joint. Also called joint aspiration.

Surgery.Arthroplasty: Surgery to repair or replace a joint.
Surgery.Joint replacement: Removing a damaged or defective joint and inserting a new, functioning one in its place.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Ringworm.symptomDescription: Ringworm is typically scaly and may be red and itchy. Ringworm of the scalp is common in children, where it may cause bald patches.

symptoms.Skin: darkening of the skin, fissures, peeling, red rashes, or scaly patches
symptoms.Also common: hair loss or itchy scalp

Ringworm.overview:
Description
A highly contagious fungal infection of the skin or scalp.
Ringworm is spread by skin-to-skin contact or by touching an infected animal or object.
Ringworm is typically scaly and may be red and itchy. Ringworm of the scalp is common in children, where it may cause bald patches.
The treatment for ringworm is antifungal medication.
Ringworm.notes:
Spreads easily
Usually self-treatable
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
HOW IT SPREADS
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Medication.Antifungal: Kills or prevents growth of fungi.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Rosacea.symptomDescription: Key symptoms are facial redness with swollen red bumps and small visible blood vessels.

symptoms.Skin: dryness, oily skin, rashes that look like acne, or swollen blood vessels in the skin
symptoms.Eyes: dryness or puffy eyes
symptoms.Also common: photosensitivity, itching, large and bulbous red nose, or red face

Rosacea.overview:
Description
A condition that causes redness and often small, red, pus-filled bumps on the face.
Rosacea most commonly affects middle-aged women with fair skin. It can be mistaken for acne or other skin conditions.
Key symptoms are facial redness with swollen red bumps and small visible blood vessels.
Treatments such as antibiotics or anti-acne medication can control and reduce symptoms. Left untreated, it tends to worsen over time.
Rosacea.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Sunblock: Protects against the sun's UV rays, which can damage the skin over time.
Self-care.Light therapy: Exposure to bright light using a device called a light box. Mimics natural sunlight.
Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.
Self-care.Artificial tears: Moistens eyes to provide soothing relief.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Vitamin A derivative: Unplugs blocked hair follicles and helps prevent new blockages from forming. Slows skin cell growth.
Medication.Topical antiseptic: Destroys or prevents the growth of microorganisms on the skin that may cause infection.

Medical procedure.Laser therapy: A focused beam of light sometimes used to treat abnormal skin.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Roseola.symptomDescription: Symptoms include several days of high fever, followed by a rash. The rash may appear as many small, pink spots.

symptoms.Whole body: fever or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: irritability, red spots on the soft palate, skin rash, swollen lymph nodes, runny nose, or sore throat

Roseola.overview:
Description
A common viral infection in young children that may cause high fever and a rash.
Roseola is a generally mild infection caused by two strains of herpes virus. It's common, usually affecting children by age two. It occasionally affects adults.
Symptoms include several days of high fever, followed by a rash. The rash may appear as many small, pink spots.
Treatment includes bed rest, fluids and medication to reduce fever.
Roseola.notes:
Spreads easily
Usually self-treatable
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Supportive care.Fluid replacement: Replacing fluids lost through sweating, bleeding, vomiting or diarrhoea to treat or prevent dehydration.

Self-care.Bed rest: Reducing activity for a short period of time following injury or illness to promote healing.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Rotator cuff tear.symptomDescription: Symptoms include shoulder pain and weakness.

symptoms.Muscular: muscle weakness or loss of muscle
symptoms.Also common: joint stiffness or tenderness

Rotator cuff tear.overview:
Description
A tear in the tissues connecting muscle to bone (tendons) around the shoulder joint.
A rotator cuff tear often occurs in people who repeatedly perform the same shoulder motions.
Symptoms include shoulder pain and weakness.
Treatment includes rest, medication, physiotherapy, corticosteroid injections and possibly surgery.
Rotator cuff tear.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.RICE (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation): Rest, ice, compression and elevation. A first-aid treatment for sprains and strains.
Self-care.Cold compress: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Surgery.Arthroscopy: Procedure to diagnose and treat joint problems using a tiny camera inserted through a small surgical opening.
Surgery.Shoulder surgery: Surgery to correct an abnormality of the shoulder.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Rotator cuff tendinitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include pain that's often described as a dull ache and stiffness around the shoulder joint.

symptoms.Also common: shoulder stiffness or tenderness

Rotator cuff tendinitis.overview:
Description
Swelling of the tissues (tendons) connecting the muscles and bones in the shoulder.
Overuse and injury are common causes of rotator cuff tendonitis.
Symptoms include pain that's often described as a dull ache and stiffness around the shoulder joint.
Rest, ice and pain relievers can help. Physiotherapy and steroid injections may be necessary.
Rotator cuff tendinitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Rest: Reducing activity for a short period of time following an injury to promote healing.
Self-care.Cold compress: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Salmonella.symptomDescription: Symptoms include diarrhoea, fever, chills and abdominal pain.

symptoms.Whole body: chills, dehydration, fatigue, fever, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: headache

Salmonella.overview:
Description
An infection with salmonella bacteria, commonly caused by contaminated food or water.
Salmonella is most common among children. People with compromised immune systems, such as older adults, babies and people with AIDS, are more likely to have severe cases.
Symptoms include diarrhoea, fever, chills and abdominal pain.
Most people only need fluids to recover in less than a week. Severe infections may require medical care, including IV fluids and sometimes antibiotics.
Salmonella.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Spreads through contaminated food or water
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
Through contaminated food or water.

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.
Supportive care.Oral rehydration therapy: Giving fluid by mouth to treat dehydration caused by diarrhoea.
Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.

Sarcoidosis.symptomDescription: Symptoms vary, depending on the organs affected.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, malaise, or night sweats
symptoms.Eyes: dryness, itchiness, or redness
symptoms.Skin: rashes or red and tender lumps
symptoms.Visual: blurred vision or sensitivity to light
symptoms.Respiratory: shortness of breath or wheezing
symptoms.Also common: coughing, swollen lymph nodes, or weight loss

Sarcoidosis.overview:
Description
The growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body.
The growths most commonly occur in the lungs, lymph nodes, eyes and skin.
Symptoms vary, depending on the organs affected.
Sarcoidosis often goes away on its own. Minimal treatment is required in most cases. For some, it may last for years and lead to organ damage.
Sarcoidosis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Scabies.symptomDescription: The most common symptom of scabies is intense itching in the area where the mites burrow.

symptoms.Skin: bumps or redness
symptoms.Also common: itching or skin burrow

Scabies.overview:
Description
A contagious, intensely itchy skin condition caused by a tiny, burrowing mite.
Scabies is contagious and spreads quickly through close physical contact in a family, school or nursing home.
The most common symptom of scabies is intense itching in the area where the mites burrow.
Scabies can be treated by killing the mites and their eggs with medication that's applied from the neck down and left on for eight hours. The mites can also be killed using oral medication.
Scabies.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Spreads by skin-to-skin contact
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Self-care.Hot water laundry: Machine washing with hot water can kill mites such as scabies mites.
Self-care.Dry cleaning: Dry cleaning can help decontaminate clothes and kill mites such as scabies mites.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Paediatric Dermatologist: Focuses on childhood disorders of skin, nails and hair.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Schizoaffective disorder.symptomDescription: Cycles of severe symptoms are often followed by periods of improvement. Symptoms may include delusions, hallucinations, depressed episodes and manic periods of high energy.

symptoms.Cognitive: belief that an ordinary event has special and personal meaning, delusion, thought disorder, racing thoughts, thoughts of suicide, or false belief of superiority
symptoms.Mood: anxiety, euphoria, hopelessness, limited range of emotions, loss of interest or pleasure in activities, or mood swings
symptoms.Psychological: depression, hallucination, paranoia, psychosis, hearing voices, or grandiosity
symptoms.Behavioural: social isolation, impulsivity, restlessness, self-harm, or sudden increases in energy
symptoms.Also common: appetite changes or rapid and frenzied speaking

Schizoaffective disorder.overview:
Description
A mental health condition including schizophrenia and mood disorder symptoms.
Schizoaffective disorder is a combination of symptoms of schizophrenia and mood disorder, such as depression or bipolar disorder. Symptoms may occur at the same time or at different times.
Cycles of severe symptoms are often followed by periods of improvement. Symptoms may include delusions, hallucinations, depressed episodes and manic periods of high energy.
People with this disorder generally do best with a combination of medication and counselling.
Schizoaffective disorder.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Therapies.Psychotherapy: A broad category of talk therapies that help overcome psychological conditions.
Therapies.Psychoeducation: Education about mental health that also serves to support, validate and empower patients.
Therapies.Family therapy: Psychological counselling that helps families resolve conflicts and communicate more effectively.

Medication.Antipsychotic: Reduces or improves the symptoms of certain psychiatric conditions.
Medication.Anticonvulsant: Prevents or controls seizures, relieves pain and treats symptoms of certain psychiatric disorders.
Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Schizophrenia.symptomDescription: Schizophrenia is characterised by thoughts or experiences that seem out of touch with reality, disorganised speech or behaviour and decreased participation in daily activities. Difficulty with concentration and memory may also be present.

symptoms.Behavioural: social isolation, disorganised behaviour, aggression, agitation, compulsive behaviour, excitability, hostility, repetitive movements, self-harm, or lack of restraint
symptoms.Cognitive: thought disorder, delusion, amnesia, belief that an ordinary event has special and personal meaning, belief that thoughts aren't one's own, disorientation, mental confusion, slowness in activity, or false belief of superiority
symptoms.Mood: anger, anxiety, apathy, feeling detached from self, general discontent, loss of interest or pleasure in activities, elevated mood, or inappropriate emotional response
symptoms.Psychological: hallucination, paranoia, hearing voices, depression, fear, persecutory delusion, or religious delusion
symptoms.Speech: circumstantial speech, incoherent speech, rapid and frenzied speaking, or speech disorder
symptoms.Also common: fatigue, impaired motor coordination, lack of emotional response, or memory loss

Schizophrenia.overview:
Description
A disorder that affects a person's ability to think, feel and behave clearly.
The exact cause of schizophrenia isn't known, but a combination of genetics, environment and altered brain chemistry and structure may play a role.
Schizophrenia is characterised by thoughts or experiences that seem out of touch with reality, disorganised speech or behaviour and decreased participation in daily activities. Difficulty with concentration and memory may also be present.
Treatment is usually lifelong and often involves a combination of medications, psychotherapy and coordinated speciality care services.
Schizophrenia.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Requires a medical diagnosis

Medication.Antipsychotic: Reduces or improves the symptoms of certain psychiatric conditions.
Medication.Anti-Tremor: Helps control tremor, shaking and unsteadiness.

Therapies.Support group: A forum for counseling and sharing experiences among people with a similar condition or goal, such as depression or weight loss.
Therapies.Rehabilitation: Retraining the brain's pathways to improve mental and physical functioning after an illness or injury. For example, after a blow to the head (concussion).
Therapies.Cognitive therapy: Talk therapy that focuses on replacing negative, distorted thoughts with positive, accurate ones.
Therapies.Psychoeducation: Education about mental health that also serves to support, validate and empower patients.
Therapies.Family therapy: Psychological counselling that helps families resolve conflicts and communicate more effectively.
Therapies.Behaviour therapy: A therapy focused on modifying harmful behaviours associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Group psychotherapy: Talk therapy where the therapist works with clients in a group instead of one-on-one.

specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.

Sciatica.symptomDescription: Pain originates in the spine and radiates down the back of the leg. Sciatica typically affects only one side of the body.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the back, buttocks, hip, or lower extremities
symptoms.Pain types: can be mild, severe, radiating, or sharp
symptoms.Pain circumstances: can occur due to injury or while sitting
symptoms.Muscular: difficulty walking or muscle weakness
symptoms.Sensory: leg numbness or pins and needles
symptoms.Also common: burning sensation, foot numbness, or weakness

Sciatica.overview:
Description
Pain radiating along the sciatic nerve, which runs down one or both legs from the lower back.
It's usually caused when a herniated disc or bone spur in the spine presses on the nerve.
Pain originates in the spine and radiates down the back of the leg. Sciatica typically affects only one side of the body.
Medication for pain and physiotherapy are common treatments.
Sciatica.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Supportive care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Muscle relaxant: Reduces muscle tension and helps relieve muscle pain and discomfort.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Nerve pain medication: Blocks pain caused by damaged nerves.

Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Chiropractic treatment techniques: Adjusting the spine and massaging the back muscles to relieve pain.
Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Acupuncture: Insertion of needles into specific points on the body to relieve pain and treat other conditions. A form of traditional Chinese medicine.

Medical procedure.Epidural steroid injection: Injection of cortisone and a numbing agent into the spine. Can relieve back, neck, arm and leg pain.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Pain Management: Eases suffering and improves quality of life for those in pain.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Scleroderma.symptomDescription: Symptoms include tightening of the skin, joint pain, exaggerated response to cold (Raynaud's disease) and heartburn.

symptoms.Skin: rashes, swollen blood vessels in the skin, or ulcers
symptoms.Also common: acid reflux, change in facial expression at rest, chronic cough, difficulty swallowing, dry mouth, fatigue, headache, joint stiffness, raynaud's, sensitivity to cold, shortness of breath, tight and hardened fingers, or weight loss

Scleroderma.overview:
Description
Chronic hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues.
Scleroderma is a group of rare diseases that more often affects women. It commonly occurs between the ages of 30 and 50.
Symptoms include tightening of the skin, joint pain, exaggerated response to cold (Raynaud's disease) and heartburn.
Treatments include medication, physiotherapy and surgery.
Scleroderma.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Proton-pump inhibitor: Decreases acid release in the stomach.

Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Immunologist: Diagnoses and treats immune system disorders.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Scoliosis.symptomDescription: Most cases are mild with few symptoms. Some children develop spine deformities that get more severe as they grow. Severe scoliosis can be painful and disabling.

symptoms.Also common: leaning to one side, muscle spasms, physical deformity, or uneven waist

Scoliosis.overview:
Description
A sideways curvature of the spine.
Scoliosis occurs most often during the growth spurt just before puberty.
Most cases are mild with few symptoms. Some children develop spine deformities that get more severe as they grow. Severe scoliosis can be painful and disabling.
Often, no treatment is necessary. Sometimes a brace or surgery is required.
Scoliosis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Devices.Back brace: A device used to support and stabilise the back. In some cases, may be used to correct an abnormal curvature of the spine.

Surgery.Bone grafting: Surgical placement of new bone around fractures to help them heal.
Surgery.Spinal fusion: Surgery to join together two or more bones in the spine (vertebrae) so there is no movement between them.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Seasonal affective disorder.symptomDescription: Symptoms include fatigue, depression, hopelessness and social withdrawal.

symptoms.Mood: anxiety, apathy, general discontent, loneliness, loss of interest, mood swings, or sadness
symptoms.Sleep: excess sleepiness, insomnia, or sleep deprivation
symptoms.Whole body: appetite changes or fatigue
symptoms.Behavioural: irritability or social isolation
symptoms.Also common: depression, lack of concentration, or weight gain

Seasonal affective disorder.overview:
Description
A mood disorder characterised by depression that occurs at the same time every year.
Seasonal affective disorder occurs in climates where there is less sunlight at certain times of the year.
Symptoms include fatigue, depression, hopelessness and social withdrawal.
Treatment includes light therapy (phototherapy), talk therapy and medication.
Seasonal affective disorder.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Medium-term: resolves within months
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Chronotherapy: Going to bed at a later time each night, all the way around the clock, until the sleep schedule is reset to normal.
Therapies.Light therapy: Exposure to bright light using a device called a light box. Mimics natural sunlight.

Medication.SSRIs: Eases symptoms of depressed mood and anxiety.
Medication.Antidepressant: Taking medications designed to help relieve symptoms of depression. Some antidepressants also have other uses, such as treating chronic pain and certain anxiety disorders.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Seborrheic dermatitis.symptomDescription: In addition to scaly patches and red skin, seborrhoeic dermatitis can cause stubborn dandruff.

symptoms.Skin: rashes, dryness, flakiness, peeling, or redness
symptoms.Also common: dandruff or itching

Seborrheic dermatitis.overview:
Description
A skin condition that causes scaly patches and red skin, mainly on the scalp.
It can also occur on oily areas of the body, such as the face, upper chest and back.
In addition to scaly patches and red skin, seborrhoeic dermatitis can cause stubborn dandruff.
Treatment involves self-care and medicated shampoos, creams and lotions. Repeated treatments may be necessary.
Seborrheic dermatitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.
Self-care.Aloe: A plant whose gel may help heal burns and other injuries when applied to the skin.

Medication.Antifungal: Kills or prevents growth of fungi.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Separation anxiety.symptomDescription: Separation anxiety differs from normal clinginess. Children with the disorder can't think about anything but the present fear of separation. They may have nightmares or regular physical complaints. They may be reluctant to go to school or other places.

symptoms.Mood: anxiety or apprehension
symptoms.Also common: crying, nightmares, palpitations, or rapid breathing

Separation anxiety.overview:
Description
A disorder in which a child becomes excessively anxious when separated from parents.
Children are especially prone to separation anxiety during times of stress.
Separation anxiety differs from normal clinginess. Children with the disorder can't think about anything but the present fear of separation. They may have nightmares or regular physical complaints. They may be reluctant to go to school or other places.
Treatment includes talk therapy and possibly anti-anxiety medication.
Separation anxiety.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Therapies.Family therapy: Psychological counselling that helps families resolve conflicts and communicate more effectively.
Therapies.Psychotherapy: Treatment of mental or behavioural disorders through talk therapy.
