Therapies.Systematic desensitization: Psychological treatment that helps people overcome fears by gradually exposing them to the things they're afraid of.
Therapies.Behaviour therapy: A therapy focused on modifying harmful behaviours associated with psychological distress.

Supportive care.Reassurance: Providing comfort and support to an anxious person whose condition is not life-threatening and may improve with time.
Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Sepsis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include fever, difficulty breathing, low blood pressure, fast heart rate and mental confusion.

symptoms.Whole body: low blood pressure, chills, dizziness, fatigue, fever, flushing, low body temperature, or shivering
symptoms.Cognitive: altered level of consciousness or mental confusion
symptoms.Respiratory: fast breathing or shortness of breath
symptoms.Also common: delirium, fast heart rate, insufficient urine production, organ dysfunction, skin discolouration, or sleepiness

Sepsis.overview:
Description
A life-threatening complication of an infection.
Sepsis occurs when chemicals released in the bloodstream to fight an infection trigger inflammation throughout the body. This can cause a cascade of changes that damage multiple organ systems, leading them to fail, sometimes even resulting in death.
Symptoms include fever, difficulty breathing, low blood pressure, fast heart rate and mental confusion.
Treatment includes antibiotics and intravenous fluids.
Sepsis.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.Mechanical ventilation: Using a machine to move air in and out of the lungs when a person cannot breathe on their own.
Supportive care.Hospitalization: A higher level of care whereby patients are closely monitored and may be given medications that would not be available at home.
Supportive care.Fluid replacement: Replacing fluids lost through sweating, bleeding, vomiting or diarrhoea to treat or prevent dehydration.
Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Blood pressure support: Helps increase blood pressure when it's too low.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Devices.Central venous catheter: A tube commonly inserted into a large vein in the groin or neck to carry medicine, fluids and nutrients into the body. Also called a central line.

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Septic shock.symptomDescription: Symptoms include low blood pressure, pale and cool arms and legs, chills, difficulty breathing and decreased urine output. Mental confusion and disorientation may also develop quickly.

symptoms.Whole body: low blood pressure, chills, fatigue, fever, or low body temperature
symptoms.Respiratory: fast breathing or shortness of breath
symptoms.Also common: fast heart rate, insufficient urine production, or mental confusion

Septic shock.overview:
Description
A widespread infection causing organ failure and dangerously low blood pressure.
Septic shock is a life-threatening condition caused by a severe localised or system-wide infection that requires immediate medical attention.
Symptoms include low blood pressure, pale and cool arms and legs, chills, difficulty breathing and decreased urine output. Mental confusion and disorientation may also develop quickly.
Emergency treatment may include supplemental oxygen, intravenous fluids, antibiotics and other medications.
Septic shock.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.
Supportive care.Oxygen therapy: Providing extra oxygen to the lungs of people with breathing problems.

Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Blood pressure support: Helps increase blood pressure when it's too low.

Devices.Central venous catheter: A tube commonly inserted into a large vein in the groin or neck to carry medicine, fluids and nutrients into the body. Also called a central line.

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.

Shaken baby syndrome.symptomDescription: Symptoms include irritability, difficulty staying awake, seizures, abnormal breathing, poor eating, bruises and vomiting.

symptoms.Whole body: fainting or lethargy
symptoms.Behavioural: crying or irritability
symptoms.Also common: altered level of consciousness, bleeding, bone fracture, bruising, coma, lack of interest in feeding in infants, retinal haemorrhage, seizures, shortness of breath, sleepiness, tremor, or vomiting

Shaken baby syndrome.overview:
Description
A serious brain injury resulting from forcefully shaking an infant or toddler.
Shaken baby syndrome usually occurs when a parent or caregiver severely shakes a child in frustration or anger, often because the child won't stop crying. Permanent brain damage or death may result.
Symptoms include irritability, difficulty staying awake, seizures, abnormal breathing, poor eating, bruises and vomiting.
Treatment will vary depending on complications related to shaken baby syndrome. In rare instances, breathing support or surgery may be required to stop bleeding in the brain.
Shaken baby syndrome.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.Monitoring in the intensive care unit: Care provided in a specialised hospital unit that can deliver medications to support blood pressure and manage breathing machines.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Paediatric Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats children in intensive care.

Shin splints.symptomDescription: The main symptom is pain in the leg.

symptoms.Also common: lower leg pain after exercise

Shin splints.overview:
Description
Pain caused by overuse along the shinbone, the large front bone in the lower leg.
Shin splints result when muscles, tendons and bone tissue become overworked. Shin splints often occur in athletes who've recently intensified or changed their training routines.
The main symptom is pain in the leg.
Treatment includes rest, ice and pain relievers.
Shin splints.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.

Self-care.RICE (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation): Rest, ice, compression and elevation. A first-aid treatment for sprains and strains.
Self-care.Strength training: Physical exercise against resistance to regain muscle function and treat disease.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Shingles.symptomDescription: Shingles causes a painful rash that may appear as a stripe of blisters on the torso. Pain can persist even after the rash is gone (this is called post-herpetic neuralgia).

symptoms.Skin: blister, scab, ulcers, or redness
symptoms.Sensory: oversensitivity or pins and needles
symptoms.Also common: painful red blister rash in linear distribution, burning sensation, fatigue, or itching

Shingles.overview:
Description
A reactivation of the chickenpox virus in the body, causing a painful rash.
Anyone who's had chickenpox may develop shingles. It isn't known what reactivates the virus.
Shingles causes a painful rash that may appear as a stripe of blisters on the torso. Pain can persist even after the rash is gone (this is called post-herpetic neuralgia).
Treatments include pain relief and antiviral medication such as aciclovir or valaciclovir. A chickenpox vaccine in childhood or a shingles vaccine as an adult can minimise the risk of developing shingles.
Shingles.notes:
Preventable by vaccine
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Local anesthetic: Blocks pain at and near the site where it's given, or along the nerve that's blocked.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Nerve pain medication: Blocks pain caused by damaged nerves.

Shoulder impingement.symptomDescription: Pain may be consistent and increase with lifting or reaching movements.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the shoulder, arm, or neck
symptoms.Muscular: limited range of motion or muscle weakness
symptoms.Also common: joint stiffness or tenderness

Shoulder impingement.overview:
Description
Shoulder pain caused by connective tissue (a tendon) rubbing on a shoulder blade.
Impingement syndrome is caused by inflammation from repetitive shoulder activities. Injury and ageing are other causes.
Pain may be consistent and increase with lifting or reaching movements.
Rest, medication and physiotherapy can help.
Shoulder impingement.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Rest: Reducing activity for a short period of time following an injury to promote healing.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
Therapies.Acupuncture: Insertion of needles into specific points on the body to relieve pain and treat other conditions. A form of traditional Chinese medicine.

Surgery.Arthroscopy: Procedure to diagnose and treat joint problems using a tiny camera inserted through a small surgical opening.
Surgery.Shoulder surgery: Surgery to correct an abnormality of the shoulder.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Sickle cell anemia.symptomDescription: Infections, pain and fatigue are symptoms of sickle cell disease.

symptoms.Pain types: can be sudden in the chest
symptoms.Whole body: dizziness, fatigue, low oxygen in the body, or malaise
symptoms.Urinary: inability to make concentrated or dilute urine or blood in urine
symptoms.Also common: abnormal breakdown of red blood cells, inflamed fingers or toes, pallor, shortness of breath, or yellow skin and eyes

Sickle cell anemia.overview:
Description
A group of disorders that cause red blood cells to become misshapen and break down.
With sickle cell disease, an inherited group of disorders, red blood cells contort into a sickle shape. The cells die early, leaving a shortage of healthy red blood cells (sickle cell anaemia) and can block blood flow causing pain (sickle cell crisis).
Infections, pain and fatigue are symptoms of sickle cell disease.
Treatments include medication, blood transfusions and rarely a bone-marrow transplant.
Sickle cell anemia.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Devices.Patient-controlled analgesia: Allowing patients to get pain medication when they need it by pressing a button on a machine. The medication is then delivered through an IV.

Medication.Narcotic: Relieves pain, dulls the senses and causes drowsiness. May become addictive.
Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.
Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.

specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Sinusitis (sinus infection).symptomDescription: Symptoms include headache, facial pain, runny nose and nasal congestion.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the face, sinuses, back of the eyes, ear, or forehead
symptoms.Nasal: congestion, distorted sense of smell, itching, loss of smell, runny nose, or sneezing
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, fever, or malaise
symptoms.Also common: sinus pressure, headache, inflammation of ear, mouth breathing, phlegm, pus, sleeping difficulty, or throat irritation

Sinusitis (sinus infection).overview:
Description
A condition in which the cavities around the nasal passages become inflamed.
Acute sinusitis can be triggered by a cold or allergies and may resolve on its own. Chronic sinusitis lasts up to eight weeks and may be caused by an infection or growths.
Symptoms include headache, facial pain, runny nose and nasal congestion.
Acute sinusitis usually doesn't require any treatment beyond symptomatic relief with pain medication, nasal decongestants and nasal saline rinses. Chronic sinusitis may require antibiotics.
Sinusitis (sinus infection).notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Nasal washing: Rinsing the inside of the nose with warm salt water to flush out irritants and excess mucus. Often done using a neti pot or squeeze bottle.

Medication.Decongestant: Relieves nasal congestion, swelling and runny nose.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Cough medicine: Blocks the cough reflex. Some may thin and loosen mucus, making it easier to clear from the airways.
Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Supportive care.Saline solution: Salt water used to replace bodily fluids, clean wounds, irrigate the sinuses and rinse contact lenses.

Medical procedure.Drainage: Making an opening in the body to remove fluids such as blood or pus.

specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Sj\u00f6gren's syndrome.symptomDescription: The main symptoms are dry mouth and eyes.

symptoms.Sensory: abnormality of taste, loss of taste, or pins and needles
symptoms.Also common: dry cough, dry eyes, dry skin, fatigue, joint stiffness, stiffness, swollen lymph nodes, or vaginal dryness

Sj\u00f6gren's syndrome.overview:
Description
An immune system disorder characterised by dry eyes and dry mouth.
With this disorder, the body's immune system attacks its own healthy cells that produce saliva and tears. Sjögren's syndrome often occurs with other such disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.
The main symptoms are dry mouth and eyes.
Treatments include eye drops, medication and eye surgery.
Sj\u00f6gren's syndrome.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Artificial tears: Moistens eyes to provide soothing relief.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Dentist: Specialises in diseases of the oral cavity, especially the teeth.

Skin cancer (melanoma).symptomDescription: Symptoms might include a new, unusual growth or a change in an existing mole. Melanomas can occur anywhere on the body.

symptoms.Common symptoms: bigger mole diameter, darkening of the skin, mole color changes, or skin mole with irregular border

Skin cancer (melanoma).overview:
Description
The most serious type of skin cancer.
Melanoma occurs when the pigment-producing cells that give colour to the skin become cancerous.
Symptoms might include a new, unusual growth or a change in an existing mole. Melanomas can occur anywhere on the body.
Treatment may involve surgery, radiation, medication or in some cases, chemotherapy.
Skin cancer (melanoma).notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required

Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.
Medical procedure.Mohs surgery: Surgical removal of skin cancer, one layer at a time, until only healthy tissue is left.

Surgery.Skin grafting: Surgically removing skin from one part of the body and transplanting it to another part. For example, to treat a serious burn or wound.
Surgery.Wide local excision: Surgical removal of a small area of tissue, along with a margin of normal tissue beyond the border of disease

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Immunotherapy: Lowers or changes normal immune response to treat disease, especially cancer.

specialists.Plastic Surgeon: Reconstructs defective, damaged or missing body parts.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Skin tags.symptomDescription: The main symptom is a growth on the skin, often on the neck, upper chest, underarms and eyelids. They may become irritated from rubbing against clothing.

symptoms.Skin: small growth of normal skin or darkening of the skin

Skin tags.overview:
Description
A common skin growth in which a short, narrow stalk sticks out.
Skin tags are usually harmless and painless.
The main symptom is a growth on the skin, often on the neck, upper chest, underarms and eyelids. They may become irritated from rubbing against clothing.
Most skin tags don't require treatment. If a skin tag is irritated or its appearance is bothersome, a doctor can remove it.

Medical procedure.Cauterization: Burning or freezing a part of the body to remove tissue or stop bleeding. For example, to seal off a wound and prevent blood loss.

Surgery.Cryosurgery: Surgery that uses extreme cold to destroy diseased tissue.
Surgery.Surgical removal: Removal of abnormal tissue with surgical techniques.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Slapped cheek syndrome.symptomDescription: The facial rash looks as if the cheeks were slapped. Sore throat, slight fever, upset stomach, headache, fatigue and itching are among other symptoms.

symptoms.Whole body: fever or fatigue
symptoms.Also common: rash on the face, coughing, headache, itching, nausea, runny nose, or sore throat

Slapped cheek syndrome.overview:
Description
A common and highly contagious childhood ailment causing a distinctive face rash.
The rash appears after several days and may spread.
The facial rash looks as if the cheeks were slapped. Sore throat, slight fever, upset stomach, headache, fatigue and itching are among other symptoms.
The virus usually clears up on its own, but pain relievers may help with symptoms.
Slapped cheek syndrome.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Spreads easily
Usually self-treatable
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).
By mother to baby by pregnancy, labour or nursing.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Sleep apnoea.symptomDescription: Symptoms include snoring loudly and feeling tired even after a full night's sleep.

symptoms.Sleep: excessive daytime sleepiness, insomnia, nightmares, sleep deprivation, or snoring
symptoms.Respiratory: episodes of no breathing, breathing through the mouth, or loud breathing
symptoms.Also common: depression, dry mouth, dry throat, fatigue, headache, irritability, mood swings, or weight gain

Sleep apnoea.overview:
Description
A potentially serious sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts.
Risk factors include age and obesity. It's more common in men.
Symptoms include snoring loudly and feeling tired even after a full night's sleep.
Treatment often includes lifestyle changes, such as weight loss and the use of a breathing assistance device at night, such as a continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) machine.
Sleep apnoea.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.

Supportive care.Continuous positive airway pressure (CPA: A machine that relieves nighttime breathing problems by pumping a steady flow of air through the nose.
Supportive care.Airway management: Clearing a blocked airway of food, foreign objects, fluid and other obstructions. A top priority in emergency situations.

Surgery.Palatoplasty: Plastic surgery to repair a split in the roof of the mouth (cleft palate). This is a common birth defect.

specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.
specialists.Respiratory Therapist: Treats and provides emergency care for patients who have trouble breathing.

Sleep paralysis.symptomDescription: Episodes involve not being able to speak or move while falling asleep or upon waking. This usually lasts one or two minutes and is often frightening.

symptoms.Common symptoms: paralysis, anxiety, or hallucination

Sleep paralysis.overview:
Description
A temporary inability to move or speak while falling asleep or upon waking.
Sleep paralysis most often occurs in people who have narcolepsy or sleep apnoea, but it can affect anyone.
Episodes involve not being able to speak or move while falling asleep or upon waking. This usually lasts one or two minutes and is often frightening.
The main treatment is improved sleep habits (sleep hygiene) including going to bed at the same time every night, ensuring a comfortable sleep environment free of distractions and avoiding caffeine before sleeping.
Sleep paralysis.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required

Supportive care.Reassurance: Providing comfort and support to an anxious person whose condition is not life-threatening and may improve with time.

Self-care.Improved sleep habits: Good sleep practices include having a regular bedtime schedule and avoiding naps, caffeine and TV before bedtime.

specialists.Clinical Psychologist: Treats mental disorders primarily with talk therapy.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Sleepwalking.symptomDescription: Sleepwalking usually occurs one to two hours after falling asleep at night. Rarely, it may involve unusual behaviours, such as climbing out of a window or urinating in a wardrobe.

symptoms.Common symptoms: inability to recall sleepwalking after awakening, excessive daytime sleepiness, falling, or fatigue

Sleepwalking.overview:
Description
The act of getting up and walking around while asleep.
Sleepwalking is most common in children, who usually outgrow it by their teens.
Sleepwalking usually occurs one to two hours after falling asleep at night. Rarely, it may involve unusual behaviours, such as climbing out of a window or urinating in a wardrobe.
Often, sleepwalking is a random, harmless event. Treatment may be required if it occurs often or causes injury. Medication and hypnosis may help.
Sleepwalking.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required

Self-care.Anticipatory awakening: Scheduling time to awaken someone from sleep to prevent conditions that occur during sleep.
Self-care.Relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, meditation, yoga, rhythmic exercise and other activities that reduce symptoms of stress
Self-care.Improved sleep habits: Good sleep practices include having a regular bedtime schedule and avoiding naps, caffeine and TV before bedtime.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Slipped disc.symptomDescription: Some herniated discs cause no symptoms. Others can irritate nearby nerves and result in pain, numbness or weakness in an arm or leg.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the arm, back, foot, or leg
symptoms.Muscular: muscle weakness, muscle spasms, or overactive reflexes
symptoms.Sensory: leg numbness, pins and needles, or uncomfortable tingling and burning
symptoms.Also common: foot numbness, hand numbness, or stiff neck

Slipped disc.overview:
Description
A condition which refers to a problem with a rubbery disc between the spinal bones.
This condition occurs when the soft centre of a spinal disc pushes through a crack in the tougher exterior casing.
Some herniated discs cause no symptoms. Others can irritate nearby nerves and result in pain, numbness or weakness in an arm or leg.
Not every disc needs intervention. When required, treatment includes medication, physiotherapy and possibly surgery.
Slipped disc.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Heating pad: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Therapies.Chiropractic treatment techniques: Adjusting the spine and massaging the back muscles to relieve pain.
Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medical procedure.Therapeutic ultrasound: Using heat and vibrations from sound waves to treat sprains, strains and other injuries.
Medical procedure.Epidural steroid injection: Injection of cortisone and a numbing agent into the spine. Can relieve back, neck, arm and leg pain.

Surgery.Spinal surgery: Correcting abnormalities of the spinal cord or its surrounding bones through surgical methods.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Soil-transmitted helminthiasis.extraName: Also called: hookworm, roundworm, or whipworm infection
Soil-transmitted helminthiasis.symptomDescription: Most people don't have any symptoms. In rare and severe cases, symptoms may include stomach pain, diarrhoea and rectal prolapse. Malnutrition can develop. Children with these infections may also have mental and physical growth impairments.

symptoms.Also common: blood in stool, loss of appetite, mild nausea, or slow growth

Soil-transmitted helminthiasis.overview:
Description
A group of infections including hookworm, roundworm and whipworm.
These infections are spread through oral or skin contact with contaminated human faeces. They are most common in warm, moist climates with poor sanitation.
Most people don't have any symptoms. In rare and severe cases, symptoms may include stomach pain, diarrhoea and rectal prolapse. Malnutrition can develop. Children with these infections may also have mental and physical growth impairments.
Soil-transmitted helminthiases is treated with antiparasitic drugs.
Soil-transmitted helminthiasis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Spreads through contaminated food or water
Medium-term: resolves within months
HOW IT SPREADS
Through contaminated food or water.

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Spider bite.symptomDescription: Symptoms include swelling, redness and pain around the bite.

symptoms.Skin: redness, blister, small bump, or pimples
symptoms.Also common: itching or swelling

Spider bite.overview:
Description
An injury caused by venom from a spider's bite.
Many spiders aren't poisonous. Bites can sometimes be severe and develop late. Poisonous spiders, such as black widows and brown recluses, generally live in undisturbed areas, such as attics or sheds, and don't bite unless threatened.
Symptoms include swelling, redness and pain around the bite.
Treatment usually includes cleaning the bite, applying ice and watching for infection.
Spider bite.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Supportive care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Antihistamine: Reduces or stops an allergic reaction.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Spina bifida.symptomDescription: Symptoms can sometimes be seen on the skin above the spinal defect. They include an abnormal tuft of hair, a birthmark or protruding spinal cord tissue.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: bowel obstruction, constipation, or leaking of stool
symptoms.Muscular: muscle weakness, stiff muscles, or overactive reflexes
symptoms.Skin: birthmark, brown spot on skin, or skin cyst
symptoms.Urinary: bed wetting, leaking of urine, or urinary tract infection
symptoms.Also common: hunched back, intellectual disability, nerve injury, paralysis, paralysis of the body's lower half, or physical deformity

Spina bifida.overview:
Description
A birth defect in which a developing baby's spinal cord fails to develop properly.
It occurs when a developing baby's spinal cord fails to develop or close properly while in the womb.
Symptoms can sometimes be seen on the skin above the spinal defect. They include an abnormal tuft of hair, a birthmark or protruding spinal cord tissue.
When treatment is necessary, it's carried out through surgery to close the defect. Other treatments focus on managing complications.
Spina bifida.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Surgery.Spinal surgery: Correcting abnormalities of the spinal cord or its surrounding bones through surgical methods.
Surgery.Colostomy: Surgical creation of an abdominal opening where stool can leave the body.
Surgery.Spinal fusion: Surgery to join together two or more bones in the spine (vertebrae) so there is no movement between them.
Surgery.Suprapubic cystostomy: A thin tube (catheter) placed through the skin just above the pubic bone into the bladder. The catheter drains urine when normal flow is blocked.
Surgery.Caesarean section: Surgical delivery of a baby through the mother's abdomen. Often done when vaginal delivery would be difficult or dangerous.

Medical procedure.Urinary catheterization: Inserting a tube into the bladder to drain urine.
Medical procedure.Urinary diversion: Surgery to reroute the flow of urine from its normal pathway. May require a new external opening.
Medical procedure.Enema: Fluid injected into the anus to stimulate a bowel movement.

Devices.Back brace: A device used to support and stabilise the back. In some cases, may be used to correct an abnormal curvature of the spine.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Maternal-Foetal Medicine Specialist: Focuses on the medical management of high-risk pregnancies.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Spinal cord injury.symptomDescription: A spinal cord injury often causes permanent loss of strength, sensation and function below the site of the injury.

symptoms.Muscular: muscle weakness, problems with coordination, stiff muscles, muscle spasms, or overactive reflexes
symptoms.Whole body: feeling faint or sweating
symptoms.Sensory: reduced sensation of touch or pins and needles
symptoms.Urinary: leaking of urine or urinary retention
symptoms.Also common: abnormal and painful sensation, leaking of stool, or shortness of breath

Spinal cord injury.overview:
Description
Damage to any part of the spinal cord or nerves at the end of the spinal canal.
A traumatic spinal cord injury may happen because of a sudden blow or cut to the spine.
A spinal cord injury often causes permanent loss of strength, sensation and function below the site of the injury.
Rehabilitation and assistive devices allow many people with spinal cord injuries to lead productive, independent lives. Treatments include drugs to reduce symptoms and surgery to stabilise the spine.
Spinal cord injury.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Critical: needs emergency care

Supportive care.Hydrotherapy: Using water to relieve pain, treat diseases and maintain health. For example, mineral baths and hot tubs.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Blood pressure support: Helps increase blood pressure when it's too low.
Medication.Muscle relaxant: Reduces muscle tension and helps relieve muscle pain and discomfort.

Surgery.Spinal surgery: Correcting abnormalities of the spinal cord or its surrounding bones through surgical methods.

Therapies.Hydrotherapy: Using water to relieve pain, treat diseases and maintain health. For example, mineral baths and hot tubs.
Therapies.Rehabilitation: Retraining the brain's pathways to improve mental and physical functioning after an illness or injury. For example, after a blow to the head (concussion).

Medical procedure.Urinary catheterization: Inserting a tube into the bladder to drain urine.
Medical procedure.Traction: Using weights and pulleys to put a broken bone or damaged joint back in position and hold it still.

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Spondylitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include pain, stiffness or tenderness in the back, hip pain and limited mobility.

symptoms.Also common: inflamed tendons or sleep disorder

Spondylitis.overview:
Description
Inflammation of the spine (vertebrae).
Spondylitis is a condition that involves inflammation of the spine. Causes include infection, injury or age-related wear and tear. A common form is ankylosing spondylitis, a type of arthritis.
Symptoms include pain, stiffness or tenderness in the back, hip pain and limited mobility.
Treatment may include medication such as antibiotics or anti-inflammatories, physiotherapy and in rare cases, surgery.
Spondylitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Heating pad: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.

specialists.Neuroradiologist: Uses imaging techniques to diagnose nervous system conditions.
specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.

Spondylolisthesis.symptomDescription: If the vertebra slips too far, it may press on nerves and cause severe back pain or nerve crowding that produces leg pain or numbness.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the legs, thighs and buttocks that worsens with standing or lower back
symptoms.Also common: hamstring tightness, stiffness, or tenderness

Spondylolisthesis.overview:
Description
A spinal disorder in which a bone (vertebra) slips forward onto the bone below it.
Spondylolisthesis risk factors include sports that put stress on the bones in the lower back, such as gymnastics and football. Genetics may also put some people at increased risk.
If the vertebra slips too far, it may press on nerves and cause severe back pain or nerve crowding that produces leg pain or numbness.
Initial treatment may include rest and medication. Severe spondylolisthesis may require surgery.
Spondylolisthesis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Devices.Back brace: A device used to support and stabilise the back. In some cases, may be used to correct an abnormal curvature of the spine.

Surgery.Facetectomy: Open back surgery to remove a damaged vertebral joint and relieve pressure on the spinal nerves.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Medical procedure.Epidural steroid injection: Injection of cortisone and a numbing agent into the spine. Can relieve back, neck, arm and leg pain.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Spondylosis.symptomDescription: Most people don't have symptoms, but some may experience pain or muscle spasms.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the back, legs, thighs and buttocks that worsens with standing, neck, or shoulder
symptoms.Muscular: muscle weakness or muscle spasms
symptoms.Also common: headache, sensation of pins and needles, or stiffness

Spondylosis.overview:
Description
A general term for age-related wear and tear of the spinal discs.
Spondylosis is common and worsens with age. This condition is often used to describe degenerative arthritis (osteoarthritis) of the spine.
Most people don't have symptoms, but some may experience pain or muscle spasms.
In many cases, no specific treatment is required. If symptoms occur, treatments include medication, corticosteroid injections, physiotherapy and sometimes surgery.
Spondylosis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Warm compress: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.
Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Muscle relaxant: Reduces muscle tension and helps relieve muscle pain and discomfort.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Narcotic: Relieves pain, dulls the senses and causes drowsiness. May become addictive.
Medication.Local anesthetic: Blocks pain at and near the site where it's given, or along the nerve that's blocked.

Surgery.Spinal surgery: Correcting abnormalities of the spinal cord or its surrounding bones through surgical methods.
Surgery.Laminectomy: Surgical removal of the back part of the vertebra to relieve pressure on the spine or nerve.
Surgery.Laminotomy: Surgical removal of the bony arch of a vertebra to relieve pressure on the spine or nerve.
Surgery.Intervertebral disc annuloplasty: Surgery to repair the outside of a bulging disc in the spine before it ruptures.
Surgery.Intervertebral disc arthroplasty: Surgical replacement of damaged discs in the spine with artificial ones.
Surgery.Laminoplasty: Surgery to relieve pressure (stenosis) on the spinal cord in the neck.
Surgery.Facetectomy: Open back surgery to remove a damaged vertebral joint and relieve pressure on the spinal nerves.
Surgery.Microsurgery: Surgery performed on very small blood vessels and nerves using a microscope.
Surgery.Foraminotomy: Back surgery to widen the opening where nerves leave the spine, relieving pinched nerves.
Surgery.Arthrodesis: Surgical fusion of the bones that form a joint.
Surgery.Spinal fusion: Surgery to join together two or more bones in the spine (vertebrae) so there is no movement between them.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Sprained ankle.symptomDescription: A sprained ankle causes swelling, pain and limited range of motion.

symptoms.Also common: ankle instability, limping, swelling, tenderness, or bruising

Sprained ankle.overview:
Description
An injury that occurs when the ankle rolls, twists or turns in an awkward way.
This can stretch or tear the tough bands of tissue (ligaments) that help hold the ankle bones together.
A sprained ankle causes swelling, pain and limited range of motion.
Many people simply treat a sprained ankle at home with rest, ice and pain relievers. Severe sprains may need medical evaluation.
Sprained ankle.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Cold compress: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.RICE (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation): Rest, ice, compression and elevation. A first-aid treatment for sprains and strains.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Devices.Brace: A device applied to the body to help stabilise, protect or limit movement of a damaged joint.
Devices.Elastic bandage: Stretchy bandages used to wrap sprains and strains. Provides support and compression during recovery.
Devices.Splint: A rigid accessory used to stabilise and protect an injured joint.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Staph infection.symptomDescription: Common symptoms include boils and oozing blisters. Staph can also cause food poisoning resulting in nausea, vomiting and stomach ache. In rare cases, staph infections can turn deadly if the bacteria invade deeper into the body or enters the bloodstream resulting in fever, joint and muscle pain.

symptoms.Skin: blister, boil, impetigo, rashes, or redness
symptoms.Whole body: chills or fever
symptoms.Also common: abscess, pus, or swelling

Staph infection.overview:
Description
An infection caused by bacteria commonly found on the skin or in the nose.
Staph can be spread from person to person and is very contagious.
Common symptoms include boils and oozing blisters. Staph can also cause food poisoning resulting in nausea, vomiting and stomach ache. In rare cases, staph infections can turn deadly if the bacteria invade deeper into the body or enters the bloodstream resulting in fever, joint and muscle pain.
Treatment often includes drainage of the infection and antibiotics. Strains of staph that no longer respond to common antibiotics are called MRSA.
Staph infection.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Spreads easily
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Medical procedure.Incision and drainage: Cutting or puncturing the skin to drain an infection such as an abscess or boil.
Medical procedure.Surgical drain: A tube inserted in a wound or surgical opening to remove pus, blood or other fluids.

specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Stasis dermatitis.symptomDescription: Skin discolouration of the ankles or shins, itching, thickened skin and open sores (ulcers) are symptoms.

symptoms.Skin: rashes, blister, darkening of the skin, discoloured and thick skin on legs, dryness, scaly rashes, ulcers, varicose veins, or redness
symptoms.Also common: itching or swelling

Stasis dermatitis.overview:
Description
Skin inflammation in the lower legs caused by fluid build-up.
Stasis dermatitis is caused by fluid build-up due to varicose veins, circulation issues or heart disease.
Skin discolouration of the ankles or shins, itching, thickened skin and open sores (ulcers) are symptoms.
Treatments may include compression stockings and prescription creams as well as treating the underlying condition.
Stasis dermatitis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Devices.Compression stockings: Elastic hosiery that squeeze blood up the legs to prevent swelling and blood clots.

Self-care.Petroleum jelly: A thick, topical ointment made from crude oil that moisturises and protects the skin. Commonly known as Vaseline.
Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.
Self-care.Barrier cream: A cream that soothes and protects irritated skin.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Vascular Surgeon: Specialises in surgery for vascular system diseases.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Stomach cancer.symptomDescription: There may be no symptoms of stomach cancer early on. Later, symptoms include feeling bloated after eating, feeling full after eating small amounts of food, nausea, heartburn or indigestion.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: dark stool from digested blood, indigestion, nausea, or vomiting blood
symptoms.Whole body: cancer-related fatigue or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: abdominal fullness, difficulty swallowing, or weight loss

Stomach cancer.overview:
Description
Cancer that occurs in the stomach.
Risk factors may include smoking and a diet of highly processed or salty foods.
There may be no symptoms of stomach cancer early on. Later, symptoms include feeling bloated after eating, feeling full after eating small amounts of food, nausea, heartburn or indigestion.
Treatment options include surgery, medication, radiation and chemotherapy.
Stomach cancer.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.
Medication.Chemotherapy protective drugs: Reduces the side effects of chemotherapy treatment.

Surgery.Gastrectomy: Surgical removal of all or part of the stomach.
Surgery.Gastroenterostomy: Surgery that connects the small intestine to an opening made in the stomach.

Supportive care.Palliative care: Works to improve quality of life while adjusting or recovering from a serious illness.

specialists.Palliative Medicine: Focuses on improving quality of life for those with severe illnesses.
specialists.Radiation Oncologist: Treats and manages cancer by prescribing radiation therapy.
specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Stomach flu.symptomDescription: Diarrhoea, cramps, nausea, vomiting and low-grade fever are common symptoms.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: diarrhoea, stomach cramps, belching, gagging, indigestion, nausea, vomiting, or flatulence
symptoms.Whole body: chills, dehydration, fatigue, fever, light-headedness, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: fast heart rate, headache, insufficient urine production, weakness, or weight loss

Stomach flu.overview:
Description
An intestinal infection marked by diarrhoea, cramps, nausea, vomiting and fever.
Stomach flu is typically spread by contact with an infected person or through contaminated food or water.
Diarrhoea, cramps, nausea, vomiting and low-grade fever are common symptoms.
Avoiding contaminated food and water and washing hands can often help prevent infection. Rest and rehydration are the mainstays of treatment.
Stomach flu.notes:
Spreads easily
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
Through contaminated food or water.
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.
Supportive care.Fluid replacement: Replacing fluids lost through sweating, bleeding, vomiting or diarrhoea to treat or prevent dehydration.
Supportive care.Oral rehydration therapy: Giving fluid by mouth to treat dehydration caused by diarrhoea.
Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Stomach ulcer.symptomDescription: Upper abdominal pain is a common symptom.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the chest or upper abdomen
symptoms.Pain types: can be dull
symptoms.Gastrointestinal: belching, heartburn, indigestion, nausea, passing excessive amounts of gas, or vomiting
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, feeling full sooner than normal, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: abdominal discomfort

Stomach ulcer.overview:
Description
A sore that develops on the lining of the oesophagus, stomach or small intestine.
Ulcers occur when stomach acid damages the lining of the digestive tract. Common causes include the bacteria H. Pylori and anti-inflammatory pain relievers including aspirin.
Upper abdominal pain is a common symptom.
Treatment usually includes medication to decrease stomach acid production. If it is caused by bacteria, antibiotics may be required.
Stomach ulcer.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Proton-pump inhibitor: Decreases acid release in the stomach.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Antidiarrhoeal: Reduces frequency and urgency of bowel movements.
Medication.Antacid: Counteracts the effects of stomach acid.

Medical procedure.Therapeutic endoscopy: Using a lighted medical instrument to see inside the body and provide treatment. For example, to stop bleeding or remove a foreign object.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Strep throat.symptomDescription: Common symptoms include sore throat, fever and swollen lymph nodes in the neck. Rarely, complications can involve the heart or kidneys.

symptoms.Whole body: fever, chills, or malaise
symptoms.Also common: sore throat, enlarged neck lymph nodes, swollen tonsils, tender lymph nodes, tonsillar exudate, bad breath, or headache

Strep throat.overview:
Description
A bacterial infection that may cause a sore, scratchy throat.
The infection is generally transmitted by direct contact with the mucus or sores of someone else with strep.
Common symptoms include sore throat, fever and swollen lymph nodes in the neck. Rarely, complications can involve the heart or kidneys.
Treatment is important to reduce complications. Oral antibiotics like penicillin, amoxicillin, cephalexin or azithromycin are commonly used. Other medicines such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help with pain and fever.
Strep throat.notes:
Spreads easily
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).

Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Stroke.symptomDescription: Symptoms of stroke include trouble walking, speaking and understanding, as well as paralysis or numbness of the face, arm or leg.

symptoms.Muscular: difficulty walking, instability, paralysis with weak muscles, problems with coordination, stiff muscles, overactive reflexes, or paralysis of one side of the body
symptoms.Visual: blurred vision, double vision, sudden visual loss, or temporary loss of vision in one eye
symptoms.Speech: difficulty speaking, slurred speech, or speech loss
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, light-headedness, or vertigo
symptoms.Sensory: pins and needles or reduced sensation of touch
symptoms.Also common: difficulty swallowing, headache, inability to understand, mental confusion, or rapid involuntary eye movement

Stroke.overview:
Description
Damage to the brain from interruption of its blood supply.
A stroke is a medical emergency.
Symptoms of stroke include trouble walking, speaking and understanding, as well as paralysis or numbness of the face, arm or leg.
Early treatment with medication like tPA (clot buster) can minimise brain damage. Other treatments focus on limiting complications and preventing additional strokes.
Stroke.notes:
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Anticoagulant: Unwanted reactions from taking drugs that inhibit blood clotting. The most common problem is too much bleeding, which can be very serious.
Medication.Statin: Decreases the liver's production of harmful cholesterol.
Medication.ACE inhibitor: Relaxes blood vessels, lowers blood pressure and prevents diabetes-related kidney damage.

Supportive care.Cardiac monitoring: Using an electronic device to monitor heart rate and rhythm. Can be done in the hospital or at home.

Surgery.Carotid endarterectomy: Surgical removal of plaque build-up in the carotid arteries, which are located in the neck.

Therapies.Speech therapy: Treats people with speech and language problems.
Therapies.Rehabilitation: Retraining the brain's pathways to improve mental and physical functioning after an illness or injury. For example, after a blow to the head (concussion).
Therapies.Occupational Therapy: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
Therapies.Stroke rehabilitation: Relearning skills that are lost when the brain is damaged by a stroke. For example, how to walk and talk.

specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Stye.symptomDescription: Styes are often filled with pus. Sometimes a stye can form on the inner part of the eyelid.

symptoms.Eyes: eyelid redness, puffy eyes, or watery eyes
symptoms.Also common: lump on the eyelid, eyelid pain, or eyelid tenderness

Stye.overview:
Description
A red, painful lump near the edge of the eyelid that may look like a boil or pimple.
A stye can develop after the small glands that line the eyelid get plugged.
Styes are often filled with pus. Sometimes a stye can form on the inner part of the eyelid.
In most cases, a stye will begin to disappear on its own in a few days. A warm washcloth applied to the eyelid may relieve pain and discomfort.
Stye.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Warm compress: Soothes painful muscles or joints and can help drain skin infections.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Subconjunctival hemorrhage.symptomDescription: The main symptom is a bright red patch in the eye that may spread and then become green or yellow, much like a bruise. Usually it disappears within two weeks.

symptoms.Common symptoms: eye redness

Subconjunctival hemorrhage.overview:
Description
A bright red patch appearing in the white of the eye beneath the clear lining of the eye (conjunctiva).
A subconjunctival haemorrhage is bleeding underneath the conjunctiva. It can occur after a sudden or severe sneeze or cough, heavy lifting, straining, vomiting or even rubbing one's eyes too roughly. It can also occur as a side effect of eye surgery or blood thinners.
The main symptom is a bright red patch in the eye that may spread and then become green or yellow, much like a bruise. Usually it disappears within two weeks.
In most cases, no treatment is required for this condition.
Subconjunctival hemorrhage.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Sunburn.symptomDescription: Symptoms include red, painful, itchy skin that's hot to the touch. Skin may also blister.

symptoms.Skin: flakiness, peeling, rashes, roughness, warmness, red spots, or redness
symptoms.Also common: blistering, itching, or swelling

Sunburn.overview:
Description
A type of skin burn resulting from too much exposure to sunlight or sunlamps.
Repeated exposure increases the risk of other conditions such as wrinkles, dark spots and skin cancer.
Symptoms include red, painful, itchy skin that's hot to the touch. Skin may also blister.
Treatment includes pain relievers and creams to relieve itching.
Sunburn.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Aloe: A plant whose gel may help heal burns and other injuries when applied to the skin.
Self-care.Sunblock: Protects against the sun's UV rays, which can damage the skin over time.
Self-care.Moisturizer: Hydrates and protects skin from damage.
Self-care.Sun protective clothing: Reduces exposure to the sun's UV rays, which can damage the skin over time.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).symptomDescription: There may be symptoms like heart palpitations or there may be no symptoms at all.

symptoms.Whole body: fainting, fatigue, light-headedness, or sweating
symptoms.Also common: fast heart rate or shortness of breath

Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).overview:
Description
A faster than normal heart rate beginning above the heart's two lower chambers.
Supraventricular tachycardia is a rapid heartbeat that develops when the normal electrical impulses of the heart are disrupted.
There may be symptoms like heart palpitations or there may be no symptoms at all.
Certain manoeuvres, medication, an electrical shock to the heart (cardioversion) and catheter-based procedures (ablation) can help slow the heart.
Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required

Self-care.Vagal maneuver: Actions such as gagging, coughing or massaging the neck to slow down a fast heart rate..
Self-care.Valsalva maneuver: Breathing out forcefully while the mouth is closed and the nose is pinched shut.

Medication.Beta blocker: Slows heart rate and decreases blood pressure. When taken in eye-drop form, it reduces eye pressure.
Medication.Antiarrhythmic: Helps control abnormal or irregular heart rhythms.

Medical procedure.Cardioversion: Using electrical shocks to restore normal heart rhythm in people with irregular heartbeats.
Medical procedure.Ablation: Removal of tissue using lasers, radiofrequency (RF) waves, focused ultrasound, heat or cold.

specialists.Cardiac Electrophysiologist: Treats patients with electrical and heart rhythm problems.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Swimmer's ear.symptomDescription: The main symptom is redness in the outer ear accompanied by warmth and pain.

symptoms.Also common: feeling of fullness in the ear, hearing loss, itching, redness, or tenderness

Swimmer's ear.overview:
Description
An infection of the outer ear canal.
Otitis externa is an infection of the outer ear canal that runs from the eardrum to the outside of the head. It's often caused by water remaining in the ear after swimming. This creates a moist environment that helps bacteria or fungi grow.
The main symptom is redness in the outer ear accompanied by warmth and pain.
A person may be prescribed ear drops and advised to keep the ear dry.
Swimmer's ear.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Ear cleaning: Keeping the ear dry to reduce the risk of infection.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Local anesthetic: Blocks pain at and near the site where it's given, or along the nerve that's blocked.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Swine flu.symptomDescription: Symptoms include fever, cough, sore throat, chills, weakness and body aches. Children, pregnant women and the elderly are at risk from severe infection.

symptoms.Whole body: chills, fatigue, or fever
symptoms.Also common: headache, shortness of breath, or sore throat

Swine flu.overview:
Description
A human respiratory infection caused by an influenza strain that started in pigs.
Swine flu was first recognised in the 1919 pandemic and still circulates as a seasonal flu virus. Swine flu is caused by the H1N1 virus strain, which started in pigs.
Symptoms include fever, cough, sore throat, chills, weakness and body aches. Children, pregnant women and the elderly are at risk from severe infection.
Typical treatment includes rest, pain relievers and fluids. In some cases antiviral medication and IV fluids may be required.
Swine flu.notes:
Preventable by vaccine
Treatable by a medical professional
Spreads easily
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Self-care.Menthol: An oil made from mint that soothes sore throats and relieves itching.
Self-care.Rest: Reducing activity for a short period of time following an injury to promote healing.

Medication.Cough medicine: Blocks the cough reflex. Some may thin and loosen mucus, making it easier to clear from the airways.
Medication.Decongestant: Relieves nasal congestion, swelling and runny nose.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Supportive care.Fluid replacement: Replacing fluids lost through sweating, bleeding, vomiting or diarrhoea to treat or prevent dehydration.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic h.symptomDescription: Symptoms can vary depending on how rapidly the condition develops. In some cases, nausea and vomiting, headache, confusion, weakness and fatigue may be experienced.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or malaise
symptoms.Muscular: cramping or muscle weakness
symptoms.Also common: headache, irritability, mental confusion, nausea, or tremor

Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic h.overview:
Description
A condition in which high levels of a hormone cause the body to retain water.
In this condition, the body retains water instead of excreting it normally in urine. This process upsets the body's balance of minerals called electrolytes, especially sodium.
Symptoms can vary depending on how rapidly the condition develops. In some cases, nausea and vomiting, headache, confusion, weakness and fatigue may be experienced.
Treatments include fluid restriction and possibly medication to adjust electrolyte balance. Underlying conditions also need treatment.
Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic h.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Self-care.Water restriction: A reduction in water intake to treat fluid overload.

Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.

Supportive care.Sodium chloride: A salt solution taken by mouth or injected into a vein to treat low levels of sodium in the body.

specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.

Syphilis.symptomDescription: The first stage involves a painless sore on the genitals, rectum or mouth. After the initial sore heals, the second stage is characterised by a rash. Then, there are no symptoms until the final stage which may occur years later. This final stage can result in damage to the brain, nerves, eyes or heart.

symptoms.Groin: painless ulcers, sores, vaginal discharge, or wart-like growths on genitals
symptoms.Skin: rashes, small bump, or ulcers
symptoms.Also common: fatigue, itching, mouth ulcer, rash on the palms and soles, rectal lining inflammation, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, or weight loss

Syphilis.overview:
Description
A bacterial infection usually spread by sexual contact that starts as a painless sore.
Syphilis develops in stages and symptoms vary with each stage.
The first stage involves a painless sore on the genitals, rectum or mouth. After the initial sore heals, the second stage is characterised by a rash. Then, there are no symptoms until the final stage which may occur years later. This final stage can result in damage to the brain, nerves, eyes or heart.
Syphilis is treated with penicillin. Sexual partners should also be treated.
Syphilis.notes:
Spreads by sexual contact
Treatable by a medical professional
Medium-term: resolves within months
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
HOW IT SPREADS
By having unprotected vaginal, anal or oral sex.
By blood products (unclean needles or unscreened blood).
By mother to baby by pregnancy, labour or nursing.

Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Taeniasis.symptomDescription: Most cases of the infection do not cause symptoms. In severe or chronic cases, symptoms may include stomach pain, lost appetite, weight loss and an upset stomach. Tapeworm segments may be visible as they pass through the anus and in the faeces.

symptoms.Gastrointestinal: nausea or passing worms in stool
symptoms.Also common: weight loss

Taeniasis.overview:
Description
A tapeworm infection that affects the digestive system.
Taeniasis is caused by eating undercooked beef or pork that contains tapeworm eggs.
Most cases of the infection do not cause symptoms. In severe or chronic cases, symptoms may include stomach pain, lost appetite, weight loss and an upset stomach. Tapeworm segments may be visible as they pass through the anus and in the faeces.
Medications are used to treat taeniasis. Adequate sanitation and cooking meat to safe temperatures can help prevent it.
Taeniasis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Spreads through contaminated food or water
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
Through contaminated food or water.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.

Tardive dyskinesia.symptomDescription: Tardive dyskinesia causes repetitive, involuntary movements, such as grimacing and eye blinking.

symptoms.Common symptoms: involuntary movements, lip smacking, or repetitive movements

Tardive dyskinesia.overview:
Description
A condition affecting the nervous system, often caused by long-term use of some psychiatric drugs.
Tardive dyskinesia is caused by long-term use of neuroleptic drugs, which are used to treat psychiatric conditions.
Tardive dyskinesia causes repetitive, involuntary movements, such as grimacing and eye blinking.
Stopping or tapering drugs that may be contributing to involuntary repetitive movements can help. In rare cases, botulinum toxin, deep brain stimulation or medication can help.
Tardive dyskinesia.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Discontinue or taper antipsychotic drugs: Reduces likelihood of developing or furthering complications related to certain types of psychiatric medications.

Medication.Sedative: Causes drowsiness, calmness and dulled senses. Some types may become addictive.

specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.

Temporal arteritis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include headaches, jaw pain, vision loss, fever and fatigue. Diagnosis usually requires biopsy of the temporal artery.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the jaw pain with chewing
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, fever, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Visual: temporary loss of vision in one eye or vision loss
symptoms.Also common: headache, scalp tenderness, or weight loss

Temporal arteritis.overview:
Description
An inflammation of blood vessels, called arteries, in and around the scalp.
The cause of the blood vessel inflammation is unknown. In some cases, the swelling affects just part of an artery with sections of normal vessel in between.
Symptoms include headaches, jaw pain, vision loss, fever and fatigue. Diagnosis usually requires biopsy of the temporal artery.
The condition needs prompt treatment with steroid medication to prevent permanent vision loss.
Temporal arteritis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.

Temporomandibular disorder (TMD).symptomDescription: Jaw pain, difficulty chewing and clicking and locking of the jaw joint are some of the symptoms.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the face, ear, jaw, or mouth
symptoms.Pain types: can be chronic
symptoms.Also common: headache, joint locking, or muscle spasms

Temporomandibular disorder (TMD).overview:
Description
Pain and compromised movement of the jaw joint and the surrounding muscles.
The temporomandibular joint or TMJ acts like a sliding hinge, connecting your jawbone to your skull. Dysfunction can lead to pain and discomfort.
Jaw pain, difficulty chewing and clicking and locking of the jaw joint are some of the symptoms.
Common treatments include medication, bite guards and physiotherapy.
Temporomandibular disorder (TMD).notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Self-care.Relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, meditation, yoga, rhythmic exercise and other activities that reduce symptoms of stress
Self-care.Stress management: Pursuing an enjoyable activity or verbalising frustration to reduce stress and improve mental health.

Therapies.Biofeedback: Controlling the body's heartbeat, brainwaves, breathing and blood pressure by monitoring them with sensors.
Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
Therapies.Acupuncture: Insertion of needles into specific points on the body to relieve pain and treat other conditions. A form of traditional Chinese medicine.

Devices.Splint: A rigid accessory used to stabilise and protect an injured joint.
Devices.Prosthodontics: Artificial replacements for teeth and other parts of the mouth. For example, bridges and dentures.
Devices.Mouthguard: Protects the teeth and gums from injury.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Nerve pain medication: Blocks pain caused by damaged nerves.
Medication.Muscle relaxant: Reduces muscle tension and helps relieve muscle pain and discomfort.
Medication.Sedative: Causes drowsiness, calmness and dulled senses. Some types may become addictive.

specialists.Dentist: Specialises in diseases of the oral cavity, especially the teeth.
specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.

Tennis elbow.symptomDescription: Pain is the primary symptom. It usually occurs on the outside of the elbow and sometimes in the forearm and wrist.

symptoms.Also common: swelling or tenderness

Tennis elbow.overview:
Description
An irritation of the tissue connecting the forearm muscle to the elbow.
Tennis elbow can be caused by repetitive wrist and arm motions.
Pain is the primary symptom. It usually occurs on the outside of the elbow and sometimes in the forearm and wrist.
Treatment includes rest, pain relievers and physiotherapy.
