Tennis elbow.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.

Self-care.RICE (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation): Rest, ice, compression and elevation. A first-aid treatment for sprains and strains.
Self-care.Cold compress: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
Therapies.Acupuncture: Insertion of needles into specific points on the body to relieve pain and treat other conditions. A form of traditional Chinese medicine.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Devices.Splint: A rigid accessory used to stabilise and protect an injured joint.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Tension-type headaches.symptomDescription: The main symptom is pain on both sides of the head that may be associated with muscle pain.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the face, muscles, or neck
symptoms.Also common: headache, difficulty falling asleep, fear of loud sounds, or sensitivity to light

Tension-type headaches.overview:
Description
A mild to moderate pain often described as feeling like a tight band around the head.
Multiple factors can bring on a tension headache, including stress, inadequate sleep and poor posture.
The main symptom is pain on both sides of the head that may be associated with muscle pain.
Treatments include pain relievers and other medication. Stress reduction, ice or heat on sore muscles and good posture may also help.
Tension-type headaches.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, meditation, yoga, rhythmic exercise and other activities that reduce symptoms of stress
Self-care.Stress management: Pursuing an enjoyable activity or verbalising frustration to reduce stress and improve mental health.

Therapies.Biofeedback: Controlling the body's heartbeat, brainwaves, breathing and blood pressure by monitoring them with sensors.
Therapies.Joint manipulation: Stretching a joint past its current restricted range of motion to restore movement and reduce pain.
Therapies.Chiropractic treatment techniques: Adjusting the spine and massaging the back muscles to relieve pain.
Therapies.Behaviour therapy: A therapy focused on modifying harmful behaviours associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Acupuncture: Insertion of needles into specific points on the body to relieve pain and treat other conditions. A form of traditional Chinese medicine.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Testicular torsion.symptomDescription: Sudden, severe pain and swelling in the testicle are symptoms.

symptoms.Also common: swelling of scrotum or tenderness

Testicular torsion.overview:
Description
A twisting of the male organ that makes hormones and sperm (testicle).
When the testicle rotates (testicular torsion), it twists the cord supplying blood to the loose bag of skin (scrotum) beneath the penis. This may occur after vigorous activity, a minor injury to the testicles or sleep.
Sudden, severe pain and swelling in the testicle are symptoms.
Surgery is required. Treated promptly, the testicle can often be saved. A longer wait may affect fertility.
Testicular torsion.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Surgery.Surgically moving the testicle into the: A surgery that fixes a testicle to the inside of the scrotum to prevent future torsions or takes an undescended testicle and moves it into the scrotum.

specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Thalassemia.symptomDescription: Symptoms include fatigue, weakness, paleness and slow growth.

symptoms.Whole body: anaemia, fatigue, or weakness
symptoms.Also common: failure to thrive, iron overload, pallor, shortness of breath, or yellow skin and eyes

Thalassemia.overview:
Description
A blood disorder involving lower-than-normal amounts of an oxygen-carrying protein.
Thalassemia is an inherited blood disorder characterised by less oxygen-carrying protein (haemoglobin) and fewer red blood cells in the body than normal.
Symptoms include fatigue, weakness, paleness and slow growth.
Mild forms may not need treatment. Severe forms may require blood transfusions or a donor stem-cell transplant.
Thalassemia.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.
Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.
Medication.Iron reducer: Removes excess iron from the body.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.

Thoracic outlet syndrome.symptomDescription: Symptoms include pain in the shoulders and neck and numbness, weakness and coldness in the fingers.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the arm, neck, or shoulder
symptoms.Sensory: pins and needles or reduced sensation of touch
symptoms.Also common: cold sensitivity of the fingers, headache, muscle weakness, or swelling

Thoracic outlet syndrome.overview:
Description
A group of disorders that occur when certain blood vessels or nerves are compressed.
Thoracic outlet syndrome affects the space between the collarbone and first rib (thoracic outlet). Common causes include trauma, repetitive injuries, pregnancy and anatomical defects, such as having an extra rib.
Symptoms include pain in the shoulders and neck and numbness, weakness and coldness in the fingers.
Treatment involves physiotherapy and pain relief. In rare cases, surgery may be required to relieve the compression.
Thoracic outlet syndrome.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Vascular Surgeon: Specialises in surgery for vascular system diseases.
specialists.Cardiothoracic Surgeon: Surgically treats diseases affecting organs inside the chest.
specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Thyroid cancer.symptomDescription: Some people have no symptoms. Others may notice a lump in the neck.

symptoms.Neck: enlarged lymph nodes, lump, or swelling
symptoms.Also common: thyroid nodules

Thyroid cancer.overview:
Description
A cancer of the thyroid, the butterfly-shaped gland at the base of the neck.
The cause of thyroid cancer is poorly understood, but may involve a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Some people have no symptoms. Others may notice a lump in the neck.
Treatments, which are usually successful, include surgery, hormone therapy, radioactive iodine, radiation and in some cases chemotherapy.
Thyroid cancer.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medical procedure.Radiation therapy: Treatment that uses x-rays and other high-energy rays to kill abnormal cells.

Medication.Antithyroid agent: Prevents the thyroid gland from making or releasing thyroid hormone.
Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

Surgery.Thyroid removal: Surgical removal of all or part of the thyroid gland.
Surgery.Endocrine surgery: Surgical treatment of the glands that produce hormones in the body. For example, to remove a tumour on the gland.
Surgery.Partial thyroidectomy: Surgical removal of part of the thyroid.
Surgery.Lymph node dissection: Surgical removal of a lymph node.
Surgery.Neck dissection: Surgical removal of lymph nodes in the neck.

specialists.Nuclear Medicine Doctor: Applies radioactive substances to diagnose and treat disease.
specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.
specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.

Thyroid nodules.symptomDescription: Most thyroid nodules don't cause symptoms.

symptoms.Common symptoms: lump in the neck or enlarged thyroid

Thyroid nodules.overview:
Description
A lump in the thyroid, the butterfly-shaped gland at the base of the neck.
A thyroid nodule is a solid or fluid-filled lump.
Most thyroid nodules don't cause symptoms.
The majority of thyroid nodules don't require treatment. Treatment options for larger or cancerous nodules, or nodules that produce additional thyroid hormones, may include medication or surgery.
Thyroid nodules.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.

Thyroiditis.symptomDescription: There may be no symptoms. When symptoms occur, they may vary depending on the stage of the inflammation.

symptoms.Whole body: excess sweating, fatigue, heat intolerance, or feeling cold
symptoms.Gastrointestinal: unusually frequent defecation or water retention
symptoms.Mood: anxiety or nervousness
symptoms.Eyes: abnormal protrusion of eyes or puffy eyes
symptoms.Also common: dry hair, dry skin, enlarged thyroid, fast heart rate, irregular menstruation, muscle weakness, overactive thyroid, sensitivity to cold, sexual dysfunction, tremor, or underactive thyroid

Thyroiditis.overview:
Description
Inflammation of the thyroid, the butterfly-shaped gland in the neck.
Thyroid inflammation can occur for many reasons. It initially causes a leak of hormones that results in symptoms of an overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism). Over time, the inflammation impairs thyroid hormone production, resulting in underactivity (hypothyroidism).
There may be no symptoms. When symptoms occur, they may vary depending on the stage of the inflammation.
Treatment is focused on the underlying cause as well as regulating thyroid function.
Thyroiditis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medical procedure.Radioactive iodine therapy: A radioactive medicine taken by mouth to reduce the functioning of the thyroid gland or completely destroy it.

Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

specialists.Nuclear Medicine Doctor: Applies radioactive substances to diagnose and treat disease.

Tonsil stones.symptomDescription: Symptoms may include a sensation of something stuck in the throat, bad breath, sore throat, difficulty swallowing and ear pain.

symptoms.Common symptoms: bad breath or sore throat

Tonsil stones.overview:
Description
A lump of calcified material in the tonsils, the fleshy pads at the back of the throat.
The cause is unknown but oral bacteria may contribute to their formation.
Symptoms may include a sensation of something stuck in the throat, bad breath, sore throat, difficulty swallowing and ear pain.
Many require no treatment. Larger ones can be removed by a doctor.
Tonsil stones.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

specialists.Dentist: Specialises in diseases of the oral cavity, especially the teeth.
specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Tonsillitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include sore throat, difficulty swallowing and tender lymph nodes.

symptoms.Whole body: chills, fatigue, fever, or malaise
symptoms.Also common: enlarged neck lymph nodes, sore throat, swollen tonsils, bad breath, excess salivation, mouth breathing, poor appetite, pus, snoring, or tender lymph nodes

Tonsillitis.overview:
Description
An inflammation of the two oval-shaped pads of tissue at the back of the throat.
Tonsillitis is usually caused by a viral infection but can be from a bacterial infection.
Symptoms include sore throat, difficulty swallowing and tender lymph nodes.
Treatment can range from home-care remedies to surgical removal.
Tonsillitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Spreads easily
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Penicillin: Stops growth of or kills specific bacteria.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

specialists.Otolaryngologist: Treats ear, nose and throat disorders.

Torn meniscus.symptomDescription: Pain, swelling, stiffness and difficulty extending the knee are symptoms.

symptoms.Muscular: difficulty walking or limited range of motion
symptoms.Also common: swollen knee or stiffness

Torn meniscus.overview:
Description
A common injury in which forceful twisting causes certain tissue in the knee to tear.
A meniscus tear occurs in the rubbery knee cartilage that cushions the shinbone from the thighbone. The meniscus can tear with forceful twisting or rotation of the knee.
Pain, swelling, stiffness and difficulty extending the knee are symptoms.
Treatment includes rest, ice, pain relievers and physiotherapy. Less commonly, surgery may be required.
Torn meniscus.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Self-care.RICE (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation): Rest, ice, compression and elevation. A first-aid treatment for sprains and strains.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Surgery.Arthroscopy: Procedure to diagnose and treat joint problems using a tiny camera inserted through a small surgical opening.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

Torticollis.symptomDescription: The most common type causes the chin to pull toward the shoulder. Symptoms include a limited range of head motion, headache or neck pain.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the muscles, neck, or back
symptoms.Also common: muscle spasms, physical deformity, stiffness, or headache

Torticollis.overview:
Description
A rare condition in which the neck muscles contract, causing the head to twist to one side.
Torticollis can be inherited and is seen soon after birth. This form may resolve without treatment.
The most common type causes the chin to pull toward the shoulder. Symptoms include a limited range of head motion, headache or neck pain.
Injecting botulinum toxin into the affected muscles often reduces the symptoms of torticollis. Physiotherapy or surgery may also be required.
Torticollis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required

Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Medication.Neurotoxin: Reduces or eliminates muscle activity and spasms by paralysing muscles.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Tourette syndrome.symptomDescription: It involves uncontrollable repetitive movements or unwanted sounds (tics), such as repeatedly blinking the eyes, shrugging shoulders or blurting out offensive words.

symptoms.Behavioural: compulsive behaviour, impulsivity, hyperactivity, meaningless repetition of own words, nonsense word repetition, repetitive movements, swearing uncontrollably, or lack of restraint
symptoms.Muscular: tic, difficulty with bodily movements, increased muscle activity, involuntary movements, involuntary muscle contraction, or jerking muscle spasms
symptoms.Mood: anxiety or apprehension
symptoms.Also common: coughing, eyelid twitching, frequent throat clearing, learning disability, repetitive blinking of eyes, or stuttering

Tourette syndrome.overview:
Description
A nervous system disorder involving repetitive movements or unwanted sounds.
Tourette's syndrome starts in childhood.
It involves uncontrollable repetitive movements or unwanted sounds (tics), such as repeatedly blinking the eyes, shrugging shoulders or blurting out offensive words.
Treatment may include medication or psychological therapies.
Tourette syndrome.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required

Self-care.Relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, meditation, yoga, rhythmic exercise and other activities that reduce symptoms of stress

Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Exposure and response prevention: A talk therapy based on exposing feared or traumatic experiences within a safe setting in order to help reduce any associated psychological distress.

Medication.Antipsychotic: Reduces or improves the symptoms of certain psychiatric conditions.

specialists.Child and Adolescent Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders in children and adolescents.
specialists.Psychiatrist: Treats mental disorders primarily with medications.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Toxoplasmosis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include muscle pain, fever and headache, all of which can last for weeks.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or fever
symptoms.Also common: enlarged neck lymph nodes or headache

Toxoplasmosis.overview:
Description
A disease that results from infection with the Toxoplasma gondii parasite.
Toxoplasmosis results from infection with a common parasite found in cat faeces and contaminated food. It can cause serious complications for pregnant women and people with weakened immune systems.
Symptoms include muscle pain, fever and headache, all of which can last for weeks.
Medication can reduce infection severity. But the best approach is prevention by avoiding exposure. People with weakened immune systems should use preventive medication.
Toxoplasmosis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Spreads by animals or insects
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months
HOW IT SPREADS
By animal or insect bites or stings.
By blood products (unclean needles or unscreened blood).
Through contaminated food or water.
By mother to baby by pregnancy, labour or nursing.

Medication.Chemotherapy protective drugs: Reduces the side effects of chemotherapy treatment.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Antifungal: Kills or prevents growth of fungi.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Immunologist: Diagnoses and treats immune system disorders.

Transient ischaemic attack (TIA).symptomDescription: Symptoms include weakness on one side of the body, vision problems and slurred speech. These are transient and often resolve within 24 hours.

symptoms.Muscular: difficulty walking, muscle weakness, problems with coordination, or weakness of one side of the body
symptoms.Whole body: feeling faint, light-headedness, or vertigo
symptoms.Visual: blurred vision or vision loss
symptoms.Also common: difficulty swallowing, mental confusion, or reduced sensation of touch

Transient ischaemic attack (TIA).overview:
Description
A brief stroke-like attack that, despite resolving within minutes to hours, still requires immediate medical attention to distinguish from an actual stroke.
A transient ischaemic attack may be a warning sign of a future stroke.
Symptoms include weakness on one side of the body, vision problems and slurred speech. These are transient and often resolve within 24 hours.
Treatment includes medication, surgery and healthy lifestyle changes.
Transient ischaemic attack (TIA).notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Anticoagulant: Unwanted reactions from taking drugs that inhibit blood clotting. The most common problem is too much bleeding, which can be very serious.
Medication.Statin: Decreases the liver's production of harmful cholesterol.

Supportive care.Cardiac monitoring: Using an electronic device to monitor heart rate and rhythm. Can be done in the hospital or at home.

Surgery.Carotid endarterectomy: Surgical removal of plaque build-up in the carotid arteries, which are located in the neck.

specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Vascular Surgeon: Specialises in surgery for vascular system diseases.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Traumatic brain injury.symptomDescription: Immediate or delayed symptoms may include confusion, blurry vision and difficulty concentrating. Infants may cry persistently or be irritable.

symptoms.Cognitive: amnesia, inability to speak or understand language, mental confusion, difficulty concentrating, difficulty thinking and understanding, inability to create new memories, or inability to recognise common things
symptoms.Behavioural: abnormal laughing and crying, aggression, impulsivity, irritability, lack of restraint, or persistent repetition of words or actions
symptoms.Mood: anger, anxiety, apathy, or loneliness
symptoms.Whole body: blackout, dizziness, fainting, or fatigue
symptoms.Eyes: dilated pupil, raccoon eyes, or unequal pupils
symptoms.Muscular: instability or stiff muscles
symptoms.Visual: blurred vision or sensitivity to light
symptoms.Also common: persistent headache, a temporary moment of clarity, bleeding, bone fracture, bruising, depression, loss of smell, nerve injury, post-traumatic seizure, ringing in the ears, or sensitivity to sound

Traumatic brain injury.overview:
Description
Brain dysfunction caused by an outside force, usually a violent blow to the head.
Traumatic brain injury often occurs as a result of a severe sports injury or car accident.
Immediate or delayed symptoms may include confusion, blurry vision and difficulty concentrating. Infants may cry persistently or be irritable.
Treatment may involve rest, medication and surgery.
Traumatic brain injury.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Critical: needs emergency care

Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.

Surgery.Decompressive craniectomy: Surgical removal of part of the skull so that an injured brain can swell without being squeezed.

Therapies.Rehabilitation: Retraining the brain's pathways to improve mental and physical functioning after an illness or injury. For example, after a blow to the head (concussion).
Therapies.Cognitive behavioral therapy: A talk therapy focused on modifying negative thoughts, behaviours and emotional responses associated with psychological distress.
Therapies.Anger management: Practicing mindfulness, coping mechanisms and trigger avoidance to minimise destructive emotional outbursts.
Therapies.Counseling psychology: A branch of psychology that treats personal problems related to school, work, family and social life.

specialists.Speech therapist: Treats people with speech and language problems.
specialists.Critical Care Doctor: Monitors and treats those in intensive care.
specialists.Occupational Therapist: Improves daily living and work skills of patients.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.

Trichomoniasis.symptomDescription: Trichomoniasis causes a foul-smelling vaginal discharge, genital itching and painful urination in women. Men typically have no symptoms. Complications include a risk of premature delivery for pregnant women.

symptoms.Pain circumstances: can occur during sexual intercourse or during urination
symptoms.Groin: cervix inflammation, vaginal discharge, vaginal inflammation, vaginal irritation, vaginal itching, vaginal odour, or vulval inflammation

Trichomoniasis.overview:
Description
A sexually transmitted infection caused by a parasite.
Trichomoniasis is among the most common sexually transmitted infections. Risk factors include multiple sexual partners and not using condoms during sex.
Trichomoniasis causes a foul-smelling vaginal discharge, genital itching and painful urination in women. Men typically have no symptoms. Complications include a risk of premature delivery for pregnant women.
Treatment involves both partners taking one large dose of a certain oral antibiotic.
Trichomoniasis.notes:
Spreads by sexual contact
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
HOW IT SPREADS
By having unprotected vaginal, anal or oral sex.

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Trigeminal neuralgia.symptomDescription: Symptoms range from mild to severe facial pain, often triggered by chewing, speaking or brushing the teeth.

symptoms.Sensory: oversensitivity or uncomfortable tingling and burning
symptoms.Also common: paroxysmal attack of facial pain, severe facial pain, sharp facial pain, unilateral facial pain, or muscle spasms

Trigeminal neuralgia.overview:
Description
A chronic pain condition affecting the trigeminal nerve in the face.
The trigeminal nerve carries sensation from the face to the brain. It's most common in women aged over 50.
Symptoms range from mild to severe facial pain, often triggered by chewing, speaking or brushing the teeth.
Treatment includes medication, injections and surgery.
Trigeminal neuralgia.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Anticonvulsant: Prevents or controls seizures, relieves pain and treats symptoms of certain psychiatric disorders.

specialists.Pain Management: Eases suffering and improves quality of life for those in pain.

Trigger finger.symptomDescription: Symptoms include stiffness, a popping or clicking sensation and tenderness in the affected finger. Triggering is usually worse in the morning.

symptoms.Common symptoms: finger catching with sudden pop release, physical deformity, stiffness, lump, swelling, or tenderness

Trigger finger.overview:
Description
A condition in which a finger gets stuck in a bent position and then snaps straight.
Trigger finger occurs when the tendon in the affected finger becomes inflamed. Those most at risk include women, people with diabetes or arthritis and people whose regular activities strain their hands.
Symptoms include stiffness, a popping or clicking sensation and tenderness in the affected finger. Triggering is usually worse in the morning.
Treatment includes splinting, medication and surgery.
Trigger finger.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Devices.Splint: A rigid accessory used to stabilise and protect an injured joint.

Medical procedure.Percutaneous trigger finger release: Using a needle to release the tendon of a finger stuck in a bent position. This restores range of motion and eases pain.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Hand Surgeon: Performs surgery to treat hand conditions.
specialists.Plastic Surgeon: Reconstructs defective, damaged or missing body parts.

Trochanteric bursitis.extraName: Also called: greater trochanteric pain syndrome
Trochanteric bursitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include pain on the outside of the hip that's worse with activities such as standing, walking or running.

symptoms.Also common: tenderness or stiffness

Trochanteric bursitis.overview:
Description
A common type of chronic hip pain.
Trochanteric bursitis may affect the hip's outer area or the outside part of the upper leg, from the hip to the knee along the thigh.
Symptoms include pain on the outside of the hip that's worse with activities such as standing, walking or running.
Treatments include ice, anti-inflammatory medication, steroid injections and physiotherapy. Weight loss might help.
Trochanteric bursitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.

Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Orthopaedic Surgeon: Performs surgery for conditions affecting bones and muscles.
specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.
specialists.Sports Medicine: Treats and prevents sports and exercise injuries.

Tuberculosis.symptomDescription: Most people infected with the bacteria that cause tuberculosis don't have symptoms. When symptoms do occur, they usually include a cough (sometimes blood-tinged), weight loss, night sweats and fever.

symptoms.Cough: can be chronic or with blood
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, fever, loss of appetite, malaise, night sweats, or sweating
symptoms.Also common: loss of muscle, phlegm, severe unintentional weight loss, shortness of breath, or swollen lymph nodes

Tuberculosis.overview:
Description
A potentially serious infectious bacterial disease that mainly affects the lungs.
The bacteria that cause TB are spread when an infected person coughs or sneezes.
Most people infected with the bacteria that cause tuberculosis don't have symptoms. When symptoms do occur, they usually include a cough (sometimes blood-tinged), weight loss, night sweats and fever.
Treatment isn't always required for those without symptoms. Patients with active symptoms will require a long course of treatment involving multiple antibiotics.
Tuberculosis.notes:
Partly preventable by vaccine
Treatable by a medical professional
Spreads easily
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.

Turner syndrome.symptomDescription: Symptoms include short stature, delayed puberty, infertility, heart defects and certain learning disabilities.

symptoms.Developmental: abnormalities in development of reproductive organs, delayed puberty, or short stature
symptoms.Whole body: high blood pressure or osteoporosis
symptoms.Heart: congenital heart defect or narrowing of the aorta
symptoms.Mouth: failure of teeth to develop normally or abnormally raised roof of the mouth
symptoms.Also common: absence of menstruation, dysplastic nail, female infertility, recurrent ear infections, widely spaced nipples, coeliac disease, elbow deformity, hearing loss, increased number of moles, kidney malformation, obesity, puffy hands and feet at birth, scoliosis, underactive thyroid, vision disorder, or webbed neck

Turner syndrome.overview:
Description
A chromosomal disorder in which a female is born with only one X chromosome
Turner syndrome results from a missing or incomplete sex chromosome.
Symptoms include short stature, delayed puberty, infertility, heart defects and certain learning disabilities.
Treatment involves hormone therapy. Fertility treatment may be necessary for women who want to become pregnant.
Turner syndrome.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

Therapies.Counseling: Professional advice and support that help people solve problems, make decisions and change their behaviour.

Medical procedure.Assisted reproductive technology: Medical procedures that help women become pregnant. Examples include artificial insemination (AI) and in vitro fertilization (IVF).

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Type 1 diabetes.symptomDescription: Symptoms include increased thirst, frequent urination, hunger, fatigue and blurred vision.

symptoms.Whole body: excessive thirst, fatigue, hunger, or sweating
symptoms.Also common: blurred vision, fast heart rate, frequent infections, headache, sleepiness, or weight loss

Type 1 diabetes.overview:
Description
A chronic condition in which the pancreas produces little or no insulin.
It typically appears in adolescence.
Symptoms include increased thirst, frequent urination, hunger, fatigue and blurred vision.
Treatment aims at maintaining normal blood sugar levels through regular monitoring, insulin therapy, diet and exercise.
Type 1 diabetes.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong
Critical: needs emergency care

Self-care.Diabetic diet: Diet that helps diabetics control their blood sugar (glucose) by reducing sugar and carbohydrates. For example, drinking less soda and eating less bread.
Self-care.Nutrition counseling: Diet advice provided by a nutrition expert to prevent or treat disease.
Self-care.Carbohydrate counting: Keeping track of the amount of carbohydrates consumed, which are found in foods like soda, bread and pasta.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.
Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Type 2 diabetes.symptomDescription: Symptoms include increased thirst, frequent urination, hunger, fatigue and blurred vision. In some cases, there may be no symptoms.

symptoms.Whole body: excessive hunger, excessive thirst, or fatigue
symptoms.Also common: frequent urination, blurred vision, or poor wound healing

Type 2 diabetes.overview:
Description
A chronic condition that affects the way the body processes blood sugar (glucose).
With type 2 diabetes, the body either doesn't produce enough insulin, or it resists insulin.
Symptoms include increased thirst, frequent urination, hunger, fatigue and blurred vision. In some cases, there may be no symptoms.
Treatments include diet, exercise, medication and insulin therapy.
Type 2 diabetes.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.
Self-care.Dietary fiber: The parts of plant foods that the body can't digest. Helps to control blood sugar, soften stools and maintain bowel health.
Self-care.Nutrition counseling: Diet advice provided by a nutrition expert to prevent or treat disease.
Self-care.Diabetic diet: Diet that helps diabetics control their blood sugar (glucose) by reducing sugar and carbohydrates. For example, drinking less soda and eating less bread.

Medication.Anti-diabetic medication: Controls the amount of sugar (glucose) in the blood.
Medication.Anticoagulant: Unwanted reactions from taking drugs that inhibit blood clotting. The most common problem is too much bleeding, which can be very serious.
Medication.Statin: Decreases the liver's production of harmful cholesterol.

Ulcerative colitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include rectal bleeding, bloody diarrhoea, abdominal cramps and pain.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the abdomen, joints, or rectum
symptoms.Pain types: can be intermittent in the abdomen
symptoms.Gastrointestinal: bloating, blood in stool, diarrhoea, inability to empty bowels, leaking of stool, or urgent need to defecate
symptoms.Whole body: anaemia, fatigue, fever, or loss of appetite
symptoms.Also common: cramping or weight loss

Ulcerative colitis.overview:
Description
A chronic, inflammatory bowel disease that causes inflammation in the digestive tract.
Ulcerative colitis is usually only in the innermost lining of the large intestine (colon) and rectum. Forms range from mild to severe. Having ulcerative colitis puts a patient at increased risk of developing colon cancer.
Symptoms include rectal bleeding, bloody diarrhoea, abdominal cramps and pain.
Treatment includes medication and surgery.
Ulcerative colitis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.
Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

Surgery.Colostomy: Surgical creation of an abdominal opening where stool can leave the body.
Surgery.Ileostomy: Surgically connecting the small intestine to an opening in the abdomen where stool leaves the body.
Surgery.Colectomy: Surgical removal of all or part of the colon.
Surgery.Proctocolectomy: Surgical removal of the rectum and all or part of the colon, which are both parts of the large intestine.

Supportive care.IV fluids: Delivering fluids, medication or blood directly into a vein.

Medical procedure.Enema: Fluid injected into the anus to stimulate a bowel movement.

specialists.Gastroenterologist: Focuses on the digestive system and its disorders.

Umbilical hernia.symptomDescription: A common sign of an umbilical hernia is a protruding bellybutton, which in infants may be most noticeable when they cry.

symptoms.Common symptoms: soft swelling or bulge near the navel

Umbilical hernia.overview:
Description
A condition in which the intestine protrudes through the abdominal muscles at the belly button.
Many infants are born with an umbilical hernia. Umbilical hernias can also be acquired in adulthood, more often in women.
A common sign of an umbilical hernia is a protruding bellybutton, which in infants may be most noticeable when they cry.
Many hernias close on their own by age one, and most by age five. Large hernias or hernias that don't close may need surgical repair. This can be an emergency if the hernia is stuck.
Umbilical hernia.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging not required

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

Surgery.Hernia repair: Surgical repair of a weak spot on the abdominal wall so that the intestines can't push through.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.General Surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries on the abdomen, skin, breast and soft tissue.
specialists.Paediatric surgeon: Performs a range of surgeries for infants and children.

Underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism).symptomDescription: Major symptoms include fatigue, cold sensitivity, constipation, dry skin and unexplained weight gain.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, lethargy, or feeling cold
symptoms.Also common: brittle nails, constipation, dry skin, enlarged thyroid, high cholesterol, irregular uterine bleeding, irritability, sensitivity to cold, sexual dysfunction, slow heart rate, sluggishness, or weight gain

Underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism).overview:
Description
A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone.
Hypothyroidism's deficiency of thyroid hormones can disrupt such things as heart rate, body temperature and all aspects of metabolism. Hypothyroidism is most prevalent in older women.
Major symptoms include fatigue, cold sensitivity, constipation, dry skin and unexplained weight gain.
Treatment consists of thyroid hormone replacement.
Underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism).notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

Upper respiratory infection.symptomDescription: Symptoms usually resolve within two weeks and include a scratchy or sore throat, sneezing, stuffy nose and cough.

symptoms.Nasal: congestion, loss of smell, post-nasal drip, or sneezing
symptoms.Respiratory: sinusitis or wheezing
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or fever
symptoms.Throat: irritation of the tonsils or soreness
symptoms.Also common: coughing, headache, inflammation of ear, phlegm, or swollen lymph nodes

Upper respiratory infection.overview:
Description
A common viral infection that affects the nose, throat and airways.
Upper respiratory tract infections usually resolve within seven to 10 days.
Symptoms usually resolve within two weeks and include a scratchy or sore throat, sneezing, stuffy nose and cough.
Treatment includes rest and medication to relieve symptoms.
Upper respiratory infection.notes:
Spreads easily
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By touching a contaminated surface (blanket or doorknob).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).

Supportive care.Rehydration: Replacing lost body fluid by drinking more fluids or administering fluids by intravenous therapy (IV).

Self-care.Nasal washing: Rinsing the inside of the nose with warm salt water to flush out irritants and excess mucus. Often done using a neti pot or squeeze bottle.

Medication.Cough medicine: Blocks the cough reflex. Some may thin and loosen mucus, making it easier to clear from the airways.
Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Uterine cancer.symptomDescription: Symptoms include vaginal bleeding after menopause and bleeding between periods.

symptoms.Menstrual: abnormal menstruation, heavy menstruation, or irregular menstruation
symptoms.Also common: abnormal vaginal bleeding or weight loss

Uterine cancer.overview:
Description
A type of cancer that begins in the uterus.
Most uterine cancer begins in the layer of cells that form the lining (endometrium) of the uterus. Risk factors include being overweight and starting periods at an early age.
Symptoms include vaginal bleeding after menopause and bleeding between periods.
Surgery to remove the uterus is the main treatment for most women with uterine cancer. Advanced cases may need chemotherapy or radiation.
Uterine cancer.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Surgery.Oophorectomy: Surgical removal of one or both ovaries.
Surgery.Cervicectomy: Surgical removal of the cervix, the lower part of the womb (uterus) that connects to the vagina.
Surgery.Lymph node dissection: Surgical removal of a lymph node.
Surgery.Salpingectomy: Surgical removal of one or both of the fallopian tubes, which carry eggs from the ovaries to the womb (uterus).

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Uveitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include redness, pain, light sensitivity, blurred vision and dark floating spots in the field of vision.

symptoms.Visual: blurred vision, seeing spots, sensitivity to light, or vision loss
symptoms.Also common: eye redness, leaked fluid out of blood vessels or an organ, or swelling

Uveitis.overview:
Description
An inflammation of the middle layer of the eye (uvea).
The most common type is an inflammation of the iris called iritis (anterior uveitis).
Symptoms include redness, pain, light sensitivity, blurred vision and dark floating spots in the field of vision.
A common treatment is eye drops that ease the inflammation. If uveitis is a result of an infection, antibiotics or antiviral medication may be prescribed.
Uveitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Infectious Disease Doctor: Treats infections, including those that are tropical in nature.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.

Vaginal yeast infection.symptomDescription: This condition can cause inflammation, intense itchiness and a thick, white discharge from the vagina.

symptoms.Pain circumstances: can occur during sexual intercourse or during urination
symptoms.Groin: vaginal discharge, vaginal itching, vaginal inflammation, or vulval inflammation
symptoms.Also common: redness

Vaginal yeast infection.overview:
Description
A yeast infection of the vagina and tissues at the opening of the vagina (vulva).
This type of yeast infection is caused by the fungus candida.
This condition can cause inflammation, intense itchiness and a thick, white discharge from the vagina.
A single dose of an oral antifungal drug or application of an antifungal cream for one to three days cures mild infections. Complicated infections require longer-term treatment.
Vaginal yeast infection.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Antifungal: Kills or prevents growth of fungi.
Medication.Dietary supplement: Works alone or in conjunction with other treatments to promote health.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Vaginitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include an unusual vaginal discharge, itching or irritation, painful urination and pain during intercourse.

symptoms.Pain circumstances: can occur during sexual intercourse or during urination
symptoms.Groin: abnormal vaginal discharge, vaginal bleeding, vaginal irritation, vaginal itching, or vaginal odour
symptoms.Also common: vaginal erythema

Vaginitis.overview:
Description
An inflammation of the vagina that can result in discharge, itching and pain.
Vaginitis is usually caused by a change in the normal balance of vaginal bacteria, an infection or reduced oestrogen levels after menopause.
Symptoms include an unusual vaginal discharge, itching or irritation, painful urination and pain during intercourse.
Treatment usually involves medication that focuses on the underlying cause.
Vaginitis.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Medication.Antifungal: Kills or prevents growth of fungi.
Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.
Medication.Hormone: Affects body processes by regulating the activity of the organs.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.

Varicose veins.symptomDescription: For many people, there are no symptoms and varicose veins are simply a cosmetic concern. In some cases, they cause aching pain and discomfort or signal an underlying circulatory problem.

symptoms.Skin: swollen blood vessels in the skin or discolouration
symptoms.Also common: bruising, heavy legs, itching, or swollen legs

Varicose veins.overview:
Description
Gnarled, enlarged veins, most commonly appearing in the legs and feet.
Varicose veins are generally benign. The cause of this condition is not known.
For many people, there are no symptoms and varicose veins are simply a cosmetic concern. In some cases, they cause aching pain and discomfort or signal an underlying circulatory problem.
Treatment involves compression stockings, exercise or procedures to close or remove the veins.
Varicose veins.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Devices.Elastic bandage: Stretchy bandages used to wrap sprains and strains. Provides support and compression during recovery.
Devices.Compression stockings: Elastic hosiery that squeeze blood up the legs to prevent swelling and blood clots.

Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.
Self-care.Weight loss: Can improve cardiovascular health and reduce the risk of complications related to obesity.

Medical procedure.Laser therapy: A focused beam of light sometimes used to treat abnormal skin.
Medical procedure.Sclerotherapy: Injecting a salt water solution into abnormal blood vessels or tissues. This causes them to collapse and fade away.
Medical procedure.Radiofrequency ablation: Removal of tissue using the heat from an electric current produced by a radio wave.
Medical procedure.Ambulatory phlebectomy: Removal of superficial veins through small slits on the legs. Done as an outpatient procedure.

Surgery.Vein stripping: Surgical removal of enlarged, twisted (varicose) veins by pulling them out of the body through small cuts.

specialists.Vascular Surgeon: Specialises in surgery for vascular system diseases.
specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.

Vasculitis.symptomDescription: Symptoms include fever, fatigue, weight loss and muscle and joint pain.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the abdomen, joints, or muscles
symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or fever
symptoms.Skin: rashes or ulcers
symptoms.Also common: joint swelling, sensation of pins and needles, shortness of breath, or weight loss

Vasculitis.overview:
Description
An inflammation of the blood vessels that causes changes in the blood vessel walls.
Vasculitis can cause vessel walls to thicken and narrow, cutting off vital blood supply to tissues and organs.
Symptoms include fever, fatigue, weight loss and muscle and joint pain.
Some forms of vasculitis improve on their own. Others require medication.
Vasculitis.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.
Medication.Blood transfusion: Transfer of blood from one person into the veins of another.

specialists.Rheumatologist: Specialises in arthritis and other rheumatic diseases.
specialists.Immunologist: Diagnoses and treats immune system disorders.
specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Ventricular septal defect.symptomDescription: Symptoms may include a bluish tint to the skin, lips and fingernails, along with poor feeding, poor weight gain and fast breathing.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue, inability to exercise, or sweating
symptoms.Heart: murmur or enlarged heart
symptoms.Respiratory: fast breathing or shortness of breath
symptoms.Also common: baby feeding difficulties, blue skin from poor circulation, failure to thrive, or swelling

Ventricular septal defect.overview:
Description
A heart defect due to an abnormal connection between the lower chambers of the heart (ventricles).
A ventricular septal defect is a common heart defect most often present at birth, but it can occur in adults after surgery or a heart attack. It involves a hole in the wall between the heart's lower chambers.
Symptoms may include a bluish tint to the skin, lips and fingernails, along with poor feeding, poor weight gain and fast breathing.
Most holes close on their own, although many may need surgery or a catheter-based procedure to close the hole. Symptoms can be treated with blood pressure medicines or diuretics.
Ventricular septal defect.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required

Surgery.Percutaneous VSD closure: Closing an abnormal hole in the heart using a long tube (catheter) inserted through a blood vessel.

Medication.Diuretic: Taking medicine that helps eliminate extra water from the body. It's also prescribed to treat high blood pressure.
Medication.ACE inhibitor: Relaxes blood vessels, lowers blood pressure and prevents diabetes-related kidney damage.

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Maternal-Foetal Medicine Specialist: Focuses on the medical management of high-risk pregnancies.
specialists.Cardiac Surgeon: Performs surgery on the heart or great vessels.
specialists.Neonatologist: Provides medical care for newborn infants.

Vitamin B12 deficiency.symptomDescription: Symptoms are rare but can include fatigue, breathlessness, numbness, poor balance and memory trouble.

symptoms.Whole body: anaemia, fatigue, or poor balance
symptoms.Also common: memory loss, pallor, reduced sensation of touch, shortness of breath, or tingling feet

Vitamin B12 deficiency.overview:
Description
Anaemia or nervous system injury from lower than normal amounts of vitamin B12.
Vitamin B12 deficiency may lead to a reduction in healthy red blood cells (anaemia). The nervous system may also be affected. Diet or certain medical conditions may be the cause.
Symptoms are rare but can include fatigue, breathlessness, numbness, poor balance and memory trouble.
Treatment includes dietary changes, B12 shots or supplements.
Vitamin B12 deficiency.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Medium-term: resolves within months

Medication.Vitamin: Helps promote normal body function, growth and development.

Self-care.Nutrition counseling: Diet advice provided by a nutrition expert to prevent or treat disease.

specialists.Geriatrician: Focuses on the health care of elderly people.

Vitiligo.symptomDescription: Loss of skin colour can affect any part of the body, including the mouth, hair and eyes. It may be more noticeable in people with darker skin.

symptoms.Common symptoms: loss of skin colour or premature hair whitening

Vitiligo.overview:
Description
A disease that causes the loss of skin colour in blotches.
Vitiligo occurs when pigment-producing cells die or stop functioning.
Loss of skin colour can affect any part of the body, including the mouth, hair and eyes. It may be more noticeable in people with darker skin.
Treatment may improve the appearance of the skin but doesn't cure the disease.
Vitiligo.notes:
Treatment can help, but this condition can't be cured
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Self-care.Sunblock: Protects against the sun's UV rays, which can damage the skin over time.
Self-care.Ultraviolet light therapy: Ultraviolet light therapy for serious skin diseases. Used along with a special medication that increases light absorption.

Medical procedure.Photodynamic therapy: Treatment that uses special drugs (photosensitising agents) along with light to kill cancer cells. The drugs must be activated by the light.

Medication.Steroid: Modifies or simulates hormone effects, often to reduce inflammation or for tissue growth and repair.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Von Willebrand disease.symptomDescription: Symptoms may include recurrent and prolonged nosebleeds, bleeding from the gums, increased menstrual flow and excessive bleeding from a cut.

symptoms.Common symptoms: easy bruising, excessive bleeding during childbirth, heavy or prolonged periods, mouth bleeding, nosebleed, or tendency to bleed easily

Von Willebrand disease.overview:
Description
A bleeding disorder caused by low levels of clotting protein in the blood.
Von Willebrand disease is often inherited, but in rare cases, it may develop later in life.
Symptoms may include recurrent and prolonged nosebleeds, bleeding from the gums, increased menstrual flow and excessive bleeding from a cut.
Treatment focuses on stopping or preventing bleeding episodes, typically by using medication.
Von Willebrand disease.notes:
Treatable by a medical professional
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging always required
Chronic: can last for years or be lifelong

Medication.Clotting promoter: Helps form blood clots to reduce risk of excess bleeding.

specialists.OBGYN Doctor: Focuses on reproductive health in women and childbirth.
specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
specialists.Haematologist: Focuses on diagnosing and treating blood disorders.

Warts and verrucas.symptomDescription: The main symptom is a fleshy, painless growth on the skin. Common areas affected include the hands, feet and genitals.

symptoms.Skin: small growths on skin or thickness
symptoms.Also common: itching or lesions in mouth or around genital regions

Warts and verrucas.overview:
Description
A small, fleshy bump on the skin or mucous membrane caused by human papillomavirus.
Warts are caused by various strains of human papillomaviruses. Different strains may cause warts in different parts of the body. Warts can be spread from one location on the body to another or from person to person by contact with the wart.
The main symptom is a fleshy, painless growth on the skin. Common areas affected include the hands, feet and genitals.
Treatment may include topical medication and removal through medical procedures.
Warts and verrucas.notes:
Spreads by skin-to-skin contact
Treatable by a medical professional
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging not required
Medium-term: resolves within months
HOW IT SPREADS
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Supportive care.Can be self-healing: Condition usually improves over time without treatment.

Medical procedure.Cauterization: Burning or freezing a part of the body to remove tissue or stop bleeding. For example, to seal off a wound and prevent blood loss.
Medical procedure.Freezing: Using extreme cold during surgery or medical treatment.
Medical procedure.Tissue scraping: Removal of tissue by scraping or scooping with a surgical instrument called a curette.

Medication.Anti-inflammatory: Prevents or counteracts swelling (inflammation) in joints and tissues.
Medication.Topical anti-tumor medication: Treats skin cancer and other skin conditions.
Medication.Chemotherapy: Unwanted reactions to drugs given for the purpose of killing cancer cells.

Surgery.Electrosurgery: Using electric current to cut tissue and control bleeding during surgery.
Surgery.Laser surgery: Surgery using an intensely hot and focused beam of light to remove tissue and control bleeding.

specialists.Dermatologist: Focuses on disorders of skin, nails and hair.

Whiplash.symptomDescription: Injuries range from mild to severe. The main symptom is pain in the neck and shoulders.

symptoms.Pain areas: in the neck, arm, back, muscles, or shoulder
symptoms.Whole body: dizziness or vertigo
symptoms.Also common: difficulty focusing, headache, muscle spasms, nerve injury, sensation of pins and needles, sleep disorder, stiff neck, or tenderness

Whiplash.overview:
Description
A neck injury that can occur when the head suddenly moves backward and then forward.
This type of injury can occur, for example, during rear-end vehicle collisions.
Injuries range from mild to severe. The main symptom is pain in the neck and shoulders.
Treatment typically begins with over-the-counter pain relievers and ice. If the pain persists, treatment can include physiotherapy and prescription medication. In rare cases, injections into the neck may help.
Whiplash.notes:
Usually self-treatable
Usually self-diagnosable
Lab tests or imaging rarely required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks

Self-care.Ice packs: Reduces inflammation and dulls sensation of pain.
Self-care.Physical exercise: Aerobic activity for 20–30 minutes 5 days a week improves cardiovascular health. If injured, pursuing an activity that avoids the injured muscle group or joint can help maintain physical function while recovering.

Medication.Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug: Relieves pain, decreases inflammation and reduces fever.
Medication.Muscle relaxant: Reduces muscle tension and helps relieve muscle pain and discomfort.
Medication.Narcotic: Relieves pain, dulls the senses and causes drowsiness. May become addictive.

Therapies.Chiropractic treatment techniques: Adjusting the spine and massaging the back muscles to relieve pain.
Therapies.Stretching: Stretching exercises can improve flexibility and improve physical function.
Therapies.Physical Therapy: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.

specialists.Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation: Restores function and quality of life to those with physical disabilities.
specialists.Physiotherapist: Restores muscle strength and function through exercise.
specialists.Emergency Medicine Doctor: Treats patients in the emergency department.

Whooping cough.symptomDescription: Besides a cough that sounds like "whoop", symptoms include a runny nose, nasal congestion and sneezing.

symptoms.Whole body: fatigue or fever
symptoms.Also common: paroxysmal cough, episodes of no breathing, vomiting, or watery eyes

Whooping cough.overview:
Description
A highly contagious respiratory tract infection that is easily preventable by vaccine.
Whooping cough is particularly dangerous for infants.
Besides a cough that sounds like "whoop", symptoms include a runny nose, nasal congestion and sneezing.
Treatment includes antibiotics.
Whooping cough.notes:
Preventable by vaccine
Treatable by a medical professional
Spreads easily
Requires a medical diagnosis
Lab tests or imaging often required
Short-term: resolves within days to weeks
HOW IT SPREADS
By airborne respiratory droplets (coughs or sneezes).
By saliva (kissing or shared drinks).
By skin-to-skin contact (handshakes or hugs).

Medication.Antibiotics: Stops the growth of or kills bacteria.

Supportive care.Monitoring for changes or improvement: Monitoring a medical condition instead of taking action right away.

specialists.Paediatrician: Provides medical care for infants, children and teenagers.
